profile: Established in 1948, Brandeis University is one of the nation’s youngest research institutions as well as the only nonsectarian Jewish institution in the country. The Massachusetts-based campus is located 10 miles from Boston and encompasses 235 acres of gothic castles, quads and pedestrian pathways. The institution’s College of Arts and Sciences offers 43 majors and 46 minors, and two thirds of the undergraduate classes have 20 students or less. Students traditionally take pictures with the bronze statue of the late Justice Louis D. Brandeis, and student groups dress him in various clothing depending on the season. Brandeis competes in the NCAA Division III with 21 varsity teams. Notable alumni include Pulitzer Prize winner and New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman, "Will and Grace" actress Debra Messing, and "Friends" co-creator Marta Kauffman.

name: Wheaton College (Wheaton)
profile: Wheaton College was founded in 1860 by Jonathan Blanchard, a well-known abolitionist and preacher. Today the college serves as a private coeducational institution affiliated with the Council for Christian Colleges and Universities. The college has begun to take initiatives in sustainability, such as remodeling the Memorial Student Center to meet LEED requirements. Wheaton also erected a new Student Rec. Center and named it after Todd M. Beamer, a Wheaton alum who helped bring Flight 93 down in a field in Pennsylvania on September 11, 2001. In keeping with the college's motto, “For Christ and His Kingdom,” the school had its first student-run mission trip to Central America in 1958; today, students can travel to and serve in more than 60 countries. Notable alumni include Pastor Billy Graham and former Speaker of the House Dennis Hastert. Wheaton competes in NCAA Division III athletics with 21 intercollegiate teams. In the past seven years, teams have won more than 50 titles in a total of 11 different sports.

name: University of Texas, Austin
profile: University of Texas, Austin is one of the largest public universities in the United States and the largest institution in the University of Texas System. Founded in 1883, it offers 100 majors in 17 different colleges and schools, with well-regarded programs in engineering, education, pharmacy, business and law, among other areas. The Longhorns compete in Division I athletics and have claimed more Big 12 Conference sports titles in men’s and women’s sports than any other school since the league began in 1996. In football, UT has won four national championships and ranks second in NCAA all-time victories. Current and former UT athletes have won a total of 88 Olympic medals, including 13 in London in 2012.

name: Lehigh University
profile: Lehigh University is a private research university located in Bethlehem, PA. The university has more than 90 undergraduate programs with over 2,000 courses to choose from. The majority of students are enrolled in the science and engineering school or in arts and sciences. On campus, the lead-up to Spirit Week includes bed races and a marching band campus tour. When first-year students arrive, they are “adopted” by the class that preceded them 50 years ago; the tradition began in 1945, when the class of 1949 was adopted by the class of 1899. The school competes in the NCAA Division I athletics and has a longstanding football rivalry with neighboring Lafayette University. The 150th match-up between the teams will draw crowds to Yankee Stadium in fall 2014. In 2015, Lehigh will celebrate its sesquicentennial anniversary (150 years).

name: University of Southern California
profile: When the University of Southern California first opened its doors in 1880, tuition was $15 a term and students were not permitted to leave the city without permission from the university president. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics and its mascot is the Trojan, who heroically rides into all home football games on Traveler, his noble white horse, one of the most famous live mascots in collegiate sports. The school has sent more students to the Olympics than any other university in the world, and, since 1912, has been the only university worldwide to have a gold medal-winning athlete in every summer Olympics. Neil Armstrong, the first man to walk on the moon, received his master’s degree from the university in 1970.

name: Brigham Young University
profile: Founded in 1875 by Brigham Young himself, Brigham Young University serves almost exclusively members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints, which sponsors the school today. BYU offers bachelor’s degrees in approximately 193 academic programs through its 10 colleges. With 164 study abroad programs in 49 countries, BYU has one of the largest study abroad programs in the nation and more than two thirds of students speak a second language. During warmer months, students camp out in Provo canyon—provided they do not camp with the opposite sex. Students are expected to adhere to a strict Honor Code, which prohibits premarital sex, alcohol and drug use; Men are asked not to grow a beard without a doctor’s permission. Dating is expected to lead to marriage at BYU: According to a survey, 51% of the graduating class of 2005 was married. Traditionally, students buy ice cream for those who have experienced their first kiss and steak for those who just got engaged. Mitt Romney graduated from BYU in 1971 and author Orson Scott Card graduated in 1975.

name: Occidental College
profile: Occidental College is a private liberal arts college in Los Angeles, CA. The college’s proximity to Hollywood makes it one of the most filmed campuses in the U.S. Founded in 1887, Occidental offers 31 majors from 40 departments and programs, ranging from theater to cognitive science. Oxy has produced 10 Rhodes Scholars and is one of the nation’s leading Fulbright feeder schools, with 72 students winning the grant since 2003. Oxy students must go through the Core Program, which includes first-year seminars and writing exercises, and live on campus for their first three years. Approximately 75% of students go abroad for study, research, internships or fellowships. The college’s U.N. program sends up to 16 students to New York to take courses and intern at a U.N.-related agency while the General Assembly is in session. Approximately 25% of students comprise Occidental’s 21 NCAA Division III teams. Famous attendees include President Barack Obama, actors Ben Affleck and Luke Wilson and athlete and politician Jack Kemp.

name: Centre College
profile: Centre College is a small, private liberal arts college established in 1819 by Presbyterian leaders. The college, located in Danville, KY, offers double majors, self-designed majors and dual degree engineering programs with Columbia University, University of Kentucky, Vanderbilt University and Washington University of St. Louis. Nearly 85% of Centre College students study abroad. The school has its own residential programs located in France, Mexico and England, among other places. More than one third of all students collaborate with professors in advanced research. There is an annual campus-wide event, Centre RICE Symposium (Research, Internships and Creative Endeavors), where students are invited to present their recent academic work. The Norton Center for the Arts regularly brings in world-class performers like soul singer Al Green, violinist Joshua Bell and the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Gustavo Dudamel. In the Honor Walk tradition, students receive a talent – a coin with the historic building “Old Centre” on one side and the college seal on the other – at the beginning of their senior year, and then give it to someone who has profoundly impacted their college career on the evening before commencement after they walk through Old Centre. In October 2012, Centre College hosted its second vice presidential debate. Centre College competes in NCAA Division III athletics as the Colonels; the football team’s 6-0 win against Harvard in 1921 is considered one of the greatest college football upsets of the 20th century.

name: University of Maryland, College Park
profile: The flagship institution of the state system, University of Maryland, College Park offers 127 undergraduate degrees and 112 graduate degrees from 13 colleges and schools. On the faculty are three Nobel laureates, five Pulitzer Prize winners and 49 members of the National Academies. University of Maryland actively promotes entrepreneurship, hosting “Innovation Fridays” every week, in which students can meet with a team of faculty and entrepreneurs to get feedback on their latest ideas for social, business and technological advances. Each spring the school celebrates “30 Days of enTREPreneurship,” awarding more than a quarter million dollars for the best ideas and innovations. Notable alumni include Google cofounder Sergey Brin, E! News reporter Giuliana Rancic and "Seinfeld" co-creator Larry David. The University of Maryland competes in NCAA Division I sports in the Big Ten Conference. The school mascot is a diamondback terrapin named Testudo, which means “tortoise” in Latin, and their slogan is “Fear the Turtle.”

name: Trinity College
profile: Established in 1823 and known as a “Little Ivy,” Trinity College is a private liberal arts college located in historic Hartford, CT. The 100-acre campus includes restored Long Walk buildings—some of the oldest examples of Gothic architecture in American schools. Trinity offers undergraduates over 900 courses and 39 majors and is known for its first-year invitation-only gateway programs in the arts, cities, science and western culture. Trinity also offers 200 academic internships for credit, both in the city of Hartford and in other national and international communities. More than 90% of undergraduates live on the 100-acre historic campus. Trinity has one of the largest college libraries in New England. Over 40% of Trinity students compete in intercollegiate athletics and others participate in 29 men's and women’s Division III varsity teams. The campus houses Cinestudio, Hartford’s art house cinema, and the Mill, a student-run space dedicated to performance art. Around 65% of Trinity alumni obtain an advanced degree in the decade after graduation.

name: Connecticut College
profile: Connecticut College is located in New London, CT and was founded in 1911. The college does not require standardized test scores in its application process. Among liberal arts colleges, Connecticut College is a top producer of Fulbright scholars. The school was one of the first to offer a human ecology major, which is now known as environmental studies. The campus participates in RecycleMania, which is a 10-week competition to determine which American higher learning institution recycles the most per capita. Connecticut College competes in NCAA Division III athletics and the school mascot is the Camel. The mascot was chosen in 1969 when the college became coed. Each fall in the Camelympics, residence halls compete against each other in activities such as dodge ball, Wii Golf and floor hockey. Graduates are presented with Eastern White Pine saplings to carry during commencement; the sapling represents the tree on the College seal and symbolizes students’ growing connection to the College. Tim Armstrong, CEO and chairman of AOL, graduated with the class of 1993. The school is currently working on an inclusive review of the curriculum, a project called Curriculum reVISION. Faculty groups are going to develop ideas regarding essential learning for 21st-century graduates into pilots for fall 2014.

name: Wofford College
profile: Wofford College, located in Spartanburg, SC, was founded in 1854 and is affiliated with the United Methodist Church. Wofford is a traditional liberal arts school offering 25 fields of study. There are nearly 17,000 living alumni residing in all 50 states and 35 different nations, many of whom are in corporate senior management, law or medicine. Wofford offers a vibrant social scene, including Greek life and a campus close to five other higher education institutions. There are also many student organizations and clubs on campus. For the past 18 years, Wofford has hosted the Carolina Panthers for their summer training camp. The college competes in NCAA Division I athletics and is a member of the Southern Conference.

name: Santa Clara University
profile: Santa Clara University is a private Jesuit university in Santa Clara, CA. It was founded in 1851. Santa Clara’s 106-acre campus is situated at the southern point of San Francisco Bay, where it is sunny approximately 300 days of the year. The university offers 45 undergraduate majors and there are more than 150 student organizations. The school was built around the Mission Santa Clara de Asis, a Spanish mission that dates back to 1777. The annual President’s Speaker Series has brought Condoleezza Rice, San Francisco 49ers CEO Jed York and others to campus. Santa Clara’s 19 intercollegiate athletic teams, nicknamed the Broncos, compete in the West Coast Conference (NCAA Division I). Notable Santa Clara alumni include University of California president and former Secretary of Homeland Security Janet Napolitano, first female White House press secretary Dee Dee Myers and NBA star Steve Nash.

name: University of Florida
profile: Founded in 1853, the University of Florida is a public research university located in Gainesville. The school is home to 16 academic colleges and over 150 research centers and institutes. Notable alumni include nine former Florida governors, two Nobel Prize laureates, eight astronauts and eight former U.S. ambassadors. The George A. Smathers Libraries house 5.3 million volumes of books and journals, plus 7 million microfilms (it is one of the largest university library systems in the U.S.). The school has a well-regarded biotech business incubator and is one of the leading U.S. universities in winning patents for research. Each year approximately 800 students participate in a 26.2-hour dance marathon that benefits patients at the University of Florida Health Shands Children’s Hospital. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is the Gator. In 1965, researchers at the University of Florida invented Gatorade in order to energize Gator football players.

name: Dickinson College
profile: Founded in 1783 in Carlisle, PA shortly after the end of the Revolutionary War, Dickinson was the first college chartered in the new U.S. Today, Dickinson offers a selection of 42 majors, with an emphasis on international studies. As one of the top producers of Fulbright Scholars among liberal arts colleges, Dickinson boasts at least 92 alumni and 56 faculty who have received a Fulbright (one or more). Committed to sustainability and green initiatives, Dickinson has a USDA organic certified farm and an alternative, environmentally-conscious mascot known as the Green Devil. In 2011, Dickinson became one of only 16 schools in the nation to receive a 99/100 "Green Rating," the highest score. The school competes in NCAA Division III athletics. According to Dickinson legend, a student will not graduate if he or she walks on the college seal embedded in the middle of Britton Plaza.

name: Boston University
profile: Founded in 1839 by Methodist ministers, Boston University administers one of the strongest private research programs in the country. Students have a choice of over 250 courses of study through 18 schools and are offered many opportunities to work and publish with faculty (students have received millions of dollars in grants and funding for their projects). The MA-based institution also has a strong international presence, with satellite campuses in Brussels, Dubai, London, Paris and Sydney. The Boston University Terriers compete in 23 NCAA Division I varsity sports and have won over 43 conference championships and five national championships in men’s hockey. Notable alumni include Academy Award-winning actress Julianne Moore, civil rights activist Martin Luther King, Jr. and shock-jock Howard Stern.

name: Georgia Institute of Technology
profile: Georgia Institute of Technology was founded in 1885 with the hope of transforming the South from an agrarian economy to an industrial one. The most popular majors include industrial engineering, computer science, mathematics and architecture. Georgia Tech has five satellite campuses worldwide, including locations in China, France and Ireland. There are over 450 student organizations and 50 Greek organizations that keep students’ social calendars full year-round. On campus, a steam whistle blows five minutes before the hour, every hour, from 7:55 a.m. to 5:55 p.m. and the faculty newspaper is affectionately named The Whistle. Notable alumni include the CEOs of Walmart, AT&T and GE Commercial Finance, plus several Nobel laureates. The Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets' mascot is Buzz and they compete in the Atlantic Coast Conference at the NCAA Division I level. Tech has a long, heated and ongoing rivalry with the University of Georgia, which the two schools refer to it as “Clean, Old-Fashioned Hate.”

name: DePauw University
profile: Founded in 1837 by the Methodist Church, DePauw is a liberal arts college located in Greencastle, IN. In addition to its liberal arts and music schools, DePauw University is widely known for its passionate athletics through the NCAA Division III North Coast Athletic Conference. The Monon Bell football game is an annual contest between the DePauw Tigers and Wabash College Little Giants. Since the start of the rivalry in 1890, more than 100 games have been played. In 1870, DePauw became home to one of the nation’s first sororities, Kappa Alpha Theta, and is also credited with the founding of the Alpha chapter of the Alpha Chi Omega sorority.

name: Earlham College
profile: Founded in 1847, Earlham College in Richmond, IN is affiliated with the Religious Society of Friends. By 1865, the school accepted non-Quaker students. Today, only 11% of Earlham’s faculty and 12% of its students identify as Quakers. About 70% of students participate in off-campus study in countries ranging from Japan to Jordan. Earlham is home to the Joseph Moore Museum of Natural History, which holds one of Indiana’s two Egyptian mummies and the world's most complete skeleton of the extinct Giant Beaver. Since 1971, incoming Earlham freshmen and transfer students have had the chance to participate in August Wilderness, a three-week pre-orientation expedition. A completely student-led cooperative operates the Earlham College Equestrian Program and the Suzanne Hoerner Jackson Equestrian Center, where pupils maintain the facility and give riding lessons. The Earlham “Quake” compete in Division III athletics with 14 varsity teams. A notable Earlham alumnus is Dexter actor Michael C. Hall.

name: Rhodes College
profile: Rhodes College is a private liberal arts college in Memphis, TN. It was founded in 1848 as the Masonic University of Tennessee. The school’s average class size is 14. Around 75% of students complete internships and 65% study abroad or at an off-campus site in the U.S. There are more than 50 majors and minors and 100 student organizations at Rhodes. Approximately 80% of students participate in community service projects. Perhaps the most famous tradition is the Rhodes Honor Code. Because of students’ pledge to refrain from dishonest acts, there is a unique level of trust on campus: Professors sometimes leave the room during exams and students often leave their doors unlocked. At orientation, freshmen are led through Palmer Hall, where they walk across the seal of Rhodes College. It is rumored that if you step foot on the seal again before graduation, you will not graduate. The men’s and women’s intercollegiate athletic teams, nicknamed the Lynx, compete at the NCAA Division III level.

name: University of Georgia
profile: Founded in 1785, the University of Georgia is a public research university located in Athens. It was the first in the U.S. to establish a school of ecology and environmental sciences. More than 300 different products that originated from university research are currently on the market and the school holds more than 500 patents. Located on North Campus is a 177-year-old chapel bell, which is rung regularly to honor athletic victories and other special occasions. UGA competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is Uga (pronounced UG-AH), a white English bulldog that is a descendant of the original Uga. Notable alumni include media personality Ryan Seacrest, PGA golfer Bubba Watson and Build-A-Bear founder Maxine Clark.

name: Denison University
profile: Denison University is a small liberal arts college located in Granville, OH. Founded in 1831, it is a standardized test-optional school. Economics, biology and communications are the most popular majors on campus. Denison also offers an individually designed major option, which allows students to create their own interdepartmental major. The Denison Campus Governance Association, comprised of 40 elected students, is responsible for allocating a $1.2 million budget to the 175 student organizations on campus. “Denison Day” – “D Day” for short – has been celebrated for 65 years with music and games. According to college lore, if a student steps on the seal embedded in front of the school's Swasey chapel, that student will not graduate. Notable alumni include actors Steve Carell and Jennifer Garner, as well as ESPN president George Bodenheimer and former Disney CEO Michael Eisner. Denison's 23 varsity teams, known as the Big Red, compete in Division III athletics. The school also offers 45 club and intramural teams.

name: University of Richmond
profile: Established in 1830, University of Richmond is a private liberal arts school with five colleges: School of Arts and Sciences, School of Law, Robins School of Business, Jepson School of Leadership Studies (the first institution in the world to offer leadership studies as an undergraduate degree), and the School of Professional & Continuing Studies. As of fall 2014, the university will offer free tuition, room and board to Virginia state students whose families earn $60,000 or less, up from $40,000 previously. The university offers 75 study abroad programs in more than 30 countries; 57% of the class of 2013 studied abroad. The University of Richmond competes in 19 NCAA Division I sports. Its teams are known as the Spiders, making Richmond the only college or professional sports organization to have an arachnid as its mascot. A longstanding legend, ladies, is that the first guy you kiss in the gazebo on West Hampton Lake is the one you’ll marry.

name: Mount Holyoke College
profile: Mount Holyoke College is a private liberal arts college for women in South Hadley, MA. It was established in 1837 by women’s education pioneer Mary Lyon. Mount Holyoke draws students from approximately 47 states and 78 countries. The college offers 50 departmental and interdepartmental major programs. Around 32% of students focus on humanities and 26% pursue a natural and applied sciences degree. Mount Holyoke is a member of the Five College Consortium, which includes Amherst, Hampshire and Smith colleges and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Mount Holyoke students can take up to two classes per semester at another Consortium member school for no extra charge. About 93% of students live on campus. The college offers over 150 student organizations to those looking to get involved outside of the classroom. One of the college’s oldest traditions is Mountain Day, an unexpected fall day when classes are canceled and students are encouraged to partake in outdoor activities. The Network, a student-run group, has brought top musicians like M.I.A. and Kanye West to campus. The college’s varsity athletic teams, nicknamed the Lyons, primarily compete at the NCAA Division III level.

name: Sewanee-University of the South
profile: Sewanee-University of the South is a private liberal arts college in Sewanee, TN. It was founded in 1857 by Episcopal delegates from throughout the South and remains affiliated with the Episcopal Church. Sewanee has produced 26 Rhodes Scholars, 45 Watson Fellows and 30 NCAA Postgraduate Fellows. Students can select from 36 majors, 32 minors and 15 special programs. Over 40% of students participate in a study abroad program. More than 95% of undergraduate students live on campus and Sewanee boasts one of the largest college campuses in the U.S., with over 13,000 acres on the Cumberland Plateau. The Sewanee Outing Program lets students and faculty take advantage of Sewanee’s location through outdoor activities like hiking, climbing, kayaking and caving. The Sewanee Union Theatre, or the “SUT,” shows recently-released movies and classic films for less than $5 per ticket. The school’s varsity athletic teams, called the Sewanee Tigers, compete in the Southern Athletic Association (SAA) at the NCAA Division III level.

name: Sarah Lawrence College
profile: Sarah Lawrence College is a private liberal arts college in Bronxville, NY. Though it was founded in 1926 as a women’s college, it is a coeducational institution today. The college utilizes an uncharacteristic approach to education. First-year students are assigned faculty member advisors, called “dons,” who serve as advisors. There are no majors—only concentrations—which allow students to tailor studies to individual interests. Students can select from courses in nearly 50 disciplines. Rather than issuing grades, Sarah Lawrence provides written evaluations of students. One-on-one conferences between students and professors are part of most courses. Prospective applicants should put down their SAT prep books and pick up their pencils—admission to Sarah Lawrence is based on transcripts and essays; submitting SAT and ACT scores is optional (they weren't accepted at all until 2013). Students close out the spring semester with Bacchanalia, an outdoor music festival that is hosted by the senior class. The school’s intercollegiate athletic teams, known as the Gryphons, compete in the Skyline Conference (NCAA Division III). Notable Sarah Lawrence alumni include former White House Chief of Staff and current mayor of Chicago Rahm Emanuel, filmmaker J.J. Abrams and fashion designer Vera Wang.

name: Furman University
profile: Furman University is a private liberal arts university located in Greenville, SC. Founded in 1826 as an academy and theological institute, the school moved to its current location in 1851. Furman does not require standardized tests for admission, and relies on interviews with applicants. The campus has an Asian garden, a replica of Henry David Thoreau’s cabin, a Florentine bell tower, a spring fed lake, 13 miles of paved trails through the woods and an 18-hole golf course. The Shi Center for Sustainability is a hub where students, faculty and community members alike can gather and generate solutions on how to develop a more sustainable environment for future generations. Furman has a master plan called Sustainable Furman, whose ultimate goal surrounds the university’s Climate Action Plan, which targets carbon neutrality by 2026. Students even have the option to major in Sustainability Science, one of the only degree programs of its kind at a liberal arts school. Ninety-seven percent of Furman University students are admitted to graduate school or have found employment within six months of graduation. Furman offers 45 areas of study, 150 student organizations and 20 NCAA Division I teams.

name: Southern Methodist University
profile: Southern Methodist University is a private research university in Dallas, TX. It was established in 1911 and is affiliated with the United Methodist Church. The university is home to the George W. Bush Presidential Center, which includes Bush’s presidential library and museum. Southern Methodist’s 16 academic departments offer nearly 40 undergraduate majors and 57 minors, as well as 19 master’s and 13 doctoral programs. SMU is a high-activity research institution, with approximately 30 research centers and institutes on campus. For students looking to get involved, there are nearly 200 student organizations on campus. The 66,000-square-foot Meadows Museum at Southern Methodist University features one of the largest collections of Spanish art outside of Spain. The Willis M. Tate Distinguished Lecture Series brings renowned speakers to campus; upcoming participants include Peter Thiel, David Brooks and Robin Roberts. SMU’s varsity athletic teams, nicknamed the Mustangs, compete in the American Athletic Conference (NCAA Division I). Notable alumni include former First Lady Laura Bush, longtime Kroger CEO David Dillon and Indianapolis Colts owner and CEO James Isray.

name: Skidmore College
profile: Skidmore College is a private liberal arts college in Saratoga Springs, NY. Its roots date back to 1903, when Lucy Skidmore Scribner founded the Young Women’s Industrial Club of Saratoga Springs. Students hail from 45 states and 60 countries. The college offers 42 majors, the most popular of which include English, management and business, studio art, theater, biology and environmental studies. Around 60% of students study abroad. There are approximately 100 student clubs on campus. The 54,000-square-foot Zankel Music Center features a 600-seat recital hall and a recording studio. The upperclassmen-only Northwoods Apartments demonstrate the school’s dedication to the environment—they rely on geothermal heating and cooling systems. Student-athletes compete at the NCAA Division III level. Skidmore’s athletic teams are known as the Thoroughbreds.

name: Gettysburg College
profile: Located near the famous Civil War battlefield, Gettysburg College was founded in 1832. The private liberal arts college is also home to the Civil War Institute. The student-to-faculty ratio is 10:1, with an average class size of 18 students. During orientation, first-year students recreate the procession through town to hear an honored guest read the Gettysburg Address, just like Lincoln had centuries before. Though there is an active Greek Life at Gettysburg, with nine social fraternities and five social sororities, students cannot rush until they are sophomores. The college boasts The Gettysburg Review, an esteemed literary magazine featuring short stories, poetry, reviews and essays. Athletic teams, nicknamed the Bullets, compete in NCAA Division III and participate in the Centennial Conference.

name: Pitzer College
profile: Pitzer College is a private liberal arts college in Claremont, CA. Founded in 1963 as a liberal arts school for women, it is one of The Claremont Colleges, a consortium of schools in the Claremont area. The schools are independent, yet they share some facilities and resources. Pitzer students can select from over 40 majors and may enroll in courses at the other four undergraduate Claremont Colleges. Pitzer is consistently one of the leading Fulbright feeder schools in the U.S. The campus is home to numerous student organizations, ranging from Badminton Club to Tutors for a Cause. The Kohoutek Music and Arts Festival, a student-run multiple day outdoor festival, has been a campus tradition since 1974. Renovations to the Gold Student Center, including the creation of more space for student organizations and an expansion of the fitness room, are new for 2014. Pitzer and Pomona College, another Claremont College, combine for intercollegiate sports. The Pomona-Pitzer Sagehens compete in Division III athletics.

name: Providence College
profile: Providence College is a private Roman Catholic university in Providence, RI. It was founded in 1917 by the Diocese of Providence and the Dominican Friars of the Providence of St. Joseph with the blessing of Pope Benedict XV. The school’s unique association continues to this day: 33 Dominican Friars and sisters are members of the faculty. Providence College offers 49 majors and 36 minors. The most popular majors for the class of 2017 are biology, marketing and elementary/special education. There are more than 100 student organizations and activities on campus. The 63,000-square-foot Ruane Center for the Humanities, which opened in 2013, is Providence College’s signature academic building. Varsity athletics first came to Providence College in 1929. The school’s teams, known as the Friars, mostly compete in Division I athletics.

name: Lawrence University
profile: Located in Appleton, WI, Lawrence University is a private liberal arts college that was founded in 1847. In addition to its 84-acre campus in downtown Appleton, the college also has a 425-acre wilderness retreat on the shore of Lake Michigan called Björkluden. Students are required to live on campus all four years. The university operates on a trimester calendar, or three 10-week terms. Seventy-five percent of students enroll in arts and sciences majors, while a quarter study at the Lawrence Conservatory of Music. Academics are bookended by Freshman Studies and the Senior Experience, a thesis or capstone project. Four Lawrence University students from the class of 2014 were awarded Fulbright Fellowships. The Great Midwest Trivia Contest, founded in 1966 by then-student James B. deRosset, is streamed online and broadcasted live on LU’s radio station WLFM in January; the contest runs for 50 consecutive hours. Known as the Vikings, the university’s 22 varsity teams compete in NCAA Division III athletics and is a founding member of the Midwest Conference.

name: Indiana University, Bloomington
profile: Indiana University, Bloomington is the flagship campus of Indiana University’s eight state campuses. The university occupies a 2,000-acre campus that includes Dunn Woods, the Arboretum and the Jordan River, providing students with an excellent natural laboratory and opportunity to enjoy the outdoors. The sprawling university offers 180 majors and 330 degree programs for undergraduates, plus more than 190 master's, doctoral and professional degrees. The IU Art Museum includes works by Picasso, Matisse and Monet. Distinguished alumni include four Nobel Prize winners, notably James Watson, who co-discovered the structure of DNA. The university annually holds the Little 500 bicycle race, which is the largest collegiate bike race in the country. In the fall, students participate in a dance marathon that raises money for Riley Hospital for Children in Indianapolis. IU, Bloomington offers 24 varsity sports teams, called the Hoosiers, that participate in the Big Ten Conference. Indiana University has won 24 national team championships. The university’s sports teams have also won more than 132 individual NCAA titles.

name: University of Minnesota, Twin Cities
profile: The flagship of the five-campus state public university system, University of Minnesota, Twin Cities has the only veterinary, pharmacy and dental colleges in the state and educates 85% of the state’s physicians. Alumni or faculty are responsible for the first wearable cardiac pacemaker, the retractable seat belt and Post-it® Notes. The university’s Andersen Library houses the world’s largest collection of Sherlock Holmes literature and memorabilia. It offers 50 joint graduate degree programs and 200 collaborative institutes and centers for interdisciplinary study. Student athletes play in NCAA Division I competition, the school colors are maroon and gold, and the mascot is Goldy Gopher.

name: Saint Olaf College
profile: Saint Olaf College is a private liberal arts college located on a 300-acre campus in Northfield, MN known as “The Hill.” It was established in 1874 and is affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church. The school is named after the King and Patron Saint Olaf II of Norway. The most popular majors are biology, economics, psychology, English and mathematics. Approximately one-third of the student body is involved with music. The college offers eight choirs, two orchestras, two bands and dozens of ensembles. The Saint Olaf Christmas Festival is one of the oldest Christmas music celebrations in the U.S. and is nationally aired on PBS. Adjacent to the main campus are 325 acres of restored wetlands, woodlands and prairie and a utility-grade wind turbine that powers one-third of the college’s electrical needs. Since 1995, the college has produced four Rhodes Scholars. Saint Olaf College competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and the teams are often referred to as the Oles.

name: Hampshire College
profile: Founded in 1965 as an experiment in alternative education, Hampshire College puts an emphasis on portfolios and faculty evaluations rather than grades or class standing. The focus is on enabling students to study the arts and humanities in a highly individualized environment. Unlike the traditional freshman-to-senior sequence, Hampshire students complete Division I, II and III work. At the end of Division III, students qualify for graduation and ring the Div Free Bell; it is considered bad luck to ring it before all coursework is finished. Hampshire College is the youngest of the schools in the Five-College Consortium. The other schools are Amherst College, Mt. Holyoke College, Smith College and the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. Alumni include actress Lupita Nyong’o and documentary producer Ken Burns. Hampshire College does not accept ACT and SAT scores in their admissions process. In 2012, a fund was established to help fund undocumented students' educations with scholarships that can exceed $25,000 per year.

name: Kalamazoo College
profile: Established in 1833, Kalamazoo College is one of the 100 oldest higher education institutions in the country, located 35 miles from Lake Michigan. A private liberal arts college, Kalamazoo has a core curriculum known as the “K-Plan,” which is comprised of four components: studying the liberal arts and sciences, participating in an internship or externship, immersing in global engagement and completing a senior project. It is ranked in the top 20 among all institutions for graduates earning Ph.D.s in foreign languages (6th), chemistry (9th), biology (7th), the physical sciences (17th) and economics (18th). Commonly called “K” College, its hilltop campus covers 60 acres. K College is a member of MIAA, the oldest collegiate athletics conference in the country and competes in NCAA Division III. A popular campus tradition is the Day of Gracious Living (DOGL), a surprise day off from classes every spring; the day is announced by the ringing of the Stetson Chapel bells. Robert Shiller is a notable alumnus who jointly won the 2013 Nobel Prize in Economics for his work analyzing asset prices.

name: Pepperdine University
profile: Pepperdine University is a private university in Malibu, CA. Founded in 1937 by Christian businessman George Pepperdine, the school remains affiliated with Churches of Christ. The 830-acre campus overlooks the Pacific Ocean. The most popular undergraduate majors at Pepperdine are business administration, psychology and sports medicine. More than 60% of undergraduate students participate in an international program. Popular campus traditions include Songfest—an annual theatrical stage show—and REELSTORIES FilmFest—a student-led film festival. Pepperdine’s Campus Ministry organizes a mission trip to San Felipe, Mexico each semester. Pepperdine has recycled all of its campus wastewater since 1972. The recycled water is used for up to 99% of campus irrigation. There are 17 men’s and women’s athletic teams at Pepperdine. Known as the Waves, Pepperdine’s teams mostly compete at the Division I level. Since 1956, 48 student-athletes, alumni and coaches have participated in the Olympics, winning 10 gold, 9 silver and three bronze medals.

name: University of California, Davis
profile: Founded in 1905 as the University Farm School, Davis hosts one of the nation’s leading veterinary schools and has strong agricultural and forestry programs, offering 28 majors focusing on plant and animal systems, human health and the environment in the College of Agricultural and Environmental Sciences. Students can choose from 100 undergraduate majors overall, divided among four colleges and six professional schools. The campus Craft Center houses a range of well-equipped laboratories and workshops where students can learn over 80 new skills from bookbinding to welding. The university is a frontrunner in sustainability efforts, and Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger once referred to it as the “environmental capital of the world.” The Davis Farmers Market has been recognized as one of the best farmers markets in the country. UC Davis has 23 NCAA Division I teams competing in the Big Sky and Big West Conferences. Its mascot is Gunrock the mustang. The school’s student-run spirit group, the “Aggie Pack,” is the largest in the country.

name: United States Coast Guard Academy
profile: The smallest of the five service schools, the U.S. Coast Guard Academy offers eight courses of study, including four that are specialized engineering programs. The school was established in 1878 aboard a schooner named Dobbin, but the modern academy was created in 1915 with the merger of the Life Saving Service and Revenue Cutter School and is located in New London, CT. The school’s motto is “The sea yields to knowledge,” and the fight song is “Semper Paratus.” The school’s athletes compete in NCAA Division III sports. Its mascot is the Bears, and the school colors are blue and orange. The academy has a Hall of Heroes, which includes a Wall of Remembrance and a Wall of Gallantry, as well as the Cadet Memorial Wall and the Heroes of Tomorrow. The Liberty Bell is a campus icon that gives good luck to cadets who ring it.

name: Lewis & Clark College
profile: Established in 1867, Lewis & Clark College is a private liberal arts college in Portland, OR. It offers 29 majors leading to bachelor’s degrees and has three colleges: the College of Arts and Sciences, School of Law and the Graduate School of Education and Counseling. Students have the option to live in themed residence housing, including a multicultural dorm and a substance-free dorm. Lewis & Clark offers about 36 international programs, and more than 60% of students study abroad. Between 1997 and 2012, Lewis & Clark students won a bounty of top scholarships, including 50 Fulbrights, 10 National Science fellowships, 17 Goldwaters, four Trumans and a Rhodes. The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and the school mascot is the Pioneers. This year’s commencement speaker was Marian Wright Edelmen, founder and president of Children’s Defense Fund. Local attractions include Powell’s Books, the largest bookstore in the country, and the Portland Art Museum and Forest Park, which spans 5,000 acres.

name: University of California, Santa Barbara
profile: The university was established in 1891 as a teacher’s college and entered the University of California system in 1944. Today the school offers more than 200 majors, degrees and credentials through five schools and the Graduate Division. There are currently five Nobel Laureates serving on the faculty. The university has the largest amount of LEED-certified buildings in the UC system. The campus is also very green in terms of transportation—biking is one of the most popular ways to get around, and bicyclists have the right of way on campus. The Koegel Autism Center in the Gevirtz School of Education is regarded as one of the top treatment centers for Autism in the nation. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and its mascot is the Gaucho.

name: Virginia Tech
profile: Virginia Tech is a public research university located in Blacksburg, VA. The motto of the university, “Ut Prosim,” means “That I May Serve.” Virginia Tech was established in 1872 and is now the commonwealth’s most comprehensive university as well as its leading research institution. Student can choose from 215 different undergraduate and graduate degree programs. Students are required to take courses in writing, society and human behavior, quantitative and symbolic reasoning and critical issues in global context. In the addition, the curriculum features the ViEWS — visual expression, writing and speaking — program. Virginia Tech occupies a 2,600-acre campus that includes 125 buildings and an airport. In 2008 Virginia Tech’s women’s softball team beat the U.S. Olympic team 1-0. At the end of the 2008 season, pitcher Angela Tincher was named USA Softball National Player of the Year. Virginia Tech competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the mascot is the HokieBird. The school’s colors are orange and maroon, selected when a committee realized no other college had this combination.

name: University of Colorado, Boulder
profile: Founded in 1876, the same year Colorado was admitted into the Union, University of Colorado, Boulder is the state’s flagship public research university. The most popular majors include psychology, integrative physiology, communication and economics. The school has built scientific instruments that have journeyed to every planet in the solar system, as well as Pluto. Faculty have been awarded five Nobel prizes, seven MacArthur fellowships and four National Medals of Science. The school is a major recipient of funding from NASA. The creators of “South Park,” Trey Parker and Matt Stone, attended the university. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the mascot is Ralphie, a live female buffalo.

name: Purdue University, West Lafayette
profile: Purdue University is a public research university in West Lafayette, IN. Founded in 1869, it is the flagship of Purdue’s five-campus system. Known as the “cradle of astronauts,” 23 alumni have been selected for space flight. Students can choose from over 200 undergraduate majors and more than 70 master’s and doctoral degree programs. Purdue has a reputation for its strong engineering program. The university offers plenty of ways to get involved outside of the classroom, too—there are more than 850 student organizations on campus. Purdue traditions include Grand Prix, a go-kart race between student teams that raises money for scholarships, and Spring Fest, a yearly two-day festival that attracts thousands of participants. Purdue is also well-known for its athletic programs: the school has won four team and 25 individual national championships. The university’s varsity teams, nicknamed the Boilermakers, are members of the Big Ten Conference. Notable former Purdue students include Neil Armstrong, first to walk on the moon, former Bechtel leader Stephen D. Bechtel, Jr. and NFL star Drew Brees.

name: Yeshiva University
profile: Yeshiva University, established in 1886 by East European immigrants, offers a curriculum that combines secular knowledge in the liberal arts with Orthodox Judaism. The school of more than 6,500 students has four campuses in New York City and one in Israel. Yeshiva consists of three undergraduate schools: Yeshiva College, Stern College for Women and Sy Syms School of Business, as well as wholly secular graduate schools in law and medicine. Students have the option to study in Israel in their first year. Its alumni’s acceptance rate to medical school has been 89% every year for the past 10 years, well above the national average. The athletic teams compete in NCAA Division III, and the nickname is the Maccabees. Notable alumni include best-selling authors Aaron Klein and Chaim Potok. Food served through the university’s dining services is entirely kosher. The Yeshiva University Museum was founded in 1973 and houses Jewish artwork; its current exhibition is called “Modeling the Synagogue: From Dura to Touro.”

name: Muhlenberg College
profile: Muhlenberg College is a private liberal arts college in Allentown, PA. It was founded in 1848 and is affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America. The college offers 40 undergraduate majors, ranging from neuroscience to theatre. More than half of Muhlenberg students study abroad during their college careers. There are more than 100 student organizations at Muhlenberg, including six a capella groups, four national fraternities and four national sororities. The college hosts a number of centers and institutes, including the Center for Ethics and the Institute for Jewish-Christian Understanding. Muhlenberg’s intercollegiate sports teams compete in the Centennial Conference at the NCAA Division III level.

name: George Washington University
profile: Established in 1821, George Washington University is a private university created at the behest of George Washington, who sought for an institution based in the heart of the nation’s capital that was dedicated to educating and preparing future leaders. With three campuses -- Foggy Bottom and Mount Vernon in Washington, D.C., and the GW Virginia Science and Technology Campus in Ashburn, VA, – George Washington University is consistently ranked as one of the most politically active institutions in the country. Every four years, during the presidential inauguration, the university hosts a black-tie event called the GW Inaugural Ball. The university also hosts its annual commencement ceremonies at the National Mall, within sight of the Washington Monument and the U.S. Capitol. About half of all GW students choose to study abroad through the university’s renowned international program. Notable attendees include Colin Powell, Kerry Washington and Alec Baldwin. GW has 23 NCAA Division I teams.

name: University of Redlands
profile: Located in Redlands, Calif., this private university was founded in 1907 by the American Baptist Convention. It is composed of four schools and five centers of distinctions, including the Johnston Center for Integrative Studies, Center for Educational Justice and the Banta Center for Business Ethics and Society. The school’s Cogeneration Plant allows it to produce the majority of its own energy, which works to heat and cool a third of on-campus buildings. The university offers a four-week May Term in which students can take an intensive class on campus or go abroad with a traveling class. The university sports teamed gained their nickname when, in 1917, the campus newspaper quoted the opposing football team’s coach calling the Redlands players bulldogs for their fighting spirit. Today, the university continues the tradition of having a live bulldog mascot. He is named Thurber. The school competes in NCAA Division III athletics. An “R” inscribed on a hill in the nearby San Bernardino Mountains as part of a freshman prank has become an important symbol for the school; the inscription is one of the largest collegiate letters in the country, measuring 415 feet in height and 275 feet in width.

name: College of the Atlantic
profile: College of the Atlantic is a private liberal arts college located in Bar Harbor, ME. Students and faculty often spend time in Acadia National Park, which is only a few short minutes from campus. Founded in 1969, it was an alternative to a traditional liberal arts college with its unique interdisciplinary learning. All students earn a B.A. in human ecology, still design their own academic programs and must complete a senior thesis. The College of the Atlantic was the first college in the U.S. to announce the goal of reducing the amount of greenhouse gases it emits. Since then, the campus uses 90% free-range, locally raised meats, organic and fair trade coffee and does not tolerate the use of bottled water. Since 2004, the college has been powered by low-flow renewable hydro-power, otherwise known as renewable electricity. Nell Newman, cofounder of Newman’s Own Organics, graduated with the class of 1987. The current President of the College is Darron Collins, a member of the class of 1992.

name: Bennington College
profile: Founded in 1932, Bennington College, located in Bennington, VT, was the first college to include visual and performing arts in a liberal arts education. Bennington values the untraditional educational process, allowing students to center their studies on ideas or questions in the “Plan Process,” during which students can determine what they want to study and how they will study it. Concentrations and courses in most traditional fields are offered, as well as in ceramics, conflict resolution and animation. The institution also requires its students to complete a Field Work Term — or a job or internship that compliments their studies — every winter term. At the Bennington Dining Hall, students traditionally post comments about the food on a large bulletin board, called “napkin notes.” Notable attendees include Academy Award-winning actor Alan Arkin and actor Justin Theroux.

name: University of California, San Diego
profile: UCSD offers 100 bachelor’s degree programs organized in six disciplinary areas. The most popular majors are social sciences, biology and engineering. The university’s faculty, staff and alumni have started 646 companies, and two alumni were members of the original Apple Macintosh development team. One of the oldest UCSD traditions is the Watermelon Drop, inspired by a 1965 physics exam question in which students toss watermelons from the top floor of Revelle’s Urey Hall, accompanied by a Watermelon Queen pageant. Every year, the campus hosts “UnOlympics,” a competition in which teams representing the school’s residential colleges compete for the “golden shoe.” The school participates in Division II athletics, and its mascot is King Triton -- a nod to the school’s proximity to the Pacific. UCSD has a strong surfing team, which has won six national championships and is consistently ranked among the best surfing programs in the country.

name: Case Western Reserve University
profile: Case Western Reserve University is a private research university located in Cleveland's 500-acre University Circle. The university offers a number of degrees in conjunction with nearby institutions, namely the Cleveland Institute of Music and the Cleveland Institute of Art. Popular majors include biomedical engineering, biology, nursing and mechanical engineering. The school has 10 colleges and schools and offers a general education program named SAGES. Case Western Reserve had the first ABET-accredited program in computer engineering and pioneered the early Free-net computer systems. The school produced 16 Nobel laureates, including the first American scientist to win the Nobel Prize, physicist Albert Michelson. The school is part of the Global E3, which allows engineering students at member universities to attend overseas schools at home institution tuition. Around one-third of the campus undergraduates are in a fraternity or sorority. The university’s oldest tradition, a 26-mile relay race called “The Hudson Relays,” is held annually to commemorate the university’s 26-mile move from Hudson, OH, to its current location in 1882. Student workers at the university’s farm produce over three tons of vegetables annually, which are served in campus dining halls. The university competes in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: University of Miami
profile: The University of Miami is a private research university located in Coral Gables, FL, comprised of 11 schools and colleges that offer 110 bachelor’s, 103 master’s and 62 doctoral programs. The university is set across five campuses, including the Rosenstiel Campus, home to the Rosenstiel School of Marine and Atmospheric Science and the Medical Campus, housing the Leonard M. Miller School of Medicine and three university-owned hospitals that make up the University of Miami Health System. The university’s study abroad locations include Prague, Rome, Cape Town and India. The athletic teams compete in NCAA Division I and the Atlantic Coast Conference as the Hurricanes, the school colors are orange, green and white. The school’s library system gives students access to nearly 3.5 million volumes. Prominent alumni include actor Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson, musician Enrique Iglesias and Indianapolis Colts wide receiver Reggie Wayne.

name: Virginia Military Institute
profile: Founded in 1839, Virginia Military Institute is the first state-supported military college in the U.S. and the last to admit women. The institute offers 14 majors and 20 minors categorized under engineering, liberal arts, humanities and the sciences. Engineering is the most popular concentration. VMI offers ROTC programs for four U.S. military branches. Ring Figure dance is held every November during which junior cadets receive class rings, a formal ring and a combat ring, at a ring presentation ceremony. Every year in May, the school honors its fallen cadets during a New Market Day parade. VMI’s sports teams, known as the Keydets, compete on Division I level, and they are also a member of the Southern Conference for wrestling and the Atlantic Sun Conference for men’s lacrosse. VMI alumni include U.S. Army’s chief of staff during World War II and the architect of the Marshall Plan, George Marshall. The school has also produced a Nobel Peace Prize winner, Pulitzer Prize winners, Rhodes Scholars and an Academy Award Winner.

name: Willamette University
profile: Willamette University is a coeducational, private liberal arts university located in Salem, OR. Established in 1842, the college was originally named the Oregon Institute. In 1942, five Sequoia trees known as Willamette’s Star Trees were planted in honor of Willamette’s centennial. These Sequoia trees are the largest on any college or university campus in the nation. Willamette places an emphasis on sustainability, and its students have the opportunity to learn about organic farming and sustainability at the school’s Zena Farm. James Albaugh, former CEO of The Boeing Company, is a graduate of the school. Willamette competes in Division III of the Northwest Conference with 19 varsity teams. The school mascot is Blitz the Bearcat – neither a bear nor a cat, but rather a nocturnal Asian mammal called the “binturong.”

name: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute
profile: Rensselaer Polytechnic University is a private technical university in Troy, NY. Founded in 1824, it is the oldest technological research university in the U.S. The school offers more than 145 bachelor’s, master’s and doctoral degrees from five schools. Rensselaer is home to 33 research centers and is especially known for its strong engineering program. There are nearly 200 clubs, sports and organizations on campus. Rensselaer uses a system called CLASS (Clustered Learning, Advocacy and Support for Students) that seeks to build support networks for students by connecting them with faculty, staff and other students. Outgoing senior classes design a banner that represents their college years, which is unveiled at senior brunch and is used at future reunions. Rensselaer has 23 varsity sports teams, nicknamed the Engineers, that compete in the NCAA Division II, except for the men’s and women’s hockey teams, which compete at the Division I level.

name: Trinity University
profile: Trinity University is a private university located in San Antonio, TX. It was established in 1869 and is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church (USA). The school offers 42 majors and master’s degrees in accounting, health care administration, education in school leadership, school psychology and arts in teaching. The school values experiential learning, offering specialized study experiences such as a geology or governance trip to China and leadership studies in Alaska. The Coates Library has more than one million volumes and won the Excellence in Academic Libraries Award from the Association of College and Research Libraries (ACRL) in 2007. The university has more than 70 guest lecturers on campus annually. Every Wednesday at 3:33 p.m. is “Nacho Hour,” which offers students free nachos. Trinity competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and its sports teams are nicknamed the Tigers. The week before the Homecoming football game is known as Tigerfest, with activities including an armadillo hunt (where students hunt a live armadillo for a cash prize). Around 65% of students participate in intramural sports.

name: Juniata College
profile: Founded in 1876, Juniata College is a private liberal arts college located in Huntingdon, Penn. It offers an on-time graduation program, and in the last few years, it has seen 96% of students complete their degrees in four years or fewer. Juniata students have an academic and general adviser from different departments, and 29% of the student body designs its own major. Over 80% of students live on campus in 20 residence halls over 110 acres. Popular traditions include Lobsterfest, an annual fall dinner welcoming students to campus, and Mountain Day, an all-day event when classes are cancelled and students, faculty and staff head to one of the state parks for outdoor activities. Super Internships is a program where Juniata offers its students stipends of up to $5,000 to offset the expenses associated with taking an internship. The college is a member of the NCAA Division III, and the athletic teams are nicknamed the Eagles.

name: American University
profile: As a private, research-based, liberal arts university located in the nation’s capital, it comes as no surprise that American University has earned a reputation for its strength in international relations, government, political science and journalism. The School of International Service was founded in 1958 and is the largest school of international affairs in the country. Today AU offers 61 bachelor’s degrees and a number of interdisciplinary degrees, including a BA in CLEG: Communications, Legal Issues, Economics and Government. WAMU, the on-campus NPR station, is rated among the best in the country. American University also boasts many service communities, such as DC Reads, a tutoring organization in which college students teach DC public school students. Each February, American hosts a Founders Day Ball at a popular D.C. venue, such as the National Museum of American History. Dozens of ambassadors and political leaders are alumni of the school, including Sen. Robert Byrd and former Sec. of Health & Human Services Donna Shalala. The university's 84-acre campus is a public garden and arboretum as designated by the American Public Gardens Association.

name: University of Delaware
profile: Founded in 1743, the University of Delaware is one of the oldest universities in the U.S. -- three of its first 10 students went on to sign the Declaration of Independence. A public research university located in Newark, DE, it offers 144 bachelor’s, 124 master’s and 59 doctoral programs. In 1923, the university became the first in the U.S. to start a study abroad program, and it’s still going strong today, offering students the opportunity to go to nearly 50 countries. Over a third of the student body participates in the international programs. The university has partnerships with Nemours/A.I. du Pont Hospital for Children, Christiana Care, Thomas Jefferson University and the U.S. Army. The school also has a 146-foot coastal research vessel that participates in ocean exploration and a high-performance figure skating center that world-class athletes use for training. It competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is YoUDee the Blue Hen.

name: College of Wooster
profile: College of Wooster was founded in 1866, and it currently offers bachelor’s of arts, music and music education. This private liberal arts institution is located mid-way between Columbus and Cleveland, OH, and has been cited as one of the “Colleges That Change Lives." It is well-known for its independent study program. Through the program, students work one-on-one with a faculty member to finish a thesis or a project during their senior year. Surrounding the program, there is a school tradition in which students receive a yellow button saying “I did it.”In 2012, the college established an advising program called APEX, which offers students comprehensive advising services that address their academic, personal and professional goals. College of Wooster competes in the NCAA Division III and is a member of the North Coast Athletic Conference. During homecoming weekend at Wooster, almost 1,000 people attend a cricket match.

name: Texas A&M University, College Station
profile: Texas A&M University, College Station was Texas’ first public higher education institution. It was established in 1876 as the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas. It is one of the nation’s largest universities situated on 5,200 acres. The university offers over 120 undergraduate and 240 graduate degree programs at its 16 colleges. The university conducts research valued at more than $700 million annually, and its endowment has reached over $5 billion. With the George Bush Presidential Library and Museum, which opened on campus in 1997, Texas A&M is one of only a few universities to host a presidential library on its campus. The school’s mascot is a live dog named Reveille; she’s cared for by the Corps of Cadets Company E-2. Texas A&M competes in NCAA Division I athletics as the Aggies. During a football game against Centre College in 1922, a student in the stands named E. King Gill volunteered to play for the injury-wracked Aggies, who were down to 11 healthy players. Though Gill never had to enter the game, his readiness helped make the phrase “12th man” a part of sports vernacular.

name: Saint Lawrence University
profile: Saint Lawrence University was established in 1856 and is named for the St. Lawrence River, which is approximately 20 miles from campus and serves as a research facility as well as the site of the crew team’s practices and competitions. The university offers more than 36 majors and 36 minors for its students, and students are also able to take classes at nearby Clarkson University and SUNY Potsdam. Students who want to study multiple disciplines but can’t find an existing department or major have the option to declare a “multi-field” major and design their own program of study. The most popular majors are economics, psychology, biology, government and environmental studies. One of the highlights of the SLU educational offerings is the Adirondack Semester, where students will learn as they rappel, climb, hike and explore the Adirondack region. Established in 1937, SLU’s Outing Club is one of the oldest and largest in the country. On “Peak Weekend” members of the Outing Club try to climb all 46 Adirondack “High Peaks” on the same weekend. The Saint Lawrence Saints compete in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: University of Denver
profile: The University of Denver is one of the nation’s first private universities; it was established in 1864. It is home to the second-highest vantage point of a telescope in the world, located at 14,148 feet above sea level near the summit of Mount Evans at the Meyer-Womble Observatory. It also offers more than 170 undergraduate programs of study. In October 2012, the school hosted the first of three presidential debates. The University of Denver’s mascot is the Pioneer, and its teams compete in NCAA Division I athletics. The school’s original rosebush was brought to the campus in 1913 and cultivated by botanist Ira Cutler to bloom in red and gold around graduation.

name: University of Vermont
profile: Founded in 1791, the school was chartered the same year Vermont became the 14th state in America. It was the fifth university established in New England and the first American institution of higher learning that declared no religious affiliation. It offers 100 undergraduate majors in eight schools and colleges. UVM’s student center was the first in the nation to receive the U.S. Green Building Council LEED Gold certification for sustainability. Its athletic teams are known as the Catamounts and compete in 18 NCAA Division I varsity sports. The university is often referred to as UVM, which is also an abbreviation of its Latin name, Universitas Viridis Montis, meaning “university of the green mountains.” The college is located in Burlington, VT, less than hour away from major ski resorts such as Bolton Valley, Stowe, Sugarbush, Mad River Glen and Smugglers' Notch. Notable alumni include author Gail Sheehy and Nobel Peace Prize Laureate Jody Williams.

name: University of Utah
profile: Established in 1850, the public research university offers over 100 undergraduate majors and more than 90 graduate options. The college operates on a three-semester system. It has the only accredited medical school and architecture program in Utah. The campus is home to the Utah Museum of Fine Arts, the Red Butte Garden & Arboretum and the Natural History Museum of Utah. The school is 40 minutes away from seven ski resorts. The university competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school’s mascot is the red-tailed hawk. Their nickname is the “Utes.” Notable alumni include science fiction author Orson Scott Card and cofounder and president of Pixar Animation Ed Catmull.

name: Presbyterian College
profile: Presbyterian College is a private college in Clinton, SC. It was founded in 1880 as Clinton College and is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.). The school offers 32 majors, nine pre-professional programs and 45 minors. All students participate in an internship, study abroad or research program, and around 75% of students do volunteer work. All students agree to a student-maintained honor code, a tradition dating back to 1915. Around 45% of students participate in Greek life at one of the school’s six national fraternities or three national sororities. Approximately 80% of students participate in intercollegiate athletics or intramural sports. Presbyterian College’s athletic teams, known as the Blue Hose, compete in Division I athletics. The unique team name comes from the blue socks that were part of their uniforms in the early 20th century.

name: Drake University
profile: Drake University, named after Civil War general Francis Marion Drake in 1881, is located in Des Moines, IA. Through its six schools, Drake offers more than 70 majors, minors and concentrations – including a flexible “build your own” major. Drake students can participate in more than 160 clubs and organizations from a wide range of focuses including academics, arts, international, religious and service. There are also 14 fraternities and sororities on campus. In 2007 and 2011, Drake University hosted nationally televised presidential debates. Currently, it competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is the Bulldog. Every April since 1910, the greatest track and field athletes arrive at the university for the Drake Relays. In Drake’s annual Beautiful Bulldog contest, hundreds of bulldog owners bring their dogs to be judged by a celebrity panel, and the winner earns the honor of serving as the official mascot of the Drake Relays.

name: University of California, Irvine
profile: The University of California, Irvine opened its doors in the early 1960s along with two other UC schools to accommodate the post-war baby boom generation. The school offers more than 80 undergraduate degree programs, over 50 master’s and over 40 Ph.D. programs. Three UCI researchers have won Nobel Prizes in chemistry and physics. The Henry Samueli School of Engineering recently received a $9.5 million gift that will go towards student scholarships and graduate fellowships, supporting STEM programs, renovating study areas in the school and a $2 million endowed deanship. The university competes in NCAA Division I athletics. An anteater in Johnny Hart’s cartoon strip “B.C.” was the inspiration for the campus mascot, Peter the Anteater. Six gold Olympic medals have been won by athletes who competed at the university, 14 gold medals by paralympians and three gold medals by graduate students and coaches.

name: Ohio Wesleyan University
profile: Ohio Wesleyan University is a private liberal arts college in Delaware, OH. It was established in 1842 and is affiliated with the United Methodist Church, though it has admitted students of all races and religions since its founding. Ohio Wesleyan offers over 90 majors, minors and concentrations. Engineering students can partake in 3-2 programs, which grant students liberal arts bachelor’s degrees in three years and sends them to engineering schools like the California Institute of Technology for an additional, two-year bachelor’s degree. Special programs like “Wesleyan in Washington,” which grants academic credit to students working full-time government jobs and internships in Washington, D.C., offer students a chance to gain practical experience while still in school. Applicants with GPAs greater than 3.5 at the end of their high school junior year can opt not to submit test scores. Ohio Wesleyan has 23 varsity teams that compete in Division III athletics. Between varsity, intramural and club sports, 75% of Ohio Wesleyan students participate in athletics. Among the school’s notable attendees is Charles W. Fairbanks, 26th Vice President of the United States.

name: Clark University
profile: Located in Worcester, MA, Clark University was founded in 1887 as the first all-graduate institution in the country. Founded by American businessman Jonas Gilman Clark, this private liberal arts college offers 32 majors, 32 minors, 10 interdisciplinary concentrations and 14 accelerated B.A./Master’s degree programs only available to Clark undergraduates (the fifth year is tuition-free). The school provides a Youth Worker Certificate to students interested in working on social justice issues in urban communities. The university also operates a public secondary school, the University Park Campus School. Cinema 320 is Clark University’s on-campus theatre, built in 1982, located in Jefferson Academic Center. Paul Siple, Ph.D. (1939) invented the theory and measurement of wind chill in his dissertation. In 1942, Siple named a mountain range in Antarctica in honor of Clark and named the peaks after six Clark professors. The University competes in the NCAA Division III, and it is also a member of the New England Women’s and Men’s Athletic Conference.

name: Tulane University
profile: Tulane was founded in 1834 and is one of New Orleans’ oldest institutions. It is the largest private employer of the New Orleans area today and is the region's leading education and research center. The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching ranked the university as one with “very high research activity.” The core consists of a TIDES freshman year seminar, two classes in public service and a capstone course for seniors. Different schools within Tulane also have different core requirements. Tulane University athletes, or “Green Wave,” compete in NCAA Division I athletics. Graduates and their families take part in the Wave Goodbye, a traditional New Orleans-style party with local food and music on the Friday night before commencement.

name: Grove City College
profile: Grove City College is a private liberal arts college located in Grove City, PA. Established in 1876, Grove City was once affiliated with the Presbyterian Church U.S.A. Every full-time student is required to attend 16 chapels per semester. The cost to attend Grove City College is less than half of the national average. The college refuses federal aid, is debt-free and advocates a free market philosophy in all aspects of campus operations. Grove City fosters future leaders throughout its Initiative for Leadership Education and Development (iLead). It also has strong affiliations with a number of think tanks, among them the conservative Center for Vision & Values and the libertarian Ludwig von Mises Institute. Some strange traditions linger such as “Creeking”: when a male student gets engaged, his friends will kidnap him, carry him to Wolf Creek while chanting “Wolf creek! Wolf creek!” and throw him in the water, while his fiancée waits nearby with a towel. The Grove City Wolverines are a NCAA Division III school that competes in the Presidents’ Athletic Conference.

name: Knox College
profile: Knox College was founded in 1837 by anti-slavery social reformers and was one of the first colleges in the country to open its doors to both people of color and women. Located in Galesburg, IL, Knox was the site of the fifth debate between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen A. Douglas in 1858, and the college gave its first honorary doctorate to Lincoln in 1860. Knox employs a 3–3 academic calendar rather than a traditional semester-based approach. In each of the three 10-week terms, students take three courses. The college offers 87 majors and minors, 11 pre-professional programs and hosts 39 off-campus programs. More than 20 Fulbright fellowships have been awarded to Knox College students in the past 15 years. At the beginning of the year, students and staff gather on the south lawn and shake hands. The event is called the Pumphandle, and the welcoming line is led by the school’s president, Teresa L. Amott. The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and the school mascot is the Prairie Fire. Past commencement speakers have included Barack Obama, Stephen Colbert and Bill Clinton.

name: Fordham University
profile: Fordham University is a Jesuit university established in 1841 and located in the Bronx, NY, with a satellite campus in mid-Manhattan. Fordham takes advantage of its location by teaming up with nearby schools and providing cross registration with Julliard and Columbia, among others. All undergrads must complete a core curriculum of 17 courses across nine different subjects including English, math, social science, philosophy and ethics, history, fine arts, religious studies, natural science and language. Each year the university hosts Spring Fling, which includes big screen movie nights, live performers and a student vs. administration softball game. Fordham also hosts Leadership Weekend, an event devoted to teaching leadership and teamwork skills to student leaders. Fordham sponsors 23 men’s and women’s varsity sports teams, and the Rams are members of NCAA Division I and compete in the Atlantic 10 Conference. Notable alumni include Donald Trump, Denzel Washington, Andrew Cuomo and Vince Lombardi.

name: Saint Michael's College
profile: Saint Michael’s College is a private liberal arts college located in Colchester, VT, right outside the city of Burlington. The coeducational school was established in 1904 and is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. There are about 2,000 undergraduates. Because the college is completely residential, all students live on campus. There are 32 major and minors, and the school requires Experiential Learning through either coursework or extracurricular activities. Saint Michael’s offers a Wilderness Program where students can explore the northern New England landscape. Participants can hike, rock climb, ice climb and kayak, while practicing environmental stewardship. Students can also ski and snowboard at nearby Smugglers’ Notch, one of the top ski resorts on the East Coast, by purchasing a full-season pass for only $30. During the spring, students grow vegetables in an organic garden that they can later sell on campus in the summer and fall. The college competes in NCAA Division II athletics, and the school mascot is the Purple Knight.

name: Hendrix College
profile: Established in 1876, Hendrix College is a private, liberal arts college located in Conway, AR, some 30 minutes from Little Rock. Hendrix College’s motto, “Unto the whole person,” reveals its dedication to the liberal arts ideal and its connection to Christian principles. The College is affiliated with the United Methodist Church.
