Students are offered 34 majors and 36 minors, and each year students have the opportunity to take a three-week trip to the Southwest to study the history, culture and environment of the region. Hendrix is known for its Odyssey Project, a mandatory part of the curriculum in which students take specialized courses, participate in school-approved activities or propose their own projects to encourage more engaged learning tailored to students’ interests. There are no fraternities or sororities. The campus has many beautiful buildings and four that are listed on the National Register of Historic Places. Athletically, the college competes at the NCAA Division III level in the Southern Athletic Association. The Hendrix Warriors have 21 varsity teams. Non-varsity athletes have the opportunity to participate in club sports.

name: Colorado School of Mines
profile: The Colorado School of Mines is a public research university that concentrates on engineering and applied science. It was founded in 1874 to meet the state’s need for new mining methods, and it was the first institution of higher learning opened in Colorado. The university has the largest collegiate section of the Society of Women Engineers in the U.S. In 2013, the school received more than $62 million in awards from private industry and federal agencies. There are 18 intercollegiate teams at the school, which is more than any other Division II school in the state. Also on campus is the school’s geology museum, which houses one of Colorado’s two moon rocks that were collected during the Apollo 17 mission. In the annual “M Climb” tradition, entering freshmen climb nearby Mount Zion, carrying a 10-pound rock, and whitewash the giant mountainside “M” monument made out of white painted rocks. By the time of graduation, seniors would return to the mountain and retrieve the rock.

name: Bard College
profile: Founded in 1860 in the idyllic Hudson River Valley in NY, Bard College was originally established as St. Stephen’s College on the precipice of the Civil War by men who believed a liberal education trumped military tradition. The belief in the power of academia in times of crisis has held firm since then. Now, the private school offers almost 50 programs in four academic divisions, as well as an Interdivisional Course of Study, where students major in multiple programs. Undergraduates declare majors during their sophomore year and complete a senior project before graduation. The Conservatory of Music hosts concerts by prominent musicians. Most on-campus dormitories have views of the Catskill Mountains or the Hudson River, and the college’s Field Station on the Hudson River provides access to research and teaching on freshwater tidal marshes, swamps, streams and forests.

name: Ohio State University, Columbus
profile: Ohio State University, Columbus is a public research university in Columbus, OH. Established in 1870, it is one of the largest college campuses in the U.S. Students hail from all 50 states and over 70 countries and can choose from more than 175 majors and 475 academic specializations. Ohio State’s 14 colleges offer approximately 12,000 courses. Ohio State’s alumni base is large, with over 500,000 living alumni. Research and development expenditures totaled $967 million last year. Famous hangouts include the Oval, the heart of the campus, and Ohio Stadium, affectionately dubbed “The Shoe,” one of football’s largest stadiums. Sports are a major part of Ohio State’s campus culture: The university operates one of the largest intercollegiate athletics programs in the nation. Most teams, nicknamed the Buckeyes, compete in the Big Ten Conference. In addition to varsity athletics, there are more than 1,000 student organizations, from fraternities and sororities to Swahili club. Notable alumni include Wikipedia co-founder Larry Sanger, entrepreneur Leslie Wexner, golfer Jack Nicklaus, artist Roy Lichtenstein and former Yankee owner George Steinbrenner. In June Michael V. Drake began his tenure as Ohio State’s 15th president.

name: Creighton University
profile: Creighton University was established in 1878 and is one of the United States’ 28 Jesuit higher-level learning institutions. Its campus is located near the downtown business district of Omaha. At Creighton, students of diverse faiths and backgrounds have the opportunity to choose from nine different schools and colleges that offer more than 100 majors. About 96% of Creighton’s undergraduate class is working, attending graduate or professional school or volunteering within eight months of the graduation ceremony. Creighton students, faculty and staff contributed more than 295,000 hours to volunteer service last year. Creighton’s athletic teams are known as the Bluejays, and they compete in NCAA Division I. Notable alumni include former COO of Coca-Cola, Donald Keough.

name: California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo
profile: One of the largest campuses in the nation, California Polytechnic State University is a public university in San Luis Obispo, halfway between San Francisco and Los Angeles. Originally founded as a vocational high school in 1901, Cal Poly now has six colleges and offers 147 bachelor’s degrees. As of fall 2012, engineering is the most popular and selective major on campus, followed by agriculture, food and environment sciences. Cal Poly sits on 1321-acres and owns an additional 8,357 acres of rolling campus in the north devoted to student farming, experimental architecture and other outdoor laboratory studies. The new construction projects include freshmen housing dormitory complex (projected date of completion: fall 2018). Another is the academic center and library building project to begin in 2015. The Poly “P,” built by students, is one of the oldest hillside initials in the West and a prominent symbol of students’ school pride. Decorating the P to spell out messages – even marriage proposals – is a long-standing campus tradition. The P was altered to GOP in 1964, to POT in the 1970s and even SPRINGSTEEN in the 1980s. Cal Poly competes in NCAA Division I athletics.

name: Syracuse University
profile: The private research university offers undergraduate degrees in over 200 majors in nine schools and colleges. The S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications is ranked among the top communication schools in the nation. SU has an exceptionally large pool of student media organizations, with a broad range of student-run magazines, radio and television stations, newspapers, PR and advertising agencies. CitrusTV is one of the nation’s largest entirely student-run television studios. The school recently opened a campus in New York City that allows students to spend a semester taking specialized coursework while completing internships. Approximately 30% of the student body is affiliated with one of the 70+ on-campus fraternities and sororities. Distinguished alumni include Vice President Joe Biden, television icon Dick Clark and sportscasters Bob Costas and Mike Tirico. The sports teams, known as the Orange, compete in NCAA Division I in the Atlantic Coast Conference. In February 2014, basketball fans set a NCAA attendance record of 35,446 in a game against Duke University.

name: Thomas Aquinas College
profile: Thomas Aquinas College is a private liberal arts college that was established in 1971 and is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. It was the first of the new orthodox Catholic colleges founded after the reforms ushered in by the Second Vatican Council. This school uses the Socratic Seminar Method; there are no lectures on campus. About 40% of Thomas Aquinas College graduates enroll in professional schools and about 11% become priests or carry out a religious lifestyle. Located in Santa Paula, CA, the college’s campus is about 65 miles from Los Angeles and close to the Los Padres National Forest. Thomas Aquinas regulates the use of the Internet while TVs, VHS and DVD players are prohibited. Thomas Aquinas has active music and theater extracurricular programs, as well as strong intramural athletics that roughly 60% of students participate in. Students also attend the traditional pre-Thanksgiving Turkey Bowl, a flag football game between the upperclassmen and underclassmen. Undergraduates also compete in the annual Tug-of-War contest.

name: Hobart and William Smith Colleges
profile: Hobart and William Smith Colleges are four-year, private liberal arts colleges located in Geneva, NY. Hobart College is a men’s college founded in 1822 and William Smith College is a women’s college founded in 1908. The colleges share a campus, administration and faculty; however, each college has its own dean and operates its own student government and athletic department. Students are offered 40 majors, 60 minors and 70 student organizations and clubs. The average class size is 17 students. Additionally, Hobart and William Smith College offer students the opportunity to live in themed houses that offer similar-minded students a common house: leadership is emphasized in the Bampton House while students in the Carr-McGuire House are committed to a substance-free life. Each semester, the colleges host multiple Professionals in Residence to allow experienced professionals the opportunity to teach students real-world knowledge. Athletically, the colleges compete in the NCAA with 11 varsity sports at the Division III. The men’s lacrosse team however, competes at the Division I level in the Northeast Conference. The mascot of Hobart is the Statesman and the mascot of William Smith is the Heron.

name: Westmont College
profile: Westmont College is a four year, interdenominational liberal arts school that is affiliated with the Christian faith. The college was founded in 1937 as a Bible Missionary Institution. Today, the college offers more than 25 majors and students have the opportunity to study off campus during their undergraduate experience at Westmont. Over half of the students take advantage of the study abroad offerings at programs in England, San Francisco, Mexico, Istanbul and a semester program across Europe. Westmont has been successful at providing students with interesting talks by world leaders. Past speakers have included Henry Kissinger, Gen. Colin Powell and Condoleezza Rice, and author Walter Isaacson. Students at Westmont are very service oriented. Nearly every student participates in a service project or trip during their studies. Westmont competes in NAIA athletics in the Golden State Athletic Conference.

name: Saint John's College (MD)
profile: Saint John’s College is a small coeducational, private college that was established in 1784. The college’s academic curriculum is uncommon for a liberal arts college; students are all required to take the same course of study and read from classics that include works by Plato, Aristotle and Homer, as well as more contemporary authors. Saint John’s College is located in the historic Annapolis district, one block away from the Maryland State Capitol building. The proximity to the United States Naval Academy has inspired comparisons between Athens and Sparta. Every year the schools meet on the front lawn of Saint John’s and compete in a croquet match that has been called, “The purest intercollegiate athletic event in America.” Saint John’s has won 25 of the 31 annual matches. Additionally, every Friday night a guest lecture is held in the Francis Scott Key auditorium.

name: Clemson University
profile: Originally an all-male military school founded in 1889, it became a coeducational institution in 1955 and renamed Clemson University in 1964. The university is divided into five colleges, with the largest enrollment in engineering and science, followed by agriculture, forestry and life sciences. Clemson is one of 18 schools that has been honored by the American Football Coaches Association for its graduation rate of about 90%. The university maintains several centers that offer entrepreneurial experience. In May 2013 two architecture graduate students placed in a national competition for their design proposals for a library in Pendleton, SC. Ice cream made and sold by Clemson students is available at the ’55 Exchange store on campus; the tradition was started by the school’s dairy science and animal husbandry departments in the 1920s. It competes in NCAA Division I-A athletics, and the school mascot is the Tiger. Notable alumni include James Byrnes, the former U.S. Supreme Court Justice and TV entertainment journalist Nancy O’Dell.

name: University of Connecticut
profile: Established in 1881, it’s a public research university that offers 102 undergraduate majors. UConn is the only public university in New England with schools of Law, Social Work, Medicine and Dental Medicine. In the dining hall, students have an exceptionally wide variety of gluten-free options. The university has its own dairy bar that serves 24 flavors of its own homemade ice cream, and it raises bees to create hundreds of pounds honey for the campus dining halls. Every year the school hosts Oozeball, a mud volleyball tournament where students splash around in 600 gallons of water and 60 tons of dirt. The University of Connecticut competes in NCAA Division I athletics, with particularly strong programs in men’s and women’s basketball, and the school mascot is Jonathan the Husky. In the 2003-04 season, the men’s and women’s basketball teams won dual national championships.

name: Beloit College
profile: Founded in 1846, Beloit College is located in Wisconsin, just 50 miles from Madison, WI. Students can choose from more than 50 majors and 38 minors– or, if that’s not enough, they can create their own program. Beloit College boasts an average class size of 15 students and maintains that one-third of their classes have less than 10 students. It competes in NCAA Division III athletics, with 19 varsity sports for both men and women, and the unofficial mascot is the turtle. There are 23 ancient Indian mounds on campus. "The Round Table," Beloit’s campus newspaper, is the second-oldest college publication in the nation. Notable alumni include Ding Darling, the Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist.

name: Pennsylvania State University, University Park
profile: Pennsylvania State University, University Park is a public research university in University Park, PA. It is the flagship of Penn State’s 24-campus system that includes 17,000 faculty and staff and over 100,000 students. It was founded in 1855 with a goal of applying scientific principles to farming. Penn State offers more than 160 undergraduate majors, and students hail from all 50 states and over 130 countries. The school’s 2+2 Plan allows students to spend two years at one campus before transferring to another campus for the remaining two years. Approximately 60% of students choose this path. More than 2,500 undergraduates take part in over 300 education abroad programs every year. Penn State offers more than 1,200 student organizations across its system, ranging from academic and professional clubs to intramural sports. Penn State hosts an annual pediatric cancer fundraiser known as THON, a 46-hour dance event that engages more than 15,000 students in Pennsylvania. THON raised over $13.3 million in 2014. Penn State teams have won 73 national championships; 2014 winners include fencing and wrestling. Beaver Stadium, home to the school’s storied football program, is the second largest American football stadium in the U.S., with seating for nearly 107,000 fans.

name: North Carolina State University, Raleigh
profile: Established in 1887, North Carolina State University, Raleigh offers over 300 undergraduate and graduate degree programs in 12 different colleges. Programs include agriculture, engineering, forestry, wood and paper science, textiles and design. NC State’s research expenditures approach $325 million annually, and the school operates two leading National Science Foundation Engineering Research Centers. Since the 1960s, it has maintained a railroad underpass as the Free Expression Tunnel, on which students may write and paint whatever they wish. Students also participate in the Krispy Kreme Challenge—running two and a half miles to the nearest Krispy Kreme, eating a dozen donuts each, and running back—in under an hour. Proceeds go to the North Carolina Children’s Hospital; $200,000 was donated in 2014. The university competes in NCAA Division I athletics.

name: College of New Jersey
profile: The College of New Jersey (TCNJ), located in Ewing, is about five miles from the New Jersey state capital, Trenton, and about one hour from Philadelphia and New York City. Students can select from more than 50 liberal arts and professional programs in the seven schools on campus. First-year students are housed in on-campus housing while many upperclassmen choose to live off-campus. In the past decade, the college began to invest in student entrepreneurship and provide counseling and workshops for students. In 2014, the Mayo Business Plan Competition awarded $30,000 to a number of student groups to start their business. In addition, the school holds entrepreneurship events for local high school students. David Sarnoff Museum exhibits the work of student artists, professional artists and local artists. It participates in NCAA Division III athletics, and the school mascot is the Lion.

name: Michigan State University
profile: Founded in 1855, Michigan State University is the first land-grant institution under the 1862 Morrill Act. In fall 2012 there were approximately 36,750 undergraduate students and 10,250 graduate students. MSU’s study abroad program is one of the largest in the country and offers over 275 programs in over 60 countries on all continents, including Antarctica. The U.S. Department of Energy has commissioned the school to design and establish a $615 million Facility for Rare Isotope Beams. The school has had 34 Goldwater Scholarships and 16 Rhodes Scholarships. The Michigan State Spartans compete in NCAA Division I in the Big Ten Conference in all sports except ice hockey. MSU plays an annual non-conference football game against the legendary Notre Dame Fighting Irish.

name: Loyola University Maryland
profile: Founded in 1852, Loyola University Maryland is a coeducational Jesuit, Catholic university in Baltimore, MD. Loyola Maryland offers majors and minors in over 40 academic fields as well as study abroad programs in Thailand, Australia and New Zealand. The university has three colleges, the School of Education, the Sellinger School of Business and Management and the college of arts and sciences, called Loyola College. The university was the first higher education institution to be named after St. Ignatius of Loyola. Loyolapalooza is an annual spring festival that includes a musical performance. The university competes in NCAA Division I athletics.

name: Hampden-Sydney College
profile: Hampden-Sydney College is a private, all-male, liberal arts college located in Hampden-Sydney, Va. The college is one of only three institutions of higher education that remains all-male. Established in 1775, it is the oldest school in the south. It is known for its strict honor code, which all freshmen are required to sign. The signing takes place during a ceremony where freshmen students sit silently and wait for their name to be called to sign the document one by one in the company of their peers. The college maintains a student-run justice system as well as a rhetoric program to enhance the speaking and writing ability of attending students. The school offers students a a unique experience to work with the Hampden-Sydney Volunteer Fire Department, which is almost entirely operated by college students, faculty and staff. Hampden-Sydney College competes in the NCAA Division III and the school’s mascot is the Tiger.

name: Hope College
profile: Hope College is a private liberal arts college located in Holland, MI. It was officially chartered in 1866 and is affiliated with the Reformed Church in America. More than 1,000 students come to pray and worship at Hope’s voluntary chapel service three times per week. Academically, Hope offers 91 majors. The school is known as one of the top liberal arts colleges for producing research publications. Hope holds more grants for summer collaborative faculty-student research from the National Science Foundation than any other liberal arts college in the country. Students at Hope have the option to study at off-campus locations in Washington, D.C., Chicago and Philadelphia, in addition to the many overseas locations. Each year, students look forward to "The Pull," a tug-of-war competition between freshman and sophomore classes that originated in 1898. Each class is coached by the grade two years ahead, and a rivalry between odd and even year classes exists as a result. Athletically the Hope Flying Dutch compete at the NCAA DIII level in the Michigan Intercollegiate Athletic Association conference. The college has won 27 of the last 38 All-Sports awards in the MIAA, of which it has been a member since 1926.

name: Worcester Polytechnic Institute
profile: Worcester Polytechnic Institute was founded in 1865 for students interested in pursuing careers in engineering and science. The school is a private research university and provides state-of-the-art research labs for aerospace, computer music, medical imaging and satellite navigation and other fields of research. Classes are project-based, and a co-op program is available to students interested in joining the workforce early. The academic schedule at WPI is divided into four seven-week terms in which students take three classes per term. WPI’s Global Perspective Program allows students to learn in one of 31 project centers on five continents. Naveen Selvadurai, cofounder of Foursquare, graduated from WPI, as did American rocket pioneer Robert H. Goddard and the inventor of stainless steel, Elwood Haynes. The WPI Engineers offer 15 varsity sports teams and compete at the Division III level.

name: SUNY, Binghamton (Binghamton University)
profile: Established in 1946, SUNY, Binghamton is one of the four university centers of the State University of New York system. The university sits on 930 acres, which includes a 190-acre Nature Preserve. Students live in six residential communities, each with a distinct personality; the system is modeled after Oxford University’s housing system. The campus is home to the University Art Museum, which houses more than 3,000 pieces of artwork, the Anderson Center for the Performing Arts, a 1,200-seat theater, and the Innovative Technologies Complex, a science and research space. The university consists of six schools, including the Thomas J. Watson School of Engineering and Applied Science and the College of Community and Public Affairs. SUNY, Binghamton competes in NCAA Division I athletics. Other residents living on campus include a rare species of spotted salamander, and in order to protect its habitat, the university has built ramps on the curbs on campuses to avoid disrupting their migration habits. Prominent alumni include “Maus” creator Art Spiegelman.

name: Wheaton College (Norton)
profile: Wheaton College was originally founded as a women’s seminary in 1834. In 1912, it officially became a four-year liberal arts college and in 1988, the school became coeducational. The most popular majors on campus are psychology, English and economics. Since 2000, Wheaton has produced 3 Rhodes Scholars, 4 Marshals Scholars, 73 Fulbright Scholars, 6 Truman Scholars and 11 Watson Fellows. Nearly every graduate at Wheaton participates in an internship, field experience, co-op, or clinical assignment before graduation. Additionally, over three-quarters of the student population participates in community service or volunteer work annually. Students come from 33 states and 23 countries to study at Wheaton. Each year, Wheaton hosts a Holi festival that is modeled after the Hindu religious festival. School traditions include a mandatory swim in Peacock Pond before graduation and keeping the front door of the chapel exclusive to seniors. The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics and its mascot is the Lyon, a nod to Mary Lyon, an influential woman who advised the Wheaton family at the founding of the seminary and helped establish the curriculum.

name: Miami University, Oxford
profile: Miami University, Oxford is a public research university located in Oxford, OH. The university was established in 1809 and now offers over 100 majors and pre-professional study programs. The China Business Program is a certificate program that combines language study, overseas experience and associated coursework, and it is one of many programs at the university that focuses on global markets. Miami University has approximately 15,000 undergraduate students and 2,500 graduate students on the Oxford campus, with an additional 3,600 undergraduate students on the Hamilton campus, 2,100 undergraduate students on the Middletown campus and 125 graduate students at the Voice of America Learning Center. The university's alumni office celebrates marriages between two Miami alumni by sending out thousands of valentines each year to these "Miami Mergers." In 2009, Miami University held a “merger moment” when 1,087 Miami Merger couples came to the university’s campus to renew their vows. The university competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and its mascot is the RedHawk. Miami University, Oxford is one of four schools to graduate both a U.S. President (Benjamin Harrison, 23rd) and a Super Bowl winning quarterback (Ben Roethlisberger).The university's alumni office celebrates marriages between two Miami alumni by sending out thousands of valentines each year to these "Miami mergers." In 2009, Miami University held a “merger moment” in which 1,087 Miami Merger couples came to the university’s campus to renew their vows. The university competes in NCAA Division I athletics and its mascot is the RedHawk. Miami University, Oxford is one of four schools to graduate both a U.S. President (Benjamin Harrison, 23rd) and a Super Bowl winning quarterback (Ben Roethlisberger).

name: Rutgers University, New Brunswick
profile: Rutgers University is a public research university system in New Jersey. Its flagship campus is spread across five campuses, named Rutgers University, New Brunswick, located chiefly in New Brunswick. Founded as Queen’s College in 1766, Rutgers is the eighth-oldest higher learning institution in the U.S. It is one of the nine “colonial colleges” founded before the American Revolution. The 18 schools and colleges at Rutgers, New Brunswick offer more than 100 undergraduate degrees. The university offers study abroad opportunities in over 30 countries. Students come from all 21 counties in New Jersey, all 50 states and over 125 countries. There are more than 400 student organizations, including over 80 fraternities and sororities and 54 club sports. The New Brunswick campus is the birthplace of college football: Rutgers and Princeton played the first game of intercollegiate football in 1869 — Rutgers won, by the way. Today, Rutgers’ varsity sports teams, known as the Scarlet Knights, compete in NCAA Division I athletics. The school recently moved to the Big Ten Conference. Notable Rutgers alumni include Ford Motor Co. CEO Mark Fields, Nobel Prize-winning economist Milton Friedman and former NBA Commissioner David Stern.

name: Hillsdale College
profile: Hillsdale College is a private, liberal arts college located in rural Michigan about 60 miles from Ann Arbor. Established in 1844, Hillsdale was the first American college to prohibit, in its charter, any discrimination based on race, religion or gender, as well as the second college in the nation to grant four-year liberal arts degrees to women. In 1984, it declined all federal funding in a protest against affirmative action, and the college now receives no federal, state or local funding. Academics at Hillsdale are based in the Judeo-Christian tradition. All students are required to study great books for two semesters in addition to the Western heritage, American heritage and Constitution courses. There are seven Greek houses on campus. Athletically, Hillsdale competes at the Division II level in the Great Lakes Intercollegiate Athletic Conference. The school mascot is the Charger. Notable alumni include Chester Marcol, the famous NFL kicker, Bob Clark, director of "A Christmas Story" and Erik Prince, former Navy SEAL and founder of private security firm Blackwater.

name: Wabash College
profile: Wabash College is a men’s liberal arts college located in Crawfordsville, IN. The school is one of only three all-male colleges left in the U.S. today, although a transition to a coeducational institution has been considered on several occasions. Wabash offers 26 majors and minors as well as pre-professional programs in business, law and medicine. To graduate, men must complete 34 courses and pass two days of written exams and one day of oral exams, known as senior comprehensive exams. Poet Ezra Pound held his first teaching position at this college. The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics. There are 11 varsity sports available to athletes on campus plus 22 intramural and four club sports. Nearly 40% of students are varsity athletes and about three-quarters take part in intramural sports.

name: New College of Florida
profile: Located on 110-acre waterfront campus, the New College of Florida is a small, public, legislatively designated honors college for the liberal arts located in Sarasota, FL. Students choose from over 40 concentrations and explore personal interests through educational, off-campus projects, such as working with manatees or studying abroad for biology projects. The school’s exchange program allow students to study abroad in 190 participating colleges and universities. The NCF has produced 80 Fulbright scholars, including 58 in the last five years. Students form their own clubs and organizations, including a club devoted to yelling and a four-part mixed a capella choir. The John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art is located next to campus, while campus proper sits on the former estate of circus tycoon Charles Ringling.

name: University of Puget Sound
profile: Founded in 1888 in Tacoma, WA, this private liberal arts university now offers over 50 traditional and interdisciplinary programs and 1,200 courses each year. The university recently won a $600,000 Mellon Foundation grant to restructure and expand interdisciplinary classes in the arts, humanities and technology. The Puget Sound Loggers compete in NCAA Division III athletics and are members of the Northwest Conference. “Once a Logger, always a Logger” is a popular campus expression. The university was formerly affiliated with the United Methodist Church. The school colors are maroon, and white and the mascot is “Grizz” the Logger.

name: Elon University
profile: Elon University was founded in 1889, and the institution was renamed in 2001 after more than 100 years as Elon College. Elon is the Hebrew word for "oak." In a nod to the school's name, entering freshmen receive an acorn as a symbol of their promise and potential; graduating seniors receive an oak sapling, signifying their capacity to thrive in future careers. The university is in the midst of a major refurbishment, having recently completed several building projects, which include a neighborhood for 324 upperclassmen to reside, its Alumni Field House and a new athletics facility. Projects currently under development include a new admissions welcome center, a school of communications and “The Global Neighborhood,” a transformative, residential six-building area with international themes. It competes in NCAA Division I, and the school mascot is the Phoenix.

name: Loyola Marymount University
profile: Founded in 1911, Loyola Marymount is a Roman Catholic university located in Los Angeles, CA. LMU offers 60 different majors and 56 minors in its undergraduate program, 41 master’s degrees, two doctorates and 12 credential programs. The Greek system includes 17 national fraternities and sororities, and students participate in 140 clubs and organizations. Schools within LMU include the School of Film and Television, the College of Communication and Fine Arts and the School of Education. Loyola Marymount has three LEED-certified buildings and was one of the first campuses in California to recycle 100% green waste. Athletic teams compete in NCAA Division I. In the past 10 years, the university has seen 19 Fulbright scholars, two Nobel Prize winners and one Pulitzer Prize award-winner.

name: Transylvania University
profile: Transylvania University is located in Lexington, KY. This private liberal arts college was founded in 1780 and is the 16th oldest college in the country; it is known to be the first college established west of the Allegheny Mountains. It is affiliated with the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ). Transylvania has 39 majors and offers students the opportunity to design their own major. Some 90% of graduates recommended for medical school are accepted, and 100% of students recommended for law school are accepted. Nearly 70% of Transylvania students study abroad, including during the optional May term. Popular locations include Argentina, China, England, France, as well as domestic locations like New York City, Chicago and Las Vegas. "Transylvania,” which means “across the woods,” is an accurate description of its location when it was first settled by pioneers, led by Daniel Boone, in 1770. The white ash tree located near the library is known as the “Kissing Tree.” This tree’s name is significant because it was named at a time when public displays of affection were extremely uncommon. The school competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and its mascot is the Pioneer.

name: University of New Hampshire
profile: Founded in 1866 as the New Hampshire College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts, the university was an early land-grant institution established to serve the sons and daughters of farming and laboring families. Today, it also supports exploration of the ocean and outer space as a sea-grant and space-grant university. UNH offers over 100 majors to its undergraduate students; the most popular bachelors programs include business administration, psychology and English. The school’s Space Science Center has supplied instruments to 23 space missions; two alumni are NASA astronauts. Just over half of undergraduates call New Hampshire their home state, with an additional 24% from Massachusetts. UNH competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is the Wildcat. The hockey team has an odd tradition that dates back to the 1970s: when the first goal is scored at a home men’s ice hockey game, a designated fan throws a fish onto the ice.

name: University of South Carolina, Columbia
profile: A public research university that was founded in 1801 and today offers 324 unique degree programs. It is the flagship school of the University of South Carolina system. Within the last five years faculty have filed 354 invention disclosures. The school became 100% tobacco-free on Jan. 1. Outdoor recreation is especially popular at this southern school, with the school providing adventure trips, biking, challenge courses, climbing walls, tennis courts, gardens and paddle sports for students. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the mascot is Cocky the Fighting Gamecock. The school is known for its lux tailgating area, the Cockaboose Railroad, a row of 22 cabooses lining a railroad track outside of Williams-Brice Stadium that each contains a well-appointed living room with running water, cable television, air conditioning and heating. Before the Clemson-USC football game, engineering students build a three-story model of Clemson’s mascot for the annual Tiger Burn ceremony.

name: University of Portland
profile: Founded in 1901, this Catholic university was originally named Columbia University, after the nearby river, and was given its current name in the 1930s. The university is affiliated with the Congregation of Holy Cross and has six colleges and schools, including the Dr. Robert B. Pamplin Jr. School of Business Administration and the Donald P. Shiley School of Engineering. A landmark building on campus is the Bell Tower, a 100-foot structure that rings its 14 bells daily. UP’s athletes participate in NCAA Division I and the West Coast Conference. The nickname is the Pilots, and the school colors are purple and white.

name: James Madison University
profile: James Madison University is a public university located in Harrisonburg, VA. Founded in 1908, JMU was originally a women’s college before becoming a teacher’s college and then a major coeducational university. JMU offers 71 undergraduate degrees, 34 master’s degrees and doctoral and educational specialist programs. JMU has been in expansion mode in the last 20 years, nearly doubling its size. Today the university has 148 buildings on campus, 34 of which are student residences. Students participate in more than 350 groups and clubs. The university has been led by only six presidents; the current president, Jonathan R. Alger, started in 2012. The university’s colors – purple and gold – can be traced to the colors used by the school’s two literary societies in 1909. JMU competes in the NCAA Division I, and the mascot is Duke Dog. Last year, the Dukes won their first NCAA basketball tournament game in 30 years.

name: Saint Anselm College
profile: Saint Anselm College in Manchester, NH, founded in 1889, is one of the oldest Catholic colleges in the U.S. The college continues to have a fully functioning and independent Benedictine abbey attached to it, Saint Anselm Abbey. The school recently redesigned its academic core for the fall 2014 semester, emphasizing humanities, writing intensives, moral inquiry and imaginative thinking. Saint Anselm College offers 44 majors and 22 minors. Playing an important role in the New Hampshire’s “first in the nation” primary during the presidential election season, Saint Anselm has attracted many future presidents, candidates and supporters to campus. Many students get involved in the process as interns and runners for the campaigns. Every year, the school hosts a Gingerbread House Building Competition. It competes in NCAA Division II athletics, and the school mascot is the Hawk.

name: Louisiana State University
profile: Established in 1853, Louisiana State University is located in Baton Rouge, LA. Today, the school has 15 colleges, including its nationally recognized School of the Coast and Environment and School of Veterinary Medicine. It is one of the only higher education institutions in the country where students can study Cajun French. LSU’s total federal funding from agencies such as the National Science Foundation, National Institutes of Health and the Department of Homeland Security has increased more than $90 million over the last few years. This year, LSU hosted its inaugural Discover Day when over 130 students from 12 colleges staged performances and presented research projects to an audience of students, faculty, staff and visitors. Pelican Promise is LSU’s aid program that provides a financial safety net for the university’s students who live below 150% of the poverty level. LSU competes in NCAA Division I athletics as the Tigers.

name: Saint Louis University
profile: Saint Louis University is a private research university located in St. Louis, MO. It was established in 1818 and is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church in the Jesuit tradition. The university was the first institution of higher learning west of the Mississippi. SLU’s approximately 100 undergraduate programs integrate service and academics. Keeping true to its mission of service, SLU is a catalyst for urban renewal, investing more than $850 million in campus development. Many students choose to enroll in SLU’s Year of Service program after graduation where they are placed with organizations like Americorps, Teach for America and Jesuit Volunteer Corps to provide one to two years of service before entering the workforce. The university competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is the Billiken. Tradition states that rubbing the belly of the bronze statue of the Billiken is good luck, especially before an exam.

name: University of Iowa
profile: Located in Iowa City, the public research university offers over 200 majors, minors and certificate programs through 13 colleges and academic units. Forty-two percent of undergraduates are involved in research. The university has top-ranked writing programs in fiction, poetry and nonfiction, and its medical school and associated hospital are among the best in the nation. The most popular areas of study are business, engineering, biology, psychology and English. In 1933 UI became the first school to broadcast educational television. It was also the first school to officially recognize a gay student organization in 1970. The University of Iowa competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is Herky the Hawk. Riverfest is a student -run weekend concert festival that occurs in the spring.

name: Ursinus College
profile: A private liberal arts college in Collegeville, PA. Established in 1869, the college is named after Zacharias Baer, a 16th century German theologian who changed his last name to Ursinus at age 16. Ursinus’ 170-acre campus is approximately 25 miles from Philadelphia. Students hail from 35 states and 12 countries and can select from more than 60 majors at Ursinus. There are over 100 student clubs and organizations on campus. Since 2000, all students and faculty members are issued laptops as part of the school’s laptop initiative. The Center for Science and the Common Good allows students to explore the intersection of science and the humanities. The Berman Museum of Art, which sees over 30,000 visitors each year, is home to more than 4,000 paintings, prints, drawings and other objects. Ursinus has a reputation for students getting married to one another at an above-average rate. The school’s varsity athletics teams compete in the Centennial Conference (NCAA Division III) and are known as the Bears. J.D. Salinger, who left after one semester in 1938, is perhaps the college’s most famous attendee.

name: College of the Ozarks
profile: College of the Ozarks was established in 1906 and is related by covenant to the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.). Known for its debt-free education, the school charges no tuition for full-time students. Around 70% of the college’s revenue is derived from gift income and earnings from endowment. To defray the cost of tuition, all students work 15 hours each week at one of 80 campus work sites, including a dairy farm, grist mill and a student-run hotel and restaurant. Through the college’s Patriotic Education Travel Program, a number of students have accompanied veterans to historic battle sites in France, Hawaii, Okinawa and Iwo Jima, among others, since the program began in 2009. The school has hosted a number of important visitors, including former Pres. George W. Bush, former Gov. Sarah Palin and former Prime Minister of Great Britain Margaret Thatcher. The college participates in NAIA athletics, and the school mascots are the Bobcats and the Lady Bobcats. It is located near Branson, MO, unofficially nicknamed "Vegas without the gambling."

name: Baylor University
profile: Baylor University prides itself on being the largest Baptist University in the world as well as the oldest continually operating institution of higher learning in Texas. There are 141 baccalaureate programs in 11 colleges, and the College of Arts and Sciences alone offers over 5,000 courses, as well as internships, international scholarships and study abroad opportunities. Since 1993, 35 Baylor students have become Fulbright Scholars. Competing in the NCAA Division I, Big 12 Conference, the Baylor Bears have 17 varsity sports teams. Baylor is credited with celebrating the first university homecoming, an event which has been held annually for over a century.

name: Bentley University
profile: Founded in 1917 as a school of accounting and finance in Waltham, Mass., Bentley University now provides a four-year private business education with Bachelor of Science degrees in 11 business fields and Bachelor of Arts degrees in five arts and science disciplines. Bentley prides itself on a fusion of liberal arts and business; many undergraduates double major in business. The school competes in NCAA Division II, with 23 men’s and women’s varsity sports teams. The Bentley women’s basketball team won the NCAA Division II National Championship this year. Bentley boasts over 100 student organizations, including theater groups, a radio station and a TV broadcasting station. On the night before finals begin, faculty and staff serve food to the students from 11:00 p.m. to 1:00 a.m. at the popular “Breakfast by Moonlight” event.

name: Southwestern University
profile: Southwestern University is a private liberal arts college in Georgetown, TX. With roots dating back to 1835, the university remains affiliated with the United Methodist Church. Southwestern’s 26 academic departments offer 40 majors and 36 minors. Students are encouraged to explore clusters of connected interdisciplinary courses, an approach the university terms Paideia. Nearly 90% of Southwestern students come from Texas and over 75% of students live in residential campus housing. There are approximately 100 student organizations on the university’s 701-acre campus The university signed an agreement with the city of Georgetown to get all of its energy from wind power over the next 18 years, making it one of the few universities with an entirely “green” power source. Southwestern’s student athletes compete in the Southern Collegiate Athletic Conference (SCAC) at the NCAA Division III. Teams are known as the Pirates.

name: University of Pittsburgh
profile: Founded in 1787, the university is composed of a main, 132-acre campus in Oakland, and regional campuses in Bradford, Greensburg, Johnstown and Titusville, PA. The university offers over 470 degree programs in its 16 undergraduate, graduate and professional schools. Research is conducted in more than 300 centers, clinics, laboratories and institutes. The top-ranked University of Pittsburgh Medical Center is affiliated with Pitt’s schools of health and medicine and operates more than 22 academic, community and specialty hospitals. Pitt athletes compete in NCAA Division I. The school colors are blue and gold, and the mascot is the panther. Featured Pitt study abroad programs include International Marketing in Ecuador, Cuban Social Policy Issues in Cuba and Monsters, Madmen, and the Modern City in Prague. In 1955, Pitt researchers developed the first polio vaccine. Prominent alumni include Oscar-winning actor Gene Kelly, Pulitzer Prize-winning author Michael Chabon and Nobel Prize winner and discoverer of cortisone, Philip Hench.

name: Manhattan College
profile: Manhattan College is a private college located in Riverdale, NY. It was established in 1853 and is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church in the Lasallian tradition. Despite the school’s name, its campus is actually located in the Bronx, across the street from New York City’s fourth largest park, Van Cortlandt Park. The school is one of 182 remaining colleges that were founded before the Civil War. Manhattan College is one of 283 institutions in the U.S. with a Phi Beta Kappa chapter, the nation’s oldest and most widely known academic honor society. Manhattan College has 3,600 students – 3,200 undergraduate. Its freshman-to-sophomore full-time retention rate is 83%. About 300 students intern each year at local organizations and businesses such as New York Mets, PricewaterhouseCoopers and Goldman Sachs. Manhattan competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school’s mascot is the Jaspers.

name: University of Wyoming
profile: A public research university in Laramie, the school first opened its doors to a class of 42 students in 1887. Today, students hail from all 50 states and over 90 countries around the globe. The university’s 8 colleges offer students approximately 190 areas of study. There are more than 200 student organizations on campus. The University of Wyoming Art Museum features more than 8,000 objects, and the school’s Geological Museum includes a 75-foot Brontosaurus skeleton. The University of Wyoming’s school colors date back to an 1895 alumni banquet. Attendees were so enamored with the decorative Brown-Eyed Susans that they chose brown and gold as the official school colors. Student-athletes compete in the Mountain West Conference at the NCAA Division I level. Varsity athletic teams are known as the Wyoming Cowboys and Cowgirls. Notable alumni include former Vice President Dick Cheney, head of Coca-Cola’s Greater China and Korea Business Unit David Brooks and late Los Angeles Lakers majority owner Jerry Buss.

name: Gustavus Adolphus College
profile: Gustavus Adolphus College is a liberal arts college in Saint Peter, MN. Retaining its Swedish and Lutheran heritage, it was founded in 1862 and is affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America. The school offers daily Sabbath services and 12 student-run religious organizations. This October marks the 50th anniversary of the Nobel Conference, welcoming Nobel Laureates, scientists, theologians, and other luminaries on campus for a series of talks. Nearly 40% of students choose to participate in GAC’s fine arts program. There are five choral ensembles, two wind orchestras, one symphony and one chamber orchestra, two jazz ensembles and numerous instrumental and chamber ensembles. Students of GAC are dubbed “Gusties.” Every winter Gusties bravely go “traying” where they take cafeteria trays and sled down the steep hills around campus. GAC is a NCAA Division III participant. In March the athletic department announced that it would discontinue its men’s and women’s Nordic skiing team.

name: University of Oklahoma, Norman
profile: Founded in 1890, this public research university is composed of 20 colleges that offer more than 150 majors at the undergraduate level, 160 master’s degrees, and 80 degrees at the doctoral and doctoral professional level. The OU Health Sciences Center is a satellite campus in Oklahoma City. The university competes in NCAA Division I athletics, with particular success over the years in football, and its teams are known as the Sooners, in reference to the pioneering settlers who rushed into the state before the official start of the government-sanctioned Land Run of 1889. The Pride of Oklahoma is the 300-member school marching band, which has its origins in an early 1900s OU pep band. The Sooner Schooner is a covered wagon driven by two ponies that crosses the football field before games.

name: Samford University
profile: Samford University is a private university in Birmingham, AL. It was founded in 1841 as Howard College. Samford offers nearly 150 undergraduate majors, minors and concentrations. The school’s recently created College of Health Sciences continues its history of preparing students for healthcare careers. While upperclassmen can petition to live elsewhere, all non-commuting students under the age of 21 must live on-campus. Students looking to get involved can take part in one of the 125 student organizations and clubs on campus, including 14 fraternities and sororities. There are many traditions at Samford, including the Lighting of the Way ceremony, when the community takes part in caroling and the lighting of the campus tree, and Spring Fling, a week of picnics, paintball and a free concert. Student-athletes compete in the Southern Conference at the NCAA Division I level. Teams are known as the Samford Bulldogs. More than 40% of students participate in intramural sports.

name: Auburn University
profile: Founded in 1856 as the East Alabama Male College, Auburn University is now a co-educational, public research institution. Auburn, a small town of about 40,000, is located about four hours from the Florida coastline. The university offers over 140 formal majors, housed in 12 colleges. Students can choose to participate in over 300 clubs and organizations. Known for their friendliness, students annually dedicate an entire day – “Hey Day” – to saying “hey” to each other. During Tiger Walk, a tradition since the early 1960s, thousands of Auburn fans line Donahue Drive two hours before each home game to cheer on the football players as they march towards the stadium. Notable alumni include actress Octavia Spencer, several NFL and NBA players, as well as Rowdy Gaines, an Olympic gold medalist.The Auburn Tigers have been nationally recognized for their athletics, winning the 2013 Southeastern Conference football championship, eight men’s swimming and diving championships, and five women’s swimming and diving championships. Auburn competes in the NCAA Division I-A, and the school mascot is Aubie the Tiger.

name: Carroll College
profile: Carroll College is a private, Catholic liberal arts college located in Montana’s capital city, Helena. About half of Carroll enrollees are Montana residents. Carroll students are required to take core curriculum classes consisting of five foundational courses. Flagship programs include biology, civil engineering, nursing, and mathematics. Carroll pre-med students consistently post an 85% acceptance rate to medical and dental schools. Over the years, Carroll undergraduates have discovered more than 10 new species. The Talking Saints forensics team has won Northwest Championships for the past 24 years.The school’s athletic teams, nicknamed the Fighting Saints, compete in NAIA athletics.

name: The Catholic University of America
profile: Catholic University of America is a private university founded in 1887 by U.S. Catholic Bishops with the support of Pope Leo XIII, and it is the U.S. national university of the Catholic Church. To date, it’s the only institution of higher education founded by the U.S. Catholic bishops. Today, 80% of undergraduates and 59% of graduates are Catholic. The university has 13 schools and 21 research facilities. The Campus Ministry Office offers campus RENEW groups and numerous student-run retreats throughout the academic year that allow students of all religions to explore their faith. Students often volunteer with organizations such as the Little Sisters of the Poor, Habitat for Humanity, and St. Ann’s Infant and Maternity Home. Campus Ministry is responsible for overseeing fellowship provided to students to maintain their Catholic faith. Students, faculty and staff are invited to sign the Community Pledge to manifest their faith to the Church’s teaching. There are three research centers at CUA: Vitreous State Laboratory, Institute for Policy Research & Catholic Studies and John Paul II Institute for Studies on Marriage and Family. The sports teams are called the Cardinals and they compete in the NCAA's Division III.

name: Saint Mary's College of Maryland
profile: Saint Mary’s College of Maryland is a non-religious, Public Honors College that opened its doors in 1840. The school was originally legislated as a girls’ boarding school. SMC offers 31 academic programs with 23 majors and 26 minors. Sixty-nine percent of SMC students choose to major or minor in a second academic discipline. The most popular degree programs are biology, economics, English, political science and psychology. With such close proximity to the nation’s capital, SMC students have the opportunity to participate in The Washington Program, a summer political science program where students enroll in a week-long foundation course, complete an internship at places like Capitol Hill, Federal Government and Think Tanks and are then matched with alumni mentors in their assigned internship to evaluate their experience. More than half of the 2012 graduating class chose to study abroad in one of SMC’s 27 programs. This waterfront school grants students free daily access to kayaks, stand-up paddleboards, windsurfing equipment and FJ sailboats for their own recreational use. Many students can also be found gathered around SMC’s abundant fire pits, outdoor fireplaces and grills outside residence halls. Saint Mary’s has 17 Division III athletic teams. SMC consistently has one of the highest percentages of student-athletes on CAC’s All-Academic team.

name: Marquette University
profile: Marquette University, a Catholic and Jesuit university, is located in Milwaukee, WI. It opened in 1881.The university had nearly 8,300 undergraduate students and an additional 3,400 graduate students enrolled for fall 2012. Nearly three-quarters of students are from out-of-state. Marquette University offers around 78 academic majors, 77 minors and pre-professional programs in dentistry, law and medicine. Marquette is home to 17,000 cubic feet of archival material, with over 11,000 volumes including a number of J.R.R Tolkien’s original manuscripts. Marquette University competes in the NCAA Division I and the school mascot is the Golden Eagle.

name: Northeastern University
profile: Located in Boston, MA, Northeastern University’s nine colleges and schools offer a wide selection of bachelor’s to doctoral degrees. The institution is best known for its co-op program, where students alternate two semesters of full-time study with semesters of full-time employment in four or five-year programs. Students in this program typically gain up to 18 months of real work experience. Co-op positions are offered in 69 countries—including the Dominican Republic, Belize, South Africa, even Antarctica — and the study abroad office boasts 60 traditional programs in 43 countries, such as Japan or England. Northeastern’s International Business Program affords students the opportunity to gain a dual-degree in a sister school in Europe or Mexico. The N.U.in Program allows first-year students to spend their first semester studying abroad in Australia, Greece, England or Ireland. Notable attendees include the founder of Napster, Shawn Fanning, and Biz Stone, cofounder of Twitter. Northeastern University competes in NCAA Division I athletics.

name: Wittenberg University
profile: Wittenberg University is a coeducational, private liberal arts university located in Springfield, OH. It was established in 1845 by a group of Evangelical Lutheran pastors to train church clergy. With a nearly $90 million endowment, today the school has grown to offer more than 60 majors and minors to around 2,000 students. Wittenberg offers cooperative programs with other U.S. colleges. Engineering students can participate in the 3-2 program, which allows students to study three years at Wittenberg followed by two years of study at Case Western Reserve University or Columbia University. Nursing and occupational therapy have similar programs with Case Western and Washington University, respectively. The school also partners with Duke University for degrees in marine biology and forestry and environmental studies. There are over 120 student organizations and clubs as well as a vibrant Greek life system. Its 23 athletic teams compete in NCAA Division III in the North Coast Athletic Conference.

name: United States Merchant Marine Academy
profile: Located in Kings Point, Long Island, the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy is a federal service academy that was founded in 1943. It was the first of the five service academies to admit women, which they started in 1974. The campus is composed of more than 80 acres and is home to 28 buildings and over 100 vessels. It is the only institution with permission to carry a battle standard in its color guard because the school’s midshipmen have served in every major foreign conflict the U.S. has engaged in since World War II. Student clubs include Regimental Marching Band, Sailing Squadron, and Debate Council.Graduates have gone on to become astronauts, CEOs, admirals and more. The campus is home to the American Merchant Marine Museum, which includes the National Maritime Hall of Fame. The Mariners athletic teams play in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: University of Dallas
profile: Founded in 1956 and affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church, the University of Dallas is located in Irving, TX. It is one of 16 Catholic universities in the nation to earn a Phi Beta Kappa chapter. There is a core curriculum of approximately 20 classes that students are required to complete over the course of two years. The University of Dallas hosts the Constantin College of Liberal Arts, the College of Business, the School of Ministry and the Braniff Graduate School of Liberal Arts. Its Center for Cybersecurity Education is one of just seven programs of its kind worldwide.The university has one of the largest study abroad programs in the country. Thirty-six students have been named Fulbright scholars over the school’s 55-year history. The university competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and the school mascot is the Crusader.

name: University of Tulsa
profile: Founded in 1894 by the Presbyterian Church, the university now offers over 60 undergraduate programs in three undergraduate colleges, including schools for arts and sciences, engineering, and business. One in 10 students admitted are National Merit Scholars, and TU students have won numerous scholarships and awards, including 57 Goldwater Scholarships, 11 Truman scholarships, 15 Fulbright grants, and two Rhodes scholarships. TU students compete in Division I of the NCAA with 18 varsity sports teams. Tulsa has won six national championships, including four in women’s golf and two in men’s basketball. Their nickname is the “Golden Hurricane.” At the university, one of the oldest traditions is the “Ringing of the Bell,” in which graduating seniors ring the Cupola bell after finishing their last exam.

name: University of San Francisco
profile: A private Jesuit-affiliated university founded in 1855, USF consists of five schools: the College of Arts and Sciences, the School of Education, the School of Law, the School of Management, and the School of Nursing and Health Professions. USF has an “extended classroom” program that works to find internships for its student body throughout San Francisco and Silicon Valley. The school competes in NCAA Division I-AAA athletics and the school mascot is Don, a Spanish Knight.

name: CUNY, City College
profile: City College of New York was created in 1847 as the Free Academy of the City of New York, and it is the oldest member of City University of New York system. Its campus is set in Upper Manhattan. Although highly reputed for its STEM education, undergraduates can select from majors as varied as sonic arts, bilingual childhood education and business. Nine City College alumni are Nobel laureates, which is the most from any public college in the country. The college includes The Grove School of Engineering and the Bernard and Anne Spitzer School of Architecture, which are the only public institutions of those fields in New York City. Through a unique five-year BS/MD program and 28-month Physician Assistant program, the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education aims to increase minority involvement in the medicine profession while helping medically neglected communities. The school’s sports teams compete in NCAA Division I, City University of New York Athletic Conference and Eastern College Athletic Conference.

name: Texas Christian University
profile: Texas Christian University was established in 1873 and is affiliated with the Christian Church. There are 130 undergraduate programs, 61 master’s degree programs and 24 doctoral study programs. Last year, the Rees- Jones Foundation gave the university a $20 million gift for the TCU Institute of Child Development, which works with children who have social, behavioral and emotional problems. Since 1973, graduate and undergraduate students have managed an Educational Investment Fund of more than $1 million in assets, which allows students to experience investing and portfolio management.The bronze frog statue located at the heart of campus was constructed in 1984 by Seppo Aarnos, an internationally known sculptor and parent of two TCU alumni; students rub the frog’s nose for good luck before exams.Texas Christian University competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is the Horned Frog.

name: Saint John's University (MN)
profile: Saint John's University in Collegeville, MN, works in conjunction with the College of Saint Benedict to provide Catholic higher education for the Minnesota area. This all-male college was established in 1857 and is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. Nearly 20% of graduates go directly to graduate school and 80% find career-related positions or enter service work upon graduating. The university offers degrees in fine arts, humanities, natural science, social science and interdisciplinary and pre-professional programs. It is also home to the famous Saint John’s Bible. Saint John’s University competes in Division III athletics. Former head football coach John Gagliardi has the most wins in all of college football; he was also the first active coach to be inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame.

name: University of California, Santa Cruz
profile: Founded in 1965, University of California, Santa Cruz only issued narrative evaluations of students. In 2001, it introduced a hybrid system including letter grades for the first time. Although the school is well-known for its science programs, the most popular undergrad degrees are psychology, business management, economics and literature. The school's Academic Excellence program has been awarded for fostering peer-to-peer mentorship opportunities for STEM students. UCSC implemented the first computer game design major in the UC system. UCSC’s organic farm and garden program is one of the oldest such initiatives at a U.S. university. The campus’ McHenry Library is home to an archive of recordings by the Grateful Dead. The school competes in NCAA Division III athletics and the mascot is the Banana Slug, a yellow mollusk that resides in the university’s redwood forest.

name: Saint Mary's College of California
profile: Saint Mary’s College of California is a private college located in Moraga, CA. It was established in 1863 and is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church in the tradition of the De La Salle Christian Brothers. Saint Mary’s was originally a school for men, and remained that way until 1970. By 2013, around 60% of students were women. The Collegiate Seminar is the foundation of the college’s core curriculum and consists of four courses that explore major works of Western civilization. January Term is a unique academic session in which students travel abroad or take only one class, which is encouraged to be outside of their major. De La Salle Week is a week-long event that includes activities like a 5k run, a campus BBQ, service opportunities, meditation retreats and prominent speakers. St. Mary’s College of California competes in NCAA Division I athletics.

name: Calvin College
profile: Founded in 1876, Calvin College is a small-size private liberal arts college located in Grand Rapids, MI. Named after John Calvin, the college is affiliated with the Christian Reformed Church. The College established a core curriculum with three parts: Gateway, Competencies and Studies, and Capstone. Students are generally required to take 45 hours of core courses during their time at Calvin. The College’s Speech Pathology and Audiology Program offers a five-year Bachelor’s to Master’s degree; students practice their skills in clinical settings such as the college’s adult-neuroscience and pediatric clinics. There are 5 chapel themes to guide weekly worship. The McGregor Fellowship Program, established in 1998 with a grant from the Detroit-based McGregor Fund, sponsors collaborative student-faculty summer research in the arts, humanities, and social sciences. The Calvin Knights compete in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: Stonehill College
profile: Stonehill College is a private, Catholic liberal arts college in Easton, MA. It was founded in 1948 by the Congregation of the Holy Cross. Students can take advantage of Stonehill’s small New England town atmosphere, though the college is a short bus or car ride from Boston and Providence. The college offers over 80 majors, minors and programs, the most popular of which include biology, psychology, education, communication, and criminology. There are over 70 student organizations on campus and around 40% of Class of 2013 students spent at least one semester studying or interning abroad. Stonehill students can select from over 200 affiliate programs in 35 countries. The college’s varsity athletic teams, known as the Skyhawks, compete in the Northeast-10 Conference at the Division II level.

name: University of Massachusetts, Amherst
profile: The flagship of the public University of Massachusetts system offers 110 bachelor’s programs, 74 master’s and 47 doctoral programs. Students have the opportunity to take classes at nearby Amherst, Hampshire, Mount Holyoke and Smith Colleges using the free Five College bus system. This year, the Board of Trustees approved a freeze on tuition and mandatory fees for in-state undergraduates. The university is one of just 16 in the U.S. to receive a gold rating for its sustainability practices from the Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education. The athletic teams compete in NCAA Division I and the Atlantic 10 in maroon and white as the Minutemen. The school motto is “By the sword we seek peace; but peace only under liberty.”

name: University of San Diego
profile: The University of San Diego is a private, Roman Catholic university that was established in 1949 and is characterized by unique 16th century Spanish Renaissance architecture overlooking the Pacific Ocean. It offers 42 bachelor’s degrees with a variety of concentrations and 50 minors. The USD Changemaker Fest is a weeklong, campus-wide celebration that promotes entrepreneurship, collaboration and innovation for positive social change. A student-run electronics waste collection center, the first of its kind on a college campus, was recently opened. The school has 17 NCAA Division I teams and 23 sports clubs. They mainly compete in the West Coast Conference and their mascot is the Torero. Fans chant, “olé, olé, olé, olé!” at sporting events.

name: Rollins College
profile: Rollins College is a private liberal arts college in Winter Park, FL. It is the oldest recognized college in Florida. Rollins offers over 60 programs of study. Undergraduate students can select from a traditional, full-time, residential liberal arts program or an evening bachelor’s program geared toward working adults. The 70-acre campus, with its Spanish-Mediterranean architecture, is located in the shores of Lake Virginia, near Orlando. One of the most unique features on the campus is the Walk of Fame, a walkway featuring stones gathered from the birthplaces and homes of notable men and women. The Walk now contains over 500 stones, including those associated with George Washington, Ralph Waldo Emerson and Jackie Robinson. Each year, students enjoy the annual Fox Day, a surprise day off when it is deemed too nice to have class. Most of the school’s 22 varsity athletic teams compete in the Sunshine State Conference (NCAA Division II). Rollins’ most famous recent graduate is Elin Nordegren, whose 2014 commencement speech made headlines.

name: Allegheny College
profile: Founded in 1815, Allegheny College is historically affiliated with the United Methodist Church.The college feels so passionate about their liberal arts curriculum that they require students to complete both a major and a minor in separate academic fields and a senior comprehensive research project. Allegheny sponsors a wide variety of study abroad programs and three-week experiential learning trips, including options in Argentina, Australia, China, Costa Rica, Ecuador, India, and Kenya. In 2013, Allegheny’s student newspaper, The Campus, won a first place Student Keystone Award from the Pennsylvania Newspaper Association. Surrounded by beautiful Pennsylvanian mountains, lakes, and streams, Allegheny has one of the oldest Outing Clubs in the country. Approximately 30% of the Allegheny student body participates in Greek life, with nine nationally affiliated fraternities and sororities. The school has welcomed a wide range of speakers in the past, including Dick Cheney, Adam Sandler, Bill Clinton, and John Updike.

name: Florida State University
profile: Florida State University is a public research university located in Tallahassee, FL. It was established in 1851 and now has 16 colleges which offer more than 275 undergraduate, graduate, doctoral, professional and specialist degree programs, including medicine and law. Florida State is responsible for governance of the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art and associated arts programs, one of the largest museum/university complexes in the nation. The university is home to some of the most powerful magnets in the country at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory, and is the birthplace of the anti-cancer drug Taxol. Florida State sends over 1,600 students per year to study abroad at their study centers in London, Florence, Valencia and Panama City and several other exotic locations where they have affiliations. Greek life has a large presence on FSU’s campus with about 56 fraternities and sororities on campus. One of FUS’s outstanding alumni includes Sara Blakely, who is one of the world’s youngest female self-made billionaires.The FSU Seminoles are a Division I school that competes in the Atlantic Coast Conference. Their men’s baseball, football and track and field organizations are among the most successful teams throughout the school’s history.

name: Saint Joseph's University
profile: Saint Joseph's University in Philadelphia, PA., was founded in 1851, and to this day remains one of only 28 institutions of the Association of Jesuit Colleges and Universities. The university offers over 50 undergraduate majors as well as joint degree programs with Thomas Jefferson University in bioscience technologies, nursing, radiologic sciences, occupational therapy and physical therapy. The university boasts the country’s second-oldest center or institute dedicated to Catholic-Jewish relations. Saint Joseph’s University competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is the Hawk.

name: Emerson College
profile: Emerson College, established in 1880, is named after founding president, Charles Wesley Emerson, an orator, preacher and teacher. Located in Boston, MA, Emerson College has become the only comprehensive college or university in the U.S. that is exclusively focused on communications and the arts in a liberal arts school structure. The institution owns a 14th century castle called Kasteel Well in the Netherlands, reserved for students who study abroad or take internships in Europe. In March of 2012, Emerson recently opened its new facility in Los Angeles to house a program that focuses on the entertainment industry. Alumni include talk show host Jay Leno and author of Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter, Seth Grahame-Smith. Emerson competes in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: University of Saint Thomas
profile: The University of Saint Thomas was founded in 1885 and is affiliated with the Catholic Church. The university has been coeducational since 1977. Currently there are 90 undergraduate majors and 60 minors for students to pursue, as well as 60 graduate degrees in 12 subject areas. The university encourages study abroad; more than 1,000 members of the student body partake in 130 different programs in over 40 countries. Student athletes compete in the Minnesota Intercollegiate Athletic Conference and NCAA Division III. The University of Saint Thomas teams are known as the Tommies.

name: University of Missouri, Columbia
profile: Founded in 1839, it was the first public university west of the Mississippi River and the first state university in Thomas Jefferson’s Louisiana Purchase territory. Today, Mizzou, as it’s called, is comprised of 19 schools and colleges offering more than 300 degree and certificate programs, including 70 online options. In addition to law, medical and veterinary programs, it boasts a nuclear research reactor. More than 1,200 students participate in study abroad programs in 58 countries. The 1,262-acre campus is designated a botanic garden, with more than 42,000 plants and trees. A row of six Ionic columns is the traditional symbol of the university; they once supported a 1840s structure called Academic Hall which was later destroyed by a fire. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics; the school mascot is Truman the Tiger, named in honor of President Harry S. Truman, a Missouri native.

name: Whitworth University
profile: Founded in 1890, Whitworth University is a liberal arts university affiliated with the Presbyterian Church located in Spokane, WA. In March 2013, the university was deemed by the President’s Higher Education Community Service Honor Roll as one of the top schools in America for its commitment to community service. It is the highest federal recognition possible for a school to earn for its service-learning and civic engagement. Whitworth also won this award in 2006, 2008, 2010 and 2012. Nearly every student on campus receives some form of financial aid during their undergraduate studies. Housing on campus offers 23 unique, themed houses where like-minded students live together. The themes range from the Coffee House, where occupants strive to maintain their Christian values while offering a place where anyone can come have coffee, to the Open Conversations house, where students provide a safe place to discuss controversial subjects. The Whitworth University Pirates compete in NCAA Division III with 18 teams in the Northwest Conference.

name: George Mason University
profile: Initially a branch of the University of Virginia, George Mason University became its own institution in 1972 and has since become one of the largest universities in Virginia. GMU is split into multiple campuses surrounding the suburban Washington, D.C. area, with its prime location in Fairfax, VA. The George Mason forensics program and debate team are consistently ranked among the top teams in the nation. Two George Mason faculty members have won the Nobel Prize in economics, and alumni include former heads of both the U.S. Treasury and the SEC. The George Mason statue is associated with many GMU traditions: students rub the statue’s toe for good luck on final exams, and student organizations decorate it to promote events. Fenwick Library is currently undergoing renovations to provide students with a more technologically advanced facility, including an installment of a naturally irrigated rooftop garden. Expected completion date is 2015. George Mason University competes in NCAA Division I.

name: Clarkson University
profile: Located in Potsdam, NY, and founded in 1896, the university was named for New York entrepreneur and businessman, Thomas S. Clarkson. Today, the university still values entrepreneurship through programs in the Shipley Center for Innovation, where students have the opportunity to commercialize their own ideas. The Reh Center for Entrepreneurship, part of the School of Business at Clarkson, allows students to work with local entrepreneurs.
