In addition, the Young Entrepreneurs and Innovators Program allows high school and college entrepreneurs to compete for the opportunity to exchange partial equity in their firm for tuition to Clarkson. At Clarkson, students are granted bachelor’s of science, bachelor’s of Professional Studies, MBA, M.S., MEng, Ph.D, and DPT degrees. On campus, there are more than 100 clubs, more than 200 intramural teams and 16 competitive design teams. Today, there are some 40,000 living Clarkson University alumni, including computer scientist Paul Horn, who initiated IBM’s Watson computer project.

name: Fairfield University
profile: Fairfield University is located in Fairfield, CT, and is a Jesuit school. It was established in 1942 and graduated its first class of women in 1972. The undergraduate school offers 41 majors, 16 interdisciplinary minors and 40 advanced degrees at the graduate level. The university has chosen “water” to be its university theme for a campus wide initiative from 2014-2016. During these years, Fairfield will offer water-focused courses and extra-curricular activities, host lectures, performances and exhibitions related to the theme of water and the faculty will be doing water-based research in order to aid in this two-year exploration. The school has a chapter of the academic honor society Phi Beta Kappa and over 60 Fairfield graduating seniors have won Fulbright Awards. The school maintains a 15,000-square-foot media center, which has a 32-foot television production satellite uplink truck. More than 400 students participate in intercollegiate, varsity athletics. Fairfield’s sports teams—known as the Stags—compete in NCAA Division I athletics. The men's and women’s basketball teams play in the 9,500-seat state-of-the-art Arena at Harbor Yard.

name: University of Oregon
profile: The University of Oregon was established in 1876 in the town of Eugene when community members raised $27,500 ($500,000 in today's dollars) to buy 17 acres and construct the school’s first building, Deady Hall. Today, there are about 200 academic programs and 25 research centers and institutes, set in a town with a temperate year-round climate and proximity to mountains, the wild Oregon coast and a host of outdoor recreational opportunities. The university has produced two Nobel laureates and nine Pulitzer Prize winners. With its duck mascot and official school colors of yellow and green, University of Oregon athletic teams compete in the NCAA Division I. The school’s rich heritage in running has earned it the moniker “Track Town USA.” The movie "Animal House" was filmed on campus.

name: Lake Forest College
profile: Lake Forest College is a private liberal arts college located in Lake Forest, IL. In the past decade, Lake Forest has developed 12 new majors and minors; including finance and digital media design; increased enrollment by 300; doubled its first-year applications; invested $100 million in new facilities and buildings on campus and expanded its off-campus study abroad opportunities.The National Survey of Student Engagement places the college in the top 10% for students who report the college to be an academic challenge, have a high rate of student-faculty interaction and a supportive campus environment. In 1977 the school invited Dr. Seuss to give the commencement speech. His entire address, “Uncle Terwilliger on the Art of Eating Popovers,” was a short poem that has since been engraved on a rock on campus. Lake Forest College competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and its mascot is Boomer the Bear.

name: Luther College
profile: Founded in 1861 by Norwegian immigrants, Luther College is a private liberal arts college in Decorah, IA. The college is affiliated with the Lutheran Church. This spring, three Luther students were awarded Fulbright awards. Luther is part of only 10 % of the nation’s higher education institutions to have a Phi Beta Kappa chapter. The college offers over 60 majors and pre-professional programs that lead to bachelor’s of arts degrees. About 40% of students participate in college’s extracurricular music groups, including choirs, bands and orchestras. Every year, more than 400 Luther students spend a semester abroad in 41 countries. The college also offers a January Term option. The college competes in NCAA Division III. One of the school’s largest annual events is the Christmas at Luther Concert, which celebrates Christmas with performances from its six choirs; over 8,000 members of the Luther College community typically attend.

name: Gonzaga University
profile: Gonzaga University dates back to 1881, but the school officially opened its doors in 1887. A private Roman Catholic university and a member of the Associate of Jesuit Colleges and Universities, Gonzaga has a strong core liberal arts curriculum integrating religious studies, philosophy, mathematics, literature and natural sciences. Students can choose from seven undergraduate degrees in 43 majors, but Gonzaga values the written word above all disciplines—Gonzaga students complete extensive writing projects across all courses of study. The university is home to the Crosby Museum, which contains the world’s largest public collection of Harry “Bing” Crosby memorabilia in honor of the famous alum. Gonzaga is a NCAA Division I school. Football, formerly known as American rugby, was played for the first time on Gonzaga’s campus.

name: Butler University
profile: Founded in 1855 in Indianapolis, IN, Butler University is a private university offering over 60 majors through six colleges. There are also pre-professional programs like engineering, law, medicine and veterinary medicine. All Butler students engage in community service as part of the University’s Indianapolis Community Requirement. Butler’s Holcomb Observatory, one of the largest public observatories in the world, houses the largest telescope in the state. Butler University’s campus features the 20-acre Holcomb gardens and the Dawghouse, which houses a convenience store, career and computer resource lab, laundry facilities and game room.The Butler Bulldogs compete in NCAA Division I-AA athletics. A live English bulldog has been the mascot since December 2000, and Blue III (also known as Trip) is the current mascot.

name: Linfield College
profile: Chartered in 1858, Linfield College is a private liberal arts institution in McMinnville, OR. Linfield offers 47 majors in three programs, a liberal arts education at the residential campus in McMinnville, the school of nursing on the Portland campus, and the adult degree program taught at eight sites in Oregon and online. The college employs a January Term that gives students four weeks to immerse themselves into a variety of topics abroad or on campus. Campus media organizations include KSLC FM radio, a student-run radio station and “The Linfield Review,” the weekly student newspaper. Students participate in 80 clubs and organizations and the campus supports nearly 20 musical and performing groups. Linfield is currently implementing its strategic plan which spans from 2012-2018 and aims at investing in faculty and facilities as well as improving access by focusing on increasing diversity on campus.The college athletic program competes in NCAA Division III as the Wildcats.

name: SUNY, College of Environmental Science and Forestry
profile: The oldest and largest college in the country dedicated solely to studying the environment and sustainability methods, SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry is a public research university in Syracuse, NY. Founded in 1911, the school offers 24 undergraduate and 30 graduate degree programs. The SUNY ESF campus includes 12 acres in Syracuse, 25,000 acres on campuses throughout Central New York and Adirondack Park, as well as properties in different ecosystems, including an island in the St. Lawrence River and a field station in Costa Rica, designed for education and research. The university’s Vision 2020 program is working to add new academic programs, and to add a summer bridge program to assist entering first-year students.SUNY, ESF’s Gateway Center uses sustainable energy to generate power and heat for the campus. Traditions include Earth Week events, SUNY ESF Day of Service, and Free Movie Nights. The school’s golf, soccer, basketball, and cross-country men’s and women’s teams compete in USCAA athletics.

name: University of Dayton
profile: The University of Dayton is a private research university established in 1850 as the St. Mary’s School for Boys. It assumed its current name in 1920 and is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. The school offers over 70 majors throughout four colleges in business, engineering, education and health sciences, and arts and sciences. The university’s research has been awarded 140 patents, with one of the most famous being the bags that Domino’s Pizza uses to keep delivery pizzas hot. The school has a very active campus ministry. The Center for Social Concern calls on students to feed the hungry, care for the sick, lobby political and economic leaders and protect the vulnerable. The university’s Marian Library has the world’s largest collection of printed materials on the Virgin Mary. The University of Dayton competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is Rudy Flyer.

name: Saint Mary's College
profile: Saint Mary's College is a private women's Catholic college founded in 1844 located in Notre Dame, IN. Founded by the Sisters of the Holy Cross, it is one of the oldest institutions for the higher education of women in the U.S. The college offers more than 30 majors and bachelor degrees in arts, business administration, fine arts, music and science, and students have the opportunity for a self designed major. The school recently introduced a Gender and Women’s Studies program for the 2014-2015 academic year. The college has a co-exchange program with the University of Notre Dame that allows St. Mary’s students to attend Notre Dame classes and co-hosted sporting events, clubs and organizations. The women’s choir regularly performs with the Notre Dame glee club. The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and its sports teams are called the Belles.

name: CUNY, Baruch College
profile: CUNY, Baruch College is a public college that was founded in 1847 as the Free Academy and is a Senior College in the City University of New York System. Located between Wall Street and Midtown Manhattan, the college was named in honor of Bernard M. Baruch, a statesman, financier, and devoted alumnus. The college has over 17,000 students who speak more than 110 languages and represent over 160 countries. Baruch competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and the school mascot is the Bearcat. In a 2011 report released by the Education Trust, a research and advocacy group, named Baruch College as one of five U.S. four-year colleges that is successfully serving low-income students. Baruch’s Zicklin School of Business is the largest accredited collegiate school of business in the country. In 2012, Baruch was one of only 18 American higher level learning institutions selected for the Brazil initiative of the Institute of International Education’s International Academic Partnership Program.

name: Sweet Briar College
profile: Sweet Briar College is a private liberal arts college for women in Sweet Briar, VA. It was founded in 1901. The college enrolls less than 800 students from nearly 40 states and 7 countries. Sweet Briar offers students 46 areas of study with an average class size of 11. The most popular majors at the college are business, biology, psychology, engineering and art history. Approximately 95% of students live on campus. There are nearly 50 student clubs and organizations on Sweet Briar’s 3,250-acre campus. For those interested in riding, the college maintains a 130-acre campus riding center plus 18 miles of trails. Students can earn a certificate in equine studies. The Virginia Center for the Creative Arts is the only artists’ retreat in the U.S. that is tied to a college or university. Sweet Briar’s intercollegiate athletic teams, known as the Vixens, compete at the NCAA Division III level.

name: Truman State University
profile: Truman State University is a public university located in Kirksville, MO. Established in 1867, the university was later renamed for President Harry S. Truman, the only president born in Missouri. Applying for admission to Truman is free. The school offers 48 majors and 45 minors; academics are based on a liberal studies core. Students are required to take classes on speech, basic math, statistics, computer literacy and physical activity. College students from underrepresented populations can participate in the McNair Program, which seeks to increase the number of undergraduates who eventually receive Ph.D. degrees. Every spring students complete a day of community service, helping Kirksville residents with cleaning, washing, painting, and gardening. Undergraduates may also intern at the Harry S. Truman Presidential Museum and Library. Truman State University competes in NCAA Division II athletics and their teams are nicknamed the Bulldogs. The most Division II Academic All-American athletics have competed at Truman State.

name: Illinois Institute of Technology
profile: Founded in 1890, the Illinois Institute of Technology’s entire main campus in Chicago was designed by architect and former IIT professor Ludwig Mies Van Der Rohe and is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. ITT is divided into eight colleges and 31 research centers and institutes, including the Pritzker Institute of Biomedical Science and Engineering and the Wanger Institute for Sustainable Energy Research. IPRO, or The Interprofessional Projects, is composed of teams of students in different areas of study that collaborate and work together to develop solutions to world problems through innovation. Greek life on campus is comprised of six fraternities and three sororities. IIT has produced three Nobel laureates, awarded in the areas of physics and chemistry. Every year, students participate in a Pumpkin Launch, where teams build a medieval-style catapults and compete for distance and accuracy. IIT athletic teams, the Scarlet Hawks, compete in NAIA athletics.

name: Augustana College (Rock Island)
profile: Augustana College is a private liberal arts college located on a 115-acre campus surrounded by woods and rolling hills in Rock Island, IL, along the Mississippi River. It is affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America. Swedish Lutheran settlers initially founded the college in 1860 as a small institution educating Swedish immigrants. Augustana College offers over 30 majors and eight pre-professional programs, including concentrations in law, dentistry, medicine, nursing and pharmacy.The college is recognized for Augie Choice, a program that provides students with up to $2,000 to pursue a high-impact learning experience of their choice, such as study abroad, an internship or research. Augustana’s Campus Ministries’ hosts an “Alternative Spring Break” trip, where students work on housing improvement throughout Appalachia. Augustana is home to seven fraternities and seven sororities. Augustana participates in NCAA Division III athletics and the school mascot is the Viking.

name: SUNY, Stony Brook (Stony Brook University)
profile: SUNY Stony Brook, one of the four SUNY university centers, is a public research university located minutes from the Long Island Sound in the town on Stony Brook. Founded in 1957, the university offers 68 majors and 80 minors. The university offers 67 majors and the most popular fields of study are psychology, biology, business management and health science. Stony Brook research has led to the identification and cataloging of 328 distant galaxies. The school is also responsible for more than 1,700 inventions and over 500 patents. The annual Roth Pond Regatta is a popular competition where students race across the pond in makeshift boats. Each spring, the university gathers at the Academic Mall to celebrate “Strawberry Fest,” a day that includes music, dancing, and strawberry treats. SUNY, Stony Brook competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is the Seawolf.

name: University of Arizona
profile: Located in Tucson, the University of Arizona is a public research school founded in 1885 that emphasizes giving students real-world experience in their area of study to better prepare them for the workforce. The university has well-regarded programs in the physical sciences and health. In the fall, it will become the first school in the U.S. to offer an undergraduate degree in law. It is home to the world’s largest institution devoted to documenting the history of modern North American photography. The UA campus is one of the greenest spaces in the state of Arizona with its own arboretum and biosphere. It is also home to a planetarium, mineral museum, pharmacy museum and several other art and anthropology museums. The school competes in Division I-A athletics and the school mascot is the Wildcat.

name: John Carroll University
profile: One of 28 Jesuit universities in the country, John Carroll University was founded in 1886 and is located in University Heights, OH, 10 miles from Cleveland. The university has 26 buildings and sits on 60 acres near the shores of Lake Erie. Degrees in nearly 60 fields are earned through the College of Arts and Sciences and the Boler School of Business. JCU serves as one of seven sites in Ohio for the distinguished Woodrow Wilson Ohio Teaching Fellowship, designed to attract talented and committed individuals with backgrounds in the STEM fields – science, technology, engineering, and mathematics – into teaching in high-need secondary schools. Each participant is awarded a $30,000 fellowship and admission into a master’s of education degree program. More than two-thirds of students engage in community service each semester and nearly 60% of graduates remain in Ohio after graduating. The university competes in NCAA Division III athletics as the blue and gold “Blue Streaks.”

name: The Citadel
profile: The Citadel, or the Military College of South Carolina, is one of the six senior military colleges in the U.S. Established in 1842, the school's ROTC detachments are authorized to offer commissions for the Army, Air Force, Marine Corps, and Navy. While a small percentage of the students are civilians, the majority form the Citadel’s Corps of Cadets, which draws students from 45 states and a dozen countries. The school was all-male until 1996. More than 1,000 alumni have served or are currently serving in Iraq and Afghanistan. Citadel’s students operate under three “Core Values:” honor, duty, and respect. The Citadel Pipe Band is one of the premiere bagpipe bands in the country. The Citadel competes in Division I athletics, and has one of the highest four-year graduation rates for athletes. Alumni include 3 U.S. senators, 12 congressmen, and a large number of professional athletes. Kevin Spacey’s character Frank Underwood in the popular Netflix series House of Cards graduated from The Sentinel, a fictionalized version of the Citadel.

name: Illinois Wesleyan University
profile: Illinois Wesleyan University is a private liberal arts university located on an 80-acre campus in Bloomington, IL. It was established in 1850. The school runs on a 4-4-1 calendar that includes a May term which allows the students to focus on a single course for three weeks and earn a full class credit. Fifty majors and programs, and eight pre-professional programs are offered. The motto, “Knowledge and Wisdom,” is attributed to notable explorer and geology professor John Wesley Powell. IWU’s International Office helps students organize studying abroad through Pembroke College in England. Additionally, the university provides domestic, off-campus semester programs in Washington, D.C., Chicago, and at the United Nations. One in three students are members of fraternities and sororities. Illinois Wesleyan competes in the NCAA Division III and the school mascot is the Titan.

name: Agnes Scott College
profile: Agnes Scott College is a liberal arts women’s college in metro Atlanta offering B.A. degrees in 30 majors and 25 minors. Students can also seek out science degrees through collaborations with Georgia Tech and Emory University as well as an MBA program with Georgia Tech. Agnes Scott is a pioneer in the campus sustainability movement, starting an environmental and sustainability studies program in 2009 and taking first steps to be completely carbon-neutral by its 150th anniversary in 2039. Four students were awarded Fulbright Scholarships last year. Established in 1889, Black Cat is one of the oldest Agnes Scott traditions, marking the end of orientation and introducing a week-long series of events including dances, skits, songs and a bonfire. Onyx class rings are also traditionally bestowed to students in their sophomore spring, earning ASC alums the “Black Ring Mafia” nickname. Many films have been shot on ASC’s campus, included The Blind Side, Fried Green Tomatoes and Scream 2.

name: University of Mary Washington
profile: Named for the mother of our country’s founding father, it was established in 1908 as a women’s only school, and became co-ed in the 1970s. It has more than 40 majors and programs of study. Devil-Goat Day is a spring festival each year featuring class competitions between undergrads who entered UMW on an odd-numbered year, who are called “devils,” and undergrads who matriculated in an even-numbered year, who are called “goats.” The University of Mary Washington Eagles compete in NCAA Division III sports in the Capital Athletic Conference. In 2014 the women’s rugby team took home the USA Rugby Women’s Collegiate Division II National Championship.

name: Fisk University
profile: One of the premier Historically Black College or Universities (HBCU), Fisk University was founded six months after the end of the Civil War and was named in honor of Gen. Clinton B. Fisk, who provided the new institution facilities near what is today’s Union Station in Nashville. It is the only HBCU ever to win the prestigious R&D 100 award, and to date has won four. The school maintains a program with Vanderbilt called the Masters-to-PhD Bridge Program, which provides a smooth transition from Fisk’s STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) master’s degrees to Vanderbilt’s Ph.D. programs. Enrollment for 2013 was 645 students, up 5% over the last year. Among notable alumni is W.E.B. Du Bois, the social critic and founding member of the NAACP. The university competes in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA) and is a member of the Gulf Coast Athletic Conference (GCAC)

name: Taylor University
profile: Taylor is an interdenominational evangelical Christian college located in Upland, IN. It was established in 1846. Undergraduate students study over 58 majors, the most popular being elementary education and biology. The fastest growing programs are accounting, biology, and exercise science. Eighty percent of Taylor students participate in a study abroad experience, and the university’s academic calendar also offers an optional January interterm, where Honors Guild students can study in South Africa, the Bahamas, Jordan, and Ireland. In keeping with the school’s Christian tradition, students also contribute to mission trips and discipleships. Seniors receive a Taylor Towel, a symbol of their commitment to Jesus Christ, upon graduation. Basketball fans perform “Silent Night” at the basketball game the Friday night before finals -- not by singing but by dressing in pajamas and remaining silent until the 10th point of the game is scored. Taylor University competes in NAIA athletics.

name: Hanover College
profile: Founded in 1827, overlooking the Ohio River, Hanover College is the oldest private college in Indiana. The college was founded in 1827 by Rev. John Finley Crowe as a Presbyterian school and maintains its affiliation today. Today, the college’s students benefit from personal interactions with professors, due to small class sizes.. Hanover College utilizes the 4-4-1 calendar, allowing students to take four classes during both the four-month fall and winter terms and focusing on one subject in the one-month spring term. A local tavern called The Shoebox is operated by students; those with a flair for entrepreneurialism may participate in the school’s Business Scholars Program, which supplements regular coursework within a student’s major with project-based internships and business case studies. Nearly hald of the students are affiliated with one of the college’s nine national fraternities and sororities. About one third of students compete in intercollegiate athletics, in 18 sports, including women’s lacrosse, added last year. Each year students look forward to the Annual Snowball Fight, which takes place on the day of the first significant snowfall.

name: Rockhurst University
profile: Rockhurst University is a private, Roman Catholic university in Kansas City, MO. It was founded by the Jesuits in 1910. Rockhurst offers over 50 undergraduate and graduate programs and is also among the largest non-profit providers of adult continuing education in the U.S. In light of business’ increasing reliance on big data, Rockhurst launched two 12-credit-hour certificate programs in January 2014: Data science and business analytics and data science and business intelligence. The university is dedicated to service: students log more than 30,000 service hours every year and graduating seniors receive two transcripts—one for academics and one for service work. The Center for Arts and Letters schedules lectures, performances, readings, films, study trips and exhibits. Rockhurst’s intercollegiate athletic teams, known as the Hawks, compete at the NCAA Division II level.

name: College of Idaho
profile: Founded in 1891 and the state's oldest liberal arts 4-year college, the College of Idaho has a system known as PEAK, which stands for “professional, ethical, articulate, and knowledgeable.” The PEAK program is an undergraduate curriculum that gives students the opportunity to graduate with an academic major and three academic minors in four years. The college’s off-campus offerings include a Winter Wilderness Experience in the Sawtooth Mountains of Idaho. C of I graduates include seven Rhodes Scholars, three Marshall Scholars, 11 Truman and Goldwater Scholars, three governors, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian, an Academy Award-winning composer, the co-discoverer of B12, and the co-founder of Patagonia Outerwear.One-third of C of I students participate in 18 varsity sports and three club sports, with athletic teams at the college are commonly referred to as the Coyotes; they have won 48 individual and team national championships for skiing and snowboarding, seven individual and relay national titles for cross country and track & field, and lastly, NAIA national championships for men’s baseball and basketball on campus.

name: Iowa State University
profile: Iowa State University is a public research university located in Ames, IA. It was established in 1858 and has a U.S. Department of Energy research laboratory physically located on its campus. Student can choose from 100 majors and programs in eight colleges and two schools and partake in more than 800 student organizations, including nearly 60 social Greek chapters. Iowa State is the birthplace of the first electronic digital computer, which its engineers debuted in 1997, and played an important role in developing the atomic bomb during World War II. Among Iowa State’s impressive faculty members is Daniel Shectman, 2011 Nobel Prize in Chemistry winner. George Washington Carver, the scientist-inventor who was believed to have been born into slavery, studied botany at the school and was its first black student and later first black faculty member.The university sits on nearly 2,000 acres and includes more than 160 buildings, some of which appear on The National Registrar of Historic Places.Iowa State competes in NCAA Division I.

name: San Diego State University
profile: San Diego State University is a public research university in San Diego, CA. Established in 1897, it is the oldest and largest institution of higher learning in the San Diego area. San Diego State is known as one of the most LGBT-friendly schools in the U.S. The university offers nearly 160 undergraduate majors and minors and almost 100 graduate degrees and credentials. Students looking to gain hands-on experience can take part in the school’s vibrant research community—faculty and staff have securing over $1 billion in research and program administration grants and contracts since 2000. Outside of the classroom and lab, students can get involved in one of the 300 student organizations on campus. There are 44 recognized fraternities and sororities at SDSU. One notable campus tradition is Aztec Nights, which provides nighttime entertainment to SDSU students ranging from carnivals to free outdoor movie screenings. Over the past ten years, SDSU has added more than $430 million worth of new campus facilities. Students looking for a little luck often rub the left foot of the life-size statue of Samuel T. Black, the university’s first president, as it is said to be a good luck charm. San Diego State’s athletic teams, nicknamed the Aztecs, primarily compete in the Mountain West Conference (NCAA Division I).

name: University of California, Riverside
profile: The University of California, Riverside originally opened its doors as the UC Citrus Experiment Station to study the region’s primary agricultural export, and began offering classes in 1954. Now it features 101 majors, 52 master’s degree programs and 42 PhD programs, and a student body that is one of the most diverse in the country. Forty acres of UCR’s east campus is occupied by the Botanic Gardens, an outdoor living plant museum. The school’s library is home to the Eaton Collection, the largest publicly accessible collection of science fiction and fantasy in the world. UCR is widely recognized for its community outreach programs, one of the most notable being the University Eastside Community Collaborative project, in which students tutor and participate in extra-curricular activities with economically disadvantaged youth. The school is located just an hour from Los Angeles, Hollywood, Disneyland, Palm Springs and Southern California’s famed beaches. Every year UCR hosts the HEAT Music Festival, an all-night concert featuring some of the world’s most popular performers. UCR competes in Division I sports in the Big West Conference. Its mascot is Scotty Highlander.

name: Pacific Lutheran University
profile: Pacific Lutheran University is a private university in Tacoma, WA. It was established by the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America in 1890. The university offers 44 majors and 54 minors. Most students must complete two religion courses—one on Christianity and one on another world religion. The school offers a January academic term, nicknamed J-Term, which allows students to focus on one or two classes in particular. Many students use J-Term to study away from campus. Pacific Lutheran offers over 25 international and domestic travel programs and was the first U.S. university to offer study abroad classes on all 7 continents simultaneously. Located near downtown Tacoma, Pacific Lutheran students can experience both the city and the wilderness of the Pacific Northwest. Among the many student organizations on campus are Habitat for Humanity, the Feminist Student Union and Hip Hop 101. KPLU 88.5 FM, Pacific Lutheran’s school radio station, is an award-winning National Public Radio affiliate broadcasting news and jazz. There is no Greek life at Pacific Lutheran. The Pacific Lutheran Lutes compete in Division III athletics.

name: University of Scranton
profile: The University of Scranton is a private Jesuit institution that was founded in 1888. The school offers 66 bachelor’s degree programs, 44 minors and 38 undergraduate concentrations or tracks. Incoming freshmen have the opportunity to participate in F.I.R.S.T.: Freshmen Involved in Reflection Service Together, in which 40 students are given the opportunity to participate in five days of Scranton community service leading up to Fall Welcome. Since 1972, 148 graduates of The University of Scranton have earned Fulbright scholarships or other prestigious international fellowships. More than 50% of students in STEM programs participate in research. The University of Scranton has 18 NCAA Division III teams that compete in the Landmark Conference. More than 3,000 students are involved with intramural teams. Their school colors are purple and white and their mascot is Iggy the Royal Wolf, named after Saint Ignatius Loyola, the founder of the Society of Jesus.

name: Seattle University
profile: Seattle University is a private, Jesuit, Catholic university in Seattle, WA. It was established in 1891. Students can select from 64 undergraduate, 31 graduate and 28 certificate programs. The school sponsors study abroad programs in places like Austria, China, Denmark and Ghana. Seattle University makes a strong commitment to community service—students and faculty contribute around 200,000 hours each year. Approximately 75% of students engage in service-- triple the national average. The school has shown a dedication to sustainability: solar panels partially power two buildings, an on-campus facility composts over 178,000 pounds each year and two community gardens allow students and faculty to grown their own food. The university boasts over 67,000 living alumni spread across all 50 states and approximately 77 countries. Seattle University’s varsity athletic teams compete in the Western Athletic Conference (WAC) at the NCAA Division I level. The school’s mascot is Rudy the Redhawk.

name: Saint Norbert College
profile: Saint Norbert College, located in De Pere, WI, was founded in 1898 as a school to prepare men for priesthood. It is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church and was named after Saint Norbert of Xanten. The college became a coeducational institution in 1952. There are 30 different majors, all rooted in the Catholic intellectual tradition or students can design and create their own majors. The school recently received a $7 million donation to create a new business school. More than 74% of students live on campus. Sitting a few miles upstream of Green Bay and Lake Michigan on the picturesque Fox River, SNC provides easy access to the historic Lambeau Field of the Green Bay Packers. Heritage Days is a week-long annual celebration of the school’s history. The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics. Their hockey team won the national championship in 2008, 2011, 2012 and 2014.

name: Bryant University
profile: Established in 1863 with the mission of educating Civil War veterans in business, Bryant University offers 98 courses of study in its College of Business and College of Arts and Sciences. All students complete both a major and a minor; students in a Business Administration major are required to complete a liberal arts minor; those in the International Business program must complete a language minor, and students majoring in the College of Arts and Sciences must complete a business minor.The school has a signature wrought iron archway which was moved from the campus’ original location in Providence to Smithfield, RI. Tradition dictates that no student may pass through the archway prior to commencement; doing so constitutes bad luck. Lore has it that those students who do walk through the archway prematurely will not graduate.The Bryant Bulldogs compete in NCAA Division I varsity athletics, with 22 teams.

name: SUNY, Geneseo
profile: SUNY Geneseo is located in upstate New York’s Finger Lakes region on 220 acres between Rochester and Buffalo, N.Y. The public, liberal arts college was founded in 1871, offering 54 undergraduate majors, dual degrees and international study programs. It is the only undergraduate SUNY college with a Phi Beta Kappa academic honors chapter. The campus is home to 17 residence halls including special interest halls: Eco House, Dante House, and Writer’s House. The “Painted Tree,” is estimated to be covered in at least 1,000 layers of paint and has been in use for decades. All-College Hour is a dedicated period of time every Wednesday when students have no classes; during this hour they are encouraged to join clubs, attend lectures and engage in activities beyond their courses. GREAT Day (Geneseo Recognizing Excellence, Achievement & Talent Day) is an annual college-wide symposium where students showcase artwork, and perform dance routines, sing or act. There is a tree on campus named the “Seuss Spruce” because it looks like vegetation that would appear in a Dr. Seuss story. Geneseo competes in NCAA Division III athletics and is a member of the SUNYAC conference.

name: Valparaiso University
profile: Valparaiso University was founded by Methodists in 1859 as one of the nation’s first coeducational colleges. In 1925 the Lutheran University Association purchased the school. The school’s campus, located just one hour outside Chicago, occupies a 320-acre campus. Valpo offers students more than 65 majors through their five undergraduate colleges as well as 19 study-abroad programs. The most popular destinations are England, Germany, China and Costa Rica. Legend has it that students who kiss the gravestone of George, the longtime campus dog, will score well on their exams. The Chapel of the Resurrection is one of the largest collegiate chapels in the world, with an organ that has more than 5,500 pipes in 101 ranks. Among the school’s 100 clubs are Handbell Choir and the Chemistry Club. Valparaiso’s 19 varsity sports teams compete in Division I athletics.

name: Austin College
profile: Founded in 1849 and affiliated with the Presbyterian Church, Austin College is the oldest institution of higher education in Texas operating under its original name and charter. It offers its small body of undergraduate students (some 1,300) majors and minors in 50 areas of study. The institution operates on a three-semester system, offering a traditional fall and spring semester, as well as a month-long January semester. All students are required to complete three January terms. Austin College has a reputation for its strong study abroad programs, offering students options in countries such as Australia, Brazil, China and South Africa. It has one of the highest participation rates in study abroad in the nation, with 70% of students going abroad in the past decade. This year the school awarded the Posey Leadership Award to Dr. Nathan Wolfe, the pioneering epidemiologist who works to prevent deadly virus threats such as HIV or SARS.The institution competes in Division III athletics, with their mascot being a kangaroo.

name: Ithaca College
profile: Founded in 1892 as a music conservatory, Ithaca College is a private school that now offers 97 undergraduate majors, 74 minors and 27 graduate majors. The college is known internationally for its communications program and has a long list of notable alumni in broadcasting and business, including Disney CEO Bob Iger and billionaire retailer Chris Burch. Ithaca values meaningful teacher-student collaborations and boasts a majority of classes of fewer than 20 students. The 669-acre contemporary campus in the Finger Lakes sits on a hill offering views of Cayuga Lake and Cornell University, and is just minutes from scenic waterfalls and gorges. The school operates satellite campuses in London, Los Angeles and New York City, plus a semester in Washington, D.C., program.The school has two radio stations, award-winning WICB and online VIC Radio. Intramural sports are also popular.The Bombers participate in NCAA Division III athletics

name: California State Polytechnic University, Pomona
profile: California State Polytechnic University, Pomona, began as an all-male southern satellite campus of Cal Poly in 1938 but broke off in 1966 and was granted university status shortly thereafter in 1972. It is the second largest polytechnic university in the U.S. and among the 23 California State University campuses with its sprawling 1,438 acres of land. Its campus was originally the winter ranch home of cereal entrepreneur W.K. Kellogg. The university has preserved many aspects of the horse ranch such as its mansion, rose gardens and the award-winning Kellogg Arabian horses, which are featured in monthly horse shows. The university offers nearly 100 majors and degree programs in eight academic colleges. The most popular academic groups are business administration, engineering and science. Some acclaimed faculty members include the Pritzker Architecture Prize laureate Thom Mayne and Fulbright scholar Renford Reese, former U.S. Secretary of Labor, Hilda Solis, and Forest Whitaker, the Academy Award-winning actor. Powered by two large solar panels, the 16-acre John T. Lyle Center for Regenerative Studies is fully carbon neutral, and the university aims to be completely carbon neutral by 2030. California State University competes in NCAA Division II athletics.

name: Ohio Northern University
profile: Ohio Northern University is a private research university in Ada, OH. It was founded in 1871 and is associated with the United Methodist Church. For the 2014-15 academic year, Ohio Northern cut tuition by 20-25%. The university’s five colleges offer a variety of study areas, ranging from creative writing to engineering. Known for its strong pharmacy program, around 28% of students are enrolled in the Raab College of Pharmacy. The college is one of the few to offer a “0-6” program, which allows students to enter pharmacy school immediately after graduating from high school. These students can earn a Pharm.D. in 12 semesters. More than 200 Ohio Northern students are enrolled under a international student visas. Ohio Northern’s sustainability efforts include the installation of three 400-kilowatt wind turbines that are expected to provide 5-10% of the university’s electricity. There are nearly 200 student organizations on campus, including four fraternities and five sororities. The university’s 12 men’s and 11 women’s teams compete in the Ohio Athletic Conference (NCAA Division III). Ohio Northern’s mascot is Klondike the polar bear.

name: Elizabethtown College
profile: Elizabethtown College, established in 1899, is affiliated with the Church of Brethren. The school offers more than 53 majors alongside 90 minors and concentrations through 19 academic departments. Its motto, “Educate for Service,” informs a campus tradition where students, faculty and staff work in surrounding communities to engage in service-learning projects one weekend every fall. Incoming students participate in the First-Year Walk, where new classmates traverse the campus three abreast, moving forward or backward in line by answering trivia questions designed to get the students acquainted with one another and their surroundings. The Elizabethtown College Blue Jays play in the Landmark Conference and belong to the NCAA Division III.

name: Pacific University
profile: Pacific University is a private university in Forest Grove, OR with additional campuses in Hillsboro, Eugene and Woodburn. Old College Hall, the heart of Pacific’s campus, is the longest-standing academic building in the western U.S. Founded in 1849 as a school for Oregon Trail orphans and Native American children, Pacific University now offers 74 undergraduate, graduate and professional programs. Students can participate in 26 study abroad programs in 11 countries. Close to 99% of undergraduates in the school’s College of Arts and Sciences receive financial aid. Students take advantage of the school’s location, including courses on rock climbing, sea kayaking and surfing. In 2007, Burlingham Hall became the West Coast’s first gold-rated LEED-certified residential building. The university is in the midst of constructing a new residence hall. Pacific University’s varsity teams, nicknamed the Boxers, compete in Division III athletics.

name: Whittier College
profile: Whittier College is located near Los Angeles, CA. It was named for John Greenleaf Whittier, a Quaker poet and abolitionist and was founded in 1887 by members of the Religious Society of Friends. The school offers 30 majors and minors including a 3-2 Engineering Program that allows students to study three years at Whittier College followed by two years at USC or the University of Minnesota. There is a strong emphasis on interdisciplinary learning, professional internships and service projects. Former President Richard Nixon graduated from Whittier in 1934, and during his time there founded a literary society chapter, the Orthogonian, which still exists. The college competes in NCAA Division III with 22 teams. Student athletes are known as the “Poets,” after the school mascot, John E. Poet, a tribute to the school’s namesake.

name: Bradley University
profile: Established in 1897, Bradley University is located in Peoria, IL and offers about 100 programs in liberal and fine arts, sciences, business, education, engineering, technology, and the health sciences through five different colleges. Bradley University boasts an impressive speech and forensics team. The school’s team has won 41 national speech championships since 1980, and in 2013 it won both the American Forensics Association Tournament and the National Forensics Association Tournament. Greek life is integral to the Bradley social scene, with 27 fraternities and sororities representing 30% of the undergraduate population. The Bradley Braves participate in NCAA Division I.

name: College of Saint Benedict
profile: College of St. Benedict is a private women’s liberal arts college located in St. Joseph, MN. Founded in 1913, it is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church and is the only Benedictine college for women in the country. The school shares academic programs with the men’s-only Saint John’s University, but the schools retain separate campuses, residences, athletic programs and traditions. Nearly two-thirds of all CSB students study abroad and over half participate in some kind of music group. The department of music is home to many ensembles including choirs, an orchestra, a wind ensemble and a jazz ensemble. Many of these groups play in tours abroad. CSB is a member of the Minnesota Intercollegiate Athletic Conference (MIAC) and the school is often referred to as the Blazers.

name: University of Nebraska, Lincoln
profile: The state’s flagship university, University of Nebraska, Lincoln, was chartered in 1869. While approximately 82% of UNL undergraduate students are from Nebraska, the college has students from over 130 foreign countries. The school pioneered the study of ecology. The University of Nebraska Press is the second largest state University Press in the United States. UNL is also host to the International Quilt Study Center and Museum, the largest publicly held quilt collection in the world, and the Sheldon Museum of Art, which contains more than 12,000 works of art. Alumni include television host Johnny Carson, investor Warren Buffet and the military expert John J. Pershing.

name: California Lutheran University
profile: A mere nine miles from Malibu, CA, California Lutheran University is a small-sized private, liberal arts university founded in 1959 by the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America. CLU houses the William Rolland Gallery of Fine Art, which opened in 2011 and the country’s only art gallery inside of an athletic stadium. In the school’s Barbara Collins Arboretum, campus flora are selected and cataloged for botany studies. Notable alumni include actor James Duke Mason and 2006 Miss California Jacuqlynne Fontaine. May 1, 1967 was CLU’s first “Yam Yad,” which is May Day spelled backward. On that day, students skipped classes and performed mock gunfights with water guns and water balloons on the set for the TV series “Gunsmoke”. Today, students celebrate the day with community service and relaxation on the shores of Zuma Beach. CLU competes in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: Covenant College
profile: Covenant College is a small Christian college of the Presbyterian Church located in Lookout Mountain, GA, just south of the Tennessee border. It offers undergraduate degrees in the liberal arts, sciences and music, as well as several pre-professional programs. The school has a strong Scottish heritage and in addition to the thistle imagery seen around campus (thistle is a Scottish national emblem), bagpipes are played at ceremonies such as convocation and commencement. Several all-school events are held each year, such as Kilter, which is a “girls-ask-boys” costume party often held in downtown Chattanooga, and the Exam Cram Breakfast, during which administrators and professors serve students breakfast foods as a late-night study break before exams.Varsity athletic teams, nicknamed the Scots or Lady Scots, participate in NCAA and NCCAA Division III athletics, and 75% of the student body participates in intramural sports.

name: Washington College
profile: Established in 1782 as the first college chartered in the newly formed United States of America, Washington College is the 10th oldest institution of higher learning in the country. Today, the college operates as a private liberal arts college in Chestertown, MD. The school offers 40 majors and 24 minors. Students come from 35 states and 40 different countries to study at Washington College. Each year, in honor of its namesake, the school hosts a “Birthday Ball” for the first president. The school boasts a beautiful shoreline with access to the Chester River, an important piece of the college’s campus. There are two waterfront locations on campus: the Truslow Boat House and the Lelia Hynson Pavilion. Washington College competes in NCAA Division III athletics with 17 varsity teams.

name: CUNY, Hunter College
profile: Originally founded in 1870 as a women’s college, Hunter College is the largest college in the CUNY system and one of the oldest public colleges in the country. It offers undergraduate and graduate degrees in over 170 programs in arts and sciences, education, nursing, social work, health professions and urban public health. It also bestows a number of accelerated BA/MA, BS/MA degrees, and advanced certificate programs. After graduating Hunter, about 20% of students enter post-baccalaureate programs within one year. Top employers of Hunter College graduates are the NYC Department of Health, US Census Bureau, Memorial Sloan Kettering and the NYC Board of Education. The college has produced two Nobel Prize laureates, five Pulitzer Prize winners and three National Medal of Science winners. Hunter is the only academic institution in the world to graduate two women who later won Nobel Prizes in medicine: Gertrude B. Elion ’37 and Rosalyn S. Yalow ’41. It competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and the school mascot is the Hawk.

name: Goucher College
profile: Goucher College is a private liberal arts college located on 287 wooded acres in Baltimore, MD. Originally founded in 1885 as the Women’s College of Baltimore, Goucher College became a coeducational institute in 1986. In 2006, it became the first liberal arts college that requires 100% of its undergraduate students to study abroad, offering 60 programs in more than 32 countries .The Julia Rogers Library underwent a facelift in fall 2013 that brought an additional 62,000 square feet and high-efficiency heating/cooling, ventilation and electrical systems to make it a LEED-compliant facility. The school participates in the Farm to Fork dining initiative, purchasing seasonal ingredients from small, owner-operated farms and ranches within a 150-mile radius of the campus café. About 80% of food served on campus is vegetarian or vegan and about 18-20 farms provide food to the school, depending on the growing season. Goucher offers five Special Interest Housing Facilities: healthy living, language, gaming and green. Each year Goucher hosts a May Day celebration, “Get Into Goucher” (GIG), kicked off with ringing the chapel bells to signal the end of classes and the start of carnival rides, games, food and music. The Goucher Gophers are a member of NCAA Division III.

name: SUNY, Buffalo (University at Buffalo)
profile: State University of New York, Buffalo is the largest campus in the 64-campus SUNY system AND one of the four university centers. It was established in 1846. The university is divided into North, South, and Downtown campuses. SUNY Buffalo offers over 100 undergraduate, 205 master’s, 10 doctoral, and 10 professional degrees. Four SUNY, Buffalo professors have won Nobel Prizes and prominent alumni include J.Crew CEO Mickey Drexler, CNN’s Wolf Blizter and astronaut Ellen Baker. The university hosts a Distinguished Speakers Series, bringing notable individuals including Hillary Clinton and Steve Martin to campus. In 2004, an initiative called UB2020 was launched; it aims to expand the school’s size by 40%. The “Finish in 4 Pledge” offers a personalized plan for students to help them graduate in four years. If students follow the stipulations of the pledge but still cannot graduate in four years, SUNY, Buffalo will offer them the opportunity to complete the remaining course free of tuition and other fees. SUNY, Buffalo competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is the Bull.

name: Cedarville University
profile: Cedarville University is a private university located in Cedarville, OH. It was established in 1887 and is affiliated with the Baptist Church. Upon inception, Cedarville University was affiliated with the Reformed Presbyterian Church in North America. An accredited member of the North Central Association of Colleges and Schools, all students graduate with a Bible minor. The most popular majors are nursing, mechanical engineering, psychology and early childhood education. Cedarville provides a number of special programs including a one-year Bible study, agricultural business, pre-professional studies, and TESOL Endorsement (Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages). The university has the only Christ-centered Professional Pharmacy program in the Midwest, and its School of Nursing has the only birthing simulator among any university in the State of Ohio. Cedarville opened its state of the art $14 million Health Sciences Center – for nursing, pharmacy and bioethics – in 2012. Students are expected to attend weekly worship at a local church to exercise their spiritual discipline. Athletic teams are nicknamed the Yellow Jackets, and the university recently transitioned from NAIA Division II athletics to NCAA II.

name: Westminster College (Fulton)
profile: Westminster College was established in 1851 in Fulton, MO. The school offers 36 majors, 34 minors and 12 pre-professional programs. Additionally, the school gives ambitious students the opportunity to design their own major. Students come from 34 states and 68 countries to study at Westminster. There are more than 60 student organizations and clubs, including the oldest Greek system of any school west of the Mississippi River. In 1909, a fire destroyed the original Westminster Hall, built in 1854. The columns remain today and serve as the backdrop for the “Column Ceremony,” a tradition in which graduates walk through the columns to signify their life transition from student to citizen. The campus is also home to the National Churchill Museum, a tribute to Winston Churchill, who delivered his famous “Iron Curtain” speech at the school in 1946. The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: CUNY, Queens College
profile: CUNY, Queens College was founded in 1937 and since its first class graduated in 1941, it has bestowed over 120,000 diplomas. It is one of the most diverse colleges in the Northeast, with a student body representing some 120 countries. QC offers nearly 70 majors, including the BA/MA program in chemistry, computer science, music, philosophy and physics. The campus consists of 77 acres with a view of the Manhattan skyline from the quad. At Queens College, two-thirds of the undergraduate class is full-time students while the majority of graduate students are part-time students. Comedian Jerry Seinfeld graduated from Queens College in 1976, and singer/songwriter Paul Simon was a member of the class of 1963. Through the Weekend College, full and part-time students can earn their undergraduate degree in four years through classes on Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays, or through a combination between weekday and weekend classes. Queens college’s 19 varsity teams compete in Division II athletics, and the school mascot is “Sir Winsalot,” an armored knight.

name: Westminster College (New Wilmington)
profile: Established in 1852, Westminster College was one of the earliest integrated and unrestricted coeducational colleges in the country; it is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church USA. Located in New Wilmington, PA, the college is home to 24 buildings and many outdoor attractions, including a 100-acre outdoor laboratory. The school offers 42 majors and 10 pre-professional programs, 81 clubs and organizations, four national fraternities and five national sororities. Every July, the campus hosts an Independence Day concert and fireworks by Lake Brittain. Westminster College’s Hillside Hall was built in 1885 and is the oldest residence hall on campus, and is allegedly haunted by Betsy, a female ghost. Westminster competes in NCAA Division III athletics with 18 varsity teams in the President’s Athletic Conference.

name: Mills College
profile: Mills College is a private women’s liberal arts college in Oakland, CA. Though its undergraduate programs are restricted to women, Mills admits men to its graduate programs. It was founded in 1852 and hosts students from 41 states and six countries. The most popular of the 41 undergraduate majors the school offers are English, nursing, psychology, biology and political, legal, and economic analysis (PLEA). It was the first women’s college to establish an undergraduate computer science degree. Mills’ Oakland location gives students the chance to explore all the San Francisco Bay area has to offer. On campus, students can get involved in over 50 student organizations. The Mills College Art Museum has the largest permanent collection of any West Coast liberal arts college with over 10,000 works of art and the Mills Chapel is a place of reflection for students of all beliefs. Student-athletes mostly compete at the NCAA Division III level and are known as the Cyclones.

name: University of Tennessee, Knoxville
profile: Originally founded as Blount College in 1794, this public university offers more than 170 undergraduate majors, concentrations, and specializations through nine colleges. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics in the Southeastern Conference. It has won 23 NCAA championships and a total of 151 SEC championship team titles, 114 of which were Men's SEC championship team titles -- the most of any league school. The Volunteers are led onto the field by a live mascot, Smokey IX, a blue tick coon hound dog. The university's colors - orange and white - are based on the orange and white daisies that grow around campus. Notable alumni include author Kurt Vonnegut, DISH Network founder Charlie Ergen and quarterback Peyton Manning.

name: University of Arkansas
profile: A public research university located in Fayetteville, near the picturesque Ozark Mountains has 10 colleges and schools offering more than 210 academic programs. It was founded in 1871 as the Arkansas Industrial University, the first state-funded university. In 1905, senior students mixed cement for a piece of walkway on campus and wrote their names on it. The tradition has continued to this day, and the engraved sidewalk is now almost three miles long. Bill and Hillary Clinton began their careers by teaching law at UA. The Fulbright Scholarship Program was named in honor of UA graduate and former president of the university, J. William Fulbright. Other notable alumni include S. Robson Walton, chairman of Wal-Mart Stores, and Jerry Jones, owner of the Dallas Cowboys. The university competes in Division I-A athletics and the school mascot is the Razorback.The “Calling of the Hogs” is one of the most recognizable chants in college sports.

name: Doane College
profile: Doane College, Nebraska’s first liberal arts and sciences college, was founded in 1872 by New England Congregationalists. The college offers students a selection of 60 areas of study, seven professional programs, and 24 minors, with elementary education, physical education and business comprising the three most popular programs. The 4-1-4 academic calendar allows students to study four courses in the fall, one in the winter and four in the spring. The institution’s 300-acre campus is a designated arboretum and boasts the historic Boswell Observatory, the oldest operating observatory west of the Missouri River. Doane College has had 59 Fulbright scholars who have studied abroad from Egypt to Peru. The school competes in NAIA athletics.

name: Asbury University
profile: Founded in 1890, Asbury University is a multi-denominational institution that aims to bring spiritual development to students based on four cornerstones: scripture, holiness, stewardship and mission. Originally named Kentucky Holiness College, the school was renamed to honor the founder of American Methodism, Bishop Francis Asbury. Asbury University offers 52 majors in 14 academic departments. The university is involved with the Asbury Theological Seminary, which is also located in Wilmore, KY. Students come from 44 states and 14 foreign nations, and the majority of the University’s students live on-campus. The entire community comes together to communally worship in the stained glass Hughes Auditorium on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. During orientation, each incoming Asbury class is assigned two faculty sponsors, and collectively chose an original name, class colors, and hymn verse that will constitute their class’ identity for the next four years. Traditionally, when a class hymn is sung in chapel, each class stands individually and sings their verse.

name: Touro College
profile: Established in 1970 as a school primarily for the Jewish community, Touro College now caters to diverse students studying on 32 school campuses in five countries, including Germany, France, Israel and Russia. Touro undergraduates can pursue various fields of study, including accounting and business, computer science and information technology, and natural sciences and pre-health professions. In 2011 the school merged with the New York Medical College. In keeping with their religious tradition, Touro stresses Jewish studies, offering bachelors in Judaic studies. The religious undergraduate schools are divided into separate men and women’s colleges. The Touro College Israel Option (TCIO) was established to allow students to complete up to 36 credits in select Israeli seminaries. Touro hosts a Manhattan campus Instant Decision Day in the summer, where administrators from the New York School of Career and Applied Studies interview candidates and decide on admission immediately.

name: University of Kansas
profile: A public research university located in Lawrence, KS, it offers 360 degree programs in 200 fields that are organized into 13 schools. The most popular areas of study are special education, city management, healthcare and social welfare. A steam whistle blows every day to signal the end of hourly classes. The University of Kansas competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the sports teams are nicknamed the Jayhawks. The basketball team has won several national titles and the school’s first men’s basketball coach was the inventor of the game, Dr. James Naismith. During games, it’s a tradition for fans to lift their arms over their heads and slowly wave them back and forth, mimicking a field of Kansas wheat swaying in the wind.

name: Cornell College
profile: Cornell College is a private liberal arts college founded in 1853 by George Bryant Bowman, a Methodist minister. The college adopts the block plan in which one academic year is divided into eight blocks and students study only one course at a time. Popular majors include economics, history and psychology. Cornell College features six centers and programs designed to enrich students’ experience with public policy, healthcare, law, literary arts, and career mentorship provided by professionals. Each year students present scholarly and creative work in a wide variety of fields at Student Symposium. Recent presentation titles include “Mathematical Modeling of HIV.” Cornell College provides students $3,000 grant for summer collaborative research. Despite Cornell’s small size and small town location, notable visitors to the school include President Obama (three times), actress Scarlett Johansson and musician Joan Jett.

name: Simmons College
profile: Simmons College is a private liberal arts college in Boston, MA. Part of Boston’s robust higher education scene, the school is within walking distance of 15 other colleges. Simmons offers over 50 undergraduate majors and programs. Students hail from 40 states and 39 countries. Though there are no sororities, students can get involved in over 50 student organizations on campus. There are many traditions at Siena, including May Day, when sophomores get the chance to wake up the seniors with pots, pans and noisemakers at the break of dawn and the Simmons Cup, an annual spring field day. The Simmons Leadership Conference is billed as the longest-running leadership forum for women in the U.S. It attracts as many as 3,000 women and has featured speakers like Oprah Winfrey, Madeleine Alright and Meg Whitman.There are over 63,000 Simmons alumni across the globe. The college sponsors ten varsity teams, known as the Sharks, which compete at the NCAA Division III level.

name: Montana State University, Bozeman
profile: Montana State University is a public research university in Bozeman, MT. It was founded in 1893 as the Agricultural College of the State of Montana. Nestled at the foot of the Rocky Mountains, students can enjoy the benefits of a college town and the great outdoors. Montana State draws from all 50 states and more than 70 countries and students can select from undergraduate degrees in 60 fields. Approximately 25% of students attend part-time. Those interested in gaining hands-on experience can take advantage of Montana State’s dedication to research—it is a land-grant university and expenditures from sponsored research programs totaled over $93 million in fiscal year 2013. It is known as the “University of Yellowstone” as it is the lead recipient of National Science Foundation grants for Yellowstone studies. There are over 175 student organizations on campus. Montana State’s intercollegiate athletic teams, known as the Bobcats, compete in the Big Sky Conference at the NCAA Division I level. Rodeo competition is conducted through the National Intercollegiate Rodeo Association.

name: Utah State University
profile: Utah State University is a public research university in Logan, UT. It was founded in 1888 as the Agricultural College of Utah. Students can take advantage of Utah State’s Logan Canyon location—the school is just minutes from hiking and biking trails with over 275 climbing routes. The university draws students from all 50 states and nearly 90 foreign countries. Utah State offers nearly 170 undergraduate degrees, 94 minors and 143 graduate degrees. The most popular majors include communicative disorders and deaf educations, teacher education and leadership, and economics and finance. Utah State claims to have sent more student experiments into space than any other university in the world. Each year, the school brings in notable lecturers, ranging from Bill Nye to Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia. The university’s varsity athletic teams, nicknamed the Aggies, compete in the Mountain West Conference at the NCAA Division I level.

name: The Master's College
profile: The Master’s College is an evangelical Christian private college located in Santa Clarita, CA. It was established in 1927 as the Los Angeles Baptist College and Theological Seminary. The college offers 13 majors and 58 areas of study. The mission statement of the college is to “empower students” with a commitment to Christ, biblical fidelity, moral integrity, intellectual growth and a life of lasting contribution through service. The school has a Biblical Studies program which trains future missionaries, church leaders and ministers. The Master’s College is a member of the NAIA Division I, offering six men’s sports and six women’s sports. Notable alumni include Mike Penberthy, a former Lakers player, and professional baseball player Jerry Owens.

name: Stevens Institute of Technology
profile: Stevens Institute of Technology is a private research university in Hoboken, NJ. It has been focused on technological innovation since its founding in 1870. Named for the Stevens family, whose members’ accomplishments include designing the first American-built steam locomotive and the first yacht to win what is now known as the America’s Cup, the school has never lost sight of its entrepreneurial spirit. Stevens draws students from 45 states and nearly 70 foreign countries and offers 32 undergraduate, over 40 master’s and 22 Ph.D. programs. The university’s core research areas include secure systems, systems engineering, and enterprise management and nanotechnology. The school’s student-athletes primarily compete in the Empire 8 (E8) conference at the NCAA Division III level.

name: Duquesne University
profile: Founded in 1878, Duquesne University was originally a Catholic college for immigrants in Pittsburgh, PA. Duquesne now offers students a selection of 80 undergraduate degree programs through 10 different schools of study. The Center for Pharmacy Services, located in the nearby Hill District, is the nation’s first off-campus community pharmacy designed and operated by a school of pharmacy. The university also offers study abroad locations around the world, including a satellite campus in Rome, Italy. Chuck Cooper, the first African American basketball player to be drafted into the NBA, graduated from Duquesne in 1950. Athletic teams, nicknamed the Dukes, compete in the NCAA Division I.

name: Quinnipiac University
profile: Quinnipiac University is a private university in Hamden, CT. The school offers 58 undergraduate majors and more than 20 graduate programs. The university offers study abroad and experimental learning programs. New for 2014 is the Quinnipiac in LA program, which allows students to live, work and study in Los Angeles. The campus is home to 17 fraternities and sororities. Quinnipiac takes part in “The Big Event,” a nationwide community service day. The Quinnipiac Polling Institute is a nationally-recognized independent organization that uses students and non-students to conduct public opinion polls about politics and public policy. Most of the school’s varsity athletic teams, known as the Bobcats, compete at the NCAA Division I level. Quinnipiac does not have a football team.

name: Lebanon Valley College
profile: Founded in 1866, Lebanon Valley College is a small liberal arts college located on 340 acres in Annville, PA. LVC is affiliated with the United Methodist Church. LVC guarantees students will earn an undergraduate degree in four years of full-time study, or the school will provide free tuition for additional courses. Students can elect to take special programs in cooperation with Pennsylvania State University and Case Western Reserve University for engineering and medical technology. Lebanon Valley College athletic teams compete in NCAA Division III, the school colors are blue and white and the mascot is the Flying Dutchman. Dutchman Day is a school tradition when LVC gives students a surprise day off to enjoy a day free of classes and filled with food and entertainment. The college is located almost 20 miles from Harrisburg and eight miles from Hershey.

name: University of Evansville
profile: A private university affiliated with the United Methodist Church, it has a campus, Harlaxton College, in Grantham, England. It offers over 80 different majors and has a strong theater program. There is a very active Greek scene on campus, with almost 30% of the student body affiliated with a fraternity or sorority. Since 2009, the school has hosted a Festival of Young Preachers, an annual event that allows aspiring preachers to strengthen their ministry. The University of Evansville competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the sports teams are nicknamed the Purple Aces.

name: Ripon College
profile: Ripon College is a private liberal arts college in Ripon, WI. It was founded in 1851. Ripon students can choose from 30 majors and 46 minors. Each incoming freshman student is assigned a faculty mentor. Ripon is a residential college, meaning all non-commuting students must live on campus. Approximately 92% of students do so, though nearly one-third of students spend at least one semester studying off-campus. There are more than 70 student groups and organizations at the college, including nine fraternities and sororities. Around 65% of students participate in the 14 intramural sports programs on campus. Ripon’s Imagine Tomorrow campaign, dedicated to increasing student scholarships and aid has raised $50 million of its $60 million goal. The college has 23 varsity athletic teams, known as the Red Hawks. Ripon student-athletes compete in the Midwest Conference at NCAA Division III level. Notable Ripon attendees include actors Harrison Ford and Spencer Tracy.

name: Western Washington University
profile: Western Washington University was established in 1886 as the Northwest Normal School in Bellingham, WA, and initially trained women for teaching. Today, Western Washington University operates as one of six state funded, four-year universities in Washington. Sustainability is an important aspect of life at WWU. The Huxley College of the Environment has been operating since 1969 and is one of the nation’s oldest environmental science colleges. Other initiatives by Western Washington University include purchasing 100% renewable energy since 2004, LEED gold certification for the renovation of Miller Hall, an academic building, and developing a new state-of-the-art energy degree in association with the Institute for Energy Studies. Additionally, the school received nearly a million dollars in grants to continue solar research. The Western Washington Vikings compete in NCAA Division II.

name: Colorado State University
profile: Residing in Fort Collins, CO, the university’s campus is located on the Front Range of the Rocky Mountains with 14,000-foot peaks visible with the blind eye. The campus occupies about 5,000 acres of land, where students can hike, ski or raft nearby. There are about 4,600 acres for research centers as well. About one-third of students are STEM majors, with the largest enrollment in biological sciences. The university offers approximately 150 programs of study via its eight colleges and 55 departments. The school is historically known for its radiation treatment for cancer and faculty members are involved in research on great global challenges, such as severe weather forecasting and bioterrorism. The Center for Disaster and Risk Analysis is working on reducing the harm of natural, technological and human-caused disasters. It competes in NCAA Division I-A, and the school mascot is CAM the Ram, with CAM standing for Colorado A & M, the former name of university. Each fall, students are given a white pebble to carry up the half-mile hike to the top of the “A,” a giant white letter that was built on top of the hill by students in 1923 as a tribute to the former mascot.

name: Albion College
profile: Founded in 1835 and historically related with the United Methodist Church, Albion offers B.A. and B.F.A degrees in around 40 majors, as well as pre-professional programs in engineering, law, social work and medicine. Students have the option to join six fraternities or sororities, and some 52% of male and 43% of female students go Greek; the school was also the first private college in Michigan to have a chapter of Phi Beta Kappa. The college's 340-acre equestrian center is open to any student and houses around 40 college and student-owned horses. In recent years, Albion has embarked on a “Theme Year” project —a campus-wide initiative created to improve the school; past themes include sustainability, wellness and global diversity. Through Service Project Appalachia, students can travel to the mountains during breaks for volunteer projects that assist low-income families. Albion welcomed its 16th president, Dr. Mauri A. Ditzler, this July.

name: Loyola University Chicago
profile: Loyola University Chicago was founded in 1870 by the Roman Catholic Society of Jesus and has since grown to the largest Jesuit university in the country. Although the university is a private Jesuit institution, half the student body has a full range of religious affiliations. LUC offers more than 80 undergraduate majors and minors. It has four Chicago campuses, but the main campus sits on the shore of Lake Michigan. The university also has satellite centers in Rome, Beijing and Ho Chi Minh City. In August 2015 the university will open a $10 million dollar, 10-story downtown hub for Loyola University Chicago’s Quinlan School of Business. The university’s Center for Experimental Learning combines academic internship programs with community service and research opportunities, helping students complete an internship program before graduation. Loyola competes in NCAA Division I athletics.

name: Goshen College
profile: Goshen College was established in 1894 in Goshen, IN and is affiliated with the Mennonite Church USA. Goshen’s 135-acre campus is home to the Mennonite Historical Library, which contains more than 65,000 volumes and is considered to be one of the largest collections of Anabaptist and Mennonite historical documents. All full-time first-year undergrads receive an iPad as part of the Goshen Core requirements. The school offers unique cultural immersion experiences such as the Study-Service Term and the Sustainability Semester. The Study-Service Term sends students to developing countries such as Cambodia, Nicaragua, Peru, Senegal and Tanzania to live with and experience living with locals and service the surrounding communities. The Sustainability Semester is at an off-campus environmental learning facility where students engage and attempt to solve environmental issues of local concern. The Globe has repeatedly been ranked as the best college radio and television station. The Goshen College Maple Leaves participate in the NAIA and compete in the Crossroads League.

name: Spelman College
profile: Spelman College is a private women’s liberal arts college in Atlanta, GA. Established in 1881, it is one of the oldest historically Black colleges (HBCU) for women in the U.S. The Atlanta area is home to the highest concentrations of colleges and universities in the southern U.S.; Spelman is within a 30-minute drive from Emory, Georgia Tech and Agnes Scott College, among others.
