The college offers 27 majors, ranging from biochemistry to religious studies. Students come from 41 states and 15 foreign countries. There are more than 70 student organizations on Spelman’s campus. As part of a tradition dating back to 1900, students are required to wear a traditional white dress ensemble for the New Student Orientation Induction Ceremony, when attending the Founders Day Convocation and under their caps and gowns during graduation. The college made headlines in 2013 when it opted to drop all intercollegiate sports after the 2012-13 academic year. Notable Spelman attendees include celebrated author Alice Walker and Sam’s Club President and CEO Rosalind Brewer.

name: Houghton College
profile: Established in 1883 as a Houghton Seminary, a coeducational high school, today Houghton College is a coeducational, private liberal arts college affiliated with the Wesleyan Church. The college is a member of the Christian College Consortium and the Council for Christian Colleges and Universities. Houghton asks that their students learn with “their faith as a lens.” Academically, students are offered 46 majors to choose from. Students come from 32 countries to study at Houghton College. In 2011 the college received a donation of $12 million from alumna Kim Pegula (Class of 1991) that will go toward building a new sports complex; the gift is the second largest in the college’s history. Houghton is also in close proximity to Allegheny State Park, Buffalo Botanical Gardens and the Buffalo Museum of Science. Houghton College competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and the school mascot is the Highlander.

name: Union University
profile: Founded in 1823, Union University in Jackson, TN, is the oldest American institution affiliated with the Southern Baptist Church. The school’s academic program houses seven schools. The institution has undergone extensive renovations within the past decade, spending $120 million on construction to establish new Georgian-Colonial classrooms and dorms. The school has established an initiative this year to introduce iPads into the classroom. Union hosts more than 50 student-produced music and theater events annually, and there are over 60 student-run clubs and organizations. The school’s athletic teams are in the process of becoming members of the NCAA Division II, with five men’s varsity teams and seven women’s varsity teams. The legendary college football coach of the University of Alabama, Paul “Bear” Bryant, once worked as an assistant football coach at Union.

name: Ouachita Baptist University
profile: Ouachita Baptist University is a private liberal arts university in Arkadelphia, AR. It is affiliated with the Arkansas Baptist State Convention. Founded in 1886, its students represent approximately 30 states and 30 countries. In addition to its core academic curriculum, Oucahita’s Campus Ministries program provides spiritual guidance for students through weekly worship services, bible clubs and activities, and mission opportunities. Although there are no national fraternities or sororities, local “social clubs” are prominent on campus. During the school’s homecoming weekend, members of these social clubs perform a musical show called Tiger Tunes. Students younger than 22 who do not live with a parent or guardian must live on campus. More than 20% of students compete on one of Ouachita’s 16 athletic teams, called the Tigers. Nearby Lake DeGray is a popular student destination. Ouachita’s 2014 graduating class was the school’s largest in 30 years. Notable Alumni include former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee and baseball Hall-of-Famer Travis Jackson.

name: Nebraska Wesleyan University
profile: Established in 1887 and affiliated with the United Methodist Church, Nebraska Wesleyan University is a private, liberal arts university located in Lincoln, NE. NWU’s College of Arts and Science offers 25 majors, and the Wesleyan Advantage adult programs offer B.S. degrees in business, criminal justice and social work, among others. NWU hosts an annual Student Symposium, where students present original academic research, host theater performances and present artwork. The institution has produced four Fulbright scholars in a single year on six different occasions since 2000. The school's psychology department is known for its “Xtreme Rat Challenge,” in which students train rats to complete athletic obstacle courses. The NWU Prairie Wolves compete in NCAA Division III and NAIA. The NWU Weary Center also just instituted a new Bike Checkout Program, in which students can rent bicycles on a first-come, first-served basis.

name: Susquehanna University
profile: Susquehanna University is a private liberal arts college in Selinsgrove, PA. It was established in 1858 by Lutherans, and remains affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church to this day. The university offers over 50 majors and minors and students hail from 35 states and 21 countries. Approximately 86% of students live on Susquehanna’s 325-acre campus. For those looking to get involved outside of the classroom, there are nearly 150 student organizations on campus, including a student-run radio station, student orchestral performances and active campus ministry programs. Popular traditions at Susquehanna include Fall Frenzy, a festival held the first weekend of fall semester, and the Christmas Candlelight Service. Susquehanna’s 23 intercollegiate athletic teams compete at the NCAA Division III level.

name: DePaul University
profile: DePaul University was founded by the Vincentians in 1898 and has grown to become the largest Catholic University in the U.S. based on enrollment; it is also one of the largest private universities in the country. Among DePaul University’s notable alumni are U.S. Senate Sergeant at Arms Terrance Gainer, Jack Greenberg, CEO of McDonald’s USA, and basketball great George Mikan. Although DePaul is traditionally Catholic, the student body has a wide array of religious, ethnic and geographic backgrounds. Students are represented by the Student Government Association, an elected body of peers. Campus traditions include 24-hour-a-day study sessions at the school library, as well as FEST, an annual on-campus outdoor concert featuring well-known artists. DePaul competes athletically at the Division I level. The “Blue Demons” basketball team has made the NCAA tournament 18 times with two final four appearances.

name: Chapman University
profile: Established in 1861 as Hesperian College, Chapman University is a private university in Orange, CA. It was founded by the Disciples of Christ. There are nine schools and colleges on campus, an accredited institution for working adults through a network of 26 campuses in California and Washington and virtual platform called Brandman University. Chapman has a campus in Singapore, offering a two-year degree program in creative producing at the Ngee Ann campus in Singapore. The university partners with the “1939” Club, one of the largest and most active Holocaust survivor organizations in the U.S. to host annual Holocaust art and writing contest. Beginning in 1965, Chapman started its “World Campus Afloat” program that evolved into “Semester at Sea.” This program has taken thousands of students and educators around to world to ports such as China, Singapore, South Africa and beyond. Chapman University competes in the NCAA Division III (non-scholarship) level.

name: Xavier University
profile: Established in 1831, Xavier University is a four-year, private university in Cincinnati, OH affiliated with the Jesuit tradition of the Roman Catholic Church. It offers 90 undergraduate majors, 55 minors and 19 graduate programs in its three colleges. Study abroad destinations are located on six continents. The Cintas Institute for Business Ethics at Xavier is a program that facilitates partnerships with the community that promote learning and awareness about social justice issues through advocacy, service and community engagement. The school’s 16 varsity teams compete in NCAA Division I athletics and the Big East conference as the Musketeers. Hinkle Hall is the oldest building on campus, which is largely inspired by castle architecture, and it is designed to look like St. Francis Xavier’s own fortress in Navarre, Spain. The campus sits on 190 acres and its school motto is, “He has seen great wonders.”

name: Oregon State University
profile: Oregon State University is a public research university in Corvallis, OR. It is one of two U.S. universities to be designated a Land Grant, Sea Grant, Space Grant and Sun Grant institution. Founded in 1868, Oregon State’s 12 colleges offer more than 200 undergraduate degrees, over 30 of which are offered online. Students hail from all 50 states and over 100 countries. OSU receives more research funding than all other schools in the Oregon University System combined. Additionally, there are more than 300 clubs and activities. The Craft Center offers studios and classes in many areas, including photography, ceramics and woodworking. The university’s College of Forests operates the nearby Peavy Arboretum, with more than 200 indigenous trees and shrubs, wildlife and trails. Oregon State’s sustainability efforts include the installation of 22 elliptical exercise machines that are hooked up to the electrical grid of the Dixon Recreation Center. There are over 40 intramural leagues and tournaments throughout the academic year. The school’s athletic teams, known as the Beavers, compete in Division I athletics.

name: Marist College
profile: Marist College is a four-year, coeducational, private college located in Poughkeepsie, NY. It was established in 1929 and is one of six institutions of higher learning nationwide that are affiliated with the Franklin D. Roosevelt Presidential Library and Museum. Marist College maintains a long term research partnership with IBM. The college also has an Institute of Public Opinion, which has provided polling data for NBC throughout the 2012 presidential election. Marist College has about 5440 undergraduate students, including about 560 adult continuing education students, and roughly 870 graduate students. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics; its mascot is Shooter the Red Fox.

name: Wesleyan College, Macon
profile: Wesleyan College is a four-year private women’s liberal arts college located in Macon, GA. The college was founded in 1836 and is affiliated with the United Methodist Church. The college has grown to offer 31 undergraduate majors and 28 undergraduate minors. The school’s motto, “First for Women,” is, in fact, true: Wesleyan College was the first college in the world chartered to grant degrees for women. Wesleyan College was also the birthplace of sororities. Alpha chapters of both Alpha Delta Pi and Phi Mu sororities are located on Wesleyan’s campus. Each year, seniors participate in the annual candle lighting ceremony, which marks the induction of seniors to the Wesleyan College Alumnae Association. Wesleyan College competes athletically at the NCAA Division III level with five varsity teams in the Great South Athletic Conference. The school mascot is the wolf.

name: Seattle Pacific University
profile: Seattle Pacific University is a private university in Seattle, WA. It was established in 1891 by the Free Methodist Church of North America. The school’s 40-acre campus is only 10 minutes from downtown Seattle. Seattle Pacific offers more than 50 undergraduate majors. The most popular undergraduate programs on campus are psychology, business administration, nursing, physiology and communication. About 43% of students come from out of state. Students can build entrepreneurial skills through the Social Venture Plan Competition, which allows students to develop a written business plan to address a social need. Teams are judged by local businesspeople and community members. Seattle Pacific’s intercollegiate athletic teams, known as the Falcons, compete at the NCAA Division II level.

name: Drexel University
profile: Drexel University was founded by legendary financier and philanthropist Anthony J. Drexel in 1891. Drexel offers students nearly 200 degree programs through its 14 schools and colleges. Most undergraduate students split their time between classroom study and work experience with up to three periods of full-time, paid employment within their field. Additionally, Drexel is known for its cooperative education program that links students to over 1,500 employers with locations in 30 states and 48 countries. Each year Drexel reports more than $110 million in sponsored research. The Drexel Dragons compete in the NCAA Division I. “The Water Boy Statue,” by French sculptor Frédéric-Auguste Bartholdi, is one of Drexel’s most treasured items and students passing through the Main Building’s Great Court rub the statue’s toe for good luck on exams.

name: University of Northwestern, St. Paul
profile: The University of Northwestern-St. Paul is a private, conservative Christian evangelical college located in Roseville, MN. Students are offered over 70 undergraduate majors, including concentrations in music, business, English, psychology and Biblical studies. Students can study abroad in Israel for a semester or a few weeks in the summer. The institution also hosts regular 10-day study trips in Turkey and Greece. Students participate in Daily Chapel, and each April, hundreds of UNW students and faculty take a day off from class to pray and volunteer in the Twin Cities. Launched by the school in 1949, campus radio station KTIS has become one of the nation’s most popular Christian radio stations. Northwestern College is affiliated with both the NCAA Division III and NCCAA Division I and competes in the Upper Midwest Athletic Conference (UMAC). The school’s athletic teams are nicknamed the Eagles.

name: Drew University
profile: Originally established as a seminary in 1867, the school now includes a college of liberal arts and a graduate studies program. The Madison, NJ, campus is home to themed houses where like-minded students can live together in residence halls such as Earth House, WoCo (a feminist house) or Spirituality. In 1985, Drew became the first liberal arts college to provide students with computers as part of their tuition and fees. Through the Drew International Seminars, students travel abroad to global destinations such as Paris, Dubai or Beijing for a three-week-stay in January or May after taking a semester-long course. The Drew Rangers participate in the NCAA Division III.

name: Siena College
profile: Siena College is a private, Catholic liberal arts college in Loudonville, NY. It was founded in 1937 by seven Franciscan friars. The college offers over 50 major, minor and certificate programs. International studies options are offered in approximately 40 countries. The Center for Undergraduate Research and Creative Activity (CURCA) helps to match students with research opportunities. For those hoping to get involved outside of the classroom, there are more than 60 student groups and organizations on-campus. The Sister Thea Bowman Center for Women promotes social justice for women by hosting events like the Honor an Awesome Woman Brunch and Human Trafficking Week. Students can take advantage of Siena’s location through outdoor activities like skiing, boating and hiking or visit the parks, concert halls and museums that nearby Albany has to offer. Siena’s 18 intercollegiate athletic teams compete at the NCAA Division I level.

name: Seton Hall University
profile: Seton Hall University is a private university in South Orange, NJ. It was founded in 1856 by Bishop James Roosevelt Bayley and remains affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. Seton Hall is the oldest diocesan university in the U.S. Students can choose from more than 90 degree programs with an average class size of 21 students. One notable perk of attending Seton Hall: Each student receives a laptop at orientation, which is upgraded after two years. Graduating seniors are allowed to keep their laptops. Those looking to get involved outside the classroom can take part in more than 130 student organizations, 22 Greek societies and over 25 intramural and club sports. The university also sponsors 14 varsity sports teams, nicknamed the Pirates. Student-athletes mainly compete in the Big East Conference (NCAA Division I). Samuel Alito was an adjunct professor at Seton Hall’s law school prior to his nomination to the United States Supreme Court. Notable attendees include New Jersey Governor Chris Christie (law degree), former Tyco International CEO Dennis Kozlowski and actor Dulé Hill.

name: Northwestern College
profile: Founded in 1882 and affiliated with the Reformed Church in America, Northwestern College defines itself as a Christian academic community. The school offers students over 40 undergraduate majors and students can also participate in pre-professional programs in fields such as law, art therapy, dentistry and medicine. Northwestern students honor the institution’s religious roots by worshipping communally at the on-campus chapel. The institution also hosts a number of Christian retreats each year in South Dakota’s Black Hill Mountains. Volunteerism is integral to the Northwestern experience, with students participating in short spring break mission and service trips to Nicaragua and the Netherlands, as well as California, New York, Mississippi and Florida. Northwestern has established its own study abroad programs in Oman and Romania, and students can also partake in 12 semester-long programs through the Council for Christian College and Universities. Around 40% of Northwestern students, or the “Red Raiders,” participate in 16 intercollegiate sports including football, soccer, tennis and golf.

name: Millsaps College
profile: Millsaps College is a private college in Jackson, MS. It was founded in 1890 by Reuben Webster Millsaps, a businessman and Confederate Army major. The school is affiliated with the United Methodist Church. It was the first college in Mississippi to establish a Phi Beta Kappa chapter. Students hail from over 27 states and 24 countries and can select from over 30 majors. More than 40% of Millsaps students study abroad. The heart of the 100-acre campus is the Millsaps Bowl, which hosts events ranging from annual commencement ceremonies to intramural sports and open-air bazaars. The Blymer Bell has presided over campus for nearly a century. The oldest building at Millsaps is the James Observatory, which has offered students a view of the sky since 1901. The college’s varsity sports teams, nicknamed the Majors, compete in the Southern Athletic Association (SAA) at the NCAA Division III level.

name: Erskine College
profile: Founded in 1839, Erskine College was the first four-year, church-related college in South Carolina and is affiliated with the Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church. Currently, the school has 560 undergraduate students and an additional 213 graduate students. Erskine College offers 21 majors and over 70% of classes have less than 20 students. Erskine’s Winter Term in January, known as “J-Term,” allows students to explore a variety of subjects such as finger-style guitar and fly fishing. Erskine College competes in the NCAA Division II and the school mascot is the Flying Fleet.

name: University of Alabama
profile: Founded in 1831 as Alabama’s first public college, the school offers undergraduate and graduate degrees in more than 200 fields of study. Many incoming freshmen and transfer students choose to participate in Camp 1831, a 3-day orientation program at an off-campus campsite. Greek life is particularly vibrant, with over 29% of the undergraduate student body participating. There are 63 social Greek-letter organizations and in fall 2011 the university earned the title of being the largest Fraternity and Sorority community in the nation. The school has one of the leading football programs in the nation, having won 23 SEC titles and 15 national championships, including the 2013 BCS National Championship and became the first school to win three BCS Titles. They are known as the Crimson Tide and their mascot is Big Al the elephant.

name: University of Kentucky
profile: Located in Lexington, KY, the University of Kentucky is a public research university with well-regarded programs in public affairs, nursing and pharmacy. It boasts the largest pharmacy education building in the world. The most popular areas of study are arts and sciences, business education and engineering. The school’s 12 libraries include about 4,023,000 volumes, over 27,000 linear feet of manuscripts and archives and over 9,000 oral history interviews spanning 250 projects. The University of Kentucky competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is the Wildcat. The school adopted the nickname “wildcat” after Commandant Philip W. Corbusier claimed the Kentucky football team “fought like wildcats” in 1909.

name: Marlboro College
profile: Marlboro College was established in 1946 and has a 300-acre campus with buildings that were originally part of a family farm in Marlboro, VT. Currently, Marlboro has less than 300 undergraduate students and its president, Ellen McCulloch-Lovell, was recently named Chair of the Association of Vermont Independent Colleges. Marlboro College requires students to participate in planning their own programs and act responsibly within a self-governing community to promote independence. While students form their own concentrations, there are 34 fields of study/degree fields offered at Marlboro, from which students choose. Students are given great independence – but they have to earn that right. By the end of second semester, all freshmen are required to pass the Clear Writing Program. That is, submit 20 pages or 5,000 words of non-fiction writing to a committee for evaluation; students whose writing isn’t up to snuff must complete a new portfolio by the end of the following semester. Beginning with the Class of 2013, the college is guaranteeing admission to its Graduate and Professional Studies programs in nearby Brattleboro for Marlboro’s graduating seniors and awarding these students a scholarship equivalent to 50% of the graduate tuition.

name: California State University, Fullerton
profile: California State University, Fullerton is a public university located in Fullerton, CA. It was established in 1957. With more than 30,000 undergraduates enrolled, the university also has a satellite campus in Irvine. The school has nine colleges, offering 55 undergraduate degree programs. In 1960, the university became Orange County’s first college to have a Greek system. CSUF’s spending generates an influence of around $1 billion to local economy and the school sustains almost 9,000 jobs in California. Notable alumni include the award-winning director James Cameron and female NASA astronaut Tracy Caldwell. CSUF's athletic teams compete in Division I-AAA athletics of the NCAA Big West Conference.

name: Coe College
profile: Coe College was created in 1851 in Cedar Rapids, IA, as a private liberal arts college affiliated with the Presbyterian Church. The college claims to have the shortest name of any U.S. institution of higher education. Coe offers more than 40 majors and bachelor’s degrees. Stewart Memorial Library is Coe’s main site that houses gallery spaces featuring collections from Iowa artists. The college’s music department is accredited by the National Association of Schools of Music. Concert bands, concert choir and various student-led music groups perform for the department and fraternities. On Flunk Day, the school’s annual tradition, students skip classes and enjoy a celebration on the quad. The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and the school mascot is the Kohawk, which was created in 1922 by a Coe professor in a mascot contest. The “Ko” derives from the Native American word meaning “like the,” and “hawk” is a nod to Iowa’s status as the Hawkeye State.

name: New School
profile: Located in downtown New York City, The New School's curriculum is “student-driven,” eschewing general education courses and encouraging students to explore topics before focusing on a concentration. It offers over 135 degree and diploma programs in several schools, including the widely respected Parsons New School of Design, New School for Social Research and Mannes College of Music. A small percentage of students elect to study abroad. The popular television show Project Runway is filmed in the Parson’s fashion department. Distinguished alumni include Tennessee Williams, Jack Kerouac, Eleanor Roosevelt, Bradley Cooper, Donna Karan, Marc Jacobs and Marlon Brando. The New School was also the first university to offer the history of film and one of the first to make courses in photography and jazz available.

name: Biola University
profile: Biola University is a private, Christian university of nondenominational affiliation located on a 95-acre campus in La Mirada – not too far from Disneyland and Knott’s Berry Farm. Committed to a biblically-centered, conservative education, Biola requires that its students complete 30 units of biblical studies and each student graduate with a minor in biblical studies. Biola offers more than 40 majors and over 80 concentrations in six schools, as well as degrees in Cinema and Media Arts, which teaches the fundamentals of screenwriting, media management and production, preparing students for careers in neighboring Hollywood. In 2012, an underground LGBTQ group emerged online and posted fliers around campus, causing the school to reiterate its code of standards which prohibits both same-sex relationships and extramarital sex. Biola University teams, nicknamed the Eagles, participate in NAIA competitions.

name: Gordon College
profile: Founded in 1889 as a missionary training institute, Gordon College holds strong to its Christian roots to this day. Students sign a Statement of Faith and a Life and Conduct statement, and regular Chapel attendance is a graduation requirement. The small, private liberal arts school currently offers 38 majors and 42 concentrations. Alcohol and drugs are strictly prohibited on campus and the dorms uphold a strict visitation policy that allows males and females in each other’s rooms only during certain hours. As a part of their effort to “Restore Creation,” Gordon is very progressive in their sustainability efforts. Gordon uses low-flow showerheads, is heated with natural gas and uses energy efficient light bulbs around campus. The Gordon College Fighting Scots participate in the NCAA Division III Commonwealth Coast Conference.

name: Bethel University
profile: Established as Baptist Union Theological Seminary in 1871, Bethel University is an evangelical Christian university, sponsored by the churches of Converge Worldwide and educating students of over 65 Christian denominations in St. Paul, MN. A liberal arts university, Bethel offers more than 100 different undergraduate and advanced degree programs in four different schools. The College of Arts and Sciences offers 88 majors and 43 minors, as well as 11 pre-professional programs. All students in the undergraduate community are required to abide by the “Covenant for Life Together,” or a mandated Biblical lifestyle. Students are expected to refrain from extramarital sex, gambling and drug and alcohol use during the academic year. Around 75% of students study abroad nationally or internationally, with programs in Washington, D.C. and L.A., as well as Turkey, Greece, the Galapagos Islands and Guatemala. The Bethel Royals compete in NCAA Division III sports teams.

name: La Salle University
profile: La Salle University, a private Roman Catholic institution in Philadelphia, PA, was established in 1863 by the Institute of the Brothers of the Christian Schools and named after their founder Saint John Baptist de La Salle. The university has three undergraduate schools: business, arts and sciences, and nursing and health sciences. La Salle has campuses in Bucks and Montgomery counties as well as in Switzerland and the Czech Republic. Students and the public can view artwork from the Renaissance period to the present at the campus museum. A new 10,000-square-foot building housing a fitness center and campus store will be coming to La Salle in spring 2015. La Salle has produced 16 Olympians, three who have won gold and two who have won bronze. A short film entitled “Empty Pages,” which was written, produced and directed by five 2013 La Salle communication graduates, was screened at the Cannes Film Festival last year. Athletic teams compete in NCAA Division I, the school mascot is The Explorer, and the colors are blue and yellow.

name: San Jose State University
profile: San Jose State University is a public university in San Jose, CA. The school’s 154-acre campus encompasses 19 city blocks in metropolitan San Jose. The university offers bachelor’s and master’s degrees in 134 study areas. There are nearly 400 student clubs and organizations on campus, including around 40 fraternities and sororities. San Jose State offers study abroad programs in 55 countries. The university is also home to a few unique centers: the Ira F. Brilliant Center for Beethoven Studies and the Martha Heasley Cox Center for Steinbeck Studies. The school’s student-athletes compete in the Mountain West Conference at the NCAA Division I level. Teams are known as the Spartans.

name: CUNY, Brooklyn College
profile: Located in Brooklyn, NY, the college describes New York City as a living classroom. The campus consists of 13 buildings on a 35-acre campus. The campus abides by its motto “Nil sine magno labore,” which means, “Nothing without great effort.” Brooklyn College offers 120 undergraduate and graduate degree programs that concentrate in creative arts, humanities, social, behavioral and natural sciences, math, education, and business. The B.A.-M.D. Program, one of the most prestigious programs in Brooklyn College, offers an 8-year path to an M.D. degree in conjunction with SUNY Downstate College of Medicine. Only 15 students are admitted to the freshmen cohort. The Scholars Program selects students with strong writing ability and academic standing and award them Presidential Scholarships every year. Diversity is an important value on campus, and Brooklyn college students represent 150 various nations and speak 105 languages. Brooklyn College teams, known as the Bulldogs, compete in NCAA’s Division III.

name: Saint John's College (NM)
profile: Saint John’s College is a private liberal arts college in Santa Fe, NM. Established in 1964, it is located 7,300 feet above sea level in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains. Over the course of their time on campus, students must take four years of mathematics, language and interdisciplinary study, three years of laboratory sciences, one year of music and two eight-week elective discussions. Throughout the year students will work through the "great books" reading list, which includes works from Homer and Plato to Einstein and W.E.B. Du Bois. Faculty members do not hold office hours. Instead, they are available outside of their teaching hours and are often found tutoring students in the Coffee Shop. The college also offers ski and snowboarding trips, rafting trips, rock climbing trips, and more. Saint John’s has one of the few student-run search and rescue teams in the country.

name: Messiah College
profile: Messiah College, located in Grantham, PA, was established in 1909 by the Brethren in Christ Church and is now affiliated with the Anabaptist, Pietist and Wesleyan traditions of the Christian Church. The school started as a bible school and in the early 1950s began offering four-year college programs in religious education and theology. Today there are more than 80 academic majors and a student body of around 3,000 students. Some majors offer three-year degree programs. Messiah also has campuses in Philadelphia (in partnership with Temple University) and in downtown Harrisburg. During finals week, students take part in a collective “Midnight Scream.” The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics and its mascot is the Falcon recently named Fandango.

name: Michigan Technological University
profile: Michigan Technological University was founded in 1885 as a training school for mining engineers named Michigan Mining School. From 1925 to 1935, the school changed its name from Michigan Mining School to the Michigan College of Mining and Technology. Eventually, the school officially changed its name to Michigan Technological University (Michigan Tech) in 1964. Today about 49% of students enroll in engineering programs, but the school also offers more than 130 degree programs. Many traditions are carried on campus such as K-Day (Keweenaw Day), a fall semester event with live music, food and activities. Michigan Tech holds the world record for the largest snowball measuring over 21 feet and for the largest snowball fight with 3,762 participants. This school competes in NCAA Division II, and its teams are called the Huskies.

name: University of the Pacific
profile: The oldest chartered university in California, it was established in 1851 by pioneer Methodist ministers as California Wesleyan College. Today, the University of the Pacific offers students more than 80 majors through its ten schools. On campus there are eight active Greek houses—four sororities and four fraternities. The university emphasizes sustainability with its MOVE (Mountains, Ocean, Valley Experience) program, which gives students the opportunity to take part in sustainability service projects. Many movies have been filmed or partially filmed on the university’s campus due to its resemblance to East Coast Ivy League institutions. The university competes athletically at the NCAA Division II level with 16 varsity teams in the West Coast Conference. The school mascot is the Tiger.

name: Brigham Young University, Idaho
profile: Founded in 1888, Brigham Young University, ID, is the state’s largest private university. As the school is affiliated with The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the vast majority of the student population is Mormon. The school adheres to a strict Honor Code, which controls dress and daily grooming habits, church attendance and prohibits premarital sex and the consumption of drugs and alcohol. BYU offers students more than a dozen associate degrees as well as approximately 80 bachelor’s degrees through its eight colleges and 33 departments. The BYU Idaho Viking sports teams were phased out in the 2000s, but the school has a thriving intramural athletics program. Prominent alumni include two-time Olympic medalist in Greco-Roman wrestling Rulon Gardner and Matt Lindstrom, Major League baseball pitcher for the Chicago White Sox.

name: Eckerd College
profile: Given Eckerd College’s waterfront location in the Gulf of Mexico in St. Petersburg, FL, it's not surprising that the school is well-known for its marine science and environmental studies programs. Established in 1958 and affiliated with the Presbyterian Church, Eckerd now offers students 40 majors, 44 minors and five pre-professional programs. During the unique freshmen orientation known as Autumn Term, students take one class for three weeks in August. Eckerd College Search and Rescue – the only volunteer student group in the country recognized by the U.S. Coast Guard – responds to more than 500 calls for help each year. Dennis Lehane, author of "Mystic River," "Shutter Island" and "Gone, Baby, Gone," graduated from Eckerd and now leads the hugely popular Writers in Paradise conference. According to “The Eckerd Edge Guarantee,” graduates who are not employed or in graduate school within six months of graduation may audit up to four classes at no cost and receive one-on-one coaching from an Eckerd Career Services professional. The Eckerd College Tritons compete in the NCAA Division II.

name: Washington & Jefferson College
profile: Washington & Jefferson College was founded in 1781 by a group of pioneering Presbyterian ministers in Washington, PA. It has since grown to offer 32 majors and 27 minors as well as pre-law and pre-health programs. Students have study abroad options in many countries with 40 approved programs. The college follows a 4-1-4 academic schedule to provide students with flexibility to do internships and other studies during their three week intersession in January. Each year, nearly $40 million in scholarships and financial aid is awarded to nearly every student on campus. Washington & Jefferson competes in NCAA Division III athletics; its mascots are George Washington and Thomas Jefferson. In 1922, Washington & Jefferson College competed in the Rose Bowl and played the only scoreless tie game in Rose Bowl history against the University of California.

name: California State University, Long Beach
profile: California State University, Long Beach is a public university founded in 1949. This urban school that is part of the 23-campus California State University System opened as the “Los Angeles-Orange County State College” and was later renamed. Steven Spielberg studied at the University in the 1970’s but left before graduating to pursue his film career. However, he returned to Long Beach to fulfill a promise he made to his parents and completed his degree in 2002 – the same year as notable alum, two-time Olympic volleyball gold medalist Misty May-Treanor. Other famed alumni include David Twohy, who co-wrote the screenplay for the Academy Award winning film The Fugitive, and Linda Woolverton, who produced the screenplays for Disney films Beauty and the Beast and The Lion King. Today, the school’s 18 men’s and women’s athletic teams are commonly referred to as the 49ers and compete in NCAA Division I athletics.

name: Wagner College
profile: Wagner College was founded in 1883 as the Lutheran Proseminary of Rochester, NY, to train Lutheran ministers. After John G. Wagner gifted the school $12,000 to purchase a new campus, the board of trustees renamed the school Wagner College, in honor of the benefactor’s son, who had died before realizing his dream of becoming a minister. Today Wagner’s scenic 105-acre campus, resides on Grymes Hill in Staten Island, once the estate of the Cunard shipping-line dynasty. Manhattan is just one 25-minute, free ferry ride away. Students benefit from the school’s unique curriculum known as The Wagner Plan, which combines traditional liberal arts with applied experiences like internships and community service. The most popular undergraduate majors are biological sciences, business, psychology and education. By spring of their senior year, 84% of students have participated in an internship or field experience. An impressive 71% of freshmen and 87% of seniors have participated in community-service or volunteer work.

name: Berea College
profile: Berea College, a private liberal arts work college located in Berea, KY, covers all tuition and admits only academically promising students, primarily those with limited financial resources from Appalachia. The school offers over 30 degree programs, and students are required to participate in a work-study program, logging at least 10 hours per week in campus and service jobs. It also provides significant funding to students who wish to study abroad through the Global Education Opportunity scholarships—which covers up to 75% of the cost of a semester abroad. A record 13 Berea College students were awarded the Benjamin A. Gilman International Scholarship to study abroad this year. The Berea Mountaineers has 14 teams in the NAIA, but was provisionally accepted into NCAA Division III in 2014. There are also intramural disc golf, flag football and dodge ball teams, among others. Notable alumni include John Fenn, 2002 Nobel Prize recipient, and Juanita M. Kreps, former U.S. Secretary of Commerce.

name: Merrimack College
profile: Merrimack College is a private college located in North Andover, MA. It was established in 1947 and is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. Merrimack College has over 2,400 students and offers over 30 majors in the liberal arts, sciences, engineering, business and education. Merrimack emphasizes interactive classes and small group project work. A dining hall employee known as Sparky has been greeting students for more than 30 years, and the school has celebrated her tenure by naming the dining hall after her. During finals week on campus the college hosts “Cram Jam,” a late-night, all-you-can-eat breakfast with live music. It competes in NCAA Division II athletics and NCAA Division I men’s hockey.

name: University of Maryland, Baltimore County
profile: The University of Maryland, Baltimore County occupies a 500-acre campus in Baltimore, MD, just 15 minutes from Baltimore’s Inner Harbor and 30 minutes from Washington D.C. It was established in 1807. It trains among the largest number of IT degree recipients of any university in the country. It is Maryland’s only public health, law and human services university. It offers 42 majors and 41 minors along with 20 certificate programs. It features a research park designed to turn ideas into successful businesses and is one of the top recipients of NASA research funding. It competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is the Chesapeake Bay Retriever, which is also the state dog of Maryland.

name: University of Mississippi
profile: Founded in 1848, Ole Miss is a public research university that is the flagship of the state’s higher education system. Its libraries are home to almost 1.9 million volumes and features the Hall of Mississippi Writers and James Meredith’s papers. The university owns late author William Faulkner’s home and houses the world’s largest archive of blues recordings; B. B. King donated his entire personal record collection to the school. The school’s 14 varsity teams compete in NCAA Division I competition as the Rebels, and the school colors are navy blue and cardinal red.

name: Concordia College-Moorhead
profile: Concordia College, Moorhead was dedicated in 1891 and is affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America. The college offers more than 60 majors and over 10 pre-professional programs, the most popular being international business and global studies. There are nine languages offered on campus. Under the core curriculum, first-year students are required to take courses in religion, culture, health and communication. On campus, about one-third of the student body participates in one or more of the 19 college music ensembles. Concordia faculty music professionals give more than 700 private lessons weekly. The school’s famous choir, Concordia Choir, travels and performs internationally. The Concordia Cobbers compete in NCAA Division III athletics, and the nickname originated from the cornfields that once surrounded the campus. Clint Hill, ’54, was a Secret Service agent who is credited with saving the first lady’s life when President Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas in 1963.

name: University of Illinois, Chicago
profile: The public research university offers 82 bachelor, 93 masters and 66 doctoral degrees through its 15 colleges. Its college of medicine is one of the largest in the country and is a major part of the Illinois Medical District, which contributes about $3.3 billion to the local economy and supports 50,000 jobs. The university recently went completely tobacco-free. The University of Illinois, Chicago, competes in NCAA Division I athletics as “the Flames,” and its mascot is Sparky D. Dragon -- both references to the Great Chicago Fire of 1871.

name: Arizona State University
profile: President Michael Crow has spent his 12-year tenure at Arizona State University working to transform the Tempe, AZ institution into a “New American University.” He has merged the multi-campus institution into a single entity – sharing students, faculty and accreditation, and has grown efforts in online degrees. ASU is now the largest public university in the country by enrollment. The school opened its largest single research facility in 2012, the Interdisciplinary Science and Technology Building IV, designed for the School of Earth and Space Exploration, Security and Defense Systems Initiative and the Schools of Engineering. Athletic teams compete in the NCAA Division I, and the school mascot is Sparky the Sun Devil. A 60-foot tall “A” was built using reinforced steel and concrete in 1955, turning “A” mountain into a very well-known campus attraction. Channeling their inner Sun Devils, participants annually climb to the top of “A” mountain with lanterns to light up Tempe on the Friday night before the Homecoming game. Donald Johanson, founder of the world’s best-known fossil, “Lucy,” in 1974, is also the founding director of the university’s Institute of Human Origins.

name: Hamline University
profile: Hamline University is a four-year, coeducational, private university located in Saint Paul, MN. It was established in 1854 and is affiliated with the United Methodist Church. Hamline is one of 283 Phi Beta Kappa institutions in the country; the honor society was founded in 1776 and counts Bill Clinton and Condoleezza Rice as members. At Hamline, 100% of students complete an internship, collaborative research project or field-based research before they graduate. Currently, the university has 1,900 undergraduate students and an additional 2,900 graduate students. Hamline University competes in the NCAA Division III, and the school’s mascot is the Piper.

name: Franciscan University of Steubenville
profile: Franciscan University of Steubenville opened its doors in 1946 to serve local veterans returning from World War II. It is a private Catholic university located near Pittsburgh, PA. Today the school offers 42 undergraduate majors and 32 minors as well as seven graduate programs. The most popular majors include business administration, nursing and theology. Students have the opportunity to live in Faith Households, groups of three or more men or women who share a similar Gospel vision expressed in a written pledge. The university coordinates domestic and international mission trips during breaks. The Austria Program is a study abroad experience where students head to Gaming, Austria to study history, philosophy, theology, art history and language. Franciscan University of Steubenville is a NCAA Division III school.

name: Mississippi State University
profile: Mississippi State University is a public research university in Mississippi State, MS. It was founded in 1878. The university offers over 160 bachelor’s, master’s and doctoral degrees. Undergraduate programs range from agribusiness to music education. The focal point of the central grounds of the 4,200-acre campus is the Junction, a green that often serves as a gathering place for students. The Mitchell Memorial Library and its branch locations house over 2 million volumes; the library is home to the Ulysses S. Grant Collection. There are more than 300 registered student organizations on campus, including 31 fraternity and sorority chapters. The annual Bulldog Bash has helped kicked off the football season since 1999, drawing crowds of up to 35,000. Mississippi State’s intercollegiate athletic teams, known as the Bulldogs and Lady Bulldogs, compete in the Southeastern Conference (SEC) at the NCAA Division I level. The school’s mascot is an English Bulldog named “Bully.”

name: Mount Saint Mary's College
profile: Mount St. Mary’s College is a private liberal arts college located on two campuses in Los Angeles, CA. The college was founded in 1925 and is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. Its traditional undergraduate programs are for women only, though the school offers co-ed graduate and weekend baccalaureate programs. It is the only Catholic liberal arts school geared toward women in the western U.S. The college’s proximity to Hollywood makes it among the most filmed schools in the nation. Mount St. Mary’s is a member of the Women in Public Service Project, which aims to educate future female leaders who are committed to global public service. Approximately two-thirds of students take part in community service work. There are over 30 student organizations at Mount St. Mary’s, ranging from academic to Greek and service clubs.

name: Kansas State University
profile: Founded in 1863 during the Civil War, Kansas State University was the one of the country’s first land-grant colleges. Undergraduates can choose from more than 250 majors and degree options. From a survey recently distributed, 97% of recent graduates said they would recommend the university. Six U.S. presidents and eight foreign heads of state have given lectures at K-State. The main campus is located in Manhattan, KS, also known as the Little Apple, a classic college town with more than 52,000 residents. Sports teams are called the Wildcats and participate in the NCAA's Division I and the Big 12 Conference. K-State has only one official color, Royal Purple. The Call Hall Dairy Bar serves student-made ice cream and dairy products; students produce over 20,000 gallons of ice cream annually.

name: George Fox University
profile: George Fox University was established in 1885 in Newberg, OR, as the Friends Pacific Academy by Quaker pioneers. It was later renamed after the founder of the Quaker movement, George Fox, in 1949. The university, a member of the Council for Christian Colleges and Universities, is now the third largest private college in Oregon with satellite campuses in Portland, Salem and Redmond. GFU offers six seminary degrees, 12 master’s and doctoral degrees, and more than 40 majors. GFU is often recognized for being a top choice university for non-drinkers or drug-users. Students are required to sign lifestyle agreements, which include attendance in chapel and current event gatherings as well as an obligation to participate in service projects. The GFU Bruins are a NCAA Division III school. The school just launched an $800,000 fundraising campaign for its baseball team to improve the team’s facilities.

name: Oklahoma State University
profile: Oklahoma State University is a public research university in Stillwater, OK. It was established in 1890. The school’s six colleges offer more than 200 majors to students hailing from all 50 states and 120 countries. Students can take advantage of OSU’s high research activity through activities like the Freshman Research program and the Wentz Research Projects, which give undergraduates a chance to gain hands-on research experience. OSU’s Learning and Student Success Opportunities (LASSO) Center provides free advising, tutoring, and success coaching for all students. Oklahoma State also offers the world’s first Ph.D. in Unmanned Aerial Systems. Besides research opportunities, the university offers a robust student group population—there are more than 450 student organizations on campus. It has one of the largest student unions in the world. The university is known for its homecoming festivities, which include the “walkaround,” when visitors tour fraternity and sorority house decorations, and a Saturday parade. Athletes compete in the Big 12 Conference and is one of the NCAA’s most storied schools: The school has won 51 national championships.

name: Washington State University
profile: Washington State University is a public research university located in Pullman, WA. WSU has 12 colleges and schools and offers students 90 fields of undergraduate study. The school also offers study abroad programs in about 18 countries throughout the world. WSU houses live grizzly bears to research hibernation and understand how the heart can adapt to stressful conditions. In addition to bears, the university also has its own golf course. There is a host of sports and outdoor activities available to students. There are Pac-12 athletic events where students can cheer on peers in various sports such as football, basketball, volleyball and rowing. For the outdoorsy types, there is nearby camping, mountain biking, snow skiing and rafting. Paul Allen, billionaire co-founder of Microsoft, attended Washington State University for two years before dropping out to accept a job in Boston. He later convinced Bill Gates to drop out of college in order to create Microsoft. Washington State University competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is the Cougar.

name: Rochester Institute of Technology
profile: Rochester Institute of Technology is a career-oriented private university located in Rochester, NY. Students from all 50 states and over 100 countries attend RIT. The school’s brick buildings span across a 1,300-acre campus that features extensive woodland and wetland. International campuses are located in Croatia, Kosovo and Dubai. The university emphasizes cooperative education, combining traditional classroom-based learning with career-related work experience. Each year more than 3,500 students participate in 5,500 co-op assignments around the globe. RIT offers degrees from nine colleges, including the National Technical Institute for the Deaf, the world’s largest technical college for students who are deaf or hard of hearing. NTID students comprise nearly 10% of the university’s total enrollment. Students and faculty members showcase everything from homemade electric vehicles to metal sculptures at the Imagine RIT: Innovation and Creativity Festival, a campus-wide exposition that draws up to 30,000 visitors each year. The men’s and women’s ice hockey teams play at the Division I level, while all other RIT Tigers compete in Division III athletics.

name: Central College
profile: Central College was founded in 1853 by a group of pioneer settlers. It was religiously affiliated with the Baptist Church but is now affiliated with the Reformed Church in America. The private liberal arts college provides 73 academic programs including majors, minors and pre-professional studies. One dean follows each class of students through all four years, along with class directors, and serves as a resource for students during their time at Central. The college provides two off-campus programs in Chicago and Washington D.C. In both cities, students have the opportunities to take internships and attend seminars organized by professionals. Two unique elements of Central College’s curriculum are active civic engagement and environmental stewardship with a number of courses requiring a service-learning component. Nearly half of the student population participates in study abroad programs. About 76% of Central students complete at least one internship or pre-professional experience. Four of the 18 music ensembles perform internationally. Athletic teams, nicknamed the Central Dutch, compete in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: SUNY, Albany (University at Albany)
profile: The oldest school in the SUNY system, the State University of New York, Albany was established in 1844. Located in the state capital, SUNY Albany is a public research university that offers 118 majors and minors plus 138 master’s, doctoral and graduate certificate programs. The university provides students with more than 500 study abroad opportunities in over 50 countries. Albany’s 19 varsity teams compete in NCAA Division I athletics and the mascot is Damien the Great Dane. Notable alumni include gay rights pioneer Harvey Milk and writer of “Wicked” Gregory Maguire. The university celebrates when it was awarded the world records for the largest games of pillow fighting and musical chairs on Guinness day each year. There are more than 200 clubs and student organizations on campus.

name: Randolph College
profile: Randolph College is a private liberal arts college in Lynchburg, VA. It was founded in 1891 as Randolph-Macon Woman’s College. The school began accepting men with the class of 2011. Students hail from 36 states and 20 countries and can select from 30 majors and 44 minors. Randolph offers the option to design your own major. There are five colleges and 16,000 students in the Lynchburg area and Randolph’s 100-acre campus is just minutes from the hiking and biking trails of the scenic Blue Ridge Mountains. The school is known for many unique traditions: Graduating classes square off against one another in the friendly, yearlong Even and Odd Rivalry, and students have performed a traditional Greek play every other year since 1909. Nearly 30% of Randolph students play on one of the school’s varsity athletic teams, nicknamed the WildCats. Randolph College competes in the Old Dominion Athletic Conference of the NCAA Division III.

name: William Jewell College
profile: Founded in 1849, William Jewell College is located in Liberty, MO. At Jewell, the motto “live what you learn” isn’t just talk: Students are encouraged to personalize their learning experience through a unique, self-designed major -- a cinch with an average class size of 16. There are also 40 traditional majors and 10 pre-professional programs offered. Students are able to choose from 23 study abroad locations plus the school has an Oxbridge Honors Program, which allows students to take tutorials in their major Oxford or Cambridge. Since 2006, the school has produced two Fulbright Scholars, two Goldwater Scholars and two Rhodes Scholar national finalists. About 96% of graduates have acquired jobs or are accepted into graduate school within six months of graduation. William Jewell College athletic teams compete in NCAA Division II with 20 varsity sports teams in the Great Lakes Valley Conference.

name: Saint Vincent College
profile: Saint Vincent College is a Roman Catholic liberal arts college of the Benedictine tradition located in Latrobe, PA. The college was founded in 1846 and was the first Benedictine monastery in the U.S.; some monks continue to teach courses at the college. The College is organized into four schools, each with distinct departments and major and minor programs. There are nearly 50 undergraduate majors as well as 29 graduate programs. President John F. Kennedy received an honorary degree of law in 1958, prompting the construction of Kennedy Hall, which contains a gymnasium, swimming pool, student union and fitness center. The college has served as the training camp host of the Pittsburgh Steelers since 1966. Vincent College competes in NCAA Division III athletics and the school mascot is the Bearcat.

name: Salisbury University
profile: Salisbury University is a public university in Salisbury, MD. It first opened its doors in 1925 as a two-year college. Students can take advantage of Salisbury’s unique location—just 30 miles from beaches and less than three hours from Baltimore and Washington, D.C. The university offers 43 undergraduate majors, 61 minors and 14 graduate degree programs. The most popular majors at Salisbury are biology, nursing, elementary education, exercise science and communication arts. Starting in fall of 2014, the school will begin offering a doctor of education degree (Ed.D.). Salisbury’s 140-acre campus is home to an arboretum with more than 2,000 species of trees, shrubs, vines and perennials. Salisbury’s student-athletes compete at the NCAA Division III level.

name: Louisiana Tech University
profile: Founded in 1894, the mid-size four-year institution has a student body more than half the size of the population in its rural home of Ruston, LA. The “Thingery,” a group managed by Louisiana Tech’s Center for Entrepreneurship and Information Technology (CEnIT), fosters interdisciplinary collaboration between the university’s students, faculty, and staff focusing on innovation and entrepreneurship in engineering and technology. Global_Campus is the university’s online education platform that grants degrees and certifications to students learning from a distance, including international students, members of the military and dual enrollment students. Known as the Bulldogs, the university has a NCAA Division I athletic program which sends athletes to professional leagues, including former Pittsburgh Steelers quarterback Terry Bradshaw and Utah Jazz power forward Karl Malone.

name: New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology
profile: Located in the Rio Grande Valley, NM and the beneficiary of a state trust, the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology experiences over 300 days of sunshine each year. The institution specializes in science and engineering, offering over 30 B.S. degrees in technology, the sciences, engineering and management. While no majors are offered in the humanities, minors are available in history, literature and philosophy. New Mexico Tech also features a 2.4-meter telescope and maintains a permanent observatory in Antarctica on Mount Erebus. Professors and students use the observatory to conduct research on the nearby active volcano and its lava lake. The campus is also home to an 18-hole championship golf course and a large outdoor swimming pool.

name: Appalachian State University
profile: Surrounded by the Blue Ridge Mountains, Appalachian State University, originally Watauga Academy, was founded in 1899 to educate teachers from the mountains of northwest North Carolina. It was renamed in 1967 and now offers bachelor’s degrees in more than 150 majors. Appalachian is a major researcher in alternative energy and economic development that benefits the region and beyond. More than 200 Appalachian students take elective entrepreneurship courses each academic year. The university offers study abroad programs on nearly every continent, and students can choose between approximately 200 foreign sites. Recreationally, Appalachian students are offered a variety of outdoor activities such as kayaking, snowboarding, climbing and hiking.

name: Christopher Newport University
profile: Christopher Newport University was established in 1960 as a two-year branch of the College of William & Mary and became a full university in 1992. Located in Newport News, VA, the public liberal arts university is named after Captain Christopher Newport, the English sailor who captained the largest of the three ships carrying settlers to Jamestown. CNU offers more than 80 areas of concentrations with a faculty to student ratio of 1:19. There are five centers available for students to conduct research in: public policy, human rights, American studies, applied research and community engagement. The President Leadership Program is designed for students who want to change the world with a focus on leadership skills. The program includes stipends for students to study abroad, pursue internships and provides scholarship support and meetings with top leaders. The school’s Ferguson Center for the Arts is a 1725-seat concert hall, a 453-seat music and theater hall and a 200-seat studio theatre. It opened in 2005 and has since welcomed more than 600,000 viewers for performances by Tony Bennett, Queen Latifah, Whoopi Goldberg and the London Synmphony Orchestra. As a tradition, every freshman receives a penny at the start of his or her CNU career, and on graduation day the students throw the same penny into Geese Fountain. The university’s athletic teams, nicknamed the Captains, participate in NCAA Division III athletics. CNU moved from the USA South Athletic Conference to the Capital Athletic Conference last year.

name: Hollins University
profile: Hollins University was founded in 1842 as Valley Union Seminary. The school became a female-only institution in 1852 and is one of the oldest universities for women in the U.S. While the undergraduate population is female-only, men are accepted into Hollins’ graduate programs. A strong creative writing curriculum makes English the most popular major. Other popular majors include psychology, studio art, business and biology. Hollins was an early adopter of the study abroad program. The university offered students the opportunity to study in Paris in 1955. Today, students have many more options including London, Ghana, Japan and South Africa. Nearly half of the students choose to study abroad during their undergraduate studies, and another 65% complete an internship in businesses, nonprofits, law firms, museums and hospitals. Each year a day of classes are canceled in October to allow students and faculty to participate in the long standing tradition called Tinker Day. The celebration, which dates back to the 1880s, consists of students and faculty dressing up in colorful outfits and weird costumes to climb Tinker Mountain. Hollins competes at the NCAA Division III level in the Old Dominion Athletic Conference. Hollins alumni include photographer Sally Mann and writer Annie Dillard, one of the school’s three Pulitzer Prize winners.

name: Birmingham-Southern College
profile: Established in 1918 as a merger between Southern University and Birmingham College, Birmingham-Southern College is a private liberal arts institution affiliated with the Methodist Church in Birmingham, AL. The college offers bachelor’s degrees in over 50 areas of study, as well as individualized majors and dual degree programs. Collaborations between faculty and students are encouraged: Contract-learning opportunities are also offered throughout the year, in which students participate in an independent study or internship for academic credit under the supervision of a faculty member. The BSC Panthers compete in NCAA Division III athletics. There are six fraternities and six sororities on campus, and every January the college sponsors “Mama’s Home Cooking,” where parents make home-cooked meal for students who live on campus.

name: Towson University
profile: Towson University is located in Towson, MD and was established in 1866. Today the university offers 65 undergraduate degree programs, including an Honors College. The College of Business and Economics is the second-largest undergraduate business school in the University System of Maryland. Towson mandates a strong core curriculum, beginning with the Towson Seminar and continuing with mandatory English, math, science, arts and U.S. history classes. The school is also home to a strong Army and Air Force ROTC program. Towson participates in the Cherry Hill Learning Zone, a community outreach effort in which students and faculty work to support high school students in southern Baltimore. Towson Unplugged, TU’s wireless network, spans 328 acres and is one of the largest Wifi networks in Baltimore. The Towson Tigers compete in 19 NCAA Division I varsity teams, winning league titles in football, baseball, lacrosse, swimming, soccer and golf. The university is home to an 11,000-seat stadium, as well as the SECU arena, a 5,200-seat venue open in the fall of 2013.

name: Morehouse College
profile: Morehouse College is a private, all-male college in Atlanta, GA. It was the first historically black college to produce a Rhodes Scholar. Founded in 1867, Morehouse has consistently been one of the nation’s premier HBCUs. Students can select from 26 majors across three areas of study. The college’s 66-acre campus has been home to many prominent alumni, including Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., filmmaker Spike Lee and actor Samuel L. Jackson. President Barack Obama delivered the school’s 2013 commencement address. Current students can make their marks on Morehouse’s storied history through the more than 70 student organizations on campus, which includes five recognized fraternities. The annual Spring Fest closes out the semester with festivities that include a drive-in movie, awards banquet and the Miss Maroon & White Pageant. The Morehouse College Glee Club, which dates back to 1911, tours the globe. The Morehouse College Martin Luther King, Jr. Collection features approximately 10,000 items from Dr. King’s personal library. Morehouse’s student-athletes compete in the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Conference (SIAC) at the NCAA Division II level.

name: Georgetown College
profile: Georgetown College is a private liberal arts school located in Georgetown, KY. Founded in 1829, Georgetown is affiliated with the Baptist Church. Georgetown offers 44 undergraduate majors and 53 minors, including a new degree program in sports administration. The school has produced five Rhodes Scholars and 31 Fullbright Scholars.By 2014 the College had eliminated all of its speech codes and now stands as one of the most protected free speech schools in America. The school has four national fraternities and sororities. The Maskrafters is the oldest collegiate theater company in Kentucky and is focused on generating original pieces. Songfest, an annual tradition, involves students writing and performing skits for a variety of awards. Georgetown College participates in the NAIA in the Mid-South Conference. In 2014, their men’s basketball team won the NAIA championship for the second time in the school’s history.

name: John Brown University
profile: John Brown University is a private university located in Siloam Springs, AR. Founded in 1919 and a member of the Council for Christian Colleges and Universities, JBU maintains a strict set of conservative Christian values, and students are expected to follow suit, signing a covenant that outlines practices to strive for (honoring the scripture, living with integrity) and avoid (occult practices, sex outside of marriage, theft). The school offers a wide range of biblical studies majors such as outdoor leadership ministries and youth & worship ministries. This year, the student ministries program will travel to Uganda, Ireland and Lithuania. Students looking to pursue careers in renewable energy are able to gain on-the-job experience at the 60-foot wind turbine on campus, while those who wish to pursue biology may use the cadaver lab for hands-on learning. Other popular majors at JBU include digital media and engineering. The university recently announced an anonymous, $6 million donation for a new nursing facility to open in fall 2016. The university competes in NAIA Division I, and the school mascot is the Golden Eagle.

name: Missouri University of Science and Technology
profile: Missouri University of Science and Technology is a public university in Rolla, MO. It is part of the University of Missouri system. Founded in 1870, it is one of the oldest technological schools west of the Mississippi River. Students can select from approximately 97 degree programs. While the university is known for its strong engineering programs, it also offers arts and humanities degrees. The university promotes undergraduate research: there are over 25 research centers, labs and institutes on campus and the majority of students graduate with research experience. One of the most notable campus features is a partial reconstruction of Stonehenge. The university used around 160 tons of granite to construct the monument, which was dedicated on the 1984 summer solstice. The school has spent more than $60 million in residence hall construction and renovation over the past five years. Missouri S&T’s eight men’s and seven women’s teams, the Miners and Lady Miners, mostly compete at the NCAA Division II level.

name: University of Houston
profile: Founded in 1927, the public research university offers over 300 degree programs throughout its 13 academic colleges and more than 40 research centers. The most popular undergraduate areas of study are social sciences, business, natural sciences and mathematics and technology. UH is home to one of the only space architecture graduate programs in the country. Each year the university celebrates Frontier Fiesta, a student-run event that features free live concerts, variety shows performed by student organization and a barbecue cook-off. Notable alumni include actors Dennis and Randy Quaid, Neiman Marcus CEO Karen Katz and golf legend Fred Couples.The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is Shasta the Cougar. Before a big game, fans rub the paws of cougar statues on campus for good luck.

name: Saint Mary's University, San Antonio
profile: Saint Mary’s University, San Antonio was founded by the Society of Mary, or Marianists, in 1852, making it the oldest Catholic university in the Southwest. The school to this day maintains ties to the Marianist tradition and the Catholic Church. The college offers students 44 academic programs and pre-professional programs including medicine, pharmacy and law. Unique programs include an evening law program, a one-year M.B.A. and three forensic science choices. The school also offers an acceleration law program, which enables undergraduates to earn both a bachelor’s degree and a law degree in just six years. In 1960, four students who went on a spelunking trek near New Braunfels stumbled upon one of the state’s largest and most majestic cave systems. It was later discovered to be a part of the Natural Bridge Caverns. Saint Mary’s University, San Antonio competes in NCAA Division II athletics and the school mascot is the Rattler, who is said to have been derived from the need to constantly clear diamondback rattlesnakes from the football practice field.

name: University of Cincinnati
profile: A public research university that attracts students from all 50 states and 100 countries, with strong programs in music, design, criminology and medicine, among other areas. The university offers over 100 bachelor degrees, over 300 degree granting programs and over 600 total programs of study. Distinguished alumni include President William Howard Taft and Joseph B. Strauss, constructor of the Golden Gate Bridge. The University of Cincinnati competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is the Bearcat.

name: Bellarmine University
profile: Established in 1950, Bellarmine University is an independent, private Catholic liberal arts institution located on 144 acres on the edge of downtown Louisville, KY. It offers its students over 50 majors in seven colleges and schools, as well as study abroad opportunities in over 50 countries on six continents. Nearly 75% of all Bellarmine students complete one or more internships for academic credit. Bellarmine students compete in NCAA Division II athletics, with the only Division I lacrosse team in the state. In 2011, the Bellarmine Knights won the NCAA Men’s Division II Basketball Championship. In 2011, Bellarmine opened a new 540-seat dining hall with indoor and outdoor seating and a 25-foot panoramic window of the state’s rolling hills. The Thomas Merton Center, located in the W.L. Lyons Brown Library, holds over 50,000 items— including drawings, photographs, audio taped conferences and pieces from the Catholic writer’s own library, the largest Thomas Merton collection in the world.

name: SUNY, College at New Paltz
profile: The university traces its roots to the New Paltz Classical School, founded in 1828, which taught Greek, Latin, and reading, writing and arithmetic. In 1948, it became one of the founding intuitions of the State University of New York system. It offers 105 undergraduate and 50 graduate programs; popular areas include psychology, early childhood and childhood education and communication disorders. The Samuel Dorksy Museum of Art is one of the largest museums in the SUNY system, housing more than 5,000 works of American Art and 19th through 21st century photography, and more. The campus library is named after Sojourner Truth, an African-American abolitionist and women’s rights advocate, who was born in Ulster County, where the college is located. The varsity athletic teams, known as the Hawks, compete in at the NCAA Division III level.

name: CUNY, Lehman College
profile: Founded in 1931 as the Bronx campus of Hunter College, Lehman College gained independent status in 1967. It is a public liberal arts college offering over 90 degree programs, including 10 interdisciplinary programs. The Lehman Scholars Program, designed for highly motivated students, operates small seminars, mentorship and extra-credit options to introduce the liberal arts in various disciplines. All first-year students participate in the Freshman Year Initiative, which allows students to take part in interdisciplinary curriculum and take advantage of faculty collaboration and peer support. The Urban Male Leadership Program endeavors to increase the number of Black and Latino males in higher education. Lehman College teams participate in NCAA Division III.

name: California State University, Los Angeles
profile: As one of the members of California State University system, CSU Los Angeles operates seven colleges and offers over 120 undergraduate major options. The Early Entrance Program offers opportunities for exceptional young students (over 11 years old) to enroll in college as full-time students. The university’s forensic science program is one of the oldest in the nation, located in L.A. regional Crime Lab. The school hosts over 20 centers and institutes, topics ranging from East Asia studies to nursing. The school’s sports teams, known as the Golden Eagles, compete on the NCAA Division II level. CSULA has produced many successful figures in entertainment, business and politics. Notable alumni embattled billionaire and Los Angeles Clipper owner Donald Sterling, tennis great Billie Jean King and Academy Award winning actress Helen Hunt.

name: University of Minnesota, Morris
profile: A small, public liberal arts college that was founded in 1960, it offers 35 major and minors and eight pre-professional programs. Through the Center for Small Towns, students and faculty work to assist local rural communities; projects have included soil and water conservation research and a feasibility study on establishing an assisted living facility. Students participate in more than 90 clubs, men's and women’s intercollegiate sports that compete in NCAA Division III athletics as the Cougars and 18 intramural leagues. This year, the school received an award for its commitment to sustainability and efforts in the field of renewable energy. Morris generates on-site renewable power from a biomass gasification plant, part of an integrated system to heat and cool campus buildings. The university offers language programs in Anishinaabe, a Native American tongue, Portuguese and American Sign Language. The school’s colors are maroon and gold, and the motto is, “A renewable, sustainable education.” During Homecoming, two residence halls compete for the ‘naming rights’ of the lake that is situated between the two buildings in a tug-of-war competition.

name: Temple University
profile: Located in Philadelphia, PA, Temple University is a public research university with strong education and healthcare academic programs. Its undergraduate programs offers over 100 courses of study in 17 schools and colleges, including the Tyler School of Art, the Fox School of Business and Management, and a School of Tourism and Hospitality Management. Temple has campuses in Rome and Tokyo, and the Tokyo campus is the oldest and largest foreign university in Japan. The school’s 24 athletic teams compete at the Division I level. Temple hosts an annual Homecoming game, featuring tailgating at the Linc, a Diamond Marching Band reunion, a pep-rally, the Ambler Fest and a giant homecoming cake. Their mascot, the Owl, honors Temple’s beginnings as a night school.

name: Stetson University
profile: Stetson University is a private university in DeLand, FL. It was founded in 1883 as the DeLand Academy. The university’s history features a number of state firsts: Stetson claims to be the first in Florida to create a college newspaper, integrate its students and establish business administration, music and law schools.
