Today, students can select from 76 academic programs. Though students must live on-campus for three years, the university offers pet-friendly housing. There are around 100 student organizations at Stetson. Stetson hosts the Floyd M. Riddick Model United States Senate every March, a three-day event where students from U.S. colleges model the procedures and activities of members of the U.S. Senate. Stetson’s 15 varsity men’s and women’s athletic teams, known as the Hatters, compete in the Atlantic Sun Conference (NCAA Division I).

name: Howard University
profile: Howard University is a four-year, coeducational, private research university located in Washington, D.C. It was established in 1867 and is one of two Historically Black Colleges classified as a “Research I” university by the Carnegie Foundation. The school has been a unique history in the civil rights movement. In 1965 President Lyndon Johnson spoke to the graduating class at Howard where he outlined his plans for civil rights legislation and endorsed plans for affirmative action. The University has 15 colleges and schools in its system, ranging from the School of Communications to the College of Pharmacy. Author Zora Neale Hurston founded the school’s newspaper, “The Hilltop” in 1924. Thanks to its location in the nation’s capital, Howard’s campus includes many historical landmarks as well as a radio station that broadcasts throughout DC in high definition. Howard is home to the largest repository on Africa and the African Diaspora and seeks to preserve important historical artifacts of the black experience. Required courses include English composition and an African-American studies course. Author Toni Morrison is a graduate of Howard University. Howard competes in NCAA Division I athletics. The Howard Bison’s have 17 varsity sports teams.

name: Saint Joseph's College
profile: Saint Joseph’s College was founded in 1916 as a women’s college, admitting its first male students in 1970. The school has two campuses in New York, one in Brooklyn and one on Long Island. The college offers more than 26 undergraduate majors, pre-professional and certificate programs and many areas of graduate study. Saint Joseph’s recently began offering degrees in hospitality and tourism management and journalism and new media. The Small Business Outreach Center is located on the Brooklyn Campus and offers consulting to entrepreneurs and small businesses. The Dillon Child Study Center, a preschool that also serves as a teaching facility for students in the child study program, was one of the first of its type on the East Coast. The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics, with the Long Island campus competing as the Golden Eagles and the Brooklyn campus competing as the Bears.

name: Berry College
profile: Founded in 1902 by Martha Berry, Berry College boasts the world’s largest continuous college campus, spanning 27,000 acres. The institution offers six different undergraduate bachelor and master’s degrees in four different schools and six pre-professional programs. More than 90% of students elect to work on-campus at some point during their four year academic careers, and the college’s Work Experience Program guarantees all students a paid, on-campus job every semester. Berry College promotes Christian values, and the campus has a chaplain and four churches and chapels—more houses of worship than any school in America. The Berry Vikings compete in Division III NCAA athletics, with teams in 21 intercollegiate sports, and its inaugural football season began in the fall of 2013. The movies Sweet Home Alabama and Remember the Titans were filmed on campus.

name: Texas Tech University
profile: Texas Tech University is a public research university located in Lubbock, TX. It was established in 1923 and strives to be a research institution with the feel of a small liberal arts school. Undergraduates are offered around 150 courses of study in ten colleges. The university has strong research programs, including the National Wind Institute, and is home to a pulsed power electronics laboratory which researches improvised explosive devices. Many students participate in the school’s 52 sororities and fraternities. The Texas Tech Red Raiders are charter members of the Big 12 Conference, and compete in NCAA Division I athletics. After each athletic win, the on-campus Victory Bells sound to celebrate the win. Texas Tech hosts the annual Carol of Lights, where choirs sing classic holiday songs illuminated by 25,000 holiday lights on the Spanish-Renaissance style buildings. The statue of Will Rogers and his horse, Soapsuds, is one of Texas Tech’s most recognizable landmarks.

name: Wisconsin Lutheran College
profile: Wisconsin Lutheran College is a coeducational, private liberal arts college located in Milwaukee, WI. Founded in 1973 with a part-time faculty and 24 students, it purchased five buildings encompassing 8.5 acres of campus space in 1977, and finally became recognized as a four-year college in 1985. The first baccalaureate degrees were granted in 1987. The college faculty and administration aim to train students to become Christian leaders. Financial aid is provided to over 95% of students at WLC. On campus there are more than 30 clubs and student organizations to choose from. The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics in the Northern Athletics Collegiate Conference with 16 varsity sports teams.

name: Simpson College
profile: Simpson College is a private liberal arts college in Indianola, IA. It was founded in 1860 by members of the Iowa United Methodist Church. Students can select from over 80 majors, minors and programs. The Center for Vocation and Integrative Learning (CVIL) helps students blend Simpson’s liberal arts education with vocational experience. Undergraduates get the chance to showcase their research findings at the annual Undergraduate Research Symposium. Outside of class and research, Simpson estimates that 84% of students participate in some type of campus activity. There are over 70 student organizations on campus. Popular traditions at Simpson include All College Sing, a music competition that is judged by college administrators, and Campus Day, a day off of classes during spring semester that dates back to 1889. Simpson’s varsity athletic teams, known as the Storm, compete in the Iowa Intercollegiate Athletic Conference at the NCAA Division III level.

name: University of Central Florida
profile: A public research university located in Orlando, the school was established in 1963 as a training venue for the Kennedy Space Center and has grown to become one of the largest universities in the U.S. by enrollment. Popular majors include psychology, nursing and finance. Every year, to celebrate homecoming students are allowed to gather in the normally closed off reflection pool for the ‘Spirit Splash.' The UCF Knights compete in NCAA Division I athletics.

name: Huntington University
profile: Founded as Central College in 1897, the school changed its name to Huntington College in 1917 and became Huntington University in 2005. Huntington is a Christian university affiliated with the Church of the United Brethren in Christ. Both the school’s curriculum and core values are “Christ-centered”. The university admitted 225 freshmen in 2013, and more than 90% of students receive some form of financial aid; $4.5 million in grants and scholarships were awarded last year. In an average year, 70-80% of resident students volunteer for community service. Since 1990, the university has invested $30 million in new facilities including residence halls, an arts center, a science building and most recently renovations to the film labs. Huntington University’s arboretum is well known and an interesting place to explore on campus. Huntington’s campus sits on 160-acres of land, which includes a lake and wooded area allowing for fieldwork for natural studies courses.The school mascot is the Forester. Huntington University competes in the NAIA Crossroads League with 18 intercollegiate sports teams.

name: Weber State University
profile: Weber State University is a coeducational public institution located in Ogden, UT, that offers professional, liberal arts and technical certificates in addition to associate’s, bachelor’s and master’s degrees. The school was founded in 1889 by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The religious affiliation was dropped during the change from private academy to state school. At Weber State, students can choose from more than 250 different undergraduate programs and 11 graduate programs. Last year, the Sales Education Foundation named the school to its “Top University Sales Programs” as one of the best schools for recruiting sales professionals and representatives. During the Great Depression, students were permitted to pay their tuition in meat, fresh produce and/or milk. Each year, students mark homecoming by lighting a giant “W” on a hill above campus. Weber State competes in NCAA Division I athletics in the Big Sky Conference.

name: Dordt College
profile: Founded in 1955, Dordt College is affiliated with the Christian Reformed Church of North America. The college offers students a choice of more than 30 programs of study and 12 pre-professional programs. The five most popular majors are education, business, engineering, agriculture and nursing. Within six months of graduation, over 90% of Dordt students are employed or attend graduate school. Many off-campus study opportunities are offered at Dordt through its affiliation with the Council for Christian Colleges and Universities. The college takes its name from the Synod of Dordrecht (held in the Netherlands in 1618-19), which produced one of three major confessional statements of the Reformed Church, The Canons of Dort. Athletic teams, nicknamed the Defenders, participate in NAIA athletics.

name: California State University, San Bernardino
profile: California State University, San Bernardino, is a large-sized public university. The school opened its door for the first time in 1965 as the San Bernardino-Riverside State College but obtained its university status in 1984. More than 70 percent of CSUSB graduates are the first in their families to earn a college degree. The university’s unique national security studies and Arabic language programs are among only a few in the United States. CSUSB’s first-to-second year student retention rate is nearly 90 percent, which is among the highest in the California State University system. Similarly, the university’s retention rates for African Americans and Hispanics also rank near the top of the CSU system. The university competes in the NCAA Division II athletics. Famous alumni include three California State Assemblymen and one California State Senate.

name: Le Moyne College
profile: Le Moyne College in Syracuse, NY, was established in 1946 and is the second youngest of the 28 Jesuit colleges and universities in the U.S and the first to open as a co-educational institution. The college offers over 700 courses that lead to a Bachelor of Arts or of Sciences in more than 30 majors. Le Moyne also offers five master’s programs and graduate-level certificate programs. The school’s mascot, the dolphin, was a sign used by Christians in the second century A.D., and represents love, tenderness and the desire for knowledge. The college annually holds the Dolphy Day tradition, which is a day in the spring when students get classes off to enjoy games, music and relaxation on the lawn. Le Moyne competes in NCAA Division II athletics. Last year, the Le Moyne College men’s lacrosse team won the 2013 National Championship against Mercyhurst University.

name: North Dakota State University
profile: A land-grant university established in 1980 in Fargo, ND, North Dakota State University is a member of the Tri-College University along with Concordia College and Minnesota State University Moorhead. Students may take classes at any of the three institutions at no extra tuition. NDSU offers over 100 undergraduate majors in nine colleges, including pre-law, pre-medicine and pre-veterinary medicine. NDSU is the largest research university in the state, and major fields of research include nanotechnology, agriculture, chemistry and polymers. North Dakota State sports teams, competing in NCAA Division I, have a strong reputation. In 2014, NDSU’s football team won its third consecutive FCS national championship. The North Dakota Bison dance team also took first place in pom at nationals for the past three years. Almost 800 students participate in fifteen fraternities and sororities. Notable alumni include numerous NFL players and three Governors of North Dakota.

name: Baldwin Wallace University
profile: Established in 1845 by Methodist settlers, Baldwin Wallace offers its undergraduate community over 60 majors and minors, with a strong emphasis on its business, music and science programs. The neuroscience undergraduate program, for example, boasts a 95% overall acceptance rate to graduate and medical school programs. The school offers a Conservatory of Music, which has hosted an annual Bach Festival for the past 82 years, and the Riemenschneider-Bach Institute is one of five institutions in North America containing manuscripts written in Bach’s own hand. BW prides itself on being one of the first colleges to admit students without regard to race or gender. The majority of students at Baldwin Wallace compete in some level of sports or fitness activity, with NCAA Division III varsity athletic programs and an expansive intramural program.

name: Warren Wilson College
profile: Warren Wilson College is a four-year, coeducational, private liberal arts college located in Asheville, NC. It was established in 1894 as the Asheville Farm School and now has around 900 undergraduate students with an additional 70 graduate students. The school is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church. To this day, students help maintain the Warren Wilson College Garden; they’re responsible for about six acres of organically raised crops, sold through Warren Wilson College’s weekly campus market. In 2010, the Carolina Recycling Association honored Warren Wilson’s recycling crew the “Outstanding Composting or Organics Recycling Program Award.” The campus of the college is centered in Blue Ridge, an artist’s community in North Carolina. Katie Spotz, an ’08 graduate of WWC, set a world record as the youngest person to row across the Atlantic Ocean solo. Today, she is also the spokesperson for Blue Planet Foundation.

name: Marietta College
profile: Originally founded as Muskingum Academy in 1797, Marietta College is one of America’s “Revolutionary Colleges.” Located in downtown, historic Marietta, OH, and nestled on the Ohio River, Marietta College showcases a history of academic achievement hosting a chapter of Phi Beta Kappa. The school was chartered in 1860 and is the 16th oldest in the nation. Marietta College offers students more than 40 undergraduate majors, including petroleum engineering, which it has become well known for, as well as unique opportunities for field experience, professional internships and study abroad. Marietta College offers students a wide variety of student clubs and organizations including a Quidditch Team, the school newspaper the Marcolian, and Greek Life. Notable alumni include Charles Gates Dawes (Class of 1884), who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his work on the Dawes Plan. The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics and the school mascot is the Pioneer. Marietta’s baseball team has won six Division III titles. Marietta College’s athletic department supports 18 teams and nearly 400 student-athletes.

name: Augustana College (Sioux Falls)
profile: Established in 1860, Augustana College is the largest private university in the state and is affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church. It offers bachelor’s degrees in over 50 courses of study and pre-professional programs, most noticeably nursing. Curriculum is divided into two 15 week semesters, separated by a January term during in which students can explore different subjects and take advantage of internships and travel courses. Ole, the Viking statue at the center of Augustana’s quad, is decorated for seasonal events. During “Viking Days,” alumni return for a weekend of tailgating and football games. Nearly 75% of students participate in intramural sports, and 25% of students participate in the arts. The Augustana Concert Band toured China four times, and the Augustana Choir toured Tanzania in 2006. The school is located in Sioux Falls, SD, the No. 1 or No. 2 FORBES “best small metro for business and careers” for eight consecutive years.

name: New Jersey Institute of Technology
profile: New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark, N.J. was established in 1881, and offers 46 majors in six specialized schools. With total research expenditures topping $107 million in 2013 alone, NJIT is known for its strong research programs, holding 187 government-issued patents by March 2014. NJIT is also a participant in the Ronald E. McNair Achievement Program, awarding grants designed to help low-income and underrepresented students majoring in STEM fields to complete their bachelor’s degrees. The school has a summer student exchange program with the Heritage Institute of Technology, Kolkata. NJIT competes in NCAA Division I varsity sports, with teams including basketball, cross-country and volleyball. Its mascot is the Highlander, derived from the school’s location in the “highlands” of Newark. In the past decade, NJIT has newly renovated its campus, doubling the size of the institution to 48 acres.

name: University of La Verne
profile: A private university located in La Verne, Calif., it offers more than 50 majors at four colleges. In Southern California, the university is a leading institution in the preparation of professional educators. The student-to-faculty ratio is 12:1, with 62% of classes having no more than 19 students. All undergraduates must fulfill a community service requirement, and a significant portion of the student body engage in the Union Rescue Mission, beach and mountain clean-ups and Habitat for Humanity projects throughout the academic year. The University of La Verne competes in NCAA Division III athletics and is a member of the Southern California Intercollegiate Athletic Conference. The school mascots are Leo and Lea the Leopards.

name: Adelphi University
profile: Founded in 1896, Adelphi University is the oldest institution of higher education on Long Island. Adelphi offers eight different colleges for undergraduates—including nursing and public health, business and education—and boasts the competitive Levermore Global Scholars program, a supplemental curriculum to traditional majors promoting global context and study and community service abroad opportunities. The school has increased their instructional faculty by 74% since 2011 and has invested millions in new state of the art facilities, including smart classrooms and equipment such as lasers for the physics buildings and Steinway pianos for the performing arts programs. The university launched the Center for Health Innovation in 2011 to unite Adelphi’s various clinical programs with community needs. Notable attendees include best-selling author Alice Hoffman and rappers Chuck D and Flavor Flav.

name: California State University, Chico
profile: Founded in 1887, California State University in Chico is the second-oldest campus in the California State University system. The main campus is in downtown Chico, but the school also owns and manages the 3,950-acre Big Chico Creek Ecological Reserve and the 300-acre Butte Creek Ecological Reserve. In addition, the university manages farm and range land. Open University program allows the general public to take Chico State classes without formal affiliation with the university. The university’s student newspaper, The Orion, was named to the Associated Collegiate Press Hall of Fame in 2005 for winning or being a finalist for the Pacemaker Award over 22 times since 1988. The student recycling program, which started in 1996, was the first of its kind in the CSU System and is one of the best programs among state campuses. Chico professor Jeff Price shared the 2007 Nobel Peace Prize as one of the leading authors of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. Chico Wildcats compete in NCAA Division II athletics.

name: Saint Mary's University of Minnesota
profile: Saint Mary’s University of Minnesota is a private research university that was established in 1912. It is affiliated with the Lasallian Catholic Church. Currently, it has approximately 6,000 undergraduate and graduate students. In addition to the main campuses in Winona and Minneapolis, there are centers located in four of the state's other cities, as well as Jamaica and Nairobi, Kenya. The school competes in Division III athletics, and the school mascot is the Cardinal.

name: College of Charleston
profile: The College of Charleston was established in 1770 and is the oldest higher level educational institution south of Virginia. Three of the College’s founders, Thomas Heyward, Arthur Middleton and Edward Rutledge, signed the Declaration of Independence, and another three were framers of the U.S. Constitution. The school offers 55 majors, including three new ones: archeology, marketing and finance. Nearly 30% of students live on campus. The school’s 21 teams compete in NCAA Division I athletics. In spring 2013, the college’s co-educational sailing team won the Intercollegiate Sailing Association/Gill Co-ed National Championship title for the fourth time. Instead of wearing robes or caps for the spring commencement ceremony, women wear white dresses and men wear white dinner jackets. Notable alumni include architect Robert Mills, who designed the Washington Monument.

name: Florida Institute of Technology
profile: Florida Institute of Technology was established in 1958 in order to provide more educational opportunities for engineers, scientists and technicians that were working for NASA. The director of NASA, four astronauts and five astronaut candidates all call Florida Tech their alma mater. Founded to provide advanced education for professional working in the space program, it is now the only independent technological university in the Southeast. While it is a technological university, FIT offers over 70 areas of study for undergraduates to choose from. FIT is home to a 15-acre botanical garden that is bordered by a stream, palm trees and other tropical growth. Florida Institute of Technology competes in the NCAA Division II and athletic teams are known as the Panthers. The school has an active Catholic ministry which offers numerous small faith groups and student retreats.

name: University of New Mexico
profile: Located in Albuquerque, it is the state’s flagship institution. Founded in 1889, the university offers 87 bachelor’s, 72 master’s and 38 doctoral programs. It offers nearly 40 programs to about 12,000 nontraditional students who attend UNM at night and on weekends each semester. The University of New Mexico competes in NCAA Division I-A athletics and the school mascot is Lobo Louie, who in the 1960's became the official human mascot of the university and has since then been joined by Lobo Lucy in the 1980s. The Pit, home to the University of New Mexico Lobo basketball team, has been ranked nationally in total attendance every season since its opening in 1966.

name: University of Rhode Island
profile: The University of Rhode Island was chartered in 1888 as the state’s agricultural college. The Oliver Watson farm was purchased as a site for the school; the original farmhouse, a listed historic landmark, remains on campus. Today, it is the only public institution in the state that offers undergraduate, graduate and professional educational programs for students to pursue. Students can choose from more than 80 majors at ten colleges: Arts and Sciences, Business Administration, Engineering, Environment and Life Sciences, Human Science and Services, Nursing, Pharmacy, University College, Continuing Ed and the Graduate School of Oceanography. In addition, there are 17 club sports teams and 15 intramural teams. The University of Rhode Island competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is Rhody the Ram; many events, such as “Rhody Rally,” incorporate this name. The University of Rhode Island’s sailing team is the only one from the U.S. to win the Collegiate Keelboat World Cup. Since that win in 1990, it has had more than 11 Kennedy Cup appearances. The University of Rhode Island is also the birthplace of the “fast break” in basketball.

name: Roanoke College
profile: Roanoke College is a private liberal arts college in Salem, VA. Founded in 1842 as a boys’ prep school, it is the second oldest Lutheran-affiliated college in America. Roanoke College’s students hail from about 40 states and 25 countries. Six of the college’s buildings, including the Administration Building, which was constructed in 1848, are on the National Register of Historic Places. Around 80% of students live on campus. The school’s average class size is 18, with 94% of classes having fewer than 30 students. Students can choose from 35 majors and 57 minors and concentrations. Those enrolled in the dual degree engineering program receive a liberal arts degree from Roanoke and an engineering degree from Virginia Tech. Roanoke College’s nine men’s and 10 women’s teams, known as the Maroons, compete in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: University of North Carolina, Wilmington
profile: Established in 1947 as a junior college, the University of North Carolina, Wilmington, has since grown into one of the major institutions in the UNC system. Its proximity to the Atlantic Ocean is a particular draw for prospective students. Popular majors include education and economics. It competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is the Seahawk. To relieve stress before the final exam period each year, students participate in the “Oozeball” mud volleyball competition. New buildings on campus include the Teaching Laboratory Building, McNeill School of Nursing and the Seahawk Crossing student residence facility. The Student Recreation center was expanded in 2013, doubling its previous size and adding a new natatorium.

name: CUNY, College of Staten Island
profile: Established in 1976, the College of Staten Island is one of the 11 members and a senior college within the City University of New York system. The college is divided into four schools and divisions offering degrees in over 20 areas of studies. Master’s degrees and doctoral programs are also available in conjunction with the CUNY Graduate Center in Manhattan. There are five interdisciplinary bachelor’s degree programs and three interdisciplinary certificate programs. The college’s sports teams, nicknamed the Dolphins, participate in NCAA Division III athletics and are a member of the City University of New York Athletic Conference.

name: California State University, Fresno
profile: California State University, Fresno is a large-sized public research university located at the northeast side of Fresno, California, nearly 60 miles from Yosemite National Park. The school was originally founded in 1911 as the Fresno State Normal School. In 1956, Fresno State moved to its present campus location. CSUF is also home to the famous Fullerton Arboretum, which is situated in the northeast part of the campus. Fresno State is the fourth largest producer of teachers and administrators among California State Universities. In 1997, the university became the first in the country to operate a fully licensed winery, where student-produce wines and have won hundreds of awards in tasting competitions. Fresno State also has the second largest sole library in the 23-campus California State University system. Notable alumni include former governor of Nevada, Kenny Guinn. Named after a stray bulldog the students brought to football games, the Fresno State Bulldogs compete in NCAA Division I-A athletics.

name: Randolph-Macon College
profile: Randolph-Macon College is a private liberal arts college in Ashland, VA. It was founded in 1830 by Methodists and, while an independent institution, still maintains a relationship with the United Methodist Church. The college’s 116-acre campus is about 15 miles from Richmond. Randolph-Macon offers more than 50 majors, minors, pre-professional programs and areas of study. The school offers a four-year degree guarantee, meaning students who fulfill the program’s requirements yet are unable to graduate in four years will not be charged tuition for the remaining courses. Students come from 28 states and 15 countries. The optional January term gives students the chance to study abroad, complete an internship or take courses on campus. The school made headlines in 2014 when two of its professors began running for the same seat in Congress. In 2013, the college opened Brock Commons, a new student center with a store, coffee shop and theater. Randolph-Macon’s varsity men’s and women’s teams, known as the Yellow Jackets, compete in the Old Dominion Athletic Conference of the NCAA Division III.

name: California State University, Sacramento
profile: California State University, Sacramento, commonly referred to as “Sac State,” is Sacramento’s only four-year university. Established in 1947, California State University, Sacramento, is a public university home to Northern California’s largest Air Force ROTC detachment, as well as to the California Smart Grid Center, which helps utility companies respond to peak electrical power demands through technological solutions. In 1972, Sacramento State students invented the world’s first microcomputer. There are nine colleges on campus and most popular undergraduate majors include nursing, criminal justice and psychology. The university holds over 30 research centers providing research opportunities on a variety of topics, including archaeological research, African peace and conflict resolution and STEM fields. About one-third of Sac State students receive financial assistance. More than half of the student body joins at least one of the 276 student organizations on campus and over 5,000 students participate in the intramural sports program. The WELL, the school’s recreation and wellness center, as well as the American River Courtyard residence hall are both certified LEED Gold for achieving impressive environmental industry standards. It competes in NCAA Division I-AA athletics.

name: College of St. Scholastica
profile: The College of St. Scholastica is a small private college founded in 1912 by a group of pioneering Benedictine Sisters for young women. It became coeducational in 1969. The main campus is located in Duluth, MN, and there are six additional campuses in Minnesota along with one in Surprise, AZ. Some of the campuses offer evening and weekend classes and online courses. The college has six divisions offering a wide range of majors and minors. CSS also provides 8 credits in general military courses and 16 credits in professional officer courses. In addition, Air Force ROTC programs are open to students. All incoming students must comply the Four Year Pledge to maintain basic academic standing and graduate on time. Exceptions are granted to students who have changed majors, choose more than one major or have taken a gap time. The college competes in the NCAA’s Division III and in the Upper Midwest Athletic Conference.

name: Clarke University
profile: Clarke University was established in 1843 by Mary Frances Clarke, the founder of the Sisters of Charity of the Blessed Virgin Mary. Clarke is the only Blessed Virgin Mary University in the country. The university occupies a 55-acre campus in Dubuque, Iowa, overlooking the Mississippi River. It offers over 40 majors and programs and a 110:1 student to faculty ratio. Last year, Clarke provided over $11 million in aid to students from alumni donation and its endowment. Clarke University competes in NAIA, and the athletic teams, known as the Crusaders, compete in the Midwest Classic Conference. The official school colors are blue and gold. Notable alumni include the Emmy Award winning singer-actress, Karen Morrow.

name: University of New England
profile: University of New England is a health sciences university grounded in the liberal arts that offers its more than 5,500 students a selection of more than 40 undergraduate, graduate and professional degree programs and is the leading health profession educator of students in the state. It is home to Maine’s only medical school and is one of only a handful of private universities with a comprehensive health education mission including medicine, pharmacy, dental medicine and nursing along with a variety of allied health professions. UNE is Maine’s only Master of Science programs for physician assistants and nurse anesthetists. UNE receives grants from a number of prominent sources, including NASA, National Science Foundation and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. UNE maintains two scenic campuses in Maine. The first is a more than 540-acre coastal campus in Biddeford and the other is a 41-acre campus in Portland with a traditional New England flair. The Biddeford campus is home to the Harold Alfond Center for Health Sciences and the marine Science Education and Research Center, which includes the Marine Animal Rehabilitation Center.

name: Centenary College of Louisiana
profile: Centenary College of Louisiana was founded in 1825, making it the 43rd oldest school in the country. A private liberal arts college, it is affiliated with the United Methodist Church and is also the oldest chartered liberal arts college west of the Mississippi River. Religious affiliation at Centenary is diverse; about 20% of Centenary students are United Methodist, 18% Baptist, and 20% Catholics, among other backgrounds. The college has 22 majors to choose from and 15 special programs including pre-professional studies, a 3/2 engineering program and a five-year education program. Students with shared interests such as sustainability, health or technology can live and study together in one of the college’s four “living learning communities.” The College Choir, nicknamed “America’s Singing Ambassadors” for their extensive travel, performed at a sold-out show at the Sydney Opera House, appeared at Christmas receptions in the White House and traveled to countries such as South Africa, Brazil, and Ireland. Nicknamed the Ladies & Gents and members of Southern Collegiate Athletic Conference, Centenary athletic teams compete in the NCAA Division III.

name: University of South Florida
profile: This public research university was established in 1956 and now offers more than 240 degree programs at the undergraduate, graduate, specialty and doctoral levels. It ranks 15th worldwide among universities granted U.S. patents and is regarded as one of the nation's most veteran-friendly universities. USF’s Tampa Bay Technology Incubator is home to 42 resident and affiliate companies. The University of South Florida competes in Division I athletics and the school mascot is Rocky the Bull.

name: Wheeling Jesuit University
profile: Wheeling Jesuit University, located in Wheeling, WV, was founded in 1954. Originally called Wheeling College, it is the youngest of the nation’s 28 Jesuit institutions of higher learning and students attend the university from 26 states and 20 countries. The university’s motto is “Luceat Lux Vestra,” or “let your light shine.” There are about 40 academic programs for students to choose from. The campus resides on 65 acres of land and has a 550-acre retreat farm and research preserve. Students at Wheeling Jesuit University can audition for the talent show known as “Jesuit Idol” every year. The International Student Club hosts an event called Cultural Fest each year in which students celebrate the diversity of WJU. The WJU Cardinals compete in NCAA Division II in the Mountain East Athletic Conference with 19 athletic teams.

name: Spring Hill College
profile: Spring Hill College is a private liberal arts college in Mobile, AL. It was founded in 1830 by a Catholic bishop and is one of the oldest Jesuit colleges in the U.S. Students hail from 39 states and 12 foreign countries and can choose from 49 undergraduate majors and areas of concentration. The college guarantees housing for all full-time undergraduates; around 85% of students choose to live on Spring Hill’s 400-acre campus. There are nearly 50 student groups at Spring Hill, including 10 recognized Greek life organizations, and students dedicate more than 20,000 hours of community service annually. Spring Hill is joining the NCAA (Division II) beginning Fall 2014; it will be the first non-HBCU member of the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Conference (SIAC). The college’s most infamous lecture was delivered by Lee Harvey Oswald just months before the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. Oswald discussed his experience in Soviet Russia.

name: University of Montana
profile: Located in Missoula, the second-largest city in the state of Montana, the university's main campus sits on 56 acres along the Clark Fork River at the base of Mount Sentinel. The 180-acre South campus is home to the school’s soccer fields, golf course, and student housing. One of its most recognizable landmarks is a letter “M” on the side of Mount Sentinel. Constructed in 1908 by students, the 125-foot-tall concrete sign stands at the end of a ¾ mile trail overlooking Missoula. The school has extensive outdoors programs including rafting, kayaking and backpacking trips. The University of Montana competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is Monte the Grizzly Bear. Every year, its football team competes against Montana State University in the “Brawl of the Wild."

name: Converse College
profile: Converse College is a private women’s college located in Spartanburg, SC, and founded in 1889. The college has 13 departments offering a variety of majors, including one individualized major linking at least three academic disciplines and one engineering dual degree taught in conjunction with Clemson University. Nisbet Honors program provides independent research opportunities to students to explore their favorite topic and work one-on-one with a faculty advisor. The college operates a number of leadership programs and award scholarships to selected students who commit to community service for over two years. Milliken Art Gallery is open 24-hours a day and the college hosts nearly 200 public performances, exhibitions, readings and lectures each year by world-renowned artists, as well as Converse faculty and students. Today, Converse is part of the Conference Carolinas and competes in NCAA Division II athletics: the highest level of competition of any women’s college.

name: Ohio University
profile: Ohio University is a public research university in Athens, Ohio. Established in 1804, it is the oldest university in the Northwest Territory and one of the oldest public universities in the U.S. Ohio University’s nine undergraduate colleges offer students more than 250 programs of study. Students in the Honors Tutorial College enroll in one-one-one tutorials with faculty members, receive priority class and house scheduling and may enroll in graduate-level courses. All first- and second-year students must live in one of the university’s 42 residence halls. College Green, the center of campus, features some of the university’s oldest buildings and has remained a fixture of campus life throughout the university’s history. There are nearly 500 student organizations on campus, including over 30 fraternities and sororities. Ohio University’s intercollegiate sports teams, known as the Bobcats, compete in the Mid-American Conference (NCAA Division I). The school’s mascot is Rufus the Bobcat. Notable alumni include Fox News President Roger Ailes, Charles Schwab President and CEO Walter Bettinger and journalist Matt Lauer.

name: Canisius College
profile: Canisius College is a small-sized private college founded in 1870 by members of the Society of Jesus from Germany. It is one of 28 Jesuit, Catholic colleges in the nation. The college has three schools which offer more than 80 major and minors, and nine special programs including two five-year MBA Dual Degrees and a fashion merchandising degree offered in conjunction with the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City. The most popular majors are business and psychology. In the last 23 years, 33 graduates have been awarded national fellowships and scholarships, including two Fulbright Scholars in the class of 2013. More than 90% of Canisius students find employment or are accepted to graduate school within one year of graduation. By the same token, nine out of every 10 students who apply to medical or health schools are accepted. It is also the Reserve Officer Training Corps hub for Western New York. A unique characteristic of the 72-acre campus is the labyrinth of underground tunnels that students use to travel through campus in the winter. The Contemporary Writers Series, started in 2003, brings renowned fiction writers and poets to campus to read from their work, sign books and meet with the college community. The Golden Griffins compete in the NCAA Division I.

name: New Mexico State University, Las Cruces
profile: Established in 1888 and predating New Mexico’s statehood by 24 years, New Mexico State University, Las Cruces is a Hispanic-serving institution, where students are known as “Aggies,” a nickname derived from the school’s beginnings as an agricultural school. NMSU has five campuses, a satellite learning center in Albuquerque, extension offices in New Mexico’s 33 counties and 12 agriculture research and science centers. New Mexico State competes in the Western Athletic Conference. The Victory Bell, a gift from the class of 1939, was originally intended to be rung after football team victories. Subject to many pranks, the bell became a contested object with NMSU’s main rival, the Texas Western Miners, and was stolen before football games. The Aggie Victory Bell is currently mounted next to the south goal of the football stadium.

name: West Virginia University
profile: Founded in 1867, West Virginia University is a public research university located in Morgantown, WV. The university has 15 colleges and schools. Some of the top fields of study include arts and sciences, business, agriculture and public health. The WVU library has more than 1.5 million printed volumes, over 2 million microforms and 10,000 electric journals. At WVU, students have many opportunities get involved on campus with 400 student organizations to choose from. There are also 20 fraternities and 8 sororities on campus. Since its founding, West Virginia University has produced 25 Rhodes Scholars, 22 Truman Scholars, 33 Goldwater Scholars and 39 Fulbright Scholars. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics in the Big 12 Conference. West Virginia’s rifle team has won 16 NCAA National Championships. The school mascot is the Mountaineer.

name: Capital University
profile: Capital University was founded in 1830 and is the oldest university in Central, OH. It is also one of the oldest and largest Lutheran-affiliated universities in North America. This year, the school announced tuition freeze for 2014-15 academic year. The school provides four bachelor’s degrees in arts, music, science and nursing and social work. Capital University has a well-established music program with renowned faculty including James Swearingen and Barry Kopetz. The school’s Shumacher Gallery carries the 502-piece Schreiber-Fox Collection African Art as well as a piece of the Berlin Wall obtained in 1992. The school’s student center, Harry C. Moores Campus Center, underwent a multi-million dollar renovation in 2013. The school’s Chapel Choir, a select mixed ensemble group, has performed in a variety of sacred and secular choral literature and has travelled to thousands of places to perform, including South Africa in 2011. Capital University also organizes the tradition of annual Martin Luther King Jr. Day of Learning, a day of workshops and special events to commemorate Dr. King and celebrate diversity. The Capital Crusaders compete in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: University of Maine, Orono
profile: Established in 1862, the public university offers more than 90 undergraduate majors and programs, 70 master's and 35 doctoral programs. It houses the state's largest library with more than 5.2 million holdings and is the official repository for state and federal documents. The campus was designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, the landscape architect who designed Central Park in New York City and the U.S. Capitol grounds. The campus has 15 miles of running, biking and cross-country skiing trails. It is a particularly ‘green’ school: each residence hall has eco-reps who coordinate recycling programs and lead environmental initiatives, and 7% of the school’s budget is spent on organic and local food. Phi Kappa Phi, the international honor society, was founded at the university in 1897. The University of Maine, Orono competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is Bananas the Black Bear.

name: University of Wisconsin, Eau Claire
profile: The University of Wisconsin, Eau Claire is a public university in Eau Claire, Wisconsin. It was founded in 1916 as the Eau Claire State Normal School and has been a member of the University of Wisconsin System since 1971. The university offers approximately 80 undergraduate and 14 graduate degree programs. There are plenty of opportunities to get involved at the school--there are more than 250 student organizations on campus and 37% of students conduct research with faculty members. The university’s 44-year-old Eau Claire Jazz Festival is one of the oldest and largest jazz festivals in the U.S. The Forum, another longstanding campus tradition, has attracted high-profile speakers like Martin Luther King, Jr. and Carl Sagan. Students can also experience the festivities of times past: the annual Viennese Ball focuses on themes from 19th-century Vienna and the Madrigal Dinner recalls 15th-century banquets. Student-athletes compete in the Wisconsin Intercollegiate Athletic Conference (WIAC) at the NCAA Division III level. The school’s teams are nicknamed the Blugolds.

name: California Maritime Academy
profile: Founded in 1929, California Maritime Academy is a small-sized public university and the smallest campus of the California State University system. Located 30 miles northeast of San Francisco in Vallejo, the school offers six bachelor’s degrees. Starting in 1940, graduates could receive a B.S. degree in addition to their Third Mate, or Third Assistant Engineer license. California Maritime Academy was the first maritime academy to allow women into a licensed maritime program; the first women were admitted in 1973. As part of the Academy’s academic requirement, students are required to take internships in shore-side companies, with government agencies or aboard commercial ships. The Academy organizes Community Ambassadors Club, which offers cadets local family connections. Arguably the most important part of a California Maritime Academy license track programs’ education is the summer cruise that takes place on the Academy’s 500-foot training ship, “Golden Bear.” On this cruise, students have the opportunity to experience classroom concepts in the field as well as apply their classroom skills in the environment. California Maritime Academy competes in NAIA athletics.

name: North Greenville University
profile: Located in Tigerville, S.C., North Greenville University maintains its affiliation with the Southern Baptist Church through mandated biweekly chapel attendance and the prohibition of alcohol consumption on or off-campus. Further rules and restrictions are outlined in a document called “The Enlightener,” which prohibits premarital sex and open declarations of homosexuality, among other acts. Women and men reside in separate dormitories. The university offers a “biblically-sound, Christ-centered” curriculum, offering multiple majors in eight colleges. NGU participates in NCAA Division II sports. There are over 20 approved student clubs and organizations, including the Ninja Geese Ultimate Frisbee Club. Theatron, a campus theater group, performs Christian theater.

name: Sonoma State University
profile: Sonoma State University is a public university in Rohnert Park, CA, 10 miles south of Santa Rosa. It was founded in 1961 and was granted university status in 1978. It is one of the most residential colleges in the California State University system, with approximately 34% of its students living on campus. The university offers 46 undergraduate majors and 47 minors as well as 15 master’s degrees. Over 100 student organizations operate on Sonoma State’s 269-acre campus, including numerous Greek chapters. The newly-opened 130,000-square-foot Student Center includes dining, conference and meeting space and a 4,000-square-foot central lounge. The university’s rec center has been recognized for its sustainability efforts. The Green Music Center is a top-of-the-line performing arts center. Sonoma State’s men’s and women’s varsity athletic teams compete at the NCAA Division II level and are known as the Seawolves.

name: University of Hawaii, Manoa
profile: The flagship campus of the University of Hawaii System, it offers more than 200 degree programs through 19 colleges and schools. Oceanography, astronomy, international business, marine biology and Pacific Islands and Asian studies are the most popular majors. It has one of the best records in the nation for educating minority students at the graduate level. Coconut Island houses the School of Ocean & Earth Science & Technology’s Hawaii Institute of Marine Biology, a world-renowned marine research institute. The university competes in NCAA Division I athletics and is a member of both the Mountain West Conference in football and the Big West Conference.

name: Hofstra University
profile: Established in 1935, Hofstra University originated as an extension of New York University. The campus was built on the estate of Dutch immigrant and lumber magnate William S Hofstra. The university and is no longer connected with NYU. In 2008 and 2012 Hofstra was selected to host the United States Presidential Election Debates. The school has its own radio station, WRHU, which is one of the top student-run stations in the nation. Hofstra hosts an annual Shakespeare festival, a tradition that dates back to 1950. Each year students perform one of Shakespeare’s 26 plays in the school’s replica of the Globe Theater. In 2011 it established a medical school, as well as a school of engineering and applied sciences in 2012. Additionally, the school of Education and Health Sciences and Human Services recently split into two schools. Notable alumni and attendees include actors James Caan and Christopher Walken, as well as Bernie Madoff, the convicted investor. Hofstra has a thriving Greek Life scene and offers more than 20 active fraternities and sororities. Athletically, Hofstra competes at the NCAA Division I level in the Colonial Athletic Association. The Hofstra “Pride” has 17 intercollegiate sports teams.

name: West Chester University of Pennsylvania
profile: West Chester University of Pennsylvania is a public university located in West Chester, PA. The school’s heritage dates back to 1812. Today, West Chester is the second largest school in the Pennsylvania State System of Higher Education and sits on just over 400 acres of land. On campus, there are about 80 undergraduate programs, ranging from Russian studies to Physics. On campus, the Frederick Douglass Institute was established to honor the former slave, journalist, author, orator and statesman; on February 1, 1895, Douglass delivered his last public speech on campus. West Chester competes athletically at the NCAA Division II level in the Pennsylvania State Athletic Conference with 23 athletic teams.

name: Georgia State University
profile: Georgia State University is an urban public research university offering 55 undergraduate and 250 graduate degree fields of study. Founded in 1913, GSU operates the largest experimental economics laboratory in the Southeast, graduates the second largest amount of baccalaureate nursing students in Georgia, and is home to the largest respiratory therapy program and the first physical therapy program in the state. The university library has more than 1.5 million volumes along with 28,000 electronic journals; it is a Federal Document Depository with over 820,000 government documents. The campus is home to a Biosafety Level 4 laboratory, which allows students and researchers to work with Ebola, Hanta Virus and Herpes B Virus. Georgia State is a NCAA Division I team that competes in the Sun Belt Conference. In May 2014, GSU announced its plan to acquire the 77-acre Turner Field in 2017 and expand the space into a 30,000-seat open-air football stadium. The marching band has plans to participate in the 2014 Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.

name: Azusa Pacific University
profile: Founded in 1899, Azusa Pacific University is one of the largest inter-denomination, evangelical, private Christian schools in the nation. Situated in the scenic San Gabriel Valley, Azusa Pacific University maintains six off-site regional centers in Southern California. With a focus on scholarship and faith-based learning, Azusa Pacific offers over 60 undergraduate courses of study in three colleges. Azusa stresses the importance of community service, requiring students to complete volunteer hours tutoring, working with orphans or mobile medical care clinics, and completing mission and outreach programs in Mexico. More than 450 Azusa Pacific University student-athletes compete in Division II of the NCAA in 19 intercollegiate sports, winning 48 national championships and 113 conference championships in their history. Bryan Clay, one of the very few decathletes to hold two Olympic medals – the silver in 2004 and the gold in 2008 – was a member of the class of ‘03.

name: Roger Williams University
profile: Roger Williams University is a private university in Bristol, RI. The school’s roots date back to 1919 and it is named after the man who settled the area that would become Providence. The university offers more than 40 majors and 55 study abroad programs. Though primarily focused on undergraduate education, Roger Williams is home to the only law school in Rhode Island. Approximately 60% of students live on campus. There are more than 70 student clubs and organizations at Roger Williams. The Performing Arts Center, affectionately dubbed the Barn, has been home to the study of dance and performance art, music and theater for 25 years. Students look forward to Spring Weekend, a themed series of events that take place each spring. Recent performers include Lupe Fiasco, Third Eye Blind and Dropkick Murphys. The school's 22 varsity athletic teams, known as the Hawks, compete at the NCAA Division III level.

name: University of Idaho
profile: Located in Moscow, Idaho, it’s a public research university that was founded in 1889 and now occupies 1,585 acres of land, including 80 acres of arboreta, 860 acres of farms and a 150-acre golf course. The school offers 130 bachelor’s, 88 master’s and 32 doctoral degrees. The university takes pride in its musical programs: the Lionel Hampton Jazz Festival was given the National Medal of Arts in 2007, which is the country’s most prestigious arts award. Every year, the campus community celebrates “Tutxinmepu Pow Wow,” a spring festival that includes dancers from around the region. The “Hello Walk” is the campus’ famous and most traveled pathways. It is lined with statues, landmarks, traditions and trees planted by famous figures like Teddy Roosevelt. The University of Idaho competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the sports teams are nicknamed the Vandals.

name: Salem College
profile: Salem College is a private, women’s liberal arts college in Winston-Salem, NC. Established in 1772, it is one of the oldest women’s colleges by founding date and one of the oldest colleges in the U.S. Salem offers more than 30 majors that can lead to Bachelor of Arts, Bachelor of Science, Bachelor of Music and Bachelor of Science in Business Administration degrees. The college utilizes a 4-1-4 calendar, meaning students take four courses during the fall and spring semesters and one January term course in order to graduate in four years. Around 70% of the school’s professors are women. There are more than 35 student clubs and organizations on campus. First-year students begin their experience at Salem by making a candlelight walk to the grave of the college’s founder, Sister Elizabeth Oesterlein; on Founders Day of their senior year, students make the same walk to end their time at the school. The college’s athletic teams, nicknamed the Salem Spirits, compete at the NCAA Division III level.

name: Carroll University
profile: Often referred to as Wisconsin’s pioneer college, Carroll University is the oldest four-year university in the state. It was founded in 1846 and is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church. Carroll University started as Prairieville Academy. During freshmen orientation, students spend half a day working on one of the many community service projects. The school has a more than 100-year history with Greek life and there are currently three national sororities and two fraternities, one local and one national, at Carroll. Carroll University athletic teams participate in the NCAA Division III and compete in 10 men's and women's sports in the Midwest Conference. On Sept. 5, 1906, Saint Louis University quarterback Bradbury Robinson threw the first legal forward pass in football history at Carroll.

name: Elmhurst College
profile: Elmhurst College was founded in 1871 by Reverend Carl Kranz, who arrived in Elmhurst, IL with 14 students to establish the German Evangelical Proseminary; for several decades all courses were taught in German. The school remains affiliated with the United Church of Christ, but now offers 50 majors to students. The campus is a 48-acre arboretum with nearly 800 trees and shrubs. Notable alumni include theologian brothers Reinhold and H. Richard Niebuhr, class of 1910 and 1912 respectively. In 1966, the college held its first annual Niebuhr Lecture; through this series and others, the campus has hosted Martin Luther King Jr., Ralph Nader, Muhammad Ali and others. It participates in NCAA Division III athletics, and its mascot is the Blue Jay.

name: Virginia Commonwealth University
profile: Virginia Commonwealth University is a public research university founded in 1838. VCU has two main campuses in Richmond, one in the west of downtown and the other in the urban center. In addition, VCU operates a School of the Arts branch campus in Education City, Qatar, offering B.F.A. degrees. The College of Humanities and Sciences is the largest academic unit, and biology and mass communications are among the most popular majors. The university’s Academic Scholars Program in Real Environments (ASPiRE) is a living-learning experience that combines academic and service-learning experiences. Last year the school received nearly $250 million in sponsored program awards, the majority going to the school of medicine. The VCU Medical Center houses the university’s health sciences schools as well as the Hume-Lee Transplant Center and Massey Cancer Center, among others. It offers state-of-the-art care in more than 200 specialty areas and maintains the region’s only Level 1 Trauma Center. The university offers students 16 varsity sports that participate in Division I athletics.

name: Hartwick College
profile: Located in Oneonta, NY, the Hartwick College was established in 1927. The college was founded with ties to the Hartwick Seminary, which was established in 1797. Today, the college is not affiliated with any denomination. The 2014-2015 campus theme is “Health and the Environment: Personal Courage and Community Activism.” Each year Hartwick College chooses a campus theme (past themes include “Exploration” and “Sustainable Living”) and offers unique courses, bringing in experts and organizing special activities around the topic. Nearly two-thirds of Hartwick students study abroad on month-, semester-, and year-long programs. Each student is further encouraged to explore his or her academic interests through a mandatory senior thesis. Hartwick offers the Three-Year Bachelor's Degree Program, which allows students to earn a B.A. or B.S. within three years, reducing the overall cost of a Hartwick college education. Many of the buildings on campus are named after the original investors in IBM who were early supporters of the college. Athletically, Hartwick competes primarily at the NCAA Division III level; however, the women’s water polo team and men’s soccer team both compete at the NCAA Division I level. The school mascot is Swoop the Hawk.

name: Jackson State University
profile: Located in Jackson, Miss., Jackson State University is a historically black university that was founded in 1877. Popular majors at this urban public university are business marketing, education and interdisciplinary studies. The campus spans 150 acres; constructed in 1903, Ayer Hall is the oldest building on campus and is listed in the National Registrar of Historic Places. The Jackson State Tigers compete in NCAA Division I athletics and the school colors are navy blue and white. The Prancing J-Settes is the name of the university’s dance line which performs with its marching band, The Sonic Boom of the South. JSU’s rival schools include Tennessee State and Mississippi Valley State. In the spring, the Jackson State baseball team beat the University of Louisiana at Lafayette and claimed its first ever win in a NCAA regional. The university’s motto is “Challenging Minds, Changing Lives” and its president is Carolyn Meyers. JSU Online is Jackson State’s online educational platform which gives students an opportunity to take classes and complete their degrees from a distance.

name: Maryville University of Saint Louis
profile: Maryville University, Saint Louis is a private research university located on a 130-acre campus 20 minutes from downtown Saint Louis. Founded in 1872, it is among the oldest private institutions in the region. There are approximately 3,000 undergraduate and 800 graduate students. There are 50 degree programs and more than 40 clubs and organizations. Every September, the campus community volunteers at the “Maryville Reaches Out” event. The university recently received $100,000 from the Monsanto Fund, which will be used to develop new high school chemistry lab curricula to increase teens’ interest in science. Maryville University competes in NCAA Division II athletics and its mascot is Louie the Saint Bernard.

name: San Francisco State University
profile: San Francisco State University is a public university in San Francisco, CA. It was established in 1899 as San Francisco State Normal School, a two-year college for teachers. SFS is known as a “college with a conscience,” meaning its students are particularly dedicated to social responsibility and community service. Students donate as much as $2 million worth of services to the community each year and the school offers more than 200 courses that combine academic study and community involvement. Students can choose from bachelor’s degrees in 75 disciplines, master’s degrees in 63 disciplines and 4 doctoral degree programs. The university also offers one of the strongest study abroad programs in the California State University system. There is a wide range of student clubs and organizations on campus as well, ranging from Philosophy Club to Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu Club. San Francisco State’s intercollegiate athletic teams compete at the NCAA Division II level.

name: University of Massachusetts, Lowell
profile: Formed out of the 1975 merger of Lowell State and Lowell Tech, the University of Massachusetts, Lowell dates back to the formation of the original institutions, the late-19th century Lowell Normal School and Lowell Textile School. The university focuses on offering students experiential, “hands on” learning at a reasonable price, with over 120 undergraduate, 39 master’s, and 33 doctoral degree programs in six colleges. The school recently joined NCAA Division I during the fall 2013. The mascot is Rowdy the River Hawk.

name: University of Alabama, Huntsville
profile: The University of Alabama, Huntsville, has 33 bachelor’s degree programs, 23 master’s degree options and 15 Ph.D. programs. It boasts strong research opportunities given its ties to NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, as well as local U.S. Army R&D centers and other government agencies. Its well-regarded nursing school is scheduled to move into a new $17 million building in fall 2014. The university competes in Division I athletics and has the only Division I ice hockey team in the South.

name: Immaculata University
profile: Located 20 miles west of Philadelphia, Pa., Immaculata University is a private, Roman Catholic institution founded in 1920 by the Sisters, Servants of the Immaculate Heart of Mary. The campus sits on 375 acres. The university became coeducational in 2005 and the gender ratio still tilts female. There are two tracks of study, arts & sciences or professional studies, depending on the student’s major, with a separate core curriculum for each. IU is expanding housing options on its West Campus and will open two new, of its planned three, residence halls in August 2014. Greek life on campuses is made up of two fraternities and four sororities. IU is considered the birthplace of modern women’s basketball. Immaculata’s Mighty Macs compete in Division III athletics.

name: Moravian College
profile: Moravian College is a private liberal arts college in Bethlehem, PA. The school’s roots date back to 1742, making it one of the oldest institutions of higher learning in the U.S. During his second term, President George Washington petitioned the school’s headmaster for the admission of two of his great-nieces. Moravian College received a charter to grant baccalaureate degrees in 1863 and remains affiliated with the Moravian Church in America. The school offers over 50 majors and courses of study, though its relatively broad curriculum requirements allow students to branch out and view their fields of study expansively. The most popular departments include biological sciences, English, education, and music and art. Housing is guaranteed for all four years and most students choose to live on campus. Students can get involved in over 80 clubs and organizations. Around 20% of students are members of one of the four sororities or three fraternities at Moravian. Student-athletes compete in the Landmark Conference and Centennial Conference (football only) at the NCAA Division III level. Varsity teams are known as the Greyhounds. Approximately two-thirds of students are involved in intramural or club sports.

name: University of North Dakota
profile: The University of North Dakota was established in 1883 and is the oldest university in the state. It offers courses in over 200 fields of study, but is best known for its School of Aerospace Sciences, which trains pilots and air controllers. It has the biggest fleet of non-military training aircraft in the world. Students built the first college-designed spacesuit to be tested by NASA. The University of North Dakota competes in NCAA Division I-AA.

name: Belmont University
profile: Established in 1890 as a private institution, Belmont University was founded in Nashville’s Belmont Mansion, a large antebellum home which remains open to the public today. The liberal arts school quickly grew to be the largest non-denominational Christian university in the state. In keeping with the city’s strong music tradition, Belmont boasts one of the only AACSB International-accredited programs for entertainment and music business in the world. Famous alumni of the school include country stars Brad Paisley and Trisha Yearwood. The Belmont Bruins participate in NCAA Division I athletics with 17 intercollegiate sports teams. In 2010, Belmont caused widespread anti-discrimination protests when women’s soccer coach Lisa Howe was allegedly fired after announcing she was having a child with her same-sex partner. The controversy prompted President Robert Fisher to add sexual orientation to the school’s list of non-discrimination practices, and to officially recognize gay student organizations for the first time.

name: King's College
profile: King’s College is a liberal arts college located in Wilkes-Barre, Penn. It was established in 1946 and is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. The school’s small campus allows students to get just about anywhere on campus in five minutes or less and an average class size of 18. All first-year students must enroll in First Year Experience, a 14-week seminar that is part of the orientation program. It is designed to equip students with proper decision-making skills to navigate them through campus life at King’s. Forty majors are offered in business, engineering, humanities and social sciences, education, and sciences and allied health. The school reports that 99% of graduates are employed or attending grad school within six months of graduation. King’s College offers 19 athletic programs and competes in the NCAA Division III with Leo Lion as the mascot. The current president of the university is Rev. John Ryan, who regularly assists the local diocesan clergy by participating in weekend liturgies.

name: Milwaukee School of Engineering
profile: Milwaukee School of Engineering is a private university in Milwaukee, WI. It was founded in 1903. MSOE students often augment classroom education with hands-on experience: Undergraduates spend an average of 600 hours in the school’s state-of-the-art academic labs and there are plenty of opportunities to conduct research through the Academic Undergraduate Research (AUR) and Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) programs. The school also offers study abroad programs, which range from a few summer weeks to a year, in places like the Czech Republic, France, India and China. The Grohmann Museum houses the world’s most comprehensive art collection focused on the evolution of human work—the “Man at Work” collection contains over 1,000 paintings and sculptures. Milwaukee School of Engineering’s 21 varsity athletic teams mostly compete at the NCAA Division III level. Its teams are known as the Raiders. The university also offers 10 intramural sport programs.

name: Saint Edward's University
profile: Saint Edward’s University is a coeducational, private university located in Austin, TX. It was established in 1878 and was founded by the Rev. Edward Sorin of the Congregation of Holy Cross, who also founded the University of Notre Dame in Indiana. Today SEU remains affiliated with the Congregation of Holy Cross and the Catholic Church. Students can choose from more than 50 undergraduate programs, one of the most popular being the Academic Exploration Program designed for students who are undecided about their career goals. Every fall and spring the school hosts a large event for students called “Hillfest” featuring concerts with live music, food and fireworks. Rumor has it that to receive good grades on exams, students should rub the nose of the plaque of Fr. Paul Foik located outside the Munday Library. The school competes in NCAA Division II athletics.

name: Vanguard University of Southern California
profile: Vanguard University of Southern California is a private university founded in 1920 and is affiliated with the Assemblies of God Church. Located one hour from Los Angeles, Ca., there are 233 palm trees and an average of 329 days a year of sunshine on campus. Spiritual life features local church worship and internship opportunities and community outreach led by ministry teams. Vanguard offers over 20 undergraduate degrees through its 15 departments. The school hosts four centers and institutes covering topics of women and justice, Pentecostal studies and Hispanic leadership. Study abroad programs include Middle-East studies in Cairo, Chinese studies in Shanghai and Russian studies in Moscow. The school competes in NAIA athletics and its mascot is the Lion. In 2013, Vanguard won the NAIA Division I Men's Basketball championship in Kansas City, Mo.

name: Lyon College
profile: Lyon College is a private liberal arts college located on 136 acres in Batesville, Ark. It was established in 1872 and is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church. Its roots can be traced to Scotland, and this heritage can be seen in its athletic mascots, the Scots and Pipers, as well as a minor in Scottish music and culture. There is also the Scottish Heritage Program on campus. The Lyon College Pipe Band consists of students, faculty, staff, and volunteer musicians from the surrounding area; the band performs at convocations, community parades and other venues in the state. The university is home to a regulation disc golf course and a hiking and biking trail for its Education and Adventure Program (LEAP). Lyon competes in the NAIA’s Division I and the American Midwest Conference. In 2013 reinstated its football program after a 62-year absence. The motto is “Perseverance Conquers All, God Willing.”

name: California State University, Stanislaus
profile: California State University, Stanislaus, opened in 1957 in the agricultural Central Valley. The school is divided into six colleges, offering over 40 undergraduate degree programs; the most popular include business administration, teacher education and nursing. CSU Stanislaus also offers an online MBA program, the first online accredited MBA program in the state. Students are able to take extra course credits during the winter intersession. Favorite on-campus activities include Warrior Date Night, Finals Stress Relief and Get Your Grub On. CSU Stanislaus’ sports teams compete in the NCAA Divisioin II level.

name: Mercer University
profile: Mercer University is a private university located in Macon, Ga. It was established in 1833 by Baptists but is no longer religiously affiliated. Mercer was a pioneer in the service-learning movement that has been embraced by universities today. The university offers its students 38 majors, 34 minors and 9 pre-professional programs of study; the school has 8,300 students university-wide. Mercer has produced 12 governors, four U.S Senators, a United States Attorney General and two Pulitzer Prize winners. In 2011, the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation awarded the university $4.6 million to establish a Center for Collaborative Journalism. Mercer is in full swing on construction on a state-of-the-art athletic facility, the Moye Football and Lacrosse Complex. This will include a new field house, field and family plaza, serving as the new home of the Mercer University Bears. This school competes in NCAA Division I athletics.

name: Illinois State University
profile: Illinois State University in Normal, Il., was founded in 1857 as the state’s first public university. It offers more than 160 majors and minors and 41 masters, specialist and doctoral programs. The Mennonite College of Nursing has one of the nation’s highest board exam pass rates and uses a high-tech, state-of-the-art simulation lab and virtual hospital unit. Over 190,000 alumni connect through a network of regional clubs. The performing arts group, Gamma Phi Circus, established in 1929, is the oldest collegiate circus in the country. ISU has 10 residence halls on campus, one of which is among the tallest residence halls in the world. Originally founded as a teaching college, ISU’s motto is “Gladly we Learn and Teach.” ISU athletic teams are a part of the Missouri Valley Conference and are cheered on by its mascot, Reggie Redbird, homage to the cardinal, the state bird of Illinois.

name: Lycoming College
profile: Lycoming College is a private, four-year liberal arts college in Williamsport, PA. Founded in 1812, its name is based on the Native American word "lacomic," which means great stream. Lycoming offers hundreds of courses that lead to 36 majors, with business, criminal justice, archeology and political science among the 10 most popular. It is affiliated with the United Methodist Church and is one of the 50 oldest colleges in the country. The college has 17 men’s and women’s sports programs, known as the Warriors, they compete in the Middle Atlantic Conference. Lycoming’s 42-acre campus has 22 total building, nine of which are residence halls. Rich Hall, the college’s oldest residential building, recently underwent months of renovation and was reopened in late spring. Kent C. Trachte, the 15th president of Lycoming College, was inaugurated in April.

name: University of Nevada, Reno
profile: Founded in 1874 in Elko, Nevada, about 300 miles from its present location, which the school moved to in 1885, the university hosts the state’s only public medical school, and it’s known for its earthquake expertise; the school is home to one of the largest earthquake-simulation labs. It has one of the largest study abroad programs in the nation. Reno’s growing artistic community and the nearby annual counterculture festival, Burning Man, lend the city and school a bohemian feel. Reno is surrounded by a variety of geographic wonders, including Lake Tahoe, Black Rock Desert and Yosemite National Park. The university’s original core campus is listed on the National Registrar of Historic Places. The Wolf Pack varsity teams compete in Division I athletics; its mascot is Alphie the Wolf.

name: Saint John Fisher College
profile: Saint John Fisher College is a coeducational, private research university located in Rochester, NY, and affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. SJFC offers 33 undergraduate majors, 9 master's programs and three doctoral programs through five schools. The most popular of these majors are biology, management/accounting, nursing, sports management, psychology and communication/journalism. One of the most popular events is the Jamaican Advantage Thru Sports for Youth (JASY), where Fisher students travel to Jamaica and host a sports camp for at-risk 8-13 year olds. SJFC competes in NCAA Division III athletics. Since 2000, St. John Fisher College has been the home of the Buffalo Bills’ annual summer training camp.

name: Hiram College
profile: Hiram College is a private, liberal arts college founded in 1850 as the nonsectarian and coeducational Western Reserve Eclectic Institute. Today, the college offers 30 majors and 36 minors for traditional undergraduates, as well as pre-professional programs. Hiram has a tuition guarantee that protects students from rising tuition rates by holding tuition rates and fees constant from freshman to senior year. In the last decade, Hiram’s undergraduate program has increased by more than 50%, with significant gains in out-of-state and minority student populations. The Terrier is an on campus bakery that is run by students and a part of a new seminar called “The Art of Making Dough.” The program was initiated to teach and encourage students to run student-operated businesses. In addition to the business initiative, Hiram offers nearly 100 clubs and student organizations. James A.
