Garfield, who served as a college instructor and principal prior to being elected U.S. President, attended Western Reserve Eclectic Institute, which later became Hiram. His wife, First Lady Lucretia Garfield also graduated from the school. Athletically, Hiram competes at the NCAA Division III level in the North Coast Athletic Conference. The team mascot is the Terrier.

name: CUNY, John Jay College Criminal Justice
profile: Founded in 1964, John Jay College of Criminal Justice is a senior college of the City University of New York located in Manhattan. The majority of students are New York state residents. Some 30 bachelor’s majors are offered, although the college is famous for its criminal studies, forensic psychology and forensic science programs. The college offers undergraduate research opportunities in criminal justice-related fields, including crime prevention, human rights, terrorism and race crime. The college’s criminology graduate program is nationally top ranked. Notable alumni include Dr. Henry Lee, a well-known forensic scientist who was involved in O.J. Simpson case, post 9/11 forensic investigation and re-investigation of President Kennedy’s assassination. John Jay College of Criminal Justice sports teams, named the Bloodhounds, compete at the NCAA Division III level.

name: University of Northern Iowa
profile: The University of Northern Iowa’s roots go back to an orphanage established in 1866 for children displaced by the Civil War. It turned to training teachers in 1876, becoming the Iowa State Normal School. Today, the university offers over 90 majors in five colleges. UNI compete in NCAA Division I-AA athletics, the mascot is the Panther and the school colors are purple and gold. The UNI Campanile, a 324-foot bell tower, is the venue for the campus tradition called Campaniling, in which students gather to kiss long-time lovers or new acquaintances in the moonlight.

name: Oklahoma Baptist University
profile: Founded in 1910, Oklahoma Baptist University is a private liberal arts university in Shawnee, Ok. Students can choose from bachelor’s degrees in 84 areas of study. Oklahoma Baptist offers study abroad and mission opportunities. Freshmen must wear beanies during orientation activities, one of the oldest traditions on campus. Since 1937, the university has presented the “Hanging of the Green,” an annual Christmas ceremony. There are over 110 student organizations and 20 intramural sports at Oklahoma Baptist. The school is shaped by its religious affiliation: All faculty members are active Christians and the student handbook requires that “students, faculty, and staff will comply with the biblical standard for sexuality,” which is defined as “faithful commitment in marriage between a man and woman and purity in relationships outside of marriage.” Those found in violation may face disciplinary action. Student-athletes currently compete in the Sooner Athletic Conference (SAC) of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA). Ohio Baptist’s varsity teams are nicknamed the Bison and Lady Bison.

name: University of South Dakota
profile: The public, coeducational research institution was established in 1862 and plays a central role in the state – the school says it has educated 70% of South Dakota’s attorneys and 48% of its physicians. It offers 205 undergraduate programs and 66 graduate programs divided into eight schools and colleges. The most popular fields of study are nursing, business, psychology, elementary teacher education and biology. The USD campus is home to the National Music Museum, which holds more than 14,800 instruments from a wide variety of cultures and time periods. Each fall the school celebrates “Dakota Days” for their homecoming weekend. The University of South Dakota Coyotes compete in Division I sports.

name: University of Alaska, Fairbanks
profile: The school was established in 1917 as the Alaska Agricultural College and School of Mines. UAF has eight colleges and schools that offer 160 degrees and certificates in 121 disciplines. Some of the most popular majors include biological sciences, mechanical engineering, emergency services, business administration and pre-nursing qualification. In the Starvation Gulch, an event to kick off the school year that dates back to 1923, student teams compete to build the most creative flaming wood sculptures. The athletic teams are known as the Nanooks. The Division I rifle team has won 10 NCAA National Rifle Championships since 1994.

name: Saint Francis College
profile: Saint Francis College, located in historical Brooklyn Heights, is primarily a commuter school. The college offers 72 major and minors in 19 departments, with the most popular including communication arts and management. SFC was established in 1859 by Franciscan friars and was first private school in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn. Thanks to its proximity to the world’s financial capital on Wall Street, students are surrounded by professional internship opportunities. Notable alumni include star referee Dick Bavetta, who has officiated over 2,500 games in the NBA. Students participate in 19 NCAA Division I athletic teams.

name: Fairleigh Dickinson University, Metropolitan Campus
profile: Fairleigh Dickinson, New Jersey’s largest private university, is made up of four campuses located in Teaneck (Metropolitan Campus) and Madison, N.J., Vancouver, Canada and Wroxton, UK. Today, FDU offers over 100 degree programs in the associate’s to doctoral levels. When it was established in 1942, it originally opened its doors to primarily World War II veterans, immigrants and visiting international students. Today, more than a third of students are minority or international and three of every four undergraduates commute from home or nearby apartments. Since the Metropolitan Campus is a short commute from the Big Apple, Farleigh Dickinson offers courses with hands-on learning opportunities on Wall Street, Broadway, the United Nations and many other distinguished organizations. Popular majors include business, professional, science and health care programs. The Metropolitan Campus is also a NCAA Division I athletic school, offering eight men’s teams and 11 women’s teams. Their mascot is Nitro the Knight.

name: North Central College
profile: Established in 1861, North Central College is a private institution affiliated with the United Methodist Church located in the small, historic town of Naperville, IL. The college offers over 55 undergraduate majors and students can also study a variety of pre-professional programs, including dentistry, occupational therapy, veterinary medicine and the law. Approximately 100 undergraduates each year participate in a wide array of study abroad and student exchange opportunities, with popular programs in Costa Rica and England. Each year, North Central hosts over 500 fine and performing arts performances by renowned artists such as cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. The college radio station, WONC, has won 20 Marconi Awards—more than any other American college. North Central College competes in NCAA Division III with 22 intercollegiate sports and its mascot is Chippy the Cardinal. The winner of an annual football game between North Central and its rival Wheaton College receives the “Little Brass Bell.”

name: South Dakota State University
profile: South Dakota State University is a public research university in Brookings, SD. Established in 1881, it is the state’s largest university. Approximately 36% of students come from outside of South Dakota. The university offers 74 majors, 67 minors, 42 specializations, 30 master’s degree programs and 13 Ph.D. programs. The university is committed to research: research expenditures for Fiscal Year 2012 totaled nearly $70 million. Undergraduates can gain hands-on research experience and submit their findings to the Journal of Undergraduate Research, which is published once every year. Outside of the classroom and laboratory, students can participate in over 200 student organizations on the school’s 275-acre campus, including eight fraternities and four sororities. South Dakota State’s marching band has performed in presidential inaugural parades, at the Tournament of Roses Parade and at NFL games. South Dakota State’s student-athletes compete primarily in the Summit League at the NCAA Division I level.

name: Lynn University
profile: Lynn University is a four-year, private university located in Boca Raton, FL, near Miami and Fort Lauderdale. It was established in 1962, and about one-quarter of its student body is made up of international students, including students with dual citizenship/residency. Lynn offers 25 bachelor’s degrees and 25 master’s degrees and graduate certificate programs. The university provides an accelerated three-year degree program. The university has five residence halls and first-year students are required to stay in campus housing. There are over 30 student clubs and organization and students enjoy the five freshwater lakes on the 123-acre campus. The university competes in the NCAA Division II athletics.

name: University of Colorado, Denver
profile: Established in 1912 as an extension of the University of Colorado at Boulder, the school now has over 130 programs of study in 13 schools. It's divided between the Anschutz medical campus in Aurora and the Denver campus, which offers liberal arts and professional programs in eight schools and colleges. The first liver transplant in the world was performed at the School of Medicine. The university has developed a range of sustainability initiatives from climate action plans to building automation systems. The school also offers a wide variety of classes that integrate sustainability into the curriculum. The Alternative Break program sends students outside the state to volunteer and explore social and cultural issues each semester.

name: University of Texas, Dallas
profile: Founded as the Southwest Center for Advanced Studies, an institution envisioned and funded by the founders of a Texas Instruments, the university was established in 1969 when the SCAS transferred assets to the State of Texas. Currently, UT Dallas offers 133 degree programs from criminology to biomedical engineering as well as arts and technology. Since 2007, students have participated in an annual Cardboard Boat Regatta, in which four-person teams build vessels using only cardboard and duct tape. The school offers full-ride scholarships to chess champions around the world, and its team has competed in the Final Four of Chess, also known as the President’s Cup, numerous times since 2001 – it has won or tied for first place five times. It competes in NCAA Division III athletics and the school mascot is the Temoc.

name: Oglethorpe University
profile: Oglethorpe University is a private liberal arts college in Atlanta, Ga. Founded in 1835, the university is named after James Oglethorpe, founder of the colony of Georgia. Students hail from 34 states and 28 countries. Oglethorpe’s core curriculum, named the Core, encompasses a wide range of knowledge, including music and biology. The first modern time capsule, the Crypt of Civilization, is located on campus; the capsule was sealed in 1940 and is not to be opened until 8113 A.D. Traditions include Oglethorpe Day, a celebration of the founding of Georgia, and the Battle of Bloody Marsh, a tug-of-war competition between student and faculty teams. Oglethorpe athletes compete in the Southern Athletic Conference (NCAA Division III). The school is known for its unique mascot: The Stormy Petrel, a seabird admired by James Oglethorpe.

name: Western State Colorado University
profile: Established in 1901, Western State Colorado University is a coeducational public liberal arts college located in Gunnison, CO. It was the first public liberal arts college west of Colorado’s Western Slope. The institution’s location in the Rocky Mountains gives students access to hiking, climbing and camping in the summer and skiing and snowboarding in the winter. A popular program is Wilderness Pursuits, which provides an affordable and safe way for students to participate in outdoor activities. Western State Colorado University has one of nation’s highest elevations for a college campus at 7,700 feet above sea level. The school can be identified by the large ‘W’ on that sits on Tenderfoot Mountain, overlooking the town of Gunnison. Students operate the college radio station 91.1 KWSB, which was founded in 1968 and is one of the oldest college radio stations in the country. The university competes in NCAA Division II athletics and the school mascot is, appropriately, the Mountaineer.

name: Pace University
profile: Pace University is a private university with campuses in New York City and Westchester County, NY. Founded in 1906, the university offers over 100 undergraduate majors and minors. The optional Winter Intersession allows students to earn three credits in four weeks. Pace has a large internship program and the school has produced 37 Fulbright scholars, 19 Watson fellows and 11 Rockefeller fellows since 2002. Approximately 70% of freshman students live on campus at both the New York City and Westchester locations. Pace is committed to helping students transition to college: High school juniors and seniors have the opportunity to take courses at Pace or high school courses supervised by Pace faculty. The television show Inside the Actor’s Studio is filmed at Pace’s Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts. The school’s varsity athletic teams, known as the Setters, primarily compete in Division II athletics.

name: University of North Carolina, Asheville
profile: The only dedicated liberal arts institution in the University of North Carolina education system, the school offers students 30 different major options. More than 60 percent of students complete original research in their field of study while on campus and nearly 20 percent of students take advantage of study abroad opportunities. UNC Asheville is headquarters for the Council of Public Liberal Arts Colleges, an organization of 27 state-supported liberal arts colleges that work together to put the liberal arts in a relevant, global context for modern students. The Kimmel Arena, part of the Sherrill Center which includes a meditation room and fitness center, is a new addition to campus that can seat as many as 3,800 students for men’s and women’s basketball games, commencements and lectures. UNC Asheville competes in NCAA Division I, the school colors are blue and white and the mascot is Rocky the Bulldog.

name: Oregon Institute of Technology
profile: The Oregon Institute of Technology is a public university in Klamath Falls, OR. It is the only public institute of technology in the Pacific Northwest. Founded in 1947, Oregon Tech offers 32 degree options. In addition to its well-known engineering programs, the school offers a diverse range of degrees covering fields such as communications and nursing. The school blends theory and practice in its curriculum. Oregon Tech is devoted to the study of renewable energy: In 2005, it became the first school in North America to offer a bachelor’s degree in Renewable Energy Engineering, and the Oregon Renewable Energy Center (OREC), established in 2001, strives to introduce renewable energy technology to businesses and consumers. The school hosts an annual Halloween haunted house that attracts as many as 1,700 visitors each year. There are over 40 student clubs on campus. Oregon Tech’s athletic teams, called the Owls, compete in the Cascade Collegiate Conference (CCC) of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA).

name: Hastings College
profile: Hastings College was founded in 1882 by early Nebraskan settlers with the support of the Presbyterian Church. Today, the Christian liberal arts college maintains a relationship with the church through weekly optional Chapel services and a requirement of at least one religion course to graduate. Hastings’ undergraduate students can choose from 64 majors in 32 areas of study and 12 pre-professional programs, in addition to personalized programs for students who wish to create their own courses of study. Annual events include the Boar’s Head Dinner, a formal meal served by the college that begins as a student walks through the dining hall with an actual boar’s head on a platter. The Bobby Gottsch Jr. Memorial College Rodeo was named Rodeo of the Year by the National Intercollegiate Rodeo Association in 2013. Hastings College competes athletically at the NCAA Division II level with 22 varsity sports teams. The school mascot is the Bronco. Bill Parcells, the famous NFL coach, began his career as a linebackers coach at Hastings College.

name: East Carolina University
profile: East Carolina University in Greenville, NC was founded in 1907 as a teacher training school and has grown into a research university. ECU surgeons were the first in the country to perform the minimally invasive robotic-assisted mitral valve heart surgery, and ECU faculty developed the widely used Greenville Gastric Bypass procedure. Alumni include three-time Pulitzer Prize winner Rick Atkinson, Academy Award winner Sandra Bullock and 2009 NFL Offensive Player of the Year Chris Johnson. The university competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is a pirate, selected by the students to reflect the legacy of Blackbeard, who operated in the region in the early 18th century. Artifacts from Blackbeard’s flagship, the Queen Anne’s Revenge, are kept at the QAR Conservation Lab at ECU.

name: Mary Baldwin College
profile: Mary Baldwin College is a four-year, women’s private college located in downtown Staunton, VA. It was established in 1842 and is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church. The school has a student-to-faculty ratio of 12:1 and two undergraduate pathways with same requirements for the bachelor’s degree: College for Women and Adult Degree. The residential women’s college has about 780 students while the adult degree program has 1,200 women and men enrolled plus 290 men and women graduate students. Mary Baldwin annually hosts Apple Day, an all-day carnival with classes cancelled campus-wide. Mary Baldwin College competes in NCAA Division III athletics and its mascot is Gladys the Fighting Squirrel.

name: University of North Florida
profile: Established in 1972, it is a public university located on 1,400 acres in Jacksonville. It is organized into five colleges: Computing, Engineering and Construction; Education and Human Services; Business; Arts and Sciences; and Health. The school ranks highly for service to students who are military veterans. The University of North Florida competes in NCAA Division I-AAA athletics; the school’s mascot is the Osprey.

name: Rowan University
profile: Rowan University is a public research university primarily located in Glassboro, NJ. Rowan was founded in 1923 as a teachers' college. Students can choose from 85 bachelor’s and 21 certification programs. All classes are taught by professors. For those looking to experience other cultures, Rowan offers more than 200 study abroad programs in more than 50 countries. For those interested in culture close to home, the university’s choral, early music, instrumental and jazz ensembles perform year-round in Rowan’s 895-seat concert hall and 225-seat recital hall. Rowan also puts on four stage productions per year and operates an art gallery. Rowan’s varsity athletic teams, known as the Profs, at the NCAA Division III level.

name: Old Dominion University
profile: Old Dominion University is a public research university in Norfolk, VA. In addition to its 251-acre main campus, Old Dominion is a leader in distance learning degree programs, which include both on-site and online learning. It was founded in 1930 as a division of the College of William and Mary and became an independent institution in 1962. Old Dominion offers 124 undergraduate programs, including approximately 2,400 courses offered by 56 departments. Students interested in conducting research can seek support and funding through Old Dominion’s Undergraduate Research Program. Over 8,000 students are involved with the more than 300 student organizations on campus, which includes nearly 30 fraternities and sororities. Old Dominion’s varsity teams, called the Monarchs and Lady Monarchs, compete in Division I athletics. Notable attendees include former United States President Jimmy Carter.

name: Otterbein University
profile: Otterbein University is a private university in Westerville, Ohio. It was one of the first U.S. institutions to include female faculty members from the time of its establishment, in 1848. It is affiliated with the United Methodist Church. Otterbein offers 73 majors and 44 minors. Notable spots on Otterbein’s 140-acre campus include Towers Hall, which is on the National Register of Historic Places, and the Frank Museum of Art, which specializes in non-Western art. Otterbein University Theatre and Otterbein Summer Theatre put on nine shows each year, ranging from Shakespeare to musicals and experimental works. There are numerous student organizations on campus, including 7 fraternities and 6 sororities. The school’s Center for Community Engagement offers various volunteer opportunities. Nearly 75% of students participated in community service during the 2012-13 academic year. Otterbein’s athletes compete in Division III athletics. They are known as the Cardinals.

name: California State University, Northridge
profile: California State University, Northridge was founded in 1958 and is one of the nation’s largest universities. CSUN is the first institution in the world to have a grid-connected fuel cell plant – it generates more than 8.3 million kWh of electricity and prevents more than 6,400 tons of carbon dioxide from entering the atmosphere annually. The waste water from the plant is used to irrigate the university’s outdoor subtropical rain forest, which is fully sustained from industrial waste byproducts. The multi-dimensional CSUN sign sculpture, developed by engineering student John Banks in 1975, spells out C-S-U-N when viewed from north, south, east or west. Adjacent to Hollywood, various films and televisions shows used the campus for shooting, including: CSI: Crime Scene Investigation, Star Trek and American Idol. The university has nine colleges offering 64 baccalaureate degrees. Besides traditional majors, the school offers a B.A. Special Major, designed to allow students to combine at least 3 academic disciplines to achieve their educational goals. CSUN competes at the NCAA Division I level.

name: University of Alaska, Anchorage
profile: The university was established in 1954, five years before Alaska gained statehood. It offers over 150 undergraduate majors; popular ones include nursing, education, business administration, human services, accounting, psychology and aviation technology. It runs a medical school in connection with state universities in Washington, Wyoming, Montana and Idaho called WWAMI that is revamping its curriculum, shifting from the traditional four-year structure to three phases -- foundations, patient care and explore-and-focus -- beginning with the 2015 entering class. The school competes in Division I in gymnastics and hockey and in Division II in nine other sports. The school mascot is the Seawolf, a mythical Alaskan native creature.

name: Richard Stockton College of New Jersey
profile: Richard Stockton College of New Jersey is a public university in Galloway, NJ, near Atlantic City. Named after an original signer of the Declaration of Independence, the college first opened its doors to an inaugural class of 1,000 in 1971. Undergraduate students can select from more than 40 majors in seven academic schools. Stockton also offers 15 graduate degree programs. Those looking to be active on campus can join one of the 130-plus student clubs and organizations, including over 20 Greek chapters. Stockton strives to be commuter-friendly—it offers a carpooling service, discounted NJ Transit passes and rental commuter lockers. Prominent campus facilities include a 154,000-square-foot rec center, the Noyes Museum of Art and the newly-opened Unified Science Center. Richard Stockton’s varsity athletic teams, known as the Ospreys, compete at the NCAA Division III level. There are also nearly 20 club and intramural sport programs on campus.

name: Elmira College
profile: Founded in 1855 to offer women an equivalent to the finest men’s colleges, Elmira became a coeducational institution in 1969. It is one of the oldest colleges that granted equal degrees to both men and women. Seven of Elmira College’s buildings are on the National Registrar of Historic Places. Elmira was awarded its charter of Phi Beta Kappa, the nation’s oldest and most prestigious honors society, in 1940. Mark Twain wrote his masterpieces in Elmira, just a few miles from the campus, and the school holds an extensive archive of his original work. Every year, students look forward to Mountain Day, a tradition begun in 1918 wherein the President cancels classes to provide pupils and faculty a day off to come together outside the classroom. Students must sing to earn this reward. In the Holiday Banquet & Ball, students invite their favorite faculty member or administrator to join them for a traditional Thanksgiving holiday dinner and then enjoy a weekend of holiday festivities. The college competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and the school mascot is the Soaring Eagle.

name: University of Texas, El Paso
profile: The University of Texas, El Paso opened its doors in 1914 and has since grown to become a public research university with more than $76 million in annual research spending. The university’s campus was built to imitate fortresses in the Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan. In 1955, El Paso became the first desegregated undergraduate program in the state of Texas. Each year, the College of Engineering pays homage to the patron saint of engineers, Saint Patrick, with their annual TCM Day, wearing green clothing and painting areas of campus green. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the teams are known as the Miners. In 1965-66, when the school was named Texas Western, the men’s basketball team made history when they won a national championship with five African-American starters, defeating an all-white Kentucky team. Within two years of this win, all-white leagues like the Atlantic Coast Conference, Southwestern Conference and the Southeastern Conference became integrated.

name: Emory and Henry College
profile: Emory and Henry College, founded in 1836, is affiliated with the Methodist Church and offers more than 25 programs and 50 degrees. The Emory and Henry campus, in Emory, VA, was used by the U.S. Navy as a training base for officers during World War II, which helped maintain enrollment at the college while many other students were away at battle. Frank Byron Rowlett, a member of the class of 1929, led a War Department group in writing ciphers for the U.S. Army and breaking Japanese code systems; he retired in 1966 as a founding father of the National Security Agency, which created a distinguished achievement award in his honor. Emory and Henry College is one of a handful of schools whose entire campus is listed on the National Historic Registrar. Around campus there are sculpted white owls with the initials ES. The letters represent Emory and Henry's secret society, the Emorium Society. EHC athletic teams, nicknamed the Wasps, compete in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: Wells College
profile: Established in 1868, Wells College is a coeducational, private liberal arts college located in Aurora, NY. Originally an all-girls school, founded by Henry Wells, who is also the founder of Wells Fargo and American Express, today Wells College offers over 25 undergraduate and students have the option to cross-enroll at Cornell University or Ithaca College. Additionally, the school has 3-2 programs in math and physical sciences, environmental studies, biological and chemical studies and in engineering. There are also 4-1 programs in education and business administration. These programs give students the opportunity to earn both a bachelor’s degree from Wells and an additional professional degree from these affiliated schools within five years. Some classes at Wells College are conducted in a seminar style. Since 1869, when graduation activities were first held, the school has hosted a commencement ceremony with activities such as rides in the original Wells Fargo stagecoach. Wells College’s 14 varsity sports teams compete in NCAA Division III.

name: Montclair State University
profile: Montclair State University is a public university in Montclair, NJ. It was founded in 1908 as the New Jersey State Normal School at Montclair and its 250-acre campus is 14 miles from New York City. The university’s six colleges and schools offer undergraduates more than 50 majors and over 60 minors and concentrations. The most popular bachelor’s degrees at MSU are psychology, business administration, biology, family and child studies and English. The optional winter session allows students to earn up to four credits in as little as four weeks. There are over 120 clubs and organizations on campus. The school’s student-athletes compete at the NCAA Division III level. Notable Montclair State attendees include author and poet Allen Ginsberg and actor Bruce Willis.

name: Bethel College
profile: Founded in 1887 in North Newton, KS, Bethel College is a liberal arts institution affiliated with the Mennonite Church. With an undergraduate population of just under 500, Bethel maintains an average class size of 21 students and offers a four-year graduation guarantee. Students who are unable to complete their degree in four years receive free tuition to finish. While the majority of students are non Mennonite, Bethel’s Common Ground core requirements include a series of courses and seminars that educate students on questions of faith, politics and society. The school offers study abroad opportunities in 17 countries, including Australia, India, Japan and Spain. There are more than 50 clubs and organizations, including an award-winning forensics and debate team, on campus. Bethel competes in NAIA Division II athletics. Its mascot, the Thresher, is named after the threshing stone—a wheat harvesting tool used by early Russian Mennonite settlers.

name: University of Texas, Pan American
profile: Established in 1927 as a junior college, it is a Hispanic-serving institution that offers 57 bachelor programs within its seven colleges. Students who have earned less than 30 credit hours and who are under 21 are required to live on campus unless they are married or live in the region. In 2004 former President Dr. Belinda Cardenas began a commencement tradition in which the graduating students wear a stole around their necks with the school colors and seal for the graduation ceremony. At the end of the ceremony the graduates are encouraged to give the stole to a person who mentored or influenced them in some way. Notable alumni include Texas State Senator Eddie Lucio, poet Rossy Evelin Lima and actor Valente Rodriguez. The university competes athletically at the NCAA Division I level with 14 varsity teams in the Western Athletic Conference. The school mascot is the Bronc; a 2,000-pound bronze Bronc statue stands guard at the school’s entrance.

name: Hood College
profile: Founded in 1893 as a women’s college in Frederick, MD, Hood began allowing male enrollment in the 1970s but didn’t provide male residencies until 2003. At Hood College, elementary education and business administration are among the most popular majors. Hood College offers 30 majors and 15 programs of study. Incoming freshmen at Hood College are given Dinks, small beanie hats colored differently depending on class. The hats are a tradition at the school and are worn for major occasions and campus events. Each freshmen class decorates a banner to be displayed in the Coblentz Dining Room and adds to the banner to celebrate each year at Hood. Brodbeck Hall, the oldest building on campus, is said to be haunted; a report by the campus posited that the resident apparitions were of the friendly sort. Ninety-five percent of full-time faculty hold a doctorate or terminal degree in their field. Hood College participates in NCAA Division III athletics, and the school mascot is Blaze.

name: Alfred University
profile: Alfred University is a private school with state-sponsored programs in engineering, art and design located 100 miles from Buffalo, NY. Thirty-one states and 20 countries are represented in the student body, which are offered over 40 undergraduate majors, internships, research and study abroad opportunities. While study abroad opportunities are offered to all students, Art & Design students can study in England and Italy while engineering students have opportunities in Europe, Japan and New Zealand. The school has a two semester system, it also offers an “Allen Term”—full semester online courses during the month-long winter break. According to local legend, the university (as well as the village of Alfred) is named after medieval England’s King Alfred, who was known for his commitment to education. The Black Knight, a plastered knight figurine, is the object of local folklore. Originally appearing in the 1907 yearbook, he was stolen by various sororities and fraternities until he disappeared in 1939 for 38 years. The Black Knight was placed in a glass case in the Powell Campus Center in 2005, but a student quickly broke the glass and stole it in the middle of the night.

name: Guilford College
profile: Founded in 1837 in Greensboro, NC, Guilford College is the only Quaker college in the southeastern U.S. Guilford offers a unique individualized study program as well as 36 majors and 53 minors. Guilford is known as one of the most environmentally responsible colleges in the U.S. The school has its own farm where they grow their own low-carbon, low-transportation produce. It has nearly doubled in size within the last year. Each summer the campus hosts the Eastern Music Festival (EMF), a series of concerts where both professional and student musicians come together to attend seminars and put on live performances. During each spring, students and alumni alike enjoy a large concert series called “Serendipity.” Guilford’s Bryan Series lectures have attracted numerous high-profile speakers, including Bill Clinton, Tony Blair and Ken Burns. This year the campus is expecting to welcome Anderson Cooper and Ron Howard, among others. The Guilford Quaker’s compete as an NCAA Division III school in the Old Dominion Athletic Conference.

name: SUNY, College at Oneonta
profile: Established in 1889, SUNY Oneonta is composed of five undergraduate schools that offer 70 majors. The campus is located about halfway between nearby Binghamton and Albany, NY. Oneonta has the largest optical telescope in New York State and one of the best graduate training programs for museum professionals in the nation. Oneonta students choose from 13 travel exchange programs in countries like Ghana, Ecuador and Sweden and have access to more than 600 other study abroad options offered through the SUNY network. The Oneonta Red Dragons compete in NCAA Division III. Green Dragon Week is dedicated to hosting events focused on sustainability and waste reduction, including a recycled fashion show and a zero waste ice cream social.

name: Saint John's University (NY)
profile: Saint John’s University is a private research university based in Queens, NY. It was established in 1870 and is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. With five campuses around New York and Italy, Saint John’s University’s mission is global. The school offers more than 81 majors, ranging from biology and education to actuarial science and enterprise regulation. The university core curriculum requires students to immerse themselves in the urban culture by requiring a three-credit Discover New York class of all undergraduates. Former governor of New York Mario Cuomo hails from this university. The Saint John’s Red Storm has 17 NCAA Division I teams.

name: Mississippi College
profile: Mississippi College is a private liberal arts and sciences university in Clinton, MS. Founded in 1826, it is the oldest higher education institution in Mississippi and the second oldest Baptist university in the nation. Students can select from over 80 areas of study and can get involved in the over 40 student organizations on campus. Mississippi College also offers 16 graduate programs and a variety of professional degrees, including the Juris Doctor. Provine Chapel, the school’s oldest building, has been a campus fixture since 1860. During the Civil War, Ulysses S. Grant used the chapel as a military hospital. The school’s spring scholarship dinners have featured a number of notable speakers over the past few years, including former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, former U.S. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Forbes Editor-in-Chief Steve Forbes. Mississippi College’s athletic teams are transitioning back into the Gulf South Conference (NCAA Division II) after a stint in the American Southwest Conference (Division II). The school’s varsity intercollegiate athletic teams are known as the Choctaws.

name: Florida Atlantic University
profile: Florida Atlantic University, located in Boca Raton, FL, was established in 1964. The school’s location on the southeast coast provides ample opportunity for students to take their learning onto the shores of the Atlantic Ocean. The Harbor Branch Oceanographic Institute is a world-renowned facility that attracts students and faculty alike who are interested in ocean engineering, marine life research and conservation, among other specialities. FAU’s Southeast National Marine Renewable Energy Center recently announced that it would be partnering with the U.S. Department of the Interior’s Bureau of Ocean Energy Management (BOEM) to become the world’s first ocean current energy test site. FAU is also home to one of the nation’s most active university record label companies, Hoot/Wisdom Recordings. The Florida Atlantic University Owls are a NCAA Division I school. Every year before the first football game of the season, there is a school-wide bonfire in which the mascot of the opposing team is burned.

name: University of North Carolina, Charlotte
profile: The University of North Carolina at Charlotte recently funded a groundbreaking breast cancer study with money raised by their volleyball program. The school has considered changing its name to University of Charlotte to avoid confusion with the other UNC schools, primarily Chapel Hill. Initially called Charlotte College, UNC Charlotte was established in 1946 as part of the GI Bill initiative to expand public education. It has grown to produce more start-up small businesses than any other school in the U.S., and is the largest institution of higher learning in the region. The University of North Carolina, Charlotte competes in NCAA Division I-AAA athletics and the school’s teams are known as the 49ers, a nod to Charlotte’s gold mining heritage and the school’s proximity to North Carolina Highway 49. The 49ers basketball team is the most popular sports team on campus and has reached the NCAA Championships 11 times.

name: Oklahoma City University
profile: Oklahoma City University, which is affiliated with the United Methodist Church, occupies a scenic 104-acre campus in Oklahoma City. It is just minutes from a number of educational, social, and cultural entertainment opportunities. The university offers more than 60 undergraduate majors and 12 graduate degrees across a variety of fields including liberal arts, fine arts, sciences and business. All of Oklahoma City University classes are taught by professors, 78% of whom hold the highest degrees in their fields, and not by graduate assistants. There are more than 60 student-led organizations on campus including six national fraternities and sororities, their own Habitat for Humanity chapter, a number of multicultural student associations, and a student government. Oklahoma City University also boasts a successful athletic program. The Stars have won 46 national championships including the NAIA Division I men’s basketball championship in 2008.

name: Abilene Christian University
profile: Chapel time and bible courses are requirements at Abilene Christian University, a private university affiliated with the Churches of Christ located 180 miles of Dallas/Fort Worth. It offers an array of traditional liberal arts and science majors as well as degrees in biblical text, youth and family ministry and vocational missions. About two hundred students go on spring break missions each year to cities all over the country. This year ACU received the Apple Distinguished School Award for the third time for its ConnectEd: Mobile Learning initiative. ACU was one of the first schools in the nation to embrace iPhone and iPod Touches for academic purposes, gifting the incoming class of 2009 a free Apple device. While Greek life societies do not exist, ACU offers a number of social club equivalents and nearly one third of students participate in “Sing Song,” an annual musical variety show since 1956. Notable alumni include several NFL stars and Olympic athletes. Ove Johansson kicked the longest field goal (69 yards) in football history at a Wildcats homecoming game in 1976.

name: Rider University
profile: Rider University is a private university located primarily in Lawrenceville, NJ. Rider also operates a campus in Princeton. The school was established in 1865 and offers 65 undergraduate and over 20 graduate programs. Students hail from 41 states, 3 U.S. territories and 77 countries. There are many student organizations and events at Rider, ranging from math clubs to theater productions. The university recognizes 11 fraternities and sororities. While Rider’s official mascot is the Bronc, its unofficial mascot may very well be the cranberry. The school’s first president, Andrew J. Rider, was a well known cranberry grower. In celebration of Rider’s profession—and aptly-named horse, Cranberry—the school hosts “Cranberry Fest” each year. Rider’s 20 athletic teams compete at the NCAA Division I level.

name: University of Alabama, Birmingham
profile: The school was established in 1936 as an extension of The University of Alabama. UAB offers 137 degrees with 48 baccalaureate programs, 49 master’s options, 37 doctoral and three professional programs. The university’s hospital is the largest in the state, offering health science students valuable experience. UAB has a forgiveness policy under which students can repeat up to four different courses in which they earned a C, D or F and have the grade removed from their GPA. Each year during homecoming week, students participate in the Gurney Derby Race, drag racing with decorated gurneys against one another. The school competes in Division I-A athletics, and the teams are nicknamed the Blazers.

name: Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, Daytona Beach
profile: Founded in 1925 exactly 22 years after the flight of the Wright Brothers, Embry-Riddle began as a school to train pilots and aircraft mechanics. It is one of the residential campuses of Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, which specializes in the science, practice and business of aviation and aerospace, offering more than 40 undergraduate and graduate degrees. Students interested in professional flight training are guaranteed to fly a school owned aircraft within two weeks of being on campus. The Air Force ROTC at Embry-Riddle is the largest in the nation and the engineering physics department is the largest in the U.S. and the only one to specialize in aerospace physics. Current NASA astronaut Nicole Stott and former astronaut Susan Kilrain are notable alumni. After a student developed the idea to convert used cooking oil from the cafeteria into biodiesel to run campus lawn-maintenance vehicles, an innovative biodiesel production facility opened in 2012. Its athletic teams compete in the NAIA.

name: Maryville College
profile: Maryville College is located between the Great Smoky Mountains National Park and Knoxville in Tennessee’s third largest city, Maryville. Founded in 1819, Maryville remains affiliated with the Presbyterian Church (USA) and is the 12th-oldest institution of higher learning in the South. Maryville offers over 60 fields of study through majors, minors and pre-professional degrees. There is even a signature program for majors in “Still Deciding.”As a Maryville senior, students participate in the “Senior Study,” a program that includes a graduate exam and research thesis or creative project. Maryville has around 1,070 students from 17 states and 15 countries and competes in NCAA Division III athletics and the school’s mascot is the Scots. .

name: University of Massachusetts, Boston
profile: The only public university in Boston, this year the school is celebrating its 50th anniversary. Located on Columbia Point in Boston Harbor, it offers 193 academic programs in 11 colleges and sponsors more than 30 research centers and institutes in Boston, including the Adult Literacy Resource Institute and the Collaborative Institute for Oceans, Climate, and Security. The John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum is next to the campus. In 2009, the university launched a 25-year Master Plans that is aimed at adding new academic buildings, renovating existing infrastructure and constructing a new segment of the waterfront path called the HarborWalk. It competes in NCAA Division III athletics, the school colors are blue and white, and the mascot is the Beacon.

name: Humboldt State University
profile: Established in 1913 as a teaching college, Humboldt State University is a small public university located in Arcata, CA, some 250 miles north of San Francisco and the northernmost school in the California State University system. HSU offers 49 different types of bachelor’s degree programs, the most popular of which include biology, business administration and wildlife. Housing on campus is divided into themed houses of like-minded students, such as the Colony of the Arts and the Eco-Living community. Starting in 1967, students put together the annual Humboldt Film Festival, now one of the nation’s oldest student-run film festivals. On campus there are over 180 clubs to join. Additionally, there are seven active Greek chapters. In 1987 students founded the optional Graduation Pledge of Social and Environmental Responsibility to encourage students to be mindful of their environmental impact. Ironically, the school’s NCAA Division II athletic teams are known as the Lumberjacks.

name: Saint Catherine University
profile: Saint Catherine University, also known as Saint Kate's, is a private university located in Saint Paul, MN. While men can enroll in associate, graduate and continuing education programs, the heart of the university remains the baccalaureate college for women. It was established in 1905 and is affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church. The most popular majors at Saint Kate’s are nursing, social work, public health, business administration and accounting. With about 20% of the student body enrolled in the nursing program, the school implemented a Mayo Innovation Scholars program where students can research Mayo Clinic invention ideas and create business plans for a medical product. St. Kate’s is a partner in the Associated Colleges of the Twin Cities (ACTC), a consortium of five liberal arts colleges located in the Twin Cities. The university competes in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: University of the Ozarks
profile: Established in 1834 by Cumberland Presbyterians as the Cane Hill School, it is the oldest university in Arkansas, and remains affiliated with the Presbyterian Church. In 1875, it became the first school in Arkansas to admit women; in 1959 it became the first historically white college in Arkansas to graduate an African-American student. Today students come from a variety of backgrounds, including from 25 states and 11 foreign countries. The university offers 29 major programs of study ranging from Music to General Business. In 1971 it became the first college in the nation to establish a program for undergrads with learning disabilities. Study Night Breakfast is a popular tradition in which faculty and staff serve students a late-night breakfast at the start of finals week. The University of the Ozarks competes athletically at the NCAA Division III level with nine varsity teams in the American Southwest Conference. The school mascot is the Eagle.

name: Florida Southern College
profile: Florida Southern College is a four-year private liberal arts college located in Lakeland, FL. It was established in 1883 and is affiliated with the United Methodist Church. Florida Southern is home to the largest Frank Lloyd Wright collection in the world; students worked with the famous architect to construct 12 of his buildings on campus. FSC allows students to take advantage of all the benefits of a central Florida climate by offering countless outdoors wellness and recreation activities. One of the most popular lakes where students enjoy water sports is Lake Hollingsworth. The campus is also just an hour away from amusement parks like Walt Disney World, Universal Studios, Sea World and Busch Gardens. The Florida Southern Moccasins compete in NCAA Division II athletics, and the school mascot is Mocsie the water moccasin. In 2014, the men’s swimming team took home the silver for the second year in a row at the National Championship.

name: University of Colorado, Colorado Springs
profile: The University of Colorado, Colorado Springs was established in 1965 at one of the highest points in the city. Today the school offers 37 bachelor’s degrees, 19 masters and five doctoral degrees. There are a number of unique high-need programs such as disaster management, geropsychology and professional golf management. UCCS has a particularly active space studies program. The UCCS Network Information and Space Security Center (NISSC) is conveniently located just minutes away from prominent military space activities such as Headquarters Air Force Space Command and Headquarters Army Space Command. The schools location also allows for weekend trips to ski resorts throughout the winter months. There are over 180 student clubs and activities for students to join. UCCS is a NCAA Division II team that competes in the Rocky Mountain Athletic Conference. Black and gold are the official school colors and Clyde the mountain lion is their mascot. The university is currently building a brand new five-story parking garage with a rooftop soccer field. The fifth level is going to house intramural sports including soccer, lacrosse and flag football. The current president of the university is Bruce D. Benson.

name: California State University, East Bay
profile: Founded in 1957, California State University, East Bay became part of the 23-campus California State University system in 2005. Divided into four colleges, the university is best known for its business and economics and education programs. There are over 100 majors and minors to choose from. The university also operates online degree programs. First year students participate in freshman learning communities to improve study habits and develop writing and communication skills. Located in the San Francisco Bay area, the university provides easy access to local attractions and tourist spots, such as beaches, city parks and museums of various sorts. In June 2011, Cal State East Bay was accepted as an active member of NCAA Division II and is currently in its third year of eligibility for conference and NCAA championships.

name: Farmingdale State College
profile: Farmingdale State College on Long Island, NY, first opened its doors in 1912 and currently offers 29 baccalaureate degrees and eight associate degrees. Those interested in solar energy, bio-fuels and other sustainability technologies can take advantage of The Institute for Research and Technology Transfer, which is working on a small-scale hydrogen-solar powered model home and developing energy-efficient fuels and renewable sources of energy. The annual Garden Festival is a campus tradition that attracts thousands of visitors across Long Island and features the horticultural talents of students and faculty. All proceeds go towards Farmingdale’s Horticultural department, one of the College’s oldest and most valued academic programs. The Farmingdale State Rams compete in NCAA Division III athletics.

name: Florida International University
profile: Florida International University is a four-year public research university located in Miami, FL. Established in 1965 with a single building on an abandoned airfield, dubbed the Ivory Tower, FIU has grown to be a large university with more than 11,000 annual graduates. FIU is a leading research institution in hurricane mitigation and established a 12-fan Wall of Wind that simulates a Category 5 hurricane to aid in higher wind speed testing. The 344-acre campus offers two separate bus shuttle services, one which runs between University Park and the Engineering Center and one which operates between University Park and the Biscayne Bay Campus. Every summer prior to the fall term, FIU hosts Panther Camp for incoming freshmen where they spend a week at a retreat center learning all of the schools cheers, chants and traditions and how to be a successful student leader. For good luck during exam week, for example, students spin the large cube in front of Deuxième Maison. FIU competes in NCAA Division I athletics and is a member of Conference USA. The school mascot is Roary the Panther.

name: Carthage College
profile: Situated on the shores of Lake Michigan, between Chicago and Milwaukee, Carthage College is a private liberal arts college affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church located in Kenosha, WI. Carthage offers more than 45 majors and 38 minors and allows students to design their own major and minor programs. Carthage has a nationally recognized center for children’s literature. The center stores more than 25,000 children’s and young adult titles from kindergarten through high school, adding 2,500 new volumes annually. Notable alumni include Alden W. Clausen, the former president of the World Bank, and Laura Kaeppeler, Miss America 2012. About a third of Carthage students are involved in varsity intercollegiate athletics, and another third participate in the many intramural and club sports offered. Nicknamed the Red Men and Lady Reds, Carthage offers 24 NCAA Division III sports.

name: Rhode Island College
profile: Rhode Island College is a public college in Providence, RI. Established in 1854, it is the oldest of the three public institutions of higher education that operate under the Rhode Island Board of Governors for Higher Education. The college’s five schools offer approximately 90 undergraduate majors and programs. About half of undergraduate students are in a professional program and half are in liberal arts or business. Students with at least 40 credit hours can submit a proposal for a student-designed major program. Wednesdays from 12:30 p.m. to 2 p.m. are a designated “free period,” during which no classes are scheduled so that students have time to get involved on campus. There are more than 80 student organizations on campus, including three sororities and two fraternities. The school has 12 women’s and 9 men’s varsity teams, known as the Anchormen. Rhode Island College competes in the Little East Conference at the NCAA Division III level.

name: University of Missouri, Saint Louis
profile: The newest university in the University of Missouri system, established in 1963. it offers 46 bachelor’s degree programs, 30 master’s degree programs, 14 doctoral degree programs and the only professional degree in optometry in the state. It has well-regarded programs in criminology, clinical psychology, information systems and evolutionary biology, among others. The school’s Des Lee Collaborative Vision links over 30 professors to more than 100 community partners and projects that benefit over 500,000 people annually. UMSL fields 13 varsity athletic teams in Division II, offering scholarships in each sport. The teams’ athletic nickname is the Tritons.

name: Queens University of Charlotte
profile: Queens University of Charlotte is a private university in Charlotte, NC. It is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church (USA) and was founded in 1857 as the Charlotte Female Institute. The university became fully coeducational in 1987. Students can choose from 39 majors, 74 minors and 11 graduate degree programs. Approximately 71% of students live on campus. There are around 40 student clubs and organizations at Queens, including five national sororities and two national fraternities. The John Belk International Program allows most students to study abroad. Participants can partake in faculty-led study tours, language and cultural immersion programs or special programs in places like Micronesia and Strasborg. The school’s 18 varsity sports teams, known as the Royals, compete in the South Atlantic Conference at the NCAA Division II level.

name: University of North Carolina, Greensboro
profile: Students at this university often can be found at the Rawk, a large boulder which has been used as a creative message board since 1973. Messages, which are painted on, must be left for at least 24 hours before they can be painted over. Founded in 1891, UNC Greensboro began as the first public women’s college in North Carolina. It has since grown into a major coeducational research university; biology and business administration are among the most popular majors. UNCG’s prominent research initiatives include the Gateway University Research Park and the Joint School of Nanoscience and Nanoengineering. The University of North Carolina at Greensboro competes in NCAA Division I-AAA athletics and the school mascot is the Spartan.

name: Wilmington University
profile: Wilmington University is a coeducational, private research university located in New Castle, DE. It was established in 1968 as Wilmington College and did not become recognized as a university until 2007. The school now offers over 60 degree programs through its seven colleges. Wilmington has also developed an extensive online program that offers 80 fields of study and concentrations as well as online certificates. On campus there are many options for student organizations and clubs including the Green Team, the Photography Club and the Business Honor Society, Sigma Beta Delta. Wilmington University competes in NCAA Division II athletics with 11 teams; the school mascot, Wiley D. Wildcat, was chosen by the student body in 2009. Wilmington University’s cheerleading team has won the Universal Cheerleading Association National Championship for the past three years.

name: Northern Arizona University
profile: A public institution located in Flagstaff, AZ, Northern Arizona University offers 161 Bachelor’s Degrees in seven different colleges. It was established in 1899 and includes a forestry school that is nationally accredited by the Society of American Foresters. The institution also enrolls students at its community college campuses and online-only programs. The Lumberjack, NAU’s weekly student newspaper, has won numerous awards, including recognition from the Society of Professional Journalists, and NAZ. Today, the university’s televised news program, is the only TV news source for the Flagstaff area. NAU competes in NCAA Division I athletics and is a member of the Big Sky Conference and the Western Athletic Conference.

name: Grand Valley State University
profile: Twelve miles west of Grand Rapids, Grand Valley State University is situated amidst ravines in Allendale, MI. The Michigan state legislature chartered Grand Valley State University in 1960 as a response to the need for a public, four-year college in the state’s second largest metropolitan region. The university has an estimated total economic impact of $730.1 million for the Kent, Ottawa and Muskegon counties. Students can choose from 86 undergraduate degrees covering over 200 areas of study. The university places a large emphasis on sustainability studies, providing coursework in natural resource management, environmental studies, and sustainable business management. GVSU has one of the highest participation levels in study abroad programs in the nation; nearly 15 of the programs cost less than a semester at Grand Valley. Grand Valley competes at the NCAA Division II and in the Great Lakes Intercollegiate Athletic Conference.

name: University of Louisville
profile: Established as the Jefferson Seminary in 1798, it is a public research university with strong programs in medicine. Researchers from the university have assisted in the development of the first fully self-contained artificial heart transplant surgery and the first successful hand transplantation. It offers graduate, professional, baccalaureate and associate degrees in over 170 fields of study through 12 schools and colleges. The Nearly Naked Mile is a homecoming tradition where students and alumni remove and donate excess layers of clothing before the start of a one-mile race. Notable alumni include author Sue Grafton and former Home Depot and Chrysler CEO Robert Nardelli. The University of Louisville competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is the Cardinal Bird. The school has a strong men’s basketball program with three national championships and 10 Final Four appearances.

name: Alma College
profile: Distinctly Scottish Alma keeps its cultural roots alive with a marching band in kilts, a Highlands dance troupe, a student bagpipe band, and its own tartan. The school prides itself on the “Alma Commitment”— a promise that all students will complete their degree in four years, and an offer of free tuition for a ninth semester if a student fails to do so through no fault of their own. The college also offers the potential for an experiential learning opportunity, or an “Alma Venture,” which could be an internship, research fellowship or study abroad, supported by up to $2,500 in Alma Venture funding. Alma runs on a three term system: fall, winter, and spring, the latter consisting of the intensive study of one course topic for the entire month of May. Alma’s Model U.N. team has earned 40 outstanding delegation awards at the Midwest Regional Conference and 34 at the National Model United Nation Conference, the most of any college or university. More the one third of Alma College participates in intercollegiate sports.

name: Loyola University New Orleans
profile: Located in New Orleans, LA., Loyola University New Orleans is a private, Jesuit university which opened its doors in 1912. Loyola is composed of five colleges and offers 64 undergraduate degrees and 14 graduate and professional programs. Students can choose from more than 50 study abroad programs around the world, some locations include Brazil, Italy, and Korea. In the last few years, Loyola has seen extensive renovations on building including the Danna Student Center and the Dominican Conference Center. The university is a member of the Southern States Athletic Conference and its athletic teams compete in NAIA Division I. Students interested in joining a fraternity or sorority have a total of 12 Greek organizations from which to choose. The university has more than 80 student clubs on campus and the office of Ministry and Mission facilitates volunteer and service programs as well as retreats and faith services.

name: Montana Tech of the University of Montana
profile: Montana Tech of the University of Montana is a public university in Butte, MT. It opened its doors in 1900 as the Montana State School of Mines and became affiliated with the University of Montana in 1994. Students can select from more than 60 degree programs; while the school emphasizes science and engineering programs, it does offer degrees in fields like information technology and secondary education. Montana Tech is one of two schools to offer a B.S. in geophysical engineering, and one of the few to offer B.S. degrees in mining engineering, petroleum engineering and metallurgical engineering. There are more than 40 student clubs and organizations on campus. The Montana Bureau of Mines and Geology (MBMG) is a department of Montana Tech. Student-athletes at Montana Tech compete in the Frontier Conference of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA). The school’s teams are nicknamed the Orediggers.

name: University of Hartford
profile: The University of Hartford is a private university that was chartered in 1877. Today UH offers 84 undergraduate majors, 11 associate’s degree programs and 38 graduate degree programs. During convocation, freshmen sign their class banner that then hangs in the library for four years and is later displayed at commencement. There is a very active Greek Life on campus, with eight social fraternities and six social sororities. The university has four a cappella groups that students can audition for in the beginning of each year. The Hartford Hawks compete at NCAA Division I level in the America East Conference. Each October the school hosts “Midnight Mania,” a kickoff to the men’s and women’s basketball season.

name: University of Southern Mississippi
profile: Established in 1910 as a teacher’s college, it is a public research university located in Hattiesburg, in the state’s Pine Belt. It offers more than 180 degree programs in six colleges. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is the Golden Eagle. Before the first home football game each year, the freshman class attempts to make its mark on campus by covering Eagle Walk with gold paint. The Pride—the university's marching band—has been performing since 1923. Singer-songwriter Jimmy Buffett graduated from the University of Southern Mississippi in 1969.

name: Monmouth College
profile: Monmouth College is a private liberal arts college in Monmouth, IL. It was founded in 1853 and is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church (USA). The school’s 112-acre campus includes a 6-acre educational garden and is just a short walk from Monmouth’s LaSuer Nature Preserve. The college offers approximately 35 majors, 30 minors and 16 pre-professional programs. The Center for Intercultural Life provides support for the nearly 25% of Monmouth students who are American minorities or international students. The college’s unique bagpipe band leads the charge at sporting events and commencement processions alike. Monmouth’s 10 men’s and 10 women’s intercollegiate athletic teams, known as the Fighting Scots, compete in the Midwest Conference at the NCAA Division III level. The school’s rivalry with Knox College dates all the way back to a football game in 1888.

name: Millikin University
profile: Millikin University is a private university in Decatur, IL. It was founded in 1901 and is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church (USA). Millikin offers undergraduate degrees in a variety of fields, ranging from theatre administration to biology. The university’s Center for International Education offers semester study abroad programs and two-week immersion courses in places like Mexico, France, Taiwan and China. Students can get involved in more than 90 student organizations on campus, including six national women’s sororities and five national men’s fraternities. Those wanting to venture off Millkin’s 75-acre campus can enjoy the surrounding community, including Decatur’s historic districts and the Scovill Zoo. Millkin’s Center for Entrepreneurship encourages business students to take part in internships or other professional opportunities in the area. Millikin’s intercollegiate athletic teams compete at the NCAA Division III level.

name: Utah Valley University
profile: A public university in Orem, Utah, it was founded in 1941 as the Central Utah Vocational School. Today, Utah Valley offers students nearly 60 undergraduate degrees and over 80 one-year certificates and associates degrees. It is the second largest four-year school in the Utah System of Higher Education. The Utah Valley University Ballroom Dance Company boasts one of the largest, most successful collegiate ballroom dance programs in the U.S. They won Dancing with the Stars’ first-ever college competition and were invited to perform in the Opening Ceremonies for the Ninth China International Folk Art Festival. Utah Valley’s intercollegiate athletic teams, known as the Wolverines, compete in the Western Athletic Conference at the NCAA Division I level.

name: Southern Illinois University Edwardsville
profile: Southern Illinois University Edwardsville is a public university in Edwardsville, IL. The school’s roots can be traced back to 1955. Students can enjoy SIUE’s convenient location—Edwardsville is just 20 miles from St. Louis, MO. Students can choose from over 40 bachelor’s and 40 master’s degree programs. SIUE is in the midst of an extensive construction and infrastructure improvement plan; recent campus additions include the Science Building West and the Charles and Mary Lukas Athletics Annex. The university’s commitment to sustainability includes the installation of a 120-foot wind turbine, 140 solar panels and over 17,500 square feet of green roof space. SIUE is also a vibrant research community: faculty and staff received 189 grants totaling over $42 million in 2013. Student athletes primarily compete in the Ohio Valley Conference at the Division I level. SIUE boasts more than 90,000 alumni spread throughout Illinois and around the globe.

name: High Point University
profile: High Point University, located 20 miles from Winston-Salem, NC, is a private liberal arts university affiliated with the United Methodist Church. High Point has been led by Nido Qubein since 2005. Qubein has overseen $700 billion dollars in campus improvements and undergraduate growth from 1,450 to a record high of over 4,000 students. Forty-seven new buildings have been built or are under construction, including four new residence halls, two stadiums and a tennis complex. In 2007, High Point University announced that it was doubling its investment from $110 to $225 million in academic programs, student life, scholarships and constructions of new facilities. As the campus has transformed, donations and gifts have further assisted in attracting high-profile speakers to campus, including former President George W. Bush, former New York mayor Rudolph Giuliani, comedian Bill Cosby and Coca-Cola Company Chairman and CEO Muhtar Kent. The North Carolina university draws students from more than 50 countries and 46 states. High Point’s “Maymester” Global Experience summer program offers students the chance to experience other cultures, allowing music students to travel to Italy to perform in renowned churches and Spanish students to master the Flamenco in Spain. The school competes in the NCAA Division I-AAA and its mascot is Prowler the Panther.

name: Andrews University
profile: Founded in 1874 as Battle Creek College, Andrews University is the Seventh-day Adventists’ flagship institution. The school offers over 130 undergraduate majors in a variety of colleges, including a Seventh-Day Adventist Theological Seminary. Affiliate schools are located on five continents, including Brazil, South Korea, Kenya and France, permitting students to study abroad with easy credit transfer. Andrews has one of the highest proportion of international students and is well-known for its 30-member “Gymnics” team— student acrobats who tour and host performances. Hundreds of Andrews students organize a yearly Passion Play for the surrounding community, with the Gymnics and music by the Andrews University Symphony Orchestra. The 1,600 acre campus, designated as an arboretum, runs adjacent to the St. Joseph River with over 30 institutional buildings. Students living in the on-campus residence homes are required to adhere to a strict set of guidelines, including an age-dependent curfew. Students of the opposite sex are not allowed in dorm rooms at any time.

name: Rocky Mountain College
profile: Rocky Mountain College is a private college in Billings, MT. Established in 1878, it is the oldest college in Montana. Rocky Mountain offers 50 undergraduate majors in 24 disciplines and 35 minors. The college has exchange program agreements with schools in Sweden, Finland, Japan, Jordan, Northern Ireland and the U.K. Rocktivities, the school’s student activities department, plans free activities for each week, including concerts and Halloween costume balls. Students can take advantage of the college’s location—its 60-acre campus is in a residential area near Billings’ theaters, museums and restaurants, and is just 90 minutes from Yellowstone National Park. The Rocky Mountain College Outdoor Recreation program schedules weekend adventures and offers for-credit courses like Beginning Rock Climbing and Wilderness First Aid. The university offers free massages during finals week. Rocky Mountain’s varsity athletic teams, known as the Battlin’ Bears, mostly compete in the Frontier Conference of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA).

name: Ball State University
profile: Ball State University, a large research institution located in Muncie, IN, is a traditional public university that prides itself on its nontraditional education. With around 180 majors and pre-professional programs Ball State stresses immersive learning experiences, requiring students to complete hands-on projects in their chosen field of study. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics and boasts 10 conference championships in football. The “Frog Baby,” a bronze chubby-cheeked little girl with two frogs dangling on her feet, lives in the middle of a campus fountain: Legend holds that if you rub her nose, you’ll do well on tests. Notable alumni include David Letterman, who gave his name to the David Letterman Communication and Media Building.

name: Meredith College
profile: Meredith College is a four-year, women’s private college located in Raleigh, NC. The school offers 32 majors and has a total enrollment of 1,980 students. Over 90% of students receive financial aid. The Cooperating Raleigh Colleges consortium allows students to take courses at other Raleigh colleges and universities, including NC State University, Saint Augustine’s College, Shaw University, and William Peace University. Meredith also offers a dual degree program with NC State University's College of Engineering. Established in 1891, the college prides itself on maintaining long-running traditions such as the Crook, which involves the senior class hiding a "crook" from the junior class. Ninety-seven percent of undergraduate students participate in internships, research or other kinds of hands-on learning.

name: Oral Roberts University
profile: Oral Roberts University is a private liberal arts university in Tulsa, OK, that was established in1963 by televangelist Oral Roberts. The university offers over 60 undergraduate majors, the most popular of which include nursing, business administration and ministry and leadership. The futuristic style of many buildings make the 263-acre campus one of the most unique places of higher education. The university remains committed to the religious values upon which it was founded: Students are expected to regularly attend chapel and must sign an honor code that prohibits consumption of alcohol and tobacco and proscribes homosexuality and non-marital heterosexual acts. Students younger than 25 who do not commute must live on campus. Dorms are separated by sex. There are more than 35 student organizations and many students participate in short-term mission trips. Oral Roberts’ athletic teams, known as the Golden Eagles, compete in Division I athletics.

name: Portland State University
profile: Portland State University is a public research university with a 50-acre campus in downtown Portland, OR. The university offers a four-year degree guarantee to students who opt in. Students who fulfill the program’s requirements, yet are unable to graduate in four years, will not be charged tuition for the remaining courses. Portland State students can choose from over 120 academic majors, minors and concentrations. The Senior Capstone program brings together students from a variety of majors, faculty members and local leaders to help solve community problems. Portland State’s intercollegiate athletic teams, known as the Vikings, compete in Division I sports. Notable Portland State attendees include UPS Chairman and CEO D. Scott Davis and former Governor of Oregon Barbara Roberts.

name: University of Nebraska, Omaha
profile: Established in 1908, the university offers students 200 areas of study. Since 2007, the university has invested $200 million in campus facilities, including The Peter Kiewit Institute for Information Science and Technology and the home of the College of Business Administration, Mammel Hall. It has 15 men’s and women’s NCAA Division I athletic teams and the school mascot is Durango the Maverick – picked in a student body vote in 1971, the creature defeated the unicorn by 51 votes. A two decade-long tradition at the university is the Bell Tower Challenge, in which students and administrators collect canned goods for local shelters.

name: Saint Cloud State University
profile: Saint Cloud State University opened its doors in 1869 as a school to produce college-level programs to train teachers, SCSU now offers more than 200 majors, minors and pre-professional programs through its six academic colleges and schools. It is largest member of the Minnesota State Colleges and Universities system. Its Science Express is a fully mobile, equipped, science lab that brings high-tech science education to thousands of regional K-12 students. SCSU produces a considerable amount of professional hockey players who have gone on to play for teams like the Washington Capitals and the Philadelphia Flyers. Saint Cloud State hockey competes in the NCAA Division I but all other teams are Division II.

name: Nova Southeastern University
profile: Established in 1964 in Fort Lauderdale, FL, the private Nova Southeastern University offers students over 140 academic programs in small classes. Aided by about $82 million in funding, undergraduate students participate in NSU research in fields such as medicine, oceanography, oncology, psychology, business, education and autism studies. Students also have extensive opportunities to enroll in study abroad programs with a focus on field-based, travel-study trips, including a semester at sea. Life 101, a series that brings leaders to campus, has featured speakers such as John Legend, Michael Phelps and Kristi Yamaguchi. NSU competes in NCAA Division II athletics. Homecoming week features the popular on-campus “Anything that Floats” raft race, where students build creations out of trash and compete in the Gold Circle Lake. The Miami Dolphins’ headquarters and training camp are also located on campus.

name: Webster University
profile: Webster University is a private university located in Saint Louis, MO. The school was established as an all-female institution in 1915 by the Sisters of Loretto, a Catholic organization.
