In 1962 Webster University became coeducational and has since grown to be a global university, with satellite campuses in China, Ghana and Thailand. Graduate students outnumber undergrads nearly 4:1. The chess team won back-to-back championships in 2013 and 2014. The Webster University Gorloks compete athletically in NCAA Division III with 14 varsity teams. Alumnus Jerry Mitchell won his second Tony Award for Best Choreography for the musical “Kinky Boots” in 2013.

name: Millersville University
profile: Millersville University is a public university in Millersville, PA. It was established in 1855 as the first normal school in Pennsylvania. The university offers 57 bachelor’s degrees and there are over 130 student clubs and organizations on campus. Students who wish to study abroad may do so either through a university program or through a non-MU program. The university sponsors summer, semester and yearlong programs with partner universities in places like Australia, Chile, China and Germany. Around 50% of the 250-acre campus grounds are maintained organically. A pair of swans, which are always named Miller and Seville, has been a fixture of the campus lake since 1966. Millersville has 19 varsity athletic teams which compete in the Pennsylvania State Athletic Conference at the NCAA Division II level. Its teams are known as the Marauders.

name: Wichita State University
profile: Wichita State University was established in 1895 in Wichita, KS, and originally named Fairmount College. It is the state’s only urban-serving research state university. The original Pizza Hut was founded in 1958 in Wichita by brothers Frank and Dan Carney who were WSU business school students at the time; the original store has been relocated to campus. In addition to the Carney brothers, WSU also produced billionaire entrepreneur Gary Burrell, the cofounder of the GPS maker Garmin. Wichita State competes in NCAA Division I with 15 teams. The school’s bowling program has won 19 men’s and women’s national championships. In 2013 the men’s basketball team advanced to the Final Four of the NCAA Tournament.

name: University of New Orleans
profile: This public university offers students 41 undergraduate and 36 graduate programs in five colleges specializing in Business Administration, Educational Administration, Political Science and Engineering. Its campus sits on a former New Orleans Naval Air Station; one of the last remaining structures from the base is a brick smokestack that is now part of the alumni and visitor center. University of New Orleans has the largest business school in the Gulf south region and a strong program in hospitality and tourism. Today, at freshmen orientation, students throw strings of beads onto the Mardi Gras Tree on campus; students believe that the higher the beads land on the tree, the better their GPA will be. The University of New Orleans competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is the Privateer.

name: University of Louisiana, Lafayette
profile: It opened its doors in 1898 as an industrial school. Today it has the largest enrollment within the nine-campus public University of Louisiana System. The school offers 120 undergraduate, graduate and doctoral programs. The university conducts a significant amount of research in Louisiana’s coastal wetlands, and hosts the National Wetlands Research Center. It is the only university to offer a Ph.D. in francophone studies and an industrial design degree in the state of Louisiana. In 2011 it became the first public educational institution in Louisiana to offer a minor in LGBT studies. Lagniappe Day is a campus holiday in which 15,000 pounds of crawfish are cooked for students each spring. Notable alumni include actress Ali Landry and former NFL quarterback Jake Delhomme. The University of Louisiana, Lafayette, competes Division I sports as The Ragin’ Cajuns.

name: Texas Woman's University
profile: Texas Woman’s University is located in Denton, TX. The school was originally founded in 1901 as the Girls Industrial College. Men have been admitted to TWU since 1972. The school’s mission remains the same: to learn through leadership and service opportunities on campus. Today, the university operates two other campuses in Dallas and Houston. The university’s occupational therapy program produces more occupational therapists than any other program of its kind in the U.S. The university is also one of the country’s leading providers of nurses and healthcare professionals and graduates more deaf and speech language pathologists than any other Texas program. Annually, TWU gives more than $10 million in scholarships. In collaboration with NASA, researchers from this university were the first group to document bone loss in space. Texas Woman’s University competes in NCAA Division II athletics. The Little Chapel-in-the-Woods, designed by students in 1939 and 1940, is TWU’s most prized piece of architecture. Students often marry in the chapel.

name: Wayne State University
profile: Wayne State University is public university located in the heart of Detroit, MI, although its campus spans more than 200 acres of land. There are 13 colleges and schools and 370 different academic and certificate programs. The Carnegie Foundation ranks Wayne State as a research university with “very high” research activity. On campus there are more than 400 student clubs and organizations to choose from. The school recently partnered with start-up incubator Bizdom to create the tech incubator TechTown. Students are able to grow their businesses and receive advice from experienced mentors as well as up to $125,000 in convertible debt funding. Bizdom, was founded by billionaire and Wayne State University Law School graduate Dan Gilbert, who owns a significant amount of real estate in downtown Detroit. The university has study abroad options in 20 different countries on five continents, and competes in NCAA Division II in the Great Lakes Intercollegiate Athletic Conference.

name: Missouri State University
profile: Missouri State University is a public research university in Springfield, MO. It was established in 1905 as the Fourth District Normal School. Missouri State offers more than 85 undergraduate and over 45 graduate degree programs. Students hail from all 50 states and over 80 countries. Missouri State’s public affairs mission emphasized ethical leadership, cultural competence and community engagement. There are plenty of ways to get involved on or around campus: Students log over 100,000 hours every year and participate in more than 300 student organizations. Missouri State’s location gives students the chance to explore the metropolitan benefits of the state’s third-largest city and the natural beauty of the surrounding Ozarks. The school’s 16 NCAA Division I varsity athletic teams primarily compete in the Missouri Valley Conference (NCAA Division I). Women’s tennis returns to campus for the 2014-15 academic year.

name: Western Kentucky University
profile: Western Kentucky University was established in 1906 although the roots of the school date back to the founding of Glasgow Normal School in 1875. Today the university is home to six colleges including the Gordon Ford College of Business, the Potter College of Arts & Letters and Ogden College of Science and Engineering. Some of the top undergraduate majors are elementary education, biology, management, psychology and agriculture. Western Kentucky’s alma mater, “College Heights,” was written by Mary Frances Bradley, a 16-year old girl who entered it into a poetry contest on the campus in 1924. The campus location on a hill in Bowling Green, has made the WKU student nickname “Hilltoppers” popular. The school competes at the NCAA Division I level in the Sun Belt Conference.

name: Carson-Newman University
profile: Carson-Newman College is located in the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains in Jefferson City, TN. It is a private, Baptist-affiliated liberal arts university with 18 honor societies. In 1880, the university was named Carson College for James Harvey Carson, who donated $15,000 of his estate to the school. For several years it existed alongside Newman College, a separate facility for the education of women named for William Cate Newman. In 1889, the two colleges merged into one of the first coeducational institutions in the South. The school offers 50 majors, nine graduate degrees, and a new (and first) doctoral program in educational leadership. Through a strong partnership with the U.S. Army ROTC, the college is the regional leader and second nationally, in 2012-2013, in supplying nurses to the U.S. military. Carson-Newman Campus Ministries founded Appalachian Outreach, a local poverty relief program, and supported the organization for the past 28 years. Through a vote on Facebook, Appalachian placed 35th on the list of over 300 organizations throughout the country and was awarded a $20,000 grant from Walmart’s “Fighting Against Hunger” national campaign.

name: Anderson University
profile: Anderson University was established in 1917 by the Church of God, Anderson, IN, and stays affiliated with the religion today. Originally a Bible training institute, Anderson has grown into a fully developed undergraduate institution with schools in nursing, theology, business, education and music. Eighty percent of AU Religious Studies students specialize in Christian ministry and the school sponsors a number of campus ministries, including at homeless shelters, prisons, or nursing homes. In 1964, Anderson University began Tri-S (Study, Serve, Share), which allows students to engage in community service while traveling abroad. In 2011, the five-year “Dreams. Discovery. Direction” endowment and comprehensive fundraising campaign concluded with $113 million raised. Notable alumni of Anderson University include legendary major league baseball player Carl Erskine, Christian singer Sandi Patty, and the administrator of TSA, John Pistole.

name: Albright College
profile: A small, private liberal arts college in Reading, PA., Albright’s hallmark is a flexible curriculum. Through innovative methods of combining learning and teaching, most Albright students have concentrations in multiple fields: from child and family studies to optical physics and the music business. It created one of the first psychobiology programs in the country in the 1960s. Albright does not require prospective students to submit SAT scores. Established in 1856, the school is affiliated with the United Methodist Church and offers a multi-faith community with chaplains from different faith traditions. Over 30% of the student body participates in intercollegiate athletics; Albright boasts 20 sport teams on the varsity level and competes in the NCAA Division III. In 2013, Albright’s football team won its seventh ECAC championship. Albright’s “Lady Lions” rugby team has been nationally ranked in the top ten teams. Notable alumni include YouTube co-founder Brent Hurley and professional wrestler J.J. Dillion. The game Six Degrees from Kevin Bacon was created in 1994 at Albright by three students watching “Footloose” during a heavy snowstorm.

name: Benedictine University
profile: Founded in 1887 by the monks of St. Procopius Abbey, the private Benedictine University continues to carry on its Roman Catholic tradition today. The school offers undergraduates over 51 traditional majors in several colleges and the opportunity to study in 300 other colleges or universities through its exchange program. Located 25 miles outside of Chicago, IL, Benedictine also has a study abroad program in Florence, Italy, and is one of six universities to host the U.S. Department of State’s Middle East Partnership Initiative, which brings students to the school from the Middle East to explore American principles and values. With 22 varsity teams, Benedictine student athletes compete in the NCAA Division III. The university encourages parental involvement in the school, hosting an annual Family Brunch for graduating seniors as well as a Family Weekend, complete with sports games, carnivals and family dinners.

name: University of North Texas
profile: Established in 1890, the University of North Texas is the largest university in the Dallas and Fort Worth region. It offers 98 bachelor’s, 82 master’s and 36 doctoral degrees. It’s known for its music program; it was the first institution of higher education in the country to have a jazz studies program. It was also the first to offer an accredited master’s program in applied behavior analysis, and a graduate program in environmental philosophy. The Mean Greens competes in NCAA Division I-A athletics and the school mascot is Scrappy the Eagle -- students show their school pride by holding up two curled fingers, the Eagle Claw. The University of North Texas’ Apogee Stadium is powered by wind turbines.

name: Ashland University
profile: Ashland University, a private school in Ashland, Ohio, offers over 70 undergraduate majors in four colleges: arts and sciences, education, business and economics and nursing. Over three-quarters of the students hail from Ohio. Ashland has a 4-Year graduation guarantee allowing students to earn their degree in four years, or the college will pay for up to an additional year of tuition. Three year degree programs permit students to graduate sooner, if financially necessary. Nearly all Ashland students (98%) receive financial aid based on academic merit, talent, or financial need. Ashland University is recognized for having a top notch all-around athletic department. Its Division II program is frequently placed in the nation’s Top 10 all-sports standings. The school mascot is Tuffy the Eagle and 25 cast iron eagles, each four feet tall and painted purple and gold, guard many of the campus buildings. It is believed that students who deposit coins in the slots of the eagles’ heads will have good luck on exams.

name: Barry University
profile: Miami, FL-based Barry University is a private, Catholic institution founded in 1940. One of the largest Catholic universities in the Southeast, Barry offers more than 60 undergraduate programs in nine schools. BU’s mission statement stresses four broad commitments: knowledge and truth, inclusive community, social justice and collaborative service. The Office of Mission Integration implements these maxims through several faith and service programs, including daily masses, as well as university-wide participation in World Aids Day, among others. The institution has 12 Division II athletic teams, winning 13 national championships and 57 Sunshine State Conference titles, and boasts 277 All-American athletes. The men’s golf team alone has won three national championships. Notable alumni include Shaquille O’Neal and the current prime minister of Haiti, Laurent Lamothe.

name: Claflin University
profile: Claflin University is a private liberal arts university located in Orangeburg, SC. It is affiliated with the United Methodist Church and is a historically black university. Founded in 1869 by Methodist missionaries, it was the first institution of higher education to accept students regardless of race or gender in South Carolina. One of the founders, Lee Claflin, also founded Boston University. There are 35 undergraduate majors to choose from. The university offers three dual-degree programs in engineering with Clemson University, engineering technology with SCSU, and biology/public health with USC. The Claflin University Concert Choir performed at the inauguration of Gov. Nikki Haley in 2011. They also performed Handel’s Messiah at the Stevenson Auditorium in November of 2012. Claflin graduates who complete the R.O.T.C. program (a cross-enrollment agreement with South Carolina State University) may be commissioned as second lieutenants in the U.S. Army. Claflin University is a member of the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Conference of the NCAA Division II.

name: Western Michigan University
profile: Established in 1903, Western Michigan University resides on a campus with over 1,200 acres in Kalamazoo, MI. The institution has 145 undergraduate programs, the second largest number of undergraduate programs offered at any university in Michigan, and it is one of the largest universities in the country. The university has a unique center for medieval studies that is recognized worldwide. Every May, about 3,000 medievalists from across the world travel to campus for the International Congress on Medieval Studies. WMU also offers students the opportunity to learn to fly in the schools’ aviation program, which celebrates its 175 anniversary this year. The Western Michigan Broncos competes in NCAA Division I with 15 varsity sports.

name: Southern Illinois University, Carbondale
profile: Southern Illinois University, Carbondale is a public research university in Carbondale, IL. The flagship of the Southern Illinois University system, it was established as the second teachers college in the state in 1869. Students hail from all 50 states and over 100 countries. The university offers over 200 majors, minors and specifications. Southern Illinois’ student center features its own bowling alley, a craft shop and a food court. The theater department puts on four to six shows each year and students can gain credit for participating in the McLeod Summer Playhouse. There are approximately 400 student organizations on campus, including 31 fraternities and sororities. Southern Illinois’ athletic teams, known as the Salukis, mainly compete in the Missouri Valley Conference (NCAA Division I).

name: Sam Houston State University
profile: Established in 1879, Sam Houston State University is a public research university in Huntsville, TX. The school’s 316-acre campus features more than $250 million in new or renovated facilities. Students hail from approximately 60 countries and can select from more than 80 bachelor’s, 50 master’s and six doctoral degree programs. Sam Houston State also offers over 20 degrees online. It is one of 19 schools—the only in Texas—to offer a degree in PGA Golf Management. SHS recently established the College of Health and Sciences, which offers academic programs in fields like nursing and kinesiology. Students looking to get involved outside of the classroom can take part in over 200 student organizations. Students support the football team through Bearkat Alley, the official tailgate area. The Bearkats compete in the Southland Conference at the NCAA Division I level.

name: Murray State University
profile: Murray State University is a public university in Murray, KY. It was founded in 1922. Students hail from nearly 30 states and nine foreign countries. Murray State offers 155 bachelor’s, 63 master’s and specialist, and four doctoral programs. Nursing, animal health technology and elementary education are among the most popular undergraduate fields of study. Students looking to get involved outside of the classroom can participate in one of the 150-plus student organizations. One of the most unique traditions at Murray State is the shoe tree: If two students fall love and marry, it is said to be good luck if each student nails a shoe to the tree. Murray State’s intercollegiate athletic teams compete in the Ohio Valley Conference (NCAA Division I). The school is particularly known for its strong men’s basketball program. The football program has a unique celebration: since 1976 touchdowns have been celebrated by a thoroughbred house, nicknamed Racer One, completing a lap on the track around the football field.

name: North Carolina A&T State University
profile: North Carolina Agriculture and Technology University is a historically black university. It was established in 1891 and today offers 177 undergraduate degrees through eight colleges and schools. The exclusive Honors Program offers special lectures, travel experiences and housing for gifted scholars on campus. Spread over 188 acres, and only blocks from downtown Greensboro, NC, the university is close to both the Appalachian mountain range and warm beaches. In 1960, students from the university made civil rights history when they staged a sit-in at the Woolworth's store in downtown Greensboro—an event commemorated by an annual celebration at the university. Students, alumni and sports teams are known as Aggies, and almost all sports compete in NCAA’s Division I. Notable alumni include NASA astronaut Ronald McNair and former politician Jesse Jackson Jr.

name: Illinois College
profile: Illinois College is a private liberal arts college located in Jacksonville, IL. Established in 1829, it is affiliated with the Presbyterian Church. Edward Beecher, IC’s first president and brother of Uncle Tom’s Cabin author Harriet Beecher Stowe, was an opponent of slavery; two campus houses are believed to have been part of the Underground Railroad. Illinois College offers more than 45 majors in the humanities, social sciences and natural sciences. The college encourages students to study abroad and hosts “BreakAways,” or group trips that last up to three weeks that allow students to travel to international destinations. It also has an exchange program with Ritsumeikan University in Kyoto, Japan. The Abraham Lincoln Residence Hall is the newest building on campus and was awarded a silver LEED certification for energy efficiency. The college is one of eleven in the state with a chapter of Phi Beta Kappa national honor society. The school competes in NCAA Division III athletics, and its mascots are the Blueboys and Lady Blues.

name: University of Arkansas, Little Rock
profile: The University of Arkansas, Little Rock, was established in 1927 as Little Rock Junior College and later joined the state school system in 1969. It offers over 100 different majors and a 14:1 student-to-faculty ratio. The university partners with the charity Children International to provide 3,000 local school-aged children with school supplies and educational opportunities, dental care and health education. It competes in Division I athletics in the Sun Belt Conference and the school mascot is the Trojan.

name: University of Mount Union
profile: The University of Mount Union was founded in 1846 in Alliance, Ohio, by Orville Nelson Hartshorn, who envisioned an institution where both men and women would be educated equally without prejudice. The school is affiliated with the United Methodist Church and is liberal arts-focused, with a low student-teacher ratio of 13:1. The campus sits on 123 acres with a 162-acre nature center. Students can choose from more than 60 majors and graduate programs in educational leadership and physician assistant studies. It also offers three pre-professional programs: pre-law, pre-medicine and pre-health, and pre-ministry. The Purple Raiders compete in NCAA Division III sports , the school colors are purple and white, and the mascot is MUcaw, a parrot.

name: University of South Alabama
profile: A public research university founded in 1963, it offers a wide variety of programs in education, health care, engineering, business and computer science. The medical school’s hospitals and physicians treat more than 250,000 patients each year and the facilities are home to the area’s only neonatal intensive care unit and Level I trauma center and a cancer center. Their school colors are red, white and blue. The school competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is a pair of jaguars named South Paw and Miss Pawla.

name: Kent State University
profile: Kent State University was established in 1910 as a teacher’s training school, and has since grown into one of the largest universities in Ohio. It offers over 280 bachelor’s degree programs. Fashion design, pre-nursing and flight technology stand out as the most popular majors. KSU is known for its aviation training program, as well as its top tier fashion design major that offers programs in Florence, Hong Kong and New York City and has affiliations in Paris and London. The school offers a free bike-sharing program which allows students an easily accessible and environmentally friendly way to get around the sprawling, 1,000-acre campus. A notable alum includes former Gov. Nancy Hollister. The school competes in the NCAA Division I Mid-American Conference and their mascot is “Flash” the Golden Eagle. The baseball team claimed the MAC tournament title this year and the Golden Flashes have won either the regular season or tournament title in 14 out of the last 15 seasons.

name: Georgia Southern University
profile: Founded in 1906, Georgia Southern University is the largest institution for higher education in the southern half of Georgia. The school has completed over $300 million in projects to support the campus’ growth. GSU first began as an agricultural and mechanical school, later evolved into a teaching college, and now offers 117 academic majors. Georgia Southern is often recognized for being a “military friendly” university; its ROTC Eagle Battalion (Military Science) is the largest in the Southeast at a non-military university campus. The 2015 Fiscal Year Budget includes funding for a new military science building. The university is currently working on expanding the Allen E. Paulson Stadium to fit an additional 6,200 seats, a privately funded $10 million Football Operations Center, and a $5.8 million Shooting Sports Education Center. At the end of commencement, the school mascot, Freedom the live bald Eagle, flies over the graduates. Georgia Southern is a NCAA Division I school and in 2014 they accepted an invitation to join the Sun Belt Conference. The school’s football team, the Eagles, have won six NCAA Division I championship.

name: Fort Lewis College
profile: Fort Lewis College is located in Durango, CO, situated at 6,872 feet atop a mesa overlooking the Animas River Valley and historic downtown Durango. Campus architecture mimics that of the region’s native Puebloan design. It was established in 1911 and began offering its baccalaureate program in 1962. The most popular majors include engineering, environmental studies and teacher education. Fort Lewis is a member of Engineers without Borders, with students traveling to Laos, Thailand and Ecuador. The college also has a Native American Center on campus that helps promote academic success and personal development for Native American students. Over 120 Native American tribes are represented on campus. The college competes in NCAA Division II, and its teams are known as the Skyhawks. FLC is a distinctively bike-friendly campus and even has trails leading into the city of Durango.

name: University of West Florida
profile: Founded in 1963, the University of West Florida is a mid-sized public research university and has several campuses in Northwest Florida. Divided into College of Arts and Sciences, College of Business and College of Professional Studies, the school offers more than 45 undergraduate degree programs. Over 80% of the student population are Florida residents. UWF provides over 500 online courses each semester through which students are able to obtain one of the seven undergraduate degrees and 14 certificates. The university’s international education center features a Japan Center and Confucius Institute. Undergraduates and faculty members are able to receive research funds through The Scholarly and Creative Activities Committee. The year ends with Exam Jam the week before finals, when students are given the chance to relax with food and entertainment. The university competes in NCAA Division II athletics and the school mascot is the Argonaut, in honor of the ancient Greek legend of Jason and the Argonauts.

name: University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee
profile: A public research university in Milwaukee that is one of only two members of the University of Wisconsin System to offer doctoral degrees. The university was established in 1956, though its roots date back to the 1880s. Its 104-acre campus is just five blocks from Lake Michigan. The university offers more than 180 academic degree programs. Students come from 49 states and 83 foreign countries. Like other schools in the University of Wisconsin System, UWM is focused on research: expenditures have increased over 160% since 2000, totaling $55 million in 2013. For those looking to get involved outside of the classroom, there are over 300 student organizations on campus; more than 1,000 events, programs, performances and games are held at UWM annually. UWM’s Peck School of the Arts, the only school dedicated solely to the arts in the University of Wisconsin system, hosts more than 300 events each year. Student-athletes compete in the Horizon League at the NCAA Division I level. The school’s 15 varsity teams are known as the Panthers.

name: Catawba College
profile: Catawba College is a private liberal arts college founded in 1851 by the North Carolina Classis of the Reformed Church in Newton. It’s the sixth-oldest college in North Carolina. Today, the college maintains ties with the successor to the Reformed Church, the United Church of Christ. There are over 70 academic fields of study to choose from. There are also pre-professional programs in health, law, medicine, ministerial and pharmacy. The most popular majors are business administration, theater arts, musical theater, and theater arts administration. Interdisciplinary programs include medical technology, forestry and environmental studies, and sustainable business and community development. Pat McCrory, the former seven-time Mayor of Charlotte, NC, was a member of the class of ‘78. In addition, Bucky “The Claw” Pope, a former professional football player for the Los Angeles Rams, graduated from Catawba in ‘64. Catawba University’s 18 athletic teams complete in NCAA Division II.

name: University of Nevada, Las Vegas
profile: Originally constructed in 1957 as a temporary extension of the University of Nevada, Reno. Centers and institutes at UNLV include the International Gaming Institute, a non-profit facility which offers education programs for professionals in the gaming and hospitality industries, and the Center for Autism Spectrum Disorders, which conducts community-focused autism research and education training. Other programs include Urban Affairs, Business and Hotel Administration as well as professional schools in Law and Dental Medicine. The university has a campus in Singapore. UNLV competes in Division I sports and the mascot is Hey Reb.

name: University of Texas, Arlington
profile: The University of Texas, Arlington is the second largest institution within the University of Texas system. It has been classified by the Carnegie Foundation as a research university with high research activity; $77 million in funding supports its programs. It offers students more than 180 degrees through its 10 different schools and colleges. It competes in NCAA Division I athletics and the school mascot is Blaze the Maverick, a white horse with a bright blue mane. A campus tradition going back 30 years is for teams of students decked out in costumes to race beds with wheels attached. For good luck on tests, students rub the head of a statue of former university president E.H. Hereford.

name: Lamar University
profile: Located on 270 acres in Beaumont, TX, Lamar University is a public research university founded in 1923. LU is 25 miles west of Louisiana and 90 miles east of Houston. The university offers 100 programs of study learning to bachelor’s, master’s and doctoral degrees and is a leader in online learning. Lamar students can join 17 fraternities and sororities. A popular tradition includes the “L” Yell, a cheer that occurs during football kickoffs when fans make an L-shape with their right hands and yell “L” and then “U.” About 2,500 students live on campus in apartment-style residence halls commonly referred to as “Cardinal Village.” Lamar University competes in NCAA Division I men’s and women’s athletics, and the sports teams are known as the Cardinals. The school brought back its football program in 2010, after going without one since 1989. Longtime president James M. Simmons retired in 2013 and was replaced by Kenneth Evans.

name: Northern Illinois University
profile: Established in 1895 as a teaching school, Northern Illinois University is now a public research institution with seven degree-granting colleges and 39 academic departments. NIU has a strong ROTC program, with a separate academic Department of Military Science. Its main campus in DeKalb, IL, rests on 756 acres with 64 buildings; the university has additional campuses in Rockford, Hoffman Estates and Naperville. Homecoming is NIU’s longest-standing tradition, featuring the “Yell like Hell” dance and cheerleading competition. Students also compete in the Recycled Boat Race, building boats out of trash and racing them. The week culminates in the pregame homecoming parade and the football game itself. Greek life is prominent on-campus, with eight sororities and 14 fraternities. Northern Illinois University competes in NCAA Division I athletics and is a member of the Mid-American Conference. The football team won the 2012 Mid-American Conference.

name: Texas A&M University, Corpus Christi
profile: Texas A&M University, Corpus Christi was established in 1947 and joined the Texas A&M University system in 1989. It is a designated Hispanic-Serving Institution. The doctoral program was added in 1992. The university is located near Austin, San Antonio and Houston, and it is 15 minutes from Padre Island National Seashore. Texas A&M University, Corpus Christi offers degrees in business, education, liberal arts, nursing and health sciences, and science and engineering. The university competes in NCAA Division I-AAA athletics in the Southland Conference, and the school colors are blue, green and silver. Students are called the Islanders because the university is called the “Island University;” it is the only university in the country that is located on its own island. A campus hand sign is the “Shaka” sign which originally was associated with “hang loose” but may also mean “hello,” "goodbye” or as a sign of approval. The university expects to complete its “Momentum 2015” strategic plan next year.

name: Russell Sage College
profile: Russell Sage College is a private women’s college in Troy, NY. It is a member of The Sage Colleges, composed of Russell Sage, the co-educational Sage College of Albany and the Sage Graduate School. Established in 1916, Russell Sage offers both liberal arts and professional degree programs. The Discovery Degree program allows some students to earn a degree in three years. More than 60% of students go on to pursue graduate studies. The Incubator for New Ventures in Emerging Sciences and Technologies (INVEST) is the only incubator of its type at a women’s college. The college has many traditions, including the practice of juniors adopting incoming “little sisters.” The college’s intercollegiate athletic teams compete at the NCAA Division III level.

name: Idaho State University
profile: Idaho State University is a public research university located in the northern Rocky Mountain city of Pocatello, ID. It was established in 1901. The university is the state’s leading institution in health professions and medical education and offers 75% of Idaho’s health profession degree programs. ISU maintains medical outpatient clinics that register more than 40,000 visits annually. The Career Path Internship is a million-dollar program which helps students find paid positions on campus that match with their academic and career interests to gain work experience before graduation. ISU is also home to the Idaho Accelerator Center, which houses more operating accelerators than any other university in North America. The school maintains campuses in Idaho Falls, Meridian and Twin Falls. Idaho State competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is Benny the Bengal.

name: Indiana University-Purdue University, Indianapolis
profile: Indiana University-Purdue University, Indianapolis was established in 1969 as a partnership between Indiana and Purdue universities. The public, coeducational college sits on 509 acres and offers over 250 degrees in 19 schools focusing on health and life sciences. The medical and nursing schools are among the largest in the country. IUPUI offers more than 300 student clubs and organizations. The Center for Service & Leadership coordinates service learning classes through a number of IUPUI schools and collaborates with nearly 300 partner organizations. In 2009, IUPUI founded an Honors College and in the same year the Honors Professional Admissions Program was established. Innovate Indiana is the name of the program that the university uses to divert resources into connecting with businesses in Indiana. The crimson and gold IUPUI Jaguars play on 14 different athletic teams and compete in NCAA Division I. IUPUI has nine fraternities and 11 sororities in its Greek system.

name: Southeastern Louisiana University
profile: Southeastern Louisiana University is a public research university in Hammond, LA. Founded in 1925 as Hammond Junior College, it is the state’s third-largest public university. The university’s five academic colleges offer over 60 undergraduate, graduate and doctoral degree programs. Southeastern Louisiana offers more than 260 distance education courses. The Southeastern Louisiana University Music Program trains more than 200 students from around the world. Students spend less on textbooks by renting books through the university rather than buying them from a third-party vendor. For most courses, rentals cost only $45 per class. There are more than 100 student organizations on the school’s 365-acre campus, including 18 Greek organizations. Gumbo YaYa in the fall and Strawberry Jubilee in the spring pay tribute to Louisiana’s unique cuisine by serving popular local dishes like jambalaya and strawberry cake. The Friendship Oak, a large tree on campus, has been a meeting place for students since the college’s founding. Southeastern Louisiana’s 15 varsity athletic teams compete in the Southland Conference (NCAA Division I).

name: University of Memphis
profile: Founded as the West Tennessee State Normal School in 1912, the university offers 50 majors and 95 concentrations in 11 schools and colleges, and it has the largest honors program in the state. The school is composed of four campuses: Main, Park Avenue, Lambuth and Downtown Law School. The university’s marching band, the Mighty Sound of the South, is known for its lively performances during games. The school mascot is a live Bengal tiger named Tom, who attends all home football games. The Heritage Room is a center on campus that houses pieces of University of Memphis history and memorabilia. The university recently passed a student fee increase that will go towards funding a 192,500-square foot recreation and fitness center that is scheduled to open in 2018.

name: University of Northern Colorado
profile: Founded in 1889 in Greeley, CO, the university offers more than 200 undergraduate and graduate degrees in its six schools and colleges, including the College of Education and Behavioral Sciences and College of Performing and Visual Arts. The most popular undergraduate degrees are interdisciplinary studies, business administration and dietetics. Its music and education programs are particularly well regarded -- UNC’s vocal jazz performing ensemble was the first college group ever to receive a Grammy nomination, and the music faculty members have won four Grammys. The school’s 19 varsity teams compete in NCAA Division I and the Big Sky Conference. The mascot is Klawz the Bear, and the school colors are navy blue and gold.

name: University of Tampa
profile: Established in 1931, about 50% of this public university’s student body come from Florida, but the school has representation from all 50 states and 130 countries. There are 150 areas of study for students to pursue. Popular undergraduate majors include biology, international business, psychology, communication and management. Plant Hall, the main academic and administrative building, was formerly the Tampa Bay Hotel, which hosted Teddy Roosevelt and the Rough Riders and baseball icon Babe Ruth. There are over 200 clubs for students to choose from, many of which focus on outdoor activities, including canoeing, deep-sea fishing, beach excursions, indoor rock climbing, paintball, trail biking and white water rafting. The University of Tampa competes in NCAA Division II sports and the school mascot is the Spartan.

name: Middle Tennessee State University
profile: Middle Tennessee State University was founded in 1911 as a normal school for training teachers. It is made up of eight undergraduate colleges and a College of Graduate Studies. Of these, MTSU is best known for its recording industry, aerospace and concrete management programs and has research partnerships with the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, the United States Army and the United States Marine Corps. In 1986, James McGill Buchanan of the class of 1940 was awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for his leadership in pioneering the public choice theory of economics. Today, the Buchanan Fellowship is the highest honor students entering the MTSU Honors College can receive; each year, 20 applicants become Buchanan Fellows. Other Nobel Laureates include former economics professor Muhammad Yunus and visiting professor Al Gore, who both received the Nobel Peace Prize. Albert Gore, Sr., a MSTU alum, served in Congress, representing Tennessee for 32 years and was a three-term U.S. senator. MSTU's Albert Gore Research Center is dedicated to preserving primary sources that document the history of the university and its region. Students can participate in more than 200 student organizations such as honor societies, clubs and Greek fraternities and sororities. Middle Tennessee State competes in the NCAA Division I Sunbelt Conference, and athletic teams are called the Blue Raiders.

name: Oakland University
profile: Oakland University is a public university in Rochester, MI. The university was founded as a Michigan State University branch campus in 1957 through a donation from Matilda Dodge Wilson, widow of automaker John Francis Dodge. Oakland students can choose from over 260 degrees and certificate programs, including 139 bachelor’s degree programs. Meadow Brook Hall, one of America’s largest mansions, and Meadow Brook Theatre, the largest non-profit producing professional theater in the state, are located on the university’s 1,443-acre campus. Oakland is currently in the midst of extensive renovations: new engineering and residence hall buildings, an athletic complex, a carillon bell tower and a parking garage are all scheduled for completion in the fall. Oakland’s athletic teams, nicknamed the Golden Grizzlies, compete at the NCAA Division I level. The programs recently joined the Horizon League. Actor David Hasselhoff briefly attended the school. There are more than 94,000 Oakland University alumni around the world.

name: Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University
profile: Florida Agricultural and Mechanical University (FAMU) was originally founded as the State Normal College for Colored Students in 1887. Today it is the only Historically Black University in the 11 member State University System of Florida. Florida A&M campus sits on top one of the seven highest hills in Tallahassee and spreads out across 422 green acres. Students can choose to study health sciences, nursing, environmental sciences, humanities, architecture, business, journalism, graphic communications, education, and science technology and agriculture. Greek life is popular, including all of the Historically Black Fraternities and Sororities, honor societies and professional organizations. Microsoft Corporation Chairman John Thompson, sportscaster Pam Oliver, and actress Anika Noni Rose all hail from Florida A&M. The NCAA Division I school earned their nickname “The Rattlesnakes” in 1891 when the campus relocated to Highwood Plantation, a place infested with rattlesnakes. Dr. Elmira Magnum began serving her tenure as president of the university in April 2014.

name: Texas State University, San Marcos
profile: Texas State University in San Marcos, TX offers its undergraduates 96 courses of study in eight colleges. In 2008, Texas State opened the largest forensic anthropology research facility in the world—the “body farm” on seven acres of the 3,500-acre research facility. Texas State also recently established the Center for Research Commercialization, a facility serving as a technology accelerator for start-ups and early-stage businesses in San Antonio. The main campus served as the location of the fictional school Texas Methodist University in the TV series “Friday Night Lights.” Texas State is home to a number of “Learning Communities,” communal living for future teachers, journalists, psychologists, businesspeople and pre-medical undergraduates. The Texas State University Bobcats compete in NCAA Division I athletics.

name: Minnesota State University, Mankato
profile: Minnesota State University, Mankato is a public research university in Mankato, MN. It was established in 1868 as Mankato Normal School and is part of the Minnesota State Colleges and Universities System. In 1872, Julia Sears was named principal of the normal college that would become Minnesota State, Mankato, and she became the first woman to head a public college in the U.S. The university offers over 140 undergraduate programs and nearly 80 graduate programs through its six colleges. The school’s 354-acre campus overlooks the Minnesota River Valley and features a number of sculptures and memorials. With more than 200 student groups, ranging from intramural sports to religious organizations and fraternities and sororities, there are plenty of ways to get involved. Minnesota State Mankato’s Campus Kitchen program fights food insecurity by providing over 6,000 meals throughout the local community each year. The school’s intercollegiate athletic teams compete in NCAA Division II with the exception of the men’s and women’s hockey teams, which compete in NCAA Division I.

name: Stephen F. Austin State University
profile: Stephen F. Austin State University is nestled in the small town of Nacogdoches, TX and sprawls across 418 acres. This public university was originally founded in 1921 as a teachers’ college. Today it offers 83 undergraduate majors from six academic colleges. In 2014 there will be 17 faculty led study abroad programs. Highlights include theater in Ireland and environment studies in Dubai. Each summer the student government association hosts the Watermelon Bash, the school’s oldest standing tradition marking the end of summer, allowing students to relax while faculty and staff serve watermelon. SFA shines a purple light on the top of the Student Center clock tower, the highest building on campus, to let students unable to attend games know when the athletic teams score a victory. The school’s 15 varsity athletics teams compete at the NCAA DI level and are known as the Lumberjacks.

name: Christian Brothers University
profile: Christian Brothers University is a private institution affiliated with the Roman Catholic Church in Memphis, TN. Founded in 1871 by the De La Salle Christian Brothers who were part of a Catholic Teaching order, it is the oldest degree-granted institution in the city of Memphis. In 1970, the university became co-educational. Today, women make up nearly 60% of the student body. It is located in the heart of Memphis, about 4 miles from downtown. Although CBU is a Catholic university, only 21% are Catholic, and there are 40 other faiths represented by the student body. The university grants degrees in four fields: arts, business, engineering and science. In 2007, the school introduced its bachelor of fine arts degree. The school hosts several engineering competitions. The arches at CBU allow students to go anywhere on campus on a rainy day without getting wet. Athletic teams, nicknamed the Buccaneers and Lady Buccaneers, compete in NCAA Division II athletics.

name: University of Akron
profile: A public research university located in Akron, OH, the University of Akron was founded as Butchel College in 1870 by the Ohio Universalist Convention. As the city developed into the “Rubber Capital” of the U.S., in 1909 the school became the first in the world to offer courses in rubber chemistry. It is now home to the largest polymer science and polymer engineering program in the world. The school offers more than 300 undergraduate and graduate programs and an accelerated, six-year BS/MD program with the Northeastern Ohio Universities Colleges of Medicine and Pharmacy. There is a lively Greek community on campus, with over 800 students affiliated with one of 16 fraternities or 9 sororities. The university competes in Division I-A athletics, and the athletic teams are referred to as the Zips. Their mascot is Zippy the Kangaroo, one of the few female college mascots in the U.S.

name: Northern Kentucky University
profile: Located in Highland Heights, KY, Northern Kentucky University is a public institution offering 72 bachelor’s degree and six associate degree programs. NKU has renovated the campus extensively in the past decade: in 2008, the school opened a $37 million, 144,000-square-foot student union building, as well as a $60 million, 9,400-seat arena for basketball games and other athletic events. In 2011, the university opened the $52.8 million and 110,000-square-foot Griffin Hall. The campus is also home to the Haile Digital Theater, which is the first classroom-accessible, laser-projection planetarium in the world. Recent lecturers at NKY include politician Bob Dole, pundit James Carville, journalist Bob Woodward and President George W. Bush. Notable past students include Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Gary Webb and actor George Clooney, who briefly studied broadcast journalism, but did not graduate. The Northern Kentucky University Norse compete in NCAA Division I sports with 15 varsity teams.

name: Kennesaw State University
profile: Located about 20 miles north of Atlanta, Kennesaw State University is a public university in Kennesaw, GA. Students can choose from 90 bachelors, masters and doctorate degree programs and participate in more than 200 student clubs and organizations. Kennesaw State’s nursing program is the largest in Georgia, and its College of Education is the highest producer of teachers in the state. The university houses the complete lunar module contingency list from Apollo 16, a lunar rover map as well as the 20 Georgia state flags that flew onboard the aircraft in 1972. It competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the mascot is Scrappy the Owl. Last year, the university celebrated its 50th anniversary.

name: East Tennessee State University
profile: East Tennessee State University opened its doors in 1911 to 29 students, offering two courses of study, a four-year high school curriculum and a two-year normal school curriculum. Today the Johnson City, TN school has 34 departments housed in five undergraduate colleges. ETSU offers some unique fields of study, including the nation’s first four-year degree program in bluegrass, old-time and country music studies, and the only academic department of Appalachian studies in the country. Graduate students can also pursue a Master of Arts in storytelling. Country singer star and four-time CMA Entertainer of the Year, Kenny Chesney, graduated from the university. With its mascot Bucky the Buccaneer, the university competes in NCAA Division I athletics.

name: Liberty University
profile: Founded in 1971, Liberty University is a private, Christian coeducational institution located in Lynchburg, VA. It is the largest private nonprofit university in the country. Liberty offers 315 programs: 206 resident programs and 166 online programs. Spirit Rock, a several ton boulder on campus, serves as a billboard for students to paint messages promoting events and school pride. Liberty University’s 20 varsity teams competes in NCAA Division I-AA, its club sports program includes 32 teams and it has intramural competition. Liberty’s debate program is highly ranked nationally, and the university offers more than 100 total clubs and organizations on campus. The current chancellor of the university is Jerry Falwell, Jr.; his father, the late Dr. Jerry Falwell, Sr. was the school's founder.

name: Bowling Green State University
profile: Established in 1910, Bowling Green State University is a public university located in the small town of Bowling Green, OH, where in-state students account for about 85% of the undergraduate population. Around 17,000 undergraduate students have a selection of 200 undergraduate majors and programs through seven different colleges, with a strong emphasis on research and teaching programs. The BGSU Falcons feature 18 Division I intercollegiate athletic teams, and its women’s basketball team has won six Mid-American Conference titles. A secret spirit organization, SICSIC, consists of six individuals who promote school spirit at sporting events. The “secret six” wear overalls and masks, only revealing themselves at the last basketball game of their senior year.

name: Boise State University
profile: Boise State University, founded as Boise Junior College in 1932 in Indiana, is a metropolitan research institution offering students over 200 degrees and certificates from 7 different colleges. The university maintains the largest undergraduate nursing program in the state and offers the nation’s only master’s degree in Raptor Biology. As one of the fastest growing biomolecular research programs in Idaho, BSU supports researchers studying Alzheimer’s disease, breast cancer, artificial cartilage, chemotherapeutic drugs and other areas. It competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascot is the Bronco, chosen to reflect Boise’s western location and the wild horses that roamed the nearby Owyhee Canyonlands. An active student association rallies around its popular football program in the fall. There are ten fraternities and seven sororities on-campus, but most students live off-campus.

name: Central Michigan University
profile: Central Michigan University is a large-sized public research university in Mount Pleasant, MI. Established in 1892, it is the fourth-largest institution in Michigan and one of the largest public universities in the country. Originally a teachers and business education school, today CMU has 200 academic programs for undergraduate to doctorate levels. At CMU, some residence halls are associated with an academic department. Industrial Engineering students have gathered every Homecoming afternoon since 1998 to race cardboard boats. Tylor Devereaux, who appeared on the show “HGTV Star,” earned his BAA in interior design and industrial engineering in 1993. The school's athletic programs are affiliated with the NCAA Division I-A and compete in the Mid-American Conference in seven men’s and nine women’s sports.

name: Western Illinois University
profile: Western Illinois University is a public, coeducational university in Macomb, IL. The school was originally founded in 1899 as the Western Illinois State Normal School, which focused on training secondary school teachers. Today the university offers 65 undergraduate majors and 41 academic departments as well as 12 pre-professional degrees. Among the top undergraduate majors are law enforcement and justice administration, biology and agriculture. The 18 intercollegiate athletic teams mostly compete in NCAA Division I athletics, except for the football team, which competes in the NCAA Football Championship Subdivision. WIU is the only public school in the country that is permitted by the Department of the Navy to use the United States Marine Corps official seal, mascot and nickname: The Fighting Leathernecks.

name: University of Toledo
profile: Founded in 1872, University of Toledo was merged with the Medical University of Ohio in 2006, forming the state’s third-largest public university by operating budget. Students can pick from over 300 undergraduate, graduate and professional programs in 17 colleges. Nationally ranked programs consist of business, engineering, law, and occupational therapy. The university also has a large online learning community. The school’s campus includes nine modern residence halls, a gothic bell tower, a student recreation center, and a new football stadium and athletic complex. The Health Science Campus features the UT Medical Center, a new $5.8 million Orthopedics Center and a Level 1 trauma center. Researchers there have accumulated a total of 125 patents and $60 million in funding and grants. The university competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school mascots are Rocky the Rocket and Rocksy the Rockette. Songfest, an annual tradition dating back to 1937, has become an elaborate song-and-dance competition in which the proceeds go to charity.

name: Indiana University of Pennsylvania
profile: Indiana University of Pennsylvania is a public university located in Indiana, PA. It was established in 1875. Once the small Indiana Normal School consisting of only 225 students and one building, Indiana University of Pennsylvania has now become the largest in the 14-member Pennsylvania state school system. The campus spreads over more than 350 acres and houses a planetarium, black box theater and museum. IUP hosts 136 undergraduate degrees, 57 master’s programs and 11 doctoral programs. IUP also operates a culinary arts academy in Punxsutawney and a police academy on its main campus. IUP’s Student Cooperative Association owns a College Lodge off campus, which hosts hiking, biking and skiing trips. A number of IUP’s prominent students have won 12 Fulbright awards; professors at IUP have won more than 60 Fulbright scholarships, as well. There are 250 recognized student organizations offered on campus including 14 fraternities and 13 sororities. The university competes in the NCAA Division II, and the school mascot is the Crimson Hawk.

name: Troy University
profile: Located in Troy, AL, Troy University is a comprehensive public university founded in 1887. Its original motto: “Educate the mind to think, the heart to feel, the body to act.” The undergraduate school offers 110 minors and majors within five schools. The campus was designed in the 1920s by the Olmsted Brothers, who also created Central Park in New York City. Troy is alma mater to more than 60 flag officers and is an educational partner with the U.S. Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps and Coast Guard. On January 12, 1992, the men’s basketball team set an NCAA record for breaking 200 points in a game when they defeated DeVry by a score of 258-141. Troy University competes in NCAA Division I athletics, and the school’s teams are nicknamed the Trojans.

name: Texas A&M University, Kingsville
profile: Texas A&M University, Kingsville was originally chartered as the South Texas Teacher College in 1917, but its opening was delayed until 1925 due to World War I. Kingsville is known for its department of teacher and bilingual education. The university’s current president is Steven H. Tallant. The main campus covers 250 acres and houses over 80 buildings; the nearby University Farm is 545 acres large. Kingsville is 40 miles from Corpus Christi and 120 miles from Mexico. Texas A&M University, Kingsville is the only school in the nation that has a javelina as a mascot; it is not a pig, but a fierce, wild boar. In 1929, a real, living javelina attacked the university’s first president, Dr. Robert Cousins, but this unfortunate incident did not lead to switching the mascot. The university competes in NCAA Division II athletics, and its school colors are blue and gold. Most of the university’s students come from south Texas.

name: Tuskegee University
profile: Founded in 1881 by Booker T. Washington, Tuskegee University is a historically black, private university. The institution is the only college or university campus in the nation to be designated a National Historic Site by the United States Congress. Undergraduate academic programs are organized into five colleges and two schools. The university is one of two centers funded by NASA to develop technology for growing food in space during space flight missions; it is also the top producer of African-American aerospace science engineers in the nation. The Tuskegee “Golden Tigers” compete in NCAA Division II sports with six men’s varsity teams and six women’s varsity teams. The football team is among the most successful among the historically black colleges, winning its 26th SIAC championship in 2013. Tuskegee is home to five Pan-Hellenic organizations. Notable alumni include author Ralph Ellison, Academy Award and Grammy winner Lionel Richie and Super Soaker inventor Lonnie Johnson.

name: Wright State University
profile: Wright State University was originally founded in 1964 as part of the Ohio State University and Miami University system, and it became independent in 1967. Most of the land for WSU was donated by the U.S. Air Force, and today the school has the largest Air Force ROTC in the region in addition to an Army ROTC program. The university is divided into eight colleges and three schools. Located in Dayton, OH, the campus is known for being compact and for a David Black sculpture that's titled “Turning Points” but is whimsically nicknamed BART (Big Ass Red Thing). Students are kept from the harsh winter environment with an underground tunnel system that permits them to comfortably travel to and from any class. Wright State’s Wingerd Service Dog Park is the only campus in the country with a park specifically for service animals. The Wright State Raiders compete athletically at the NCAA Division I level.

name: Coastal Carolina University
profile: Located in Conway, SC, the Coastal Carolina University campus is only a few minutes from the Myrtle Beach resort area. It was originally founded as Coastal Carolina Junior College in 1954, and it became an independent public university in 1993. The University comprises 72 main buildings on 630 acres plus over 1,000 acres of coastal environments for study and research. The university teams compete in NCAA Division I athletics, and its mascot is Chauncey the Chanticleer. CCU also has a golf course right outside of the city of Conway; it is the only university golf course on the east coast stretch of beaches. The course is a par 72 golf course managed by the school’s Professional Golf Management Program at Coastal Carolina University. CCU has established a new academic program for fall 2014, the Educational Specialist in Leadership degree (Ed.S.), for those who want a career as a school district-level leader.

name: University of Missouri, Kansas City
profile: Chartered in 1929 it offers more than 50 majors and programs in 125 academic areas, with a 12:1 student-teacher ratio. The schools of study include music, education, biological sciences, medicine and computing and engineering. Some 47% of alumni reside in Missouri, and 57% reside in the greater Kansas City metropolitan area. The athletic teams compete in the Western Athletic Conference and NCAA Division I as the Kangaroos, and the school colors are blue and gold. The mascot, Kasey the Kangaroo, was first drawn by Walt Disney.

name: Eastern Michigan University
profile: Eastern Michigan University was established in 1849 for instruction in teaching, husbandry and agricultural chemistry. Today, EMU offers undergraduate study in 170 majors, as well as 136 minors and certificate, post-baccalaureate and pre-professional study programs. Eastern Michigan’s Science Complex was recently awarded LEED Gold certification, establishing it as a beacon of excellence in the green movement. Students supporting other causes partake in the tradition of painting a concrete pillar called the “Pray-Harrold Kiosk” to increase campus awareness of certain issues or events. The Eastern Michigan Eagles compete in NCAA Division I and are members of the Mid-American Conference (MAC). The Eagles have won the MAC Rose Trophy, the men’s all-sports champion, four times (1988, 1991, 1996 and 2008). The men’s cross country team have been victorious in a total of 13 MAC championships.

name: University of Central Oklahoma
profile: Established in 1890, it is a public research university located in Edmond, OK. UCO offers 114 undergraduate majors and 63 graduate programs and is known for its physics and jazz music programs. The campus is tobacco-free, and the school has a number of sustainability programs, one of the most popular of which is Bum-A-Bike, in which the community can “bum” a bike from the school free of charge. Students broke the World Record for the largest game of Duck, Duck, Goose in 2011. The university competes in NCAA Division II athletics, and the school mascot is Buddy Broncho.

name: Metropolitan State University of Denver
profile: Metropolitan State University of Denver is a public university located in Denver, CO. It was established in 1965. Metro State has more than 23,700 students and educates more undergraduate Coloradans than any other institution of higher learning in the state. In addition to Denver, the school has campuses in Northglenn and Greenwood Village. The school’s Precision Flight Team received the 2011 Loening Trophy, the oldest and most prestigious collegiate aviation award in the nation. Originally the university's mascot was the Mustang, but students voted to replace it with the roadrunner in reference to their practice of running between university buildings in downtown Denver to get to class; campus has since become much more pedestrian-friendly. The Roadrunners compete in NCAA Division II athletics and hold six NCAA championships: two in track (2009), two in women’s soccer (2004 and 2006) and two in men’s basketball (2000 and 2002).

name: Columbia College Chicago
profile: Columbia College Chicago is located in the South Loop district. Founded in 1890 as the Columbia School of Oratory, CCC is a private institution of higher learning specializing in arts and media. The most popular concentrations are film and video, art and design, and entertainment and media management. It is also one of the very few schools that offers undergrad program in cultural studies. In 2011, YouTube launched the first YouTube Creator Institute programs at the school. The college supports a museum, eight galleries (three of which are exclusively devoted to student work) and an art shop. The Semester in L.A. program allows Columbia students to experience the business of Hollywood while networking with professionals in the industry. Today, there is a 96,000-person network of alumni, which is the largest alumni network of any arts and media college internationally.

name: Youngstown State University
profile: The university was founded in 1908 when a local YMCA in Youngstown, OH, started offering college courses on law, business and engineering. The university adopted its current name in 1955. It offers more than 115 undergraduate majors as well as more than 30 graduate programs. Youngstown State has six fraternities and seven sororities. The 145-acre campus is home to five university residence halls and a $12 million fitness center. The Ward Beecher Planetarium at Youngstown State is free and open to the public and features a new state-of-the-art dome video system called the Spitz SciDome. The number of female faculty in the YSU College of Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics has increased more than 40% in the last seven years, part of a concerted effort to boost the presence of women in the college's student and faculty ranks. The university competes in NCAA Division I athletics.

name: University of Texas, San Antonio
profile: The university was established by the Texas Legislature in 1969 and currently offers students 142 degree programs at the undergraduate and graduate levels. The College of Business is the largest in the University of Texas system. The university competes athletically at the NCAA Division I level with 15 varsity teams in Conference USA. The school mascot is Rowdy the Roadrunner.

name: Colorado Mesa University
profile: Colorado Mesa University, formerly known as Mesa State College, is a public university founded in 1925. Students can choose to graduate within three years via the university’s MAV3 Plans. Approximately $1 million is available to support research and scholarly pursuits at the university, and undergraduates can engage in research with faculty members. There are also various service learning opportunities for students to combine classroom experience with community service. CMU’s 86-acre main campus is situated between mountains and high-desert canyons. It receives 300 days of sunshine per year and offers skiing and snowboarding at nearby Powderhorn Mountain Resort; student discount season passes are offered. Serving as the state-designated regional education provider for 14 Western Slope counties, CMU utilizes interactive video and online classes to reach nontraditional students and rural areas. There are about 700 student-athletes on campus, and 23 CMU teams compete in NCAA Division II athletics. Overall, the Mavericks have earned more than 72 conference and regional titles.

name: Tennessee State University
profile: Established in 1912, Tennessee State University is an urban land-grant institution located in downtown Nashville and its suburbs adjacent to the Cumberland River. The school is a historically black public institution. The college offers 45 bachelor’s degree programs in eight colleges and schools.The university has the largest number of African Americans who have earned bachelor’s degrees in agriculture, agriculture operations and agriculture-related sciences. At TSU, students can choose from 77 majors in eight undergraduate and graduate colleges and schools. The school’s budget for sponsored research has reached more than $32 million. The TSU Tigers compete in NCAA Division I sports. Greek life is prominent on campus, with nine fraternities and sororities. TSU students on the forensics team have won over 700 awards for public speaking in the past three years. Jesse Russell, the father of the modern cell phone, attended Tennessee State, as did Oprah Winfrey.

name: Texas A&M University, Commerce
profile: The fifth oldest university in the state, Texas A&M University, Commerce was established in 1889 as East Texas Normal College. In addition to the Commerce campus, it operates campuses in Dallas, Mesquite and Rockwall, and offers over 100 major areas of study at the bachelor’s, master’s and doctoral levels. The Honors College awards 50 top students from each class year with free tuition for all four years. Notable buildings on campus include a planetarium, and the Rayburn Student Center. In 2010, the university opened a new music building that is home to a 600-seat concert hall, rehearsal rooms, and electronic music labs. The university competes in NCAA Division II athletics, the mascot is Lucky the Lion, and the school colors are blue and gold.

name: Eastern Kentucky University
profile: Eastern Kentucky University was established as Eastern Kentucky State Normal School in 1906 for the training of teachers. In 1922 it became a four-year college, awarding its first degree in 1925. While EKU continues to focus on educating teachers, its liberal arts curriculum offers undergraduate degrees in over 80 fields of study as well as two-year associate degrees in programs such as para-medicine, police studies and agriculture. EKU students have a proud civil rights history — on a road trip in the 1960s, the entire football team left a theatre when their African-American teammate was refused entry. Students still have a habit of taking matters into their own hands, quite literally: they rub the left toe of the Daniel Boone statue by the Keen Johnson Building for good luck. In 2012-2013 the Colonels sent four competitors to the NCAA 2013 Outdoor Track and Field Championships, all in long distance running events.

name: Cleveland State University
profile: Cleveland State University was established in 1964 and today, 90% of the student body is from Ohio. CSU has eight colleges and more than 200 academic programs. The Campus International School provides International Baccalaureate curriculum and Chinese Mandarin language courses through a partnership with the Confucius Institute at CSU. CSU is one of the only universities in the nation with a public K-12 school on campus where students can gain teaching experience. At CSU, there are more than 250 partnerships and collaborations, such as the Cleveland Clinic Foundation and the NASA Glenn Research Center. The majority of students commute from home, but student housing is expanding. The $50 million, nine-building project concluded in August 2013, includes 278 apartments, shops, restaurants and public spaces. The university’s athletic teams are known as the Vikings, and they compete in NCAA Division I athletics. President Obama has visited the university four times.

name: Indiana State University
profile: Indiana State University is a public research university located in Terre Haute, IN. It was established in 1865 and is a member of the College Consortium of Western Indiana. This allows full-time students to take classes at the other member institutions, including the Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology and Saint Mary-of-the-Woods College. Since 2009, the university has been creating a new Master Plan, a blueprint for campus improvements in academic programs, housing choices and other infrastructures. The University has six academic colleges and offers more than 100 majors, marked by aviation, education, business and nursing. The university’s dedication to sustainable campus forestry has earned Indiana State the Tree Campus USA awards from the Arbor Day Foundation. Indiana State competes in NCAA Division I-AA athletics, and the school mascot is Sycamore Sam; though its teams are now called the Sycamores, they were once known as the Fighting Teachers.

name: Morgan State University
profile: Morgan State University is an historically black public university in Baltimore, MD. It was founded by the Baltimore Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church as the Centenary Biblical Institute in 1867. The oldest building on campus, Carnegie Hall, is the product of a $50,000 grant from Andrew Carnegie. Students can choose from more than 40 bachelor’s, 30 master’s and 10 doctoral degree programs. Morgan State features one of the nation’s premier choral ensembles, the Morgan State University Choir. The Choir has worked with the New York Philharmonic, the Lincoln Jazz Center Orchestra and the Baltimore Symphony. The Carl J. Murphy Fine Arts Center is home to an art gallery and a concert hall with seating for more than 2,000. Student-athletes compete in the Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference (MEAC) at the NCAA Division I level.

name: Texas Southern University
profile: Established in 1947, Texas Southern University is one of the largest historically black colleges in the nation. Undergraduates are offered over 80 courses of study in 11 colleges. Today, nearly one-third of all African American pharmacists in America are TSU graduates. In addition, the university is responsible for about 3,000 jobs in the Houston metropolitan area. Texas Southern sports teams compete in NCAA Division I in the Southwestern Athletic Conference. The school’s football team plays at the newly built BBVA Compass Stadium, which is shared with the MLS team the Houston Dynamo. Its marching band, the Ocean of Soul, has performed at Super Bowl, NBA and Houston Texans games. Central to campus life is “The Walk,” or the maroon and gray paved street on campus where outdoor social activities are held. Notable attendees include football player-journalist Michael Strahan and two-time Olympic gold medalist Jim Hines. The Thurgood Marshall School of Law is located on campus with an extensive library.

name: Johnson & Wales University
profile: Located in Providence, RI, Johnson & Wales University celebrates its centennial this year. The university was founded by Gertrude Johnson and Mary Wales who created the business school for women in 1914. JWU is orientated towards career development and is divided into five schools that offer over 40 undergraduate degrees, plus graduate programs in physician assistant studies and education leadership, among others. A new building on campus is the Cuisinart Center for Culinary Excellence, an 82,000 square-foot, LEED certified hub for culinary education. JWU’s current president, Mim Runey, is the first woman at the helm of the university since its original female duo. The “Sno Ball” is an annual winter formal event, and the Wildcat Wahoo is a spring festival and concert that brings musical acts campus. JWU competes in NCAA Division III and the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics. The school colors are blue and white, and the mascot is the Wildcats.
